It was pretty good for a small cafe and being in a hurry.  Not a lot of seating so not the best for groups or kids.

Sorry folks but there's nothing "gourmet" about this place. I tried the falafel pita pocket and soup combo and left very disappointed. Although the lentil soup was decent, the falafel was some of the most tasteless and uninspiring I've ever eaten. Any other place I've had a falafel pocket at served hummus on it, which Baladie does not. This was a surprise and disappointment too.

It's the first rainy day of fall which means it's time to head over to Baladie for an Iron Bowl with falafel! 9 bucks for the biggest (3 bowls, easy), heartiest most delicious soup full of lentils, spinach, rice, caramelized onions, and tooooons of falafel. Took the advice of another reviewer here and asked for an extra container of their spicy green sauce - GREAT idea. I like stuff mega spicy so next time I'll probably ask for another. We've had them cater meetings at work before as well, and their lamb meat is SO delicious, I bet a lamb shawerma would be off the chain. You pass about 3 other gyro places to get from my office to here, but don't get distracted - your prize is the Iron Bowl!

Every time my company gets together for a meeting I typically order from Nick's place. They deliver on time and with absolutely no mistakes. And the best part is it's a crowd pleaser. Their plates are very generous and often enough for two. Highly recommend!

Fast service, kind employees, great food. I love this place. The eggplant salad (add lamb, make it spicy) is my favorite salad in the entire city. I haven't heard of someone going here and not liking their meal. Large portions too! I highly recommend Baladie!!

You know it's a dive if it has rundown decor, unenthusiastic staff, and iffy hygiene.  If the food is awesome, the shabby decor and dirt add character. If the food sucks, you feel like an idiot for eating at a crappy hole in the wall. Baladie is that crappy hole in the wall. The food is below average, the prices are not cheap for the meh-on-a-plastic-plate, and there is no restroom for customers. How it has 4 star reviews is a mystery.
This review is for the lentil soup only.  It's a perfect, healthy meal for a rainy day...  Filling and affordable (which is not always the case downtown).  Get it spicy with extra croutons!  Yum
Excellent Mediterranean food. Try the Mujadara, this is the best I've ever had from any other Greek places. Soft rice cooked with lentils. Huge portion, too.
Interesting find in SF. Very nice outside seating for all of your people watching needs while you enjoy a good bite to eat.
Delicious and excellent lunch place. Cheap, fast, and delicious. I had the Chicken shawerma and had some extra for later left over.
After trying Sunrise Deli around the corner I grew a new appreciation for Baladie's.
Man, I love this place!!
Their tabouli salad is delicious! I'm definitely coming back here.
Review of their Catering:

Quick take-out place but a real gem.  The sultan's iron bowl deserves it's regal name.  Also, the kid who works evenings could not be nicer.  Some of the staples could be improved (greek salad and hummus, for example, but with so many great items, who cares?  I am a regular.

Baladie did a FANTASTIC job doing a last minute catering order for 130 people for our company! They were very helpful, prepared a great menu with a variety of options, they were on time, and set up everything very nicely and very presentable. Our guests and employees loved everything about it! We will definitely be having them cater other events for us! Thank you Baladie!
I really want to like this place. Because Gyro, Shwarma, Falafel, and Hummus are among my favorite foods.
Total hole in the wall sort of place. Dive-y, dingy and dark but delicious.
The fatoush salad is outstanding. It's plenty of food, super tasty and including a drink lunch was under 10 bucks. Pretty hard to beat that anywhere near the FiDi.

I came during the lunch rush and got my food quick, my coworker, on the other hand did not. They had lost his order. I mean, it happens, but when you see someone waiting there right next to the counter for a while, wouldn't you think to ask them about their order. He had to ask about it, twice. Food was good. I got the lamb and beer shawarma and it was super runny, but still good.
$9.95 Lamb Shawarma Menu with fries and a drink.
Went back for the lentil soul which was great.

I ordered the lamb beef shawarma which was hearty. I liked it but I felt like it was missing something. I ended up putting some hot sauce on it and it definitely brought it up a notch. I would eat here again but I won't be rushing back.
Mmmmmm
Good lamb Shawerma! Friendly place. I come back here every day.

I'm a little torn in writing this review. The staff in here are so friendly, yet it can't overshadow the average food they serve. Getting off after a half day on Christmas Eve, I found most of the Fi-Di locations were either completely closed or closed by 1 pm. I saw this place on Yelp with a 4 star rating, a hole in the wall joint in the middle of a busy area on Kearny Street, it should deliver decent food, right? Not really, I ordered the lamb and beef gyro, falafel, and the 5 spice fries. Then the 'dings' started going off. What kind of bell was I hearing? Microwave dings. Unlike Pavlov's dogs, the dinging did not stimulate anything but ominous aberrations.

Why do I hear the microwave open and close?  And beeping?  Constantly?  The Shawerma is overwhelmed with hummus. The chicken is tasteless and it's not even close to "mesquite".  By far the worse Greek food restaurant - ever.

We were out and about shopping at Chinatown and got hungry.  I searched on yelp and saw this restaurant not too far away from where we were so we headed in that direction.  When we got there I ordered lamb shawerma and Mediterranean platter.  This was more than enough to feed me, my sister and mama dukes.
Updated to a 4 because I love this place because 1) it's cheap, 2) they're nice and fast, 3) they have fairly healthy options!

Good food, good price. Not amazing, though. I think that for 9 dollars, I should be eating amazing mediterranean food and this place was pretty close. The beef and chicken were tender and spiced well but didn't blow my mind by any means. The salad was kind of bland and soggy, too. I did like the hummus and the pita bread, though. Overall, a good value in the middle of downtown and open fairly late.

Good stuff.  9 times out of 10 I grab the dip platter - portions vary a bit but the babaghanoush is always great - smoky, spicy, silky goodness.  Hummus is average decent.  A couple falafel balls, some taboulli, a few thick cut cukes and tomatoes, and a chunk of feta round it out.  They even throw in an orange wedge for dessert.  Friendliest med place in FiDi.  Yum.

I went around closing time, so the lamb and beef meat in my gyro tasted like it had been sitting a while and wasn't as flavorful. The eggplant salad was spicy yet good. The eggplant was a little soggy, but that's eggplant. I probably should've gotten spinach instead. But with a drink, salad, and huge gyro for under $15, how can I complain?
Authentic lentil soup and good  spicy salad dressing. Frozen chicken strips in my food and plain packaged pitas.

Today Baladie catered lunch at my office and it was pretty tasty.  The lunch came with chicken and pitas, which we had to put together ourselves as we pleased, but the chicken was delicious and flavorful.  We also had a platter that included hummus, olives, cucumbers, and those little grape-leaf treats ( I always forget what they're called).  So anyways, I was overall pretty satisfied with this lunch besides the fact that I think they forgot to bring our beef and lamb dish.  I'd be willing to eat here again, though.

My coworkers took me out here on my first day of work. I got the lamb and beef shawerma, and my dining partners got veggie wraps. Their wraps are ginormous! I should've restrained myself from eating the entire thing, but the deliciousness of the saucy melange of hummus, fresh veggies, and savory meat eliminated any sensibility I have for pacing my eating. They definitely don't skimp on the meat in their wrap--I want to say that maybe 50% of the filling was meat, which is actually more than I need. Alas, food coma at work for the rest of the afternoon. I also didn't have to eat for the rest of the day.
Great food and service!
I had their lamb & beef gyro for take-out, and it was delicious. Tomatoes, cucumber, lettuce, and a really nice tzatziki sauce.
Baladiarrhea. Nuff said.
Bad service but good food.

Update: I was extremely appreciative that the manager reached out to me about the experience I had on Saturday nov 14th. I definitely can respect when a manager goes the extra mile to do their best to rectify the situation. And honestly I would not mind if they did not offer take out I just would like for their to be a sign or some kind of clear policy so I don't get mixed messages from different servers.

Kathy. ..The food was good, but left a horrible after taste after what happened.  I was there on vacation from an  8 hour drive ..trying to enjoy myself with the family and it was just plain wrong what your staff did...I am seriously thinking of contacting the BBB...my kids all felt harrassed!!!!
Stop searching for a restaurant and come here!!! You won't be disappointed!
What's the sign of a truly great restaurant?
Excellent food!  Many vegetarian choices.  Always a line waiting out the door.  Definitely will go again!
Update review

Disappointed.   We ate here all the time in the 90's and occasionally the 2000s, but it's been 5-6 years since our last visit.  I've never minded the service--which is more amusing than anything else--but the food that once justified the long waits has now become bland and mediocre.  For example, the hot and sour soup--so amazing in the past--was almost tasteless this time.  Same with most of the other dishes, with the exception of the poached scallops.  Not sure how to explain the decline, although I know the owner now spends his time at Fang (his daughter's restaurant) and may be less involved in upholding the quality at Nan King.  Whatever the reason, the food was completely unimpressive and not worth the trip.  Sad to see this great San Francisco gem slip into total mediocrity.
Only reason why it doesn't get 5 stars is because it's not fancy. Which is just how I like it! Other than that, the food and service is 5 star spot on!
Very touristy place. Food is average. They have two sets of menus. Be sure to ask for authentic Chinese food menu, otherwise you'l just have Americanized Chinese food.

Ridiculously amazing! Recommend the homemade pork dumpling soup (which comes with delicious crispy rice in it!), marinated tofu in black bean sauce with broccoli (the tofu is cooked to perfection and the sauce mouthwatering) and the best dish of all - the juicy scallop tower with eggplant which was just indescribable.
Excellent food, just like i remember from 15 years ago, but now a menu! Enjoyed salt and pepper mushrooms thoroughly.

Good was awesome! There was a line out front but it went very quickly so the wait was no problem. Do not expect top notch service the servers will barely acknowledge you, they are hustling to get the food out. Killer good food the people next to us ordered sesame chicken and offered us a taste it was unreal! Noodles were great and potstickers were really good too. Would go back for another meal In a heartbeat
Hands down the best kept secret in SF. Always come with a big group ready to eat and ask for the managers special, the owner will bring you exactly what you've been searching for in Chinese cuisine!

I went here with my friend yesterday and had the five spice fish and dumpling soup. The atmosphere was very cool and I saw a lot of financial people eating here. I had always wanted to try this place but there was always a line. Luckily when we went here someone just left.

You know how divey places have a special flavor all their own? That is Nanking. We got the recommendation to go here in a roundabout way, my friend thought he should call a Japanese American friend for a rec in Chinatown LOL but he was right... go to Nanking. We just beat a long line, had sesame noodles and famous sesame chicken and a type of fried rice. All were delicious and the dollar value is excellent. After this I see lots of recs for Nanking, I concur!

Hands down the best Chinese food I have ever had in my life! I ate here last year while attending The Dreamforce convention in November. I was floored with how good the food was.. I came back here this year for Dreamforce with some in trepidation.. Afraid that house of Nanking could not live up to my hype! I'm happy to say that it crushed my expectations!!
Terrible service. Very rude and they are cheating visitors into huge tips. There are plenty of great restaurants in this area and I would not recommend this place to anyone. Food itself is OK.

Food outstanding! Service iffy but what do you expect that's is there reputation.  I have been here in the past but ordered about 6 things from the menu.  They were all excellent except the five spice pork chops which were horrible. My favorite dish was a garlic chicken cooked with squash!!' The green beans side excellent and shrimp and mushroom dish is a must this is the way mushrooms should taste it was awesome!!!

This is the only place I will come for Chinese on my infrequent visits to San Fran.  Both times I've been here, the server took our menus without letting us order and just said "I'll take care of you." She would bring out one dish to eat family style, and then replace it with another when we'd finished. By the end of the meal, we'd eaten a great variety of delicious food that we may not have been smart enough to order for ourselves :)

The food here was good but the service was really bad. Maybe it was just busy that day but seriously the guy did not deserve a tip after waiting for a table we were rushed to order and it was so hard to communicate with the waiter we were so hungry so we just ate and left. we didn't get the chance to enjoy the food. Not going here again.

Great spot. Amazing wonton soup and Nanking chicken. Clean and most staff friendly. Came here for lunch, hubby and I were very satisfied with our meal and service.  Reasonably priced too!  Def worth checking out.

Absolutely terrible. The lady at the door refused to seat me and my friends for no apparent reason at all. We said we would wait until a table would open up and she repeatedly said no and refused to seat us.

I cannot imagine anyone who is actually Asian liking this place.   This is hands down the worst Asian food I've ever had.   There is a single brown sauce that goes on everything, and it is extremely salty.
The best Chinese in San Francisco, hands down.
A hidden gem for working people prices in San Francisco. Best Chinese food I have ever had, ambience is community style, friendly and the vibe is comfortable and casual. I love this place.

I was in San Francisco with my wife on our honeymoon and we decided to try some authentic Chinese cuisine. I must say, it may have been the best Chinese food I've ever had. I highly recommend the "Melts in your Mouth Fried Calamari".

This place is something very unique. It is a hole in a wall. The restaurant has boxes of beer and cans stacked ceiling high. It reminds me of what I would assume an authentic Chinese place would look like in China.

I'd walked by this place before, but the persistent line is always discouraging. We finally decided to give it a go based on high praise from a friend. As it turned out, we got lucky and there was no line and we were seated immediately.

Food is great, service sucks. The rude employees completely soured the meal. A simple smile goes a long way. The waitresses and waiters asked us a minimum of six times if we were ready to order after only viewing the menu for less than five minutes. A bit overbearing, don't you think? Then the waitress dropped the plates at our table. She didn't PLACE them down at each one of our seats, but she DROPPED them at the end of the table. So much sass and attitude here. No idea what the reason is, but definitely not returning.

I was very impressed with the food! I absolutely loved the green beans which drew me there a second day for lunch since I was in the city for two days for training! I also tried the Nanking chicken and the chow mein which were also good. Would go back again however, I would recommend an improvement in service.
So I heard about this place from my friend and found this place after searching for a while.  I ordered a noodle dish which was just ok but what sucked was a rude employees.
Nangkin chicken and chow mein taste great! Their service was far from fabulous but their food was decent. Hot and sour soup was also very unique we really liked it.

I'm not a big fan of Chinese food but this place was really good. Our group got several dishes and we shared family style. We had the Sizzling Rice soup and it was my favorite part of the meal. Rice, chicken, corn and other veges in a chicken type broth with a kick. Awesome! We also got the house noodles which weren't my favorite. There was a salad with vinegar on top which over powered any other flavor. We got the house fried rice and it was ok. The fried eggplant was really good. And finally the sesame chicken was awesome! There was a lot of sauce on it but super good. Overall great meal for good price.

Popular tourist destination in the North Beach/ Chinatown area.  Lines can be long at standard meal times, but the specials menu which contains a list of meals for less than $10 is a tasty thing to check out. Off of that, the crispy short ribs and Nanking chicken are my favorites here. *CASH ONLY*

Service clearly is atrocious. The food is quite good but not outstanding - lacks spices - we had the tofu in black bean sauce and sesame chicken and the beef wrap and also pork dumplings which were good.
just tried the house noodles with pea shoots for the first time last night; delicious
We came here with extremely high expectations and got shot down.

Probably the best Chinese food I have ever had. The owner stopped by as we were deciding on food and just took the reigns family style. He didn't disappoint. Steamed pork rolls, to shrimp, sesame chicken, to beef, to noodles, and on...  Excellent food and service.
Date night with the hubby, who works as a tour bus driver in S.F. He's the one who mentioned this place. My first time eating here. His, too.
Pretty good. Like the chow mein and fried rice. But the service is not so good. Some of the servers can be rude.
Ham Sui gok was different from the norm. BBQ pork buns had a tender slightly sweet bun which I love, although the meat was kind of tough.
Excellent Bbq pork buns, pork mushroom dumpling. Didn't like the potstickers as much as the pork mushroom dumplings. Really good prices too.
Very nice food and prompt service. Visited during lunch hours after walking on the shore, a perfect ending for sightseeing.

I haven't been here in ages.  It's the family's original go-to dimsum place when we're in the city.  We love everything they sell from hargow to siomai to shrimp & chive dumplings to sticky fried rice to combination steam bun--which is my all-time favorite by the way--to so much more.   Their food is fresh and hot everytime we come over.  I have noticed that they wear gloves when handling cash, but don't recall if they take them off when handling food, or if it's the other way around.  I have to pay closer attention next time I visit.
Winging it.

Best pork bun I've ever had.  Must try the shrimp and pork dumplings.  When the hot sauce is great.  Don't let the poor curb appeal scare you away!  Fed four of my business colleagues (17 bucks) here today and they are like it was the last supper!

I would to give this place a 4 star, because I do like what I had, the flavors were pretty on-point to what I have had in HK and other dim sum placed around the US. I ordered my favorite lo mai gai and the typical ha gow and sui mei. The lo mai gai was HUGE, one is comparable to 2.5 of a typical one from a sit down dim sum restaurant. After eating it, I was too stuff to eat the other dumplings I got, hopefully they will still be good when I warm them up for dinner. I was slight disappointed that some of the sticky rice was undercooked and hard. Maybe it got stale because I got it mid-dat at 3 and not in the AM or maybe because its so huge it hard to cook-through and they under estimated their steaming time. Either way, flavors were great, but needed a little longer cooking time. I def will try it again and hope to update this post.

I don't usually give many five star reviews, but this place deserves one. I had bbq pork buns and a piece of turnip cake. The pork buns had an ample amount of meat. The sauce was sweet and salty. The sauce didn't cover all of the meat, so a little grilled ham flavor came throughout in the bun. The dough was also good. The turnip cake was browned and had a good flavor. The brown parts had a slight crunch even though the rest of the cake was soft. The cake was salty and starchy. Well worth your time if you're on Stockton St.
Any two items with white rice, soup and tea for less than $5.
Value: 5 stars

I was born with dim sum in my belly. Literally. That was the last meal my mom had before giving birth. I like to think that's why I'm such a dim sum fiend (although I'm probably just addicted to the msg).

Been in SF just enough to realize that all the dim sums here are HUGE. which are fine but I prefer the authentic small ones. Dim sums are suppose to be delicate and delicious quality over quantity you know?
This is a quick place to get dim sum to go. The service is quite quick and efficient. They individually wrap each item. The portion is generous but it still taste pretty fine.

Customer service is awful. Refused legal US tender because my nickel was oxidized. Do not recommend. Also heard them bad-mouthing customers in Chinese. They don't wash their hands after handling money. This is bad because they use their hands to get your food.
Came in today on Sunday May 4th, 2014 and got 3 har gow dumplings, 3 pork dumpings, and a diet coke for $4.60 out the door which was amazing.
Decent takeout dim sum. The same usually grease balls you get at any of these places along Stockton street.

this is where I always get my dai guy bow it is a large chicken bun with chicken ,Chinese mushroom, egg and a piece of sausage I always buy this  .now they do have a regular chicken bun too .but not with all the goodies. pork bun is ok but too much fat in it . ha gow / shrimp ball is good and their shark fin dim sum is good ."I'm sure it is not really shark fin" their sausage bun is ok. I always buy their  Chinese tamales juong  they have 2 kinds one with boiled peanuts ,pork meat ,sausage and salted egg. the other one has mashed yellow beans instead of the peanuts .but the rest is the same.i always get the bean one.

The pan fried dumplings have no meat and the Shrimp dumpling is not as fresh and Great Eastern Restaurant. Of course the price is double in great Eastern restaurant compared to Wing sing but still.....quality is 3 times better.
If all you care about is price, it's 5 stars. Two of us ate for $4.80 and it was a touch too much food. Seriously lacking in charm with average flavor at best.

This place is awful. The cheung fan is microwaved and dense and the lo mai gai looks like a dirty diaper. Don't always trust a high rating. If I had to guess, the owner has a lot of friends. The owner was nice but that can't excuse the hideous food. I suppose you get what you pay for.

This is my most favorite place in all of the San Francisco Chinatown area!!! I love coming here and to make a stop to Wing Sing Dim Sum just to buy some of my most favorite dim sum items like what you will see at a dim sum restaurant!!! Wing Sing Dim Sum isn't that bad of a place except when it gets really really crowded!! And the prices of the dim sum isn't that expensive!!! And not only that they also have some really good hot food items as well!!!
I bought their hom go. They are located in the windowcase. Fried dumpling with meat/seafood filling. And also a pebble. Could have broke my tooth. I told them about it and they did nothing. so sorry.
The only place to get good dumplings in San Francisco. We always go here before heading back to San Diego. Not expensive like other places and there are many selections.
4.75 for two items - tasty, nice varieties, good portion size and cheap - who can beat this.

This place is just... memorable. I remember a long time ago as a child going here with my father just to try the Dim Sum before the New Year's Parade and remembering the nice lady who handed us our platter of Dim Sum with a smile... I believe i was ten at the time, and since then i forgot this place in the hustle and bustle of life. It wasn't till recently that when i finally made my trek up to Stockton in hopes of finding some Indonesian terasi for nasi goreng, i came across this joint again...
My go to Dim Sum spot.   Their dumplings are big and soft and chewy.  YUM!
Only had the steamed BBQ pork bao...it was a craving...leave me alone. I can be more adventurous...just not today. ; )
Their egg tarts are a little too egg-y for my taste, but for the price they are A-OK.
Great dim sum. Hole in the wall

As a Chinese, I start getting disappointed about the dim sum here, the shrimp dumplings have a thick skin which doesn't mean a good quality, Cuz I know how the shrimp dumpling taste is really good. Prices go higher now. Well I found somewhere else is better!

Good spot for a quick takeaway fix. Before you jump in the line, take a gander at the window (mostly desserts) and figure out what you want in the steamers. Most of the conversation is in Cantonese, but the ladies know the English names for most of the food - though it does help to know what you're getting, so this isn't a good place for dimsum newbies.

Hole in the wall, with a dim sum corner and another section for Chinese fast food. There's only a narrow front section for people to make their orders, and you can hear a lot of yelling from outside. Came in at about 2pm on Friday, but it was still full of customers, which I took as a good sign. It can be pretty intimidating if you don't speak Chinese, but the cashiers were surprisingly patient with those customers who ordered in English/were too indecisive because they didn't know what to order. Not something you see everyday in the hustle and bustle of Chinatown. It did help that everyone knew to have their cash ready for quick exchange.

I love this place. Stumbled across this place and ordered the shrimp dim sum because it was so cheap. We about died at how good it was so we went back and got some chicken on a stick. Mmmmmmm for less then $3 we had some incredible food. I wish I had tried more stuff.

Let me paint you a picture. Four tall, caucasion,  north easterners are walking around the infamous San Francisco China town, navigating the streets and reading what yelp has to say about finding some REAL dim sum. I can only imagine how absolutely ridiculous we looked especially after stepping off the infamous and very touristy Grant Ave. Lets just say, we were a little out of our element but yelp pulled through yet again.
This is another one of my usual go-to Chinatown places. Things I normally get:

Just had lunch here after yelping cheap and delicious food in Chinatown. First impression is that they had a HUGE selection of chinese fast food that's like a dim sum restaurant and hong kong cafe combined. I am here specifically for their lunch special though - 3 dishes with rice for $4.75 or 2 dishes with fried rice noodles for $4.75.
I'm a fan because they have tables and it's self-service so you DO NOT NEED TO TIP.
Yeah, not so much on the English here but two hungry girls can stuff themselves for six dollars so we can just point and shout.

Just as good as good mong kok near by and less crowded and the servers less bitchy. I've gotten the lotus wrapped sticky rice, the beef shumai, the pork shumai, the shrimp dumplings, the taro cake, the turnip cake and baos (don't remember the filling, though). They're all good quality and easy on the wallet. They also have a great selection of hot tray options for takeout dinners. Me likey!
Delicious food, generous portion, will gladly throw a plate together of whatever they have ready that catches your eye. Try the sweet buns for dessert!
Definitely hole in the wall take-away place. I don't think there was even room to sit down (and I wouldn't want to sit there anyway...)

This is a hole in the wall with no where to sit and enjoy your food.  My combo was $7.60 which is pretty pricey.  There's no set price for things, and it seems it's up to the preson and his mood to call the price.
Gourmet Kitchen has cooked chinese food in the steam tables, ready to scoop and go.

I was on my way to get my favorite pastry from Napolean next store (1049 Stockton) and stumbled upon this place on a Monday early afternoon.  What caught my eye from the open doorway was the beautiful bright green colors of the broccoli and green beans.  It looked really fresh and I didn't eat enough veggies the prior day so I ordered this one.  In my broken Cantonese, I said small dish "sai deep" and pointed to the veggies.  This guy behind the counter filled up a small take out carton and said $3.50.  I found that this dish also has tofu, wood ear mushrooms, chicken morsels, slices of red bell pepper and other veggies I couldn't identify.  I thought to myself, this is a lot of work if I were to make it myself.  It was a tiny bit greasy, but otherwise great deal for predominately colorful veggie dish.
Why is everyone reviewing this so highly?

it's a hole in the wall mom and pop shop that made me feel like i was eating at another hole in the wall shop in china. with the limited seating and minimal decor, we were willing to give the place a try for the 4 star yelp reviews. the food wasn't anything special, but it wasn't bad either. we paid $5/plate of food and it comes with a cup of hot tea. surprisingly, everyone else after us only paid $3.50/plate. soooo, tourists have a surcharge? i guess we should've read through more of the yelp reviews, but it's disappointing to be taken advantage of like that. i'd recommend eating somewhere else.

I love the fried drumsticks here. I always end up getting two to three pounds of the delicious oily wings. I come here sometimes when I go shopping around in Chinatown or if I have a party to go to and I buy party platters of the chicken or fried rice or noodles. I'm not sure if the guy is the owner, but the one guy with the kinda pink cheeks, the one that can speak english, I'm guessing is and he's great. He's really friendly and funny. He offers me a drumstick to try sometimes and I love that. It's never really so full that you have to wait in line here but sometimes the wait can be around 5-10 minutes. Come here for some great Chinese food!

I cannot find anything good to say about this place. The food is greasy. The sweet and sour pork was mostly fat. They have to heat the food up in a microwave. Need I say more? They do get a star for having fairly cheap food.

This small family-owned restaurant has delicious chinese take-out for unbeatable prices. Their stir-fry eggplant, and garlic green beans are positively scrumptious. The sesame rolls are perfect if you need to satisfy your sweet tooth with asian pastries. They also have hot tea and a small dining area available if you wanted to sit-in for a quick bite.
Cheap, good and fast Chinese food.  Love their combo rice deals!  There's over 10 items to choose from, and they're all delicious!  Rice with 2 items - $3.25!  Can't beat that!

Come here for their $3.50 rice box with two sides. There are many choices you can have with your rice box. Got their fried fish and sweet and sour pork. Minus one star because the fish was a bit stale but I guess it was my fault for going late in the afternoon though but the sweet and sour pork was very good though with really good sauce. I would prefer Gourmet Kitchen for their cheap rice boxes.

This place is as cheap as it gets, $3.50 for a rice box?! They give you large portions as well and there are several different vegetable and meat dishes to choose from. Yes, the food is REALLY oily but the sauces taste really gooood. Everytime I come here, the workers are really patient when you're deciding what to get. If you don't speak Chinese, just point at the dish you want.

This place is cheap, but I really don't like how the food is very greasy/oily. I can see a lot of oil in the chow mein. and the fried rice is really dry. you would think fish tastes good, but it was super salty! talk about unhealthy.

If you have read any of my other reviews then you know that most of my ratings are based upon expectations.  In the big scheme of things this is not a 4 star restaurant.  For cheap Chinese takeout for lunch, this place is great.   When I say cheap, I mean CHEAP!!  3.50 for a two item combo plate over rice.  The portions are not huge, but if you want three items it will cost you $5 out the door.  Where can you find a hot lunch for $5 anywhere near downtown SF?  Chow Mein noodles will cost $1 more, still a great deal!

I've come to this place for their rice with black bean spare ribs and veggies a few times, but unfortunately this last time was not a great experience. In a nutshell, I was charged more than before because this time I ordered in English. I'd like to think that it was just that all the prices have gone up, but since it was only 2 weeks prior that I got the exact same thing for less, I'm skeptical. It's not a good feeling knowing that I just got jipped, so I'll think twice before ordering food from here again.
they serve lots of homestyle cooking, the kind of stuff your Chinese mother / grandmother use to make at home
If you want dim sum on demand, this is the place to come!

Our church used to order catering from gourmet kitchen every sunday. This place has the hands down best chicken drumsticks in all of chinatown. They also have the best chowmein and a wide variety of hot food for sale by the pound. Whenever we're in Chinatown I always stop by and buy some sweet and sour pork, chow mein, and chicken drumstick to go.

we went an hour before closing on a wednesday(the day that for some reason every chinese restaurant on this street is closed wtf?!)  I put my trust in you yelpers and this is what i walked away with.  I stared through the glass at the food that seemed to be staring back at me and a wave of sadness came over me.  It's not unlike seeing starving children on TV with those big glassy eyes that beg for you to either save them or put them out of their misery.  So whatever, i ordered anyway, chowmein, the fried chicken looking stuff and sometype of fried rice(pork?).  The lady piled everything onto one plate and then tossed it into a microwave.  I gave my wife a crazy kind of look like I was imagining things.  Once the food was nuked i took a bite of the chicken only to discover it was undercooked and bloody.  I tried to fill up with fried rice after that only to discover some type of pube/nose hair.  AHHH!!! CHINATOWN SAN FRANCISCO...WHYYYY???  What happened to those magical golden yearss!!  I was so happy then!!! Fireworks! dragons!  BRUCE LEE!!!!!  Someone wake me from this horrible nightmare!!

Grew up eating what my friends and I call fondly as "Chinatown Fried Chicken" and can I just say this place is the one of the best?  I know the place looks iffy but if it's that authentic garlicky goodness you're seeking this place has it! The fried chicken drummettes are the best.  Yes the chicken is oily but it's soo good.  Just blot the oil out before you eat it and you won't feel as guilty as you indulge!
Man oh man... Do I love tofu! A lot of the times I get tofu cravings and a reminder goes off in my head, "I need to eat more protein!"  And, boy, does Gourmet Kitchen satisfy my tofu cravings!

Yum, my favorite is the thick chow mein, and the miniature fry drum stick. (If it is nice and fresh) and you can just feel the oil roll down the side of your mouth, and you bit into it. Ok, OK, its not that bad, I usually soak out the oil on a towel, before enjoying the fried drum stick

This is the best place for  fried chicken drummettes. The chef here used to work for the place 2 doors down, Gourmet Delight BBQ, for many years. The story is that he and a couple others took the recipe and opened up this place, improve on the chicken drummettes, and now is doing better than the former shop.

My friend's parents own this place . They have jook , dim sum , buns , etc. It's nice and cheap . $1.25 for a jook which tastes decent . Better than making it yourself right ? It literally takes FOREVER to make it . The chicken drumsticks are pretty good . The food is really greasy though .. -_______-;;

$3 for a lunch plate? WOO. It's a great deal. Generous with the rice but not as generous with the two sides. Still pretty good though. Enough to fill you up for sure. Didn't see anything about the $3 lunch plate at the actual shop hanging around but it's on yelp!

I know the owners they are my friend's parents.  They rice box with two items are the cheap in San Francisco not just Chinatown.  I would they are family own.  Some people its to Greasy, get your lazy ass up and exercise.  Healthy food are expansive in this economy.  It is just one meal.  One pound of chow mien i three dollars.   It is cash only.  They can warm it up in Microwave.
For my daughter's party, we already have cakes from Aki's, fresh spring rolls from Dakao, fried chicken drum sticks and egg rolls from King Eggroll.  Do we want more food?  Sure, why not!
Great dim sum, fresh from the oven/steamers daily.
This is becoming one of my favorite lunch spot!
I used to come here very often after elementary school since they have their $1 fried rice or chow mien! I used to get a drumstick whenever i came here with my mommy.

One morning on a recent trip to SF, I wanted some dim sum to pair with the custard tarts I had just purchased at Napoleon Super Bakery.  I was on the go and didn't have time for my usual Yelp research, so I just wandered next door to Gourmet Kitchen.
Yummy, yummy chicken. Definitely not diet friendly but super yummy. One of my favorite lunch spots when I'm just having a bad cay and looking for a treat.

Chicken wings, drummettes, wingdings, whatever the hell you call them, those you find here are fried with extreme prejudice.  Do not fear if they are cold by the time you get them home: they are thick and juicy enough to reheat in the oven.

A simple hole in the wall shop like many on Stockton Street on the outskirts of China Town.  And what a gem of a hole it is.  If you're hooked on KFC, then you're about to be converted to the Asian side of Fried Chicken.

This place gets 4 stars just for their fried chicken. Their drummettes (the little fried chickens) to be exact. They taste good hot or even just outta the fridge at midnight. Minus one star cause other places have better food items. While i was ordering, a cat RAN into the store and straight into the kitchen like it was time for her usual lunch at home. Sometimes you just gotta laugh at these things and think, "if the food tastes good, that's all that matters."
They are known for their fried chicken drummettes and once you've tried it fresh, you'll be hooked like everyone else, no joke.

The Fried Chicken Drumettes!!!!! Da Bombs!!!! I think they are better than San Tung. Ohhh yeah, you heard me!!! Better than San Tung original dried fried chicken. They are much cheaper too and ya just can't eat one. They put crack in da seasonings so you be feenin for'em.

What do you do when you're walking around Chinatown and starving and don't want to go through the riggamoro of sitting down to eat.  Come here!!!  Their chow mein is so delcious, I asked for half pound and it was only $1.  If I were homeless, this is what I'd be saving up for!!  And I agree, their chicken drumsticks are yum!!!
Great place for soups.
Came here for my first Chinese restaurant experience in SF since my hotel was just down the block.

My favorite dumplings in los angeles.  I think i tried better only in NYC Chinatown,  but looking all around LA for authentic dumplings- i think this one is a winner.  I liked pretty much everything i ordered here. Service is good and polite.  Call before coming to check approximate waiting time. One time at peak of lunch time i waited about an hour,  the other two times no wait time at all.
Love this place.
Great home away from home food! The beef noodle soup was very good, noodles are perfect texture. The dumplings are delicious, the owner is very nice and attentive.
Clean location albeit very TIGHT.

Solid 3.5 stars but rounding to 4 for nice, friendly service. Tasty beef noodle soup, green onion pancake, xiao long bao, chicken chow mein and thousand layer bun (steamed or fried). Heard the skewers are good but did not try.
Came here for lunch on a business trip and ordered the beef noodle soup and another order of bok choy thinking that I'd try to be good and eat less of the noodles..I was gravely mistaken.

Small restaurant just border line of chinatown, financial district and north beach. Unfortunately food is anything but spectacular. Food was very mediocre. We ordered the beef noodle soup and pork knuckle soup, broth was bland, lacked flavor. Handmade noodles were nice, they were al dente. The shanghai dumplings was just ok. Some of them broke, which resulted in no soup inside. There was only 1 waitress early evening on a Friday, restaurant was almost half full, expect to wait.

My sister and I came here upon realizing we wouldn't have time to eat at House of Nanking next door and still make our plans afterwards. Her pork pot stickers were much better than my non-fried cabbage and chicken dumplings. In fact, they were delicious. The shredded pig ear appetizer scarred me for life. I wasn't sure what to expect, but it was like hard gelatin that was kind of musty and minty at the same time. I try to be adventurous, but my American palate can only take so much. No regrets.

Still great. Xiaolongbao is super hot, juicy. What I like about this place in SF is that unlike some other Chinese restaurants in town, I know for certain that this place is clean, that certain dishes' elements, like the pig knuckle soup (amazing, clean flavor, with marrow pieces!) is thoroughly cleaned. Again, I'm partial because my aunt (not blood relative) runs the place. Not only has she put her heart and soul into this, but she also has an extensive background in hospitality management. How many restaurant owners can claim that? And no, she has no idea I'm writing this. Tehe.
Need: Tackled my battles its been a long day. Im Hungry, and ready to throw down $$ for good food (not pub food) in the No Beach/Chinatown area, casual n walk-in friendly for 1.
Small restaurant and easy to miss but one of the few places that has Xiao Long Bao in chinatown.  There is even a man hand pulling noodles in a glass window.
just so so.  could use more work to make the green onion pancake more delectable.

Oh dear lord how I love this place. Tiny little space, too many people, dude in a pope-mobile style booth making the hand pulled noodles...  It was so busy but the service was fast and our waitress was very helpful.

we were guided by the Lonely Planet to try the House if Nanking. but the super long waiting line outside at a chill made us step into this restaurant. But it was so good and nice. We four people had noodle, steamed buns, dumplings and also vegetables. The price is so good. and the owner there is always smiling to us. The owner even tried to stop us from ordering too much food. We all just had a good dinner. We even wish to go back again. but what a pity we just stayed in SF for one night. We highly recommend u to order the shanghai steamed buns.

The manager tried to take advantage of me when I tried to pay a 7.56 meal with a debit card. I only had 8 cash with me. When I came in,  I asked the server if I could pay with a debit card,  server said yes.  My bad that I didn't confirm that if there is a minimum amount of purchase.
I was walking around the neighborhood looking for a quick lunch before a meeting. This place looked welcoming, had one open table and a friendly yet busy waitress to welcome me in.
Food was fine (the chive, pork, and shrimp dumpling was a standout), price was reasonable for SF, but the service was atrocious.
Love this place. A bright clean space with friendly and attentive management and service. Great food. Good prices.

I am updating as I've been back here another couple of times and am overdue.  They have more staff and everyone is more of a groove getting you seated and your food.  I still think the to-go option is tough to manage, no place for people to hang in this cramped little spot while they are waiting.  There are times there are things not available on the menu.  But the food is a solid 4 stars and the toothy noodles are delicious!
This place is in China Town, small hole in the wall place.

Very good service here.  Had a chance to practice my cantonese.  Had the soup dumpling, beef tendon noodles, and beef and fish ball noodles.  Also added a Choy Sum with garlic as a vegetable.  The food was tasty.  Would come back again.  Parked at a nearby underground garage for $5.
Really bad dumplings.  Thick thick skin that's unpleasant to chew and tiny amount of fillings inside.  Recommend that you try the chive and shrimp dumplings from San Tung.

The handmade pulled noodle was pretty good. I had the meat in gravy noodle. You can choose the type of noodle. There is a chef performing some of his noodle cutting skill in the front of the store... it is interesting to watch.
Pretty good. 3.5 stars,  but not 4.
I felt like throwing up when I saw the 1cm roach float up after I finished the noodles. So I had to wait a few weeks to cool down before writing a more objective review.

This place has no business of calling itself Xi'an Dumpling, as any people who have actually visited Xi'an will attest this place is no where even close to the real deal. No Lamb soup? No pulled pork bun? REALLY?? Nevertheless, considering the fact it is an ocean away from Xi'an, ok, I will cut some slacks.
Horrible service. The food is ok but far from authentic, not even remotely related with Xi'an food. Will never go again, and will never recomend to our friends.

We were looking on yelp for dumpings near our hotel and found this. Despite the lower rating we decided to come right before they were closing. The service was fast because of this and the food was great and the price cheap. We ordered the dumplings and the dumplings with the soup inside it. Excellent. If I had more time I would have looked at the menu and yelp longer to order the noodles. Sucked we missed out of that. Later that night we went to a very popular ramen restaurant where we waited an hour and had 3000+ reviews and the food was totally not worth it. Goes to show you that sometimes yelp is hit or miss.
4.5 stars. My new favorite place for lunch. This place always gets packed.
It's a chill and low key mama papa kind of spot for steamed dumplings, steamed pork buns (xiao long baos) and hand pulled fresh noodle soup!

I am a regular customer at House of Xian Dumpling, and am a big fan of their food.  I've tried all the pork, shrimp, and fish dumplings (with various combinations of chives and cabbage) and all of them are very tasty. The beef tendon soup and the braised beef noodle soup are also very tasty and spicy, and are the hand pulled noodles are nice and chewy.  The cold spicy beef tendon and also the shredded pig ears are also very tasty appetizers.  The only real downside is that the service is sometimes a bit slow, and the portions are a bit on the small side, however they're always very friendly, and the northern chinese food is quite a bit different than the neighboring Cantonese and Vietnamese restaurants.
Xian food in SF? What? Rarity! The only places I know of to get Xian Chinese food would be in mainland China and the popular Xi'an Famous Foods in NYC.
Although the food here is good, I had a ridiculous experience with the service. I've been to this restaurant maybe 6 times now, and have never had an issue with any of the staff.
Its a convenient and clean place to try some chinese dumplings when wondering in downtown SF. Service is quick.

Came here at around 3-ish for a late lunch. I'd the beef tendon noodle soup. Noodles & tendon were fine but I find the soup to be a little salty. Service was just horrible. The server didn't bother to clean up the tables (even though the customers have left over 10 mins ago, and I saw a table (with the customers still around) where the empty bowls & plates were all piled up at the corner of the table. When I asked for the bill, the server came with my check, and then walked away without removing the empty bowl of noodle soup from my table. She went back to spot she was earlier to chat with her coworkers. Ugh, I hate restaurants with poor service. Don't think I'll ever come back again.
Dumplings are really good. However, expecting a long wait for the food and check.

Relatively new spot on Kearny with hand made noodles and dumplings and other Chinese food (dumplings are so good that I've never had anything else on the menu). The dumplings and dumpling noodle soup are worthy of 5 stars and the people running the restaurant are fabulous. The ambiance, perceived cleanliness and the lack of decor knocks off a star. Paying a bit more attention to the details would serve this establishment well. If you're a fan  of dumplings, this is a must try.
We loved this place!  So sooooo much better than House Of Nanking.
Worth the wait.

Expensive dim sum I've ever been to and I live in san gabriel. $4.xx a plate that is ridiculous! The prices were probably jacked up because president obama ate here. Although this place has the most reviews we will check out other dim sum options the next time we are in chinatown. I gave this place two stars because ita ridiculoua what they are charging tourist for dim sum let alone locals.

Really bad. Still remember how bad this place was considering I went in the beginning of the year (jan). Their shrimp rice noodle tasted BRUNT!! How do you even eff up shrimp rice noodle?!?! Never in my 23 years of dim sum, have I ever tastes brunt rice noodle.

I had never had dim sum before, and this place was a great first place to try it. The pork buns were amazing, as were the potstickers. We ordered five different small dishes, which was plenty for two people. The prices were really reasonable- between $3 and $5 per dish. The hot tea and tasty bites were a warm and wonderful break from the foggy weather outside. One star deduction because we asked for a glass of water that we never received. We will definitely be back!
I've been here a few times for din dum only and I haven't been disappointed.
5 stars for the food and 1 star for the service.  We went on a Monday at 11.  The restaurant was fairly empty.
Good selection and authentic. If it's good enough for the president it is good enough for us. Nothing to really write home about but a unique experience.
The food is mediocre and the service is dismal, even for an old-style Chinese restaurant.
First time dine in at this restaurant. The decoration is very nice. Our president Mr. Obama went for his lunch there. Great service and the food is very good.
This is the first restaurant in Chinatown where I have been really disappointed, both with the service and the food.

By Chinatown standards, this place is always a good choice for Chinese food... even President Obama stopped by. I used to come here as a kid with my family for dinner and now for dim sum whenever I'm in the area.

5 stars for superior dim sum - my Chinese mom turned me on to this place and I have not had better dim sum for the price (yes, Yank Sing is excellent but 4x what you'd pay here).  You order from a menu instead of carts, but that just insures your food is fresh.
Food was okay, but service really bad. Snippy answers from the waiter, not friendly at all.
Started off with rude customer service. But completely satisifed with the food. Served fast and good taste.

My first real meal in San Francisco was at the Great Eastern Restaurant.  We went with Mom's friend, as we were hungry from our long flight.   We lucked out as most places don't serve dinner till 5:00 pm, but Great Eastern Restaurant was open for diners.  The place is spacious with a tank in the back with swimming fish, lobster and shrimp, which no doubt will end up in diners' stomachs.

Did this for lunch on a busy Sunday. We loved all of the food. The pan fried shrimp and leak dumplings were wonderful. And the shrimp and cilantro dumplings too. The place was jam packed, but it was well worth the wait. The staff was super friendly and seemed to handle the business well...probably because it's their normal day. My wife loves dim sum and felt that this ranked near the top of anything she's had in the states.
The dim sum was ok. They didn't have chili oil!!! Come on! You need that to pair with dim sum! The tripe was tough. Ok service.

This is one of my favorite places to eat chinese food and dim sum in sf's chinatown. The pork buns and dumplings were delicious as well as the duck egg custard buns. Mmmmmm,m. The prices are very reasonable and it's amazing how full you'll feel after eating so little.

One of worst or at best below average dim sum places in the city.   I was suckered in by the Obama photos and the zagat stickers by their door.  Don't be fooled.  The dim sum was extremely so so.   Basement seating is dingy and some staff were rude.  One waiter gave me attitude because I wanted more water.

We got lucky and got seated upon arrival and a line soon started and was growing when we left. The food was very tasty, but the little bit of dim sum available for dinner was heavenly. I can't wait for my next trip to try them for lunch and get my dim sum on.
CANT BELIEVE OBAMA CAME HERE.
We went for the set Menu which was really nice and enough food for the 2 of us. Great service and they were all really pleasant.
Used to forget what street it was on. Waiters have sense of humor. I eat duck, giant prawn, a few chickens, and like to share. I always end up drinking a lot of tea, and I don't drink tea often.

A bunch of my college friends and I recently got together for Dim Sum at Great Eastern Restaurant. Apparently, this is one of the more popular dim sum restaurants in San Francisco. There is a wait, which seemed pretty long, but, thankfully, since I running late, I didn't have to wait - my friends waited and I conveniently joined them when they were already seated. There are no carts here for those of you who enjoy dim sum cart browsing - instead, there is a menu that you order the dim sum from and then, when ready, the dishes are brought out to you. The food was good - we ordered the usual go-to dim sum dishes and a few others - but I've been to better dim sum places.

Most of the reviews from Yelp for this place were for breakfast / dim sum.   We came here for a late dinner and I was surprised that there were fair number of customers there.   The food was okay and was really not that memorable.   I think this place should be your last resort if you don't want to wait in the long lines in other restaurants and you don't mind the lackluster atmosphere and so so food.
Been here several times over the past 15 years.   Always great food and friendly staff!
The food is three star average food, but the service was bad. They counted every penny in front of you as if you don't pay enough. So rude.
This isn't like the dim sum places I'm used to where the dishes are pushed around on carts, instead you order off of a menu and your dishes are brought out to you.

Large restaurant with lots of seating so the wait is never long, even when they are slammed. Enjoyed dim sum appetizers and the Singapore noodles were crazy good! For our mains we ordered ribs- the salted pork ribs and the beef ribs. The pork ribs were extremely fatty which I did not enjoy. The beef ribs were yummy but beware; the ribs come with the marrow. Since I do not indulge in the marrow delicacy this meant that the portion of meat was rather small. We were happy with the dim sum and noodles and will be sure to try something else next time! The menu is huge - perfect for adventurous eaters! Very authentic and fast service.
Some of the best chinese I have ever had.  High-energy family-style delicious feasting.

All the Chinese restaurants in Chi-town were packed especially Great Eastern. Outside the lobby area they have pictures displayed of the owner and servers with President Obama having Chinese take out. My hubby remembered this particular Obama story on the news. Our wait was about 20 minutes, and we sat in the second level. The restaurant is clean and of formal setting. My family had the wonton soup, clams with black bean sauce, combination chow mein, saute green beans & pork and rice. We orginally wanted the fried flounder, but it was $38 which is over priced. The service was attentive and friendly. The food was good, but nothing extraordinary.

So my friends and I ended up in Chinatown and I was craving for some Dim Sum. Right outside this place there was a sign advertising that Obama had ordered food here, which I assumed had to make this restaurant extra good. Unfortunately that wasn't the case
It's decent dim sum but I don't know why it's so busy all the time.  Everyone must think it's really good, I think it's just ok.
The dim sum was nice. However there were some major problems.
Lousy service. Food ok.

Check this place out when in San Francisco. The Door Man @ The Fairmont recommended this place, and it did not disappoint. If it says "spicy" on the menu, they mean it. Please order the combination fried rice, delicious!
This is the BEST DIM SUM I'VE HAD (if you don't count dim sum in CHINA).
I was hoping for some dim sum, but don't think it's served during dinner. I was intrigued that Obama visited this restaurant; therefore, it had to be good.
This is my go to spot for dim sum in chinatown. They take reservations which is a huge plus. The food is good and reasonably priced.

WOW! Really good place to come for dim sum in China Town! We had to wait for about 45 minutes but there's so many places to just walk around to in the block, didn't seem like that long. The food was fresh! Totally was experimental with a lot of things, but of course we had to get the usual orders. Those I only know by looking at pictures - and they had a MENU FULL OF PICTURES! Perfect!

Very unique, REAL milk and REAL tea boba. It's an odd setting inside a gift shop, but conveniently between Chinatown and the Financial District. I wouldn't say it's my favorite boba ever, but it's worth walking a few blocks out of the way to try it because it is definitely different, and not in a bad way.

This place is nothing short of impressive. Coming in on a Monday afternoon tired from walking across all SF, I wanted some cold bubble tea to chill and cool down. I Yelped for places around and this place seemed to have less reviews, but I decided to give it a try anyway. It looked like a souvenir store at first, but I immediately saw that the store includes what looked  like a mini cafe at the same time.

I had high hopes since this cafe has some pretty good reviews. However, the roasted barley tea that I ordered was disappointing. It tasted a lot like coffee due to the roasted barley, and I could barely taste any tea in it. I like my boba to have a strong tea taste, so this was definitely disappointing. Also, the drink was extremely sweet.

Friendly and fast employees, and great milk tea! Real, too! To the Tea Era lovers from Mountain View and Cupertino, I think I've found roasted barley milk tea in SF! I'm not quite sure if they're the same taste since I didn't have them both to try one after the other, but it's good alright!

As one of the reviewers mentioned (and thankfully so), this cafe is hidden under the facade of a souvenir shop! Ok, maybe it's not a facade, but the name of the cafe is not clearly labeled on the outside. Had I not serendipitously looked into a window at a sign that DEFINED what boba was (my bf and i were having a fun spat over what the correct name of the drink is.. boba vs bubbles vs pearls vs tapioca balls, etc), I would have completely missed it since the sign was posted by Good Earth Cafe!! They do have a few chairs and tables (can maybe fit 6 people?), but it seems more of a order and leave type of cafe.
write 3

When my friends and I first walked in, we couldn't believe this place had gotten such good reviews and rechecked Yelp. It's really weird, because it's a milk tea bar combined with American fast food, also selling super tourist-y SF/Chinatown merchandise (like sweaters and stuff.)

Excellent overall! We got black bubble tea and avocado smoothies. This was the BEST avocado smoothies I have had--made with fresh avocados you can tell by taste and color. You can also customize the type of milk (fat free vs. whole) and the level of sugar you want in your drinks. The owners are nice and friendly. I would definitely go back there!
Excellent customer service, simplistic location, and delicious boba!

Honestly not sure what all the 4 and 5 stars are about. I was hoping for a great milk tea experience, but I have to say that I was sorely disappointed. The boba was not sweet as some of the comments mentioned, and the tea did not taste like black tea. Not sure what they use, but I was very sad about it. The people are nice though, and they are happy to customize your drink for you. I wish this establishment well!
THE REAL DEAL...

It's inside a gift shop called "California Gifts." The price is great for PMT, and it comes in a very large size for thirsty people. The tea itself is a bit too sweet for me however, and there's not enough tea aroma in the tea. The owner (who appears to be Asian but doesn't seem to speak Chinese) was super nice though.

I was standing nearby this place waiting for the Chinese New Years parade to start.  It was warm for February so I wanted from cold bubble tea.  There were many places nearby serving bubble tea so the best thing to do is Yelp.  This place has the best reviews.  I ordered the almond milk tea.  The menu shows a picture of them brewing tea like in Hong Kong using a tea sock. When you order, they start mixing the drink.  I can see they use real Half and Half instead of Coffee Mate like some other places.  I asked for less sugar, and the drink came out right, not too sweet.  The tea flavor was intense for a boba store, and I can taste the difference between real tea vs tea powder.  Also, I can taste real bits of almond in my tea.  Another plus, they accept credit cards.
I'm glad I stumbled upon this place with fresh, authentic mild tea. It was one of those great yelp finds where I probably wouldn't have tried it on my own since it's hidden within a casual gift shop.

Stopped by here based on other Yelp reviewers saying their tea is brewed vs powder since you can get powdered tea anywhere. You can definitely taste the difference in quality here, and the tea is great. The boba is perfectly chewy without being hard.
Incredible bubble tea. They use brewed tea instead of powder. So happy I stumbled onto this place. My daughter loved her strawberry/banana fruit freeze. Owners are super nice.

While there has been a recent explosion of milk tea places with different novelties (toppings, flavors, etc.) in Chinatown, I haven't found them to differ too much in terms of taste and quality. I came to this tourist shop thanks to Yelp; seriously wouldn't have stepped in here if it weren't for the reviews.
Good Earth Cafe is a snack food place inside California Gifts, a store geared for tourists (wines, souvenirs, clothes)
Had to come back a second time for their amazing bubble tea. They were delicious and cheap. The proprietress was also very nice, and even remembered us and our order from our first visit.

There are no good boba places in Chinatown, but this place is decent enough! It's definitely not what you would expect walking in...I brought a friend one day, and I think she was a bit frightened since, on the outside, it's a random tourist shop, and a bit run-down. However, inside you'll find a very clean, equipped establishment. The teas are really strong, the milk is REAL people, they use brown sugar, and the boba is perfectly cooked. Since the place does run a very small operation, they can run out of boba, but otherwise, this place totally beats Tii next door, and Ten Ren, and Cool Tea, etc. I'm a slave to boba, so I've been to them all.
HEALTHIEST MILK TEAS IN SAN FRANCISCO

A hidden gem within Chinatown, this place is inconspicuously located within a gift shop "California Gifts." I agree with the other review. This place does know how to make good burgers! And boba milk tea too! $2.75 for a regular-size, original boba milk tea. They make their drinks with real tea and you can customize it to your liking (more sugar, less sugar, less ice, etc), and the boba always tastes fresh. This place has been my regular go-to boba shop in Chinatown!!

We were visiting the famous San Francisco Chinatown.  We were attracted with the Stanford/Cal sweatshirts this gift shop/cafe was selling.  Since we were hungry and tired from all the walking, we decided to order some food .  We had the cheeseburger & fries, chicken tenders and ramen with spam and fried egg.  To our surprise, the food came out really good, not like one of those tourist traps.  The cheeseburger was very tasty, and the ramen with spam tasted just like the ones I had in Hawaii.  We also ordered some boba milk tea.  The ordering of tea reminded me of Gong Cha in Hong Kong and Singapore.  You pick a tea, sugar level and ice level.  They tell me the teas are all fresh brewed and not powdered like most places.  The workers were very helpful with San Francisco directions and information.  After eating and resting, we were  off to explore more of this beautiful city.

I found this cafe open again, but not selling noodles like before.  Now they are offering burgers, fries, and snack food.  I tried their cheeseburger and fries.  These people know how to cook a burger.  The meat was hot and juicy, and the bun was nicely toasted.  The burger was around $4 and fries $2.50.  Not bad for a hot lunch in the fidi area.  I actually like their burgers more than the ones at Clown Alley (no more) and Bistro.

I was introduced to Hang Ah almost 20 years ago and have been a regular ever since. I must admit that I was disappointed when they closed for two months and reopened with an Ikea makeover, not that the old decor was all that charming, but that was never a reason to eat here.

We were exploring Chinatown and was approached by a friendly stranger who directed us here. In fact, he walked us to the restaurant & seated us at our table :) Now that's service! The staff was attentive & service was prompt. The dimsum was fresh & we enjoyed everything we ordered: Ha gow, bak toll gow, siu mai, fun gor, jai won ton, bok choy in garlic sauce, lai wong bao, & sesame balls.
Feels like a tourist trap. With exception to the 1950's beauty pageant girls on the wall, nothing seems like it was the first dim sum...let alone from 1920's.

Service was great. Food was cheap but to me seemed bland compared to other places I've been. menu was kind of limited. No ha chong fun. No taro cake. I'm not an expert but for what I like it was just OK.

I set up dinner here for a big student group (30) and we had a great experience. With a few days advance notice, Frank opened the restaurant for us on a night when they were closed. He wrote a menu of rice dishes, noodle dishes, and dim sum since we weren't sure what to get. Frank explained the restaurant's history and the history of dim sum for our students, and his love for the cooking and the culture were obvious. Most importantly, the dim sum was very good, particularly the pork shu mai, the fried shrimp balls, and the homemade hot sauce. Thanks Frank. I will certainly return here.
I stumbled upon this place while strolling around the Financial District in SF. What intrigued me was that they claim to be the "oldest dim sum restaurant" in the city.

Conveniently located in the Chinatown part closer to Financial District (although uphill from FiDi), this is one of my go-to lunch spots. Yes, the dim sum menu is not huge and there are no carts, but the items they do have are quality (my favorite is their siu mai, a dim sum staple).

Had done dim sum & the vegetable soup. Nothing was that good. The pork buns were decent but that was pretty much it. I was very disappointed! I expected  San Fran Chinese food to be better represented. It was also expensive for being located in Chinatown. The only saving grace was that the waiter was nice, although it took awhile to bring our bill. Of all the items we ordered, don't get the veggie pot stickers, they have no taste.
A bit of a tourist trap, and disappointing as far as dim sun places go.

I had the best Hung Tao Yee Foo Won Ton ever for a long time.  The service is great and all the dim sum is like old Chinatown authentic style.  The foil wrapped Chicken is unheard of these days, but they have it here.  I recommend you try this very historic restaurant in San Francisco Chinatown.

As this is Chinatown, there are loads of family favorite places that my sister and I could have gone to for lunch but then we saw this adorable little sign pointing it out as the oldest dim sum place around and thought, why the hell not. If anything, the place was good to try out. As we came before lunch, it was pretty slow but still had quite a few patrons (which doubled as we left). The service was pretty good and much less harried than we are normally used to (so yeah, pretty big plus!). As with any new dim sum places, we ordered the sui mai and har gow and man were they good!! The pork mixture in the sui mai was the right sort of savory sweetness. The har gow had all the right texture and taste - loved the wrapping! We also ordered the rabbit shaped dumplings, and as it turned out, they were just rabbit shaped har gow. It was definitely cute but we could have done with just one or the other. Their meal plans are decently priced with some good mixes but for dim sum, it's pretty pricey and the sizes were on the small size. It was a nice novelty experience but we wouldn't come back again.
I asked to swap out dish from their meal plan and was willing to pay the difference. They refused. So, I got up and left.
down an alley. mom and pop type of place, that seems like its trying to get commercialized. I wouldn't want them to get any more commercialized than they are. was pleased with dim sum.

This is a decent choice for dim sum in Chinatown. Every time I go it seems to be less busy than other dim sum places, which is nice if you're in a hurry. The staff is really sweet and very attentive. The food is nothing special but it will fulfill your dim sum craving.
My husband wanted to try dim sum during our San Francisco visit and he suggested this place.
Known as the oldest Chinese restaurant in china town this esthetic restaurant has great food. Look carefully to find it, but it is well worth the experience and the price.
I have to say this is one for the best dim sum I ever had. The service was excellent and the food quality was excellent. If you read reviews do give this place a chance I would not think twice.

I really love this place.  There are no ladies pushing dim sum carts around.  You order off a menu.  Food is fresh and very good and reasonably priced.  It is located off an alley across from an outdoor volleyball court on a blacktop.  I also order to go, so that I could take on a plane home.  They did a very nice job of putting into a clear container and wrapped it with plastic wrap.
I shall be telling this with a sigh

Best dim sum in the city. Also oldest dim sum restaurant in the US. Always owned by the same family and the great (great great?) grandson has taken over and dramatically improved the kitchen, if that was possible. They even now have California wines and good beer. You have to go there if you like dim sum.. They are now open 6 days a week, closed Tuesday. We go there all the time an live on Nob hill. Well worth the visit. They open for lunch and dinner until 10 pm.. Try it after work for beers/wine and some apps.

I went here on 7-31-14 7:50pm'sh and met up with my friends.  Ordered tomato beef chow mein, salt/pepper pork, and few others, better than decent food, I actually know some friends that work here, it's cool to talk with them.
Second or third time here.

I have an affinity for trying dim sum in every city I visit. Having lived so close to Chicago's China Town, I've set high standards for how I like dim sum and this place did not disappoint!! This is the nations first dim sum house, operating  for 94 years (and counting).

Google lead me to this quaint and classic Chinese dim sum restaurant.  Its off the beaten path which I loved, so it's not packed with tourist, but local Chinese folks, good sign.  The owner is adorable and goes the extra mile to make a connection with his customers.  It's not a fancy place, which again, I liked and wasn't expecting.  I went to eat good Dim Sum, not oodle over the décor.  The prices are very reasonable, two of us ate for $25 and took a doggie bag.  The shrimp dumplings I am still craving today!  Go and eat if you want down home Chinese cooking without being over run with tourist crowds.  The service was excellent, and the food equally matched.  I will be back  before summer is over.

It's the middle or so of the afternoon, and finding a Chinatown restaurant that serves dim sum all day AND one that takes credit cards is VERY TRICKY! I probably could've gone to better dim sum restaurants had I had any cash (stupid me), but it's all water over the dam now. Lessons learned!
Great hidden gem! Good dim sum, nice wait staff, cool decor. Unassuming, not touristy. I would come back for sure.

Every placed we walked to for dim sum was closed. We rounded the corner and found this one. The food was so tasty and came out very fast!  the gentleman who served us was very sweet. Totally hit the spot!

Hole in the wall joint in china town.  Don't go here for the decor or atmosphere but if you like experience an area this is the place. We wondered into Hang Ah while walking though Chinatown.  The green tea was delicious, I think I drank 3 cups.  We shared the chicken feet, rabbit shaped dumplings and best of all the salt and pepper wings.  I could have eaten a truck load of those wings.  My husband who doesn't care for meat on the bone even went back for more.  I would go back just to eat the wings.

This authentic Chinese restaurant is a bit off the main streets of China Town and therefore a lot less noisy! Hang Ah Tea Room offers a wide variety of authentic dishes and drinks! We went for dinner with our 2 boys, loved every dish we tried and would highly recommend: egg rolls, BBQ pork buns, shrimp chow mein, Dim Sum Comb and Curry Chicken... Wow simply delicious food, friendly staff and fast service... We will be back for sure!!!

I recently got to dine her for lunch with my favorite cousin in the world, Lizzy (yes, this is important to the review).  She informed me that it is the OLDEST dim sum restaurant in the US of A!  How cool is that!!??  Their dim sum is delicious, wait staff is friendly.  Wish they had larger water glasses is my only complaint.  They have neat old pictures from the early 1900s of mis. beauty queen pageants and events in San Francisco.  I real fun piece of San Francisco history right here.  I HIGHLY recommend you try this place out.

This was my favorite restaurant from my trip to San Francisco! I'm really sad that I don't live closer so I can go more. The staff were all very friendly and the food was authentic and delicious, probably the best dim sum I've had. We tried the Hang Ah purse dumpling, fried shrimp ball, pot stickers, fried sesame ball, BBQ pork bun and fried rice.  They were all great, my favorite was the sesame ball. The fried rice looked kind of plain when it arrived but it was packed with flavor. Great place, can't say enough. I will be back on my next San Fran trip.
Exactly what I wanted. No frills, home made dim sum.

This place is tucked away behind a little playground in San Francisco's china town. It claims to be the oldest dim sum resaurant in the continental US, and it definitely seems authentic. We had the shrimp dumplings, BBQ pork buns, and the pineapple chicken fried rice. For dessert we ordered lotus dumplings-on the regular menu- because they're kinda sweet. It was a solid place for lunch.
Outstanding, and I don't say that lightly.  Walked in there on a rainy Sunday afternoon for a take-out order - really nice owners who made me feel welcome, offered me tea/hot water while I waited.

Their chili sauce was so good, we consumed almost a whole jar during dinner and then bought one to go!  The Hang Ah Purse dumpling was our favorite dinner item - a mix of peanuts, meat, and spice.  The BBQ pork bun was simple, but add their chili sauce and it turned awesome.  For dessert, we enjoyed both the egg custard and lotus buns.

Super chill spot and the food was very tasty. We had pork dim sun, hot tea and egg rolls. The family staff was very attentive and made us feel comfortable. The prices we super affordable $10 for dinner.
We got dim sum to take out on a picnic.  The 6 selections we had & the portion size of each were wonderful.  Everything we tried was delicious!
The food tasted ok. I wish they had more dim sum options.

After moving back into the Bay Area less than a year ago we have been on a dim sum eating rampage, sampling my favorite haunts: Ton Kiang and Hong Kong East Ocean Seafood in Emeryville, as well as Yank Sing, Great Eastern Restaurant, and Good Luck Dim Sum in the Richmond district.  Moved on to try Hang Ah Team Room today (oldest dim sum restaurant in the US) and I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the dumplings.  We tried Ha Gow, Bak Toll Gow, Fun Gor, as well as pot stickers, egg rolls, wonton soup, steamed pork buns, green beans with black bean sauce, and combination fried rice.  The taste and quality of the dim sum was as good as anywhere I've been in the Bay Area.  That said, the wonton soup lacked flavor compared with some of the other places around.  The fried rice was savory, although a little too oily for my family's liking.  Generally, I agree with some other posts that the non-Dim Sum offerings are limited and below quality compared to what can be found at the other restaurants listed above.  The ambiance/decor can be improved, although certainly not as dingy as can found elsewhere in Chinatown.  I would repeat if in the area - hopefully they will expand their menu by then.  I do agree with other posts that their homemade chili sauce is a nice bonus surprise!
Grand re-opening of this historic Chinatown restaurant.  Food quality is very good, I would come again.
