This place is a trek to get to since it's right smack in between Chinatown and North beach. The only good thing about this place is the calamari and maybe the Hong Kong style noodles but also, they open pretty late for club goers.
Rude service! Went in here with a party of 8 and the restaurant did not close for 3 hours.

Went with my wife, she had a noodle soup I had sweet and sour Schrimps.  I loved it and she did too. Service was really good, very prompt and very polite. This is probably how the restautants look back in Bejing but I wish it was more clean, it felt a bit dirty, hence the 4 stars. Would I go back? Absolutely.

The location is conveniently located.  However, worst Chinese food I have ever had in Chinatown.  Slow serivice, duck feet were sour, some clams served unfresh or bad, fried noodles were not evently cooked.  Please watch out, if you must try stay away from traditional Chinese dishes and go somewhere else.

I really wish there was an option to not give this place any stars at all. The service was horrible. What I would expect is a smile no bad looks and just serve us. My friends ended up getting sick. That's two people throwing up. The place is filthy. When we were leaving we were nice enough to leave $3 for tip. Bill was $38.35 we gave her $41.35 she counts the money in front of us and says there isn't enough. Says that we owe her a six dollar tip. Forget that!! She didn't deserve it. Won't recommend this place at all. Don't go!! Trust me!!
One of my favorites in all of Chinatown San Francisco. Authentic and delicious. Service is good and friendly. Go for the crab, it so goood. #chinatown #sanfrancisco #dungenesscrab
Ummm can you say FOOD POISONING! I should have walked out when I saw the pigeon walking around inside with no cook or waitress fleeing him out, only giggles in response.

After hitting up China Town, my parents and I were starving and decided to eat somewhere nearby since the BNB we were staying at was in Pacifica. On the way back to the car, my Dad spots this place adorned with the photos of the owner with various hosts from Travel Channel and Food Network (ie Samantha Brown and Andrew Zimmern), plus the Zagat stickers from 2011 - 2014. I checked the reviews on Yelp and it had 4 stars so it must be good right? So we decided to eat here.

Fried oysters were inedible....UGH.  Calamari was not up to par. Ginger beef was good, but such a small amount!!  Servings, overall, were small.  Mediocre experience and over priced.  Try another spot.

I came here from Long Beach, ca. Bombass food freal. I don't eat shellfish but my ma absolutely loved the giner and green onion crab ! ($42) and the portion was HUGE. They season all of their dishes very well. We also got the chinese brocoli with cod fish and beef chinese noodle. All delicious !!

The reason why people think Yuet Lee serves good Chinese food is because it's 2:00 in the morning and you find yourself in North Beach, drunk and hungry, and desperate for anything greasy and oily that would help soak up all the alcohol.  So your options are limited at this hour of the day as is your judgment for what good food is, and Yuet Lee happens to be one of two Chinese restaurants opened (the other is Sun Hong Kong further down Broadway, which is even worst but at least much cheaper).  I've eaten Chinese food all my life and all over the world, and there's no other reason to eat at a place like Yuet Lee other than that.  Its prices are outrageous.  The food is mediocre at best, super greasy and oily and will likely give you the runs later.  Don't get caught up with all the celebrity photos on the wall, most of them have no idea about authentic and good Chinese food, and don't pay an average person's price when they go out to eat.  They're just playing tourist when they come here, don't get trapped!
The family and I ate dinner at Yuet Lee the night before attending Outside Lands in Golden Gate Park.

I haven't been to this place in a while, but I remember loving it so much when I lived in SF. I ate here several times. This is the kind of restaurant that does stir fried things well. And deep fried things, too, for that matter. Also, the lobster is good.
Loved the clams. Didn't care for the salt and pepper squid because I thought it was too salty. Food came out super quick. Place is kind of ghetto, but it makes the place seem authentic.
Delicious Chinese food, a must go. Best thing is you can pay with credit card with an order minimum (I believe) of $10.
They say they're open, but when you try to place an order they tell you they're not open and give you an attitude. Completely unappreciated and disrespectful. This place is terrible.
open late. good salt and pepper calamari. cooked well, seasoned great, nice light crispy breading
The service was excellent and quick. The food was delicious. It's small but homey. I recommend the Peking ribs. They are awesome.

The food here is a bit pricier than most simple Chinese restaurants. The service is quick but a bit hostile. The food was pretty good. But I would definitely head to Broadway Cafe before heading here since their prices are more reasonable for the same type of dishes.
I have been coming to Yuet lee since 2010.

I was feeling a bit hungry because the Moroccan food I had for dinner didn't seem too satisfying.  It was good cuisine, a belly dancer put on quite a show and all, but it was finger foods, you know?  So I made the trek to Chinatown, specifically to Yuet Lee, for some no nonsense, old fashioned comfort food.  I had a Tsingtao beer, plain won ton and clams in pepper, black bean sauce.  The food hit the spot!  I left full & with a grin on my face.  I'm just a simple Chinese man....
Im from LA so when everyone told me to go to Chinatown I figured it doesnt matter where u eat...
Loved the salt and pepper squid.  Great pan fried noodles too.  The braised pork chops rocked too.
My favorite Chinese seafood restaurant. (Well, to be fair, the only Chinese seafood restaurant I can ever remember going back to, but that's besides the point).

The food is outstanding and I have now found a new favorite place in Chinatown FINALLY! The other reviews about the staff being rude is a bunch of bullshit, maybe certain customers need to check their ego's in at the door. The hours are great also for a late night bite.
Good food...but if they are going to be this way about prices (see picture)......then I can't recommend......it.
So delicious! Love the salt and pepper calamari, beef chow fun, and the sweet and sour pork chops! Everything is so good actually. LOVE!

I was visiting from NY with some friends and stopped here after reading all these great reviews. We wanted to eat light but just could not stop ourselves, it smelled amazing in there with loads of pictures of all their meals hanging around. I found myself exponentially hungrier with one glance.
Good food, but service is horrible. The waiter will harass you if you don't leave him more than a five dollar tip. The cups and plates were dirty. I wouldn't recommend this place

When we first walked in, I was a bit hesitant in staying. It looked like your typical hole in the wall Chinese place with sticky tables and dirty floors. However, plastered all over the restaurant walls were photos of Eric Tsang! One of the funniest Kungfu actors in HK with their restaurant's chef! If that guy can eat here why can't I? Ambience aside or lack there of, the food was a different story!

I've been coming here for 30 of the 38 years it's been here and it's just as good today as it has been over the years. Where else can you get a tasty meal at 11:30pm. They don't have the friendliest of people but at least they are consistent.
For the money, this was the very best of the Chinese establishments since the 70's, and usually had decent service.

This place is great. They open really late, which means that a lot of people who work late can come and eat. Another thing is, their stuff is fresh. They truly care about their welfare of their customers. I learned a lot Yuet Lee by a local High Schooler's video. Visit " Multimedia: Yuet Lee" for more info. The owner is reeaalllyyyy nice!

AWFUL! HORRIBLE SERVICE! They have two waitress both with glasses but WATCH OUT for the younger one with round face and short hair as she is extremely rude as she is blatantly told me that I don't tip her enough which is over 20%! also the foods is overly priced!

I've heard so much about this place I had to give it a try while staying in SF for a night. My first impression walking in was that it was packing at midnight and the customers were not all Asian, surprisingly. Usually these restaurants are just filled with hungry Asian people who are either coming from the bars or just hungry asian people who stay up late.

So with both Yuet Lee and New Sun Hong Kong offering classic Chinatown late night bites, how does one decide on which business to frequent?  Service at both are as you'd expect from late night C-town restaurants, brusk and to the point.  So do you go with the restaurant with the green trim or the one w/ the yellow trim?

Came here today for a work meeting and the food was mediocre at it's best. Some dishes were way too salty while others were too bland. We ordered the roasted pork clay pot and it was very watery and salty. I've never had a clay pot like it and was completely disappointed. Probably the best thing I had was the beef chow fun. Something I want to note was that we found a hair in our soup.. Our server took it and brought us new bowls. NO BIG DEAL! but the chef was screaming at her! That poor woman... She returned with a new bowl of soup with red eyes and a red nose. It was evident that she was crying and I felt so bad. No one should ever cry at work. Best believe we left her a big tip.
I enjoyed my lunch experience here.

You don't really go to a Chinese restaurant and expect great customer service.  And this place did not disappoint.  Bad service and the  food was mediocre.  Tips were optional from my understanding.  I normally tip well above 15% if they deserve it.  I felt that they didn't deserve anything but I still tipped.  As my partner and I were leaving, the waitress stopped us and pointed at tip and said "That's not enough tip."

I can never get enough of this place. Yuet Lee has been around for over 30 years. This is one place I always have to go to when in Chinatown even during the late night. My friends and I always end up going to Yuet Lee after a fun night out. The food is so good. Love getting their salt and pepper calamari, Peking spare ribs, fish, clams, their soups, chow mein and so much more. When I go there I never have a problem with their service.
The only thing I like coming to this place is their char siu , roasted pork, roasted duck , soy sauce chicken , and their fried chicken !
Love the inexpensive yet tasty fried drumstick and chow mein.

I stayed outside once again cause I just don't like going into most of the stores in Chinatown. So crowded. My mom went in to buy a soy sauce chicken & roasted duck. In the past, I've had their salt-n-pepper chicken wings which were delicious.

This place has the BEST chicken drumettes EVER! It's seasoned perfectly throughout with just the right amount onioy/garlicy goodness and is very lightly battered before it's fried which makes it perfectly crispy without feeling overly greasy like the stuff you get elsewhere.
This is now called New Golden Daisy! Check their addresses minus the zip code...!
So my fiance's mom left for Vietnam/China for a good month. We started panicking...crap...this means we're going to do take-out for a month?

Usually when I come and buy food from this place.... The one food item that I really like to eat when it comes to buying something at Sun Sang Market my favorite food item would be the Sweet & Sour Pork!!!!!

They had cooked chickens hanging in the window that looked absolutely divine. But I have zero Chinese language skills, and I'll admit, I was intimidated, so I would only pass by occasionally and stare longingly at the chicken.
I was actually trying to get to New Golden Daisy because I heard so much about their fried chicken drumettes but I accidentally went in here (damn, don't people put the store names on the windows?).
This is the other Sun Sang BBQ place on stockton..
I always come here for pho.

I'll always give this place 5 stars, I've been a regular here for over three years. I'll admit though if you're a tourist or don't speak Chinese it might be a little tough ordering. Once they recognize you're a regular the atmosphere totally changes. The food is always on point and service is fast. They have over 300 things to choose from, I lean more towards the Vietnamese pages with Pho.

Probably the best Pho Ga I had outside of Vietnam. We went there for the afternoon Happy Hour. Between 3pm and 6pm beers and wine are 50% off. There is also a selection of dishes for 5$ including Pho Ga. The quality of the food was high and portions were huge.
If this place wasn't in Chinatown which is pretty far out of the way for me, my boyfriend and I would definitely be a regular of this place.

I came here for the first time with a few coworkers during lunch. After sauntering through Chinatown, we entered this restaurant. I just couldn't begin where to look in the menu, because there were just so many different styles of noodle preparation!
i'm a regular at this cafe. very good service for a chinatown joint. their happy hour prices are outrageously cheap. their pho is bomb and big portion. their dirnks are cheap, around 1$.
I stumbled upon this restaurant while walking through Chinatown.  A clean, modern, and cheerful place with friendly service and reasonable prices.  The Pho Tai was impeccable.
really good spot!
Large, clean, well-lit, good prices, and decent food.
Excellent quality food and very reasonably priced.  Try both the iced lychee and fresh lemonade drinks, they will make your tastebuds dance and sing!
Cheap, fast, quality = 4 yelps

Excellent place to go in Chinatown.  It's very large, clean, well priced and has a huge variety of foods, plus wifi which is both excellent and quite unique to the area.  You could tell it was good because it was off the main road and full of Asians.
Clean pho place in Chinatown

Awesome place with great food, service and price.  I ordered a wonton soup which is my favorite , but what  made it even better was the option to choose my own type of noodles.  I had the pure rice noodle which I never had before abd it was thr perfect compliment to wontons. Also you must try the 3 color bean drink.  The menu has pictures with each item that helped since I am visual person.
This place is awesome!

This restaurant has a very extensive menu..And I mean extensive!!! A minimum of a double sided 5 page menu with at least 10 different dishes on each page making it incredibly hard to decide! Everything from Vietnamese, Cambodian and Chinese!
I ordered the dumplings with veggies. The soup is huge and really lovely in a savory broth. Fast service. The atmosphere is kind of boring, but clean and bright.

A decent hokkien/teochiu (southern Fujian, northern Canton) noodle and rice joint.  They also offer Vietnamese food (a lot of Chinese from Vietnam are Teochiu).  I order the combo soup noodles  with thin rice noodles.  It was pretty light with fish balls, pork, shrimp, kidney, fried onion, g onions and bean sprouts.  The soup noodles remind me of the ones in Taiwan (most Taiwanese have ancestors from southern Fujian).  You can choose a variety of Teochiu/Fujian/Cantonese noodles : wide rice noodles (Cantonese fun), thin rice noodles (Fujian rice vermicelli or mi fen), thin Cantonese egg noodles, yellow noodles (round spaghetti like Fujian egg noodles), a couple of varieties of kway teow (round rice noodles from Fujian).
This is one of my favorite restaurant I eat out and I always get number 55 all the time. Eating me some Chinese food for lunch I haven't been here in a while.
Free wifi. The service is always friendly . If you go there around 5 to closed Don't order any noodle soup.
First Time Experience:
400 items on the menu. That's right. FOUR. HUNDRED. That means if you went there every day for a YEAR, you wouldn't get through everything.
Delicious!  Great service.

I first ate here in high school when they were first located on Stockton in a much smaller place next to Little Paris. What people aren't understanding that this place is a chaozhou or teochew cuisine WHICH is Chinese and not Vietnamese so please don't just assume its a Vietnamese restaurant because they serve Pho - i could go on about this but i'll just continue by reviewing the food. They have a large menu with pictures to display what dishes they serve. The new location is a lot bigger and cleaner. I always get the Chicken Pho on cold days and scrambled eggs over beef chow fun on the warmer days. My mom loved the seafood fried crispy noodles. They most definitely raised the prices but can't blame them for needing to keep up with surviving in this country. They have great customer service and free wifi :)
Found this place wandering around Chinatown on a rainy day . The service was amazing, the food was brought directly to us. I most definitely recommend this restaurant. I love their crispy noodles!
lets go as simple as possible: large variaties of food here, cheap with very plain taste.

First off please note that this is a chiu chow style cuisine,known for its seafood and vegetarian dishes and is commonly regarded as being healthy. Its use of flavouring is much less heavy-handed than most other Chinese cuisines and depends much on the freshness and quality of the ingredients for taste and flavour. As a delicate cuisine, oil is not often used in large quantities and there is a relatively heavy emphasis on poaching, steaming and braising, as well as the common Chinese method of stir-fry.

Happy hour =$2.00 Sapporo?! Sounds amazing to me.  The food seemed to be extremely oily but still yummy.  We got the chow mein, vegetable pot sticks, and hot&sour soup.  By far the BEST hot &sour soup!!!  It was only $5.00 &they gave you sooo much.  I shared with my boyfriend &we both got 2 servings each.  The service was alright, didn't get my water glass refilled but I think the waitress was training which is understandable.  The waitresses were still very sweet.
Short Story:

While the food was acceptable, I would look elsewhere. We had been trekking through Chinatown and were growing hungry. Not wanting to indulge on Dim Sum we stumbled upon San Sun. Probably an OK place if I had never had real Vietnamese food, but given that I have certain expectations it was a real let down. I've dined at Chinese run Vietnamese places before that have really good food but unfortunately this wasn't one of them.
July 4th was great fun this year, making the pilgrimage to San Francisco, except the highlight of eating out in Chinatown with family didn't come close to meeting expectation.

It looks like a Vietnamese restaurant from the outside, and even their first few pages of the menu are dedicated to Vietnamese dishes, but this is quite clearly a Chinese style restaurant.  Don't be deceived by the menu because their pho is far from good.  What kind of place actually asks you what kind of noodles you want in your pho?  Our hero wanted to try what it would be like with egg noodles (oh the folly of such a decision), and was sorely disappointed.
Been coming here since their old location and it's still really good. Never lets me down.

A friend and I ate here; she got stir fried noodles with vegetables and tofu, and I got vegetable noodle soup.  Both dishes were pretty unpalatable.  My soup was bland as can be, a very simple clear broth with stuff thrown in.  Her dish was covered in a slimy, clear gravy with little flavor and bad texture.

A very traditional Chinese canteen.  A lot of good eats from noodles to rice plates.  What really made me write this review was their fried fish balls.  I had to order a second plate.  It was extremely yummy!
I loved them at their old location, but they had to move because of the new Chinatown station to be build there.  Now I have to deal with walking up the hill to this newer, larger, quieter location.
Great soup! My girl and I got the Cambodian combination rice noodle soup. Delicious. They give you big portions so we shared.  We also got egg rolls, can't complain.
I ducked into this restaurant as I was running away from some bad men in Chinatown; that's the last time I'll parkour in the area. The adrenaline subsided and hunger began to set in so I sat down.
I remember eating here whenever I went to SF Chinatown with my mom when I was young.

Very delighted to still see this restaurant around.  This restaurant has been with me growing up. I don't live in SF anymore but whenever i go back to visit, the food is always good.  My favorite dish is the beef and egg over chow fun.  It is the bomb.  I also really like the satay beef noodle, and their pho is good too.  Their food is always hot and made to order.  This is the to go place in whenever I go to SF!  This place is awesome, they have free wifi toO!  This place surely reminds me of my childhood!
Wow, this place serves HUGE portions! But am I complaining? No, sirree!

I always get their vermicelli bowls or rice plates when I am here! I always order it with BBQ chicken or with BBQ pork. Their chicken and pork are extremely flavorful and it's the best part of the bowl or plate!
I really like this location. Really.

There are many good Vietnamese restaurants in the heart of Chinatown. I have passed by here many times and never had an opportunity to dine here. But after my first visit, coming here was indeed a big mistake.

I had the pho tai. It was ok. There's no hot pepper oil & they're cheeky with the cilantro & green onions. They also use red onions instead of white. This may be nothing to most ppl but I'm kind of a pho addict  and thought you should know. I wouldn't go again.
WATCH OUT!!! GOT FOOD POISONING AFTER HAVING LUNCH AT THIS PLACE YESTERDAY 08/01/14!!!! SYMPTOMS INCLUDING: DIARRHEA, VOMITTING, HEADACHE AND STOMACH CRAMPS!!!

Small mom and pop spot recommended to me by a friend for great pho. I got #23 the satay beef. Veggies are fresh, flavor is good and has nice spice. I am disappointed in the imperial rolls, too greasy and too much batter and served very hot. Portions are good sized and the price is very reasonable for what you get. Inside is clean and the overall quality is high. I will definitely come back.

Really sucks. I don't even know how they have stayed open! Worst Vietnamese restaurant ever! And they charged me 3$ for extra blood in my Bun Bo Hue, which was the worst I have ever had btw. Thai tea was watered down, nothing good!

Went here for lunch yesterday and we were able to be seated quickly.  My mom ordered the crab and pork noodle soup... but she couldn't find any crab (not ordering that again). I ordered chicken and mixed veggies rice plate-- pretty good! May I add..  tge place was very tight and small, not ideal to go with 4+ people.
Very welcoming and attentive staff. Ordered vermicelli rice noodles with BBQ pork and imperial rolls. Big portion but the BBQ pork and rolls were smaller than I thought. Very good though!
They give way too big of portions. Noodles for days. It's a little overwhelming.
$8.09 lemongrass pork vermicelli, less than 5 min wait.

I gave this place 3 stars because I found hair in my food and I kindly told them about it. She took my plate and then brought it right out that she took the hair out. I didnt make a big deal because the food was good. The pork chop was real good. Also, get their fresh lemon drink.
Great Food!  Had a great bowl of Pho. Loved the imperial rolls. Prices were great and service very quick. I was well pleased

I came here for lunch the other day per co-workers suggestion.  I ordered the chicken pho and I have to say the pho had a "lightness" to it that I enjoyed very much compared to the majority of other places where I ordered this.  I also really liked the type of noodles they served.  It was very thin, like the vermicelli rice noodle we would get at a Chinese restaurant but still taste like the regular pho.  Very interesting, I thought.
Food was overpriced and mediocre. On the bright side, food comes very quickly and the restaurant looks pretty clean.

All I have to say is.. crab. noodle. soup. OMG, SO GOOD! It doesn't have crab chunks, so don't be fooled. It does have pork, and my oh my will it fill you up even on your hungriest days. About $8 with tax, and the lunch crowd is always poppin in this place. The waitresses are super friendly, but super busy. I've also tried a few other dishes, and they were very delicious as well. I'd say this is your best bet if you'd like to try Vietnamese food, or just want a good bowl of pho. Highly recommend this place.
Great on a cold day.
It's a little more expensive here compared to other Vietnamese restaurants.  I've eaten at over 80 Vietnamese restaurants and this place was definitely below average.

Good, cheap Vietnamese near FiDi, Chinatown, and North Beach. Portions are good size and the meals are cheap and tasty. Pho is legit. Clay pots are legit and the combo plates are pretty good too. Most meals are under $8.50.

Cheap and tasty. What more can one ask?  My old standby in the area is the House of Nanking, but I was on an extreme budget so I was browsing for something that cost next to nothing. Well, I found it with their hot and crunchy BBQ chicken Vietnamese sandwich for only $3.50!  Can't tell you about anything else on the menu, but if everything else is as good as the sandwich. This place is a find!

I was walking with a friend around dinnertime in sf on Kearny street and I was looking for a good place to eat. Since fellow yelpers seemed to agree that this was a good place, and I was craving phò, I decided to go to this restaurant.

For no apparent reason at all, I didn't feel like eating today. It's completely out of character considering I would normally fantasize about trying something new for lunch, especially after having a dull breakfast of cereal or yogurt. But you gotta eat, so what do you do? Play 'food volley' with your co-worker who's in the same funk. After 5 minutes of food suggestions back and forth, Vietnamese food struck a chord with both of us. (you can tell work is a huge priority for us) =)

Unfortunately greatly disappointed in the place, I'm Vietnamese and the food here is definitely not Vietnamese. Pho has too many Chinese spices and even curry taste, taste like Indian-Chinese soup. The cha gio( spring roll) are the size of a toothpick, more rice wrap than filling. I would not recommend the place, go down the street to the Vietnamese restaurant, it look a bit sketchy but more authentic than here.

I will be back again and again to this Pho house. The Pho broth has more cinnamon than I am used to but that is part of the charm of Vietnamese food. Although the recipes have a base set of core ingredients - Vietnamese cooks add their own special flair to make the dish their own.

I'm there every week with my co-workers. Love the E-Sup! (The special beef.) The portion is huge and delicious. I don't really remember how the other items taste because it has been a while since I got anything but the special beef - number 20. My parents and friends come in from abroad and this is one of the places I bring them every time.
I think prices have gone up since some of the reviews on this place. I got a claypot because I had been craving one for awhile. My friend got a pho, which was quite a generous portion.
bbq chicken with imperial roll and rice noodle taste really good.

Came here with a girl friend yesterday after work for a casual dinner.  I got the bbq beef with grilled shrimp over vermecelli and she got the bbq pork with imperial rolls over vermecelli.  Both amazing!  The food is fresh, non-greasy, and has great taste!  Will definitely recommend and be back again!
Their pho is delicious if you are looking for hot noodle soup with meat - especially on cold days when the fog comes withering in!

Good food at reasonable prices.  For some reason this place isn't as busy (yet) as very similar Vietnamese places nearby, which is fine with me.  The service has been good everytime I've eaten here and the food is good.  The combo plates are just right with a good mix of food but the pho is probably the best deal.  The "Special Pho" is the typical everything beef but without the tripe that so many other places load up on - this is how I prefer it.
seriously good lunch spot. the food here is delicious and the prices are very reasonable.  for a large lunch portion, you get a good sample of food with their combo plates.

love this place.  so many options, good quality and inexpensive, quick friendly service. I would recommend #23 satay beef pho (a bit spicy), any of the clay pots, veggie rolls, mongolian beef, i don't really like vermicilli bowls but their vermicilli bowl with half chicken/shrimp is delicious.

Love this place.  The portions are very generous and the staff is extremely friendly.  They are one of the few Asian restaurants that take card and not exclusively cash.  Prices are very cheap - less than $10 per person.
Hmmmnnn..
We stumbled across this place while wandering around Chinatown. The food was amazing, and the service was great, and even better for the prices.
Bottom Line: Good vietnamese cuisine smack in the middle of town for reasonable prices.

After passing Quickly's not far from here, my friend and I decided to come here since it had been a while since we've had vietnamese food. For SF, I thought this was surprisingly cheap. My meal came out to be under 10 dollars (seems like a rarity here). I had the House Special Beef Noodle Soup (first one on the menu when you look for Pho).

I often get take out from this place for lunch. It's a convenient location and their spring rolls (both shrimp and vegetarian) are soo good. I tried their chicken pho last week and was sadly unimpressed. The broth was pretty bland. Sometimes it takes a while to get my order (even when it's just an order of spring rolls) but it does seem like they are always busy during lunch.
This restaurant is famous in China. But I do not like wait in line for hours. I won't be there for awhile. :)
Writing this because of Yelp, hours aren't correct...yelp said open, we went at 9pm on Thursday and was closed.
We had an early lunch here, drawn in by the picture menu and the nicely done facade of the place. It's off the main tourist path a bit, a small but clean dining area with the typical decor.
I've come here a few times for a good ol' Hot Pot, cause not only food is good, it's never crowed or noisy, service is fast, and price are reasonable.

If you like it spicy hot, this is your place! I came in ahead of my party and was chatting with the server who was super nice. She explained how they started serving Xiang cuisine in addition to the Sze Chuan cuisine so the owner updated the Chinese name of the store to Mao Jia Wan and gave the restaurant a face life in February.
I just came here for lunch and I thoroughly enjoyed the food. Everything I ate was like a flavor punch in the mouth, and everything was adequately spicy.

We stumbled across this restaurant in the back alleys of China town. The waitress didn't speak much English and the menu had quite a few misspellings on it- we took this as a good sign of authentic Chinese cuisine. We had two different dishes split between us. One of them was a three cup chicken (pretty good) and the other was a Szechuan Beef.

OMG! This place is so good. We come here when Z+Y Szechuan is busy. It holds its own. We go to Z+Y b/c it's closer. My favorite dish here is the salt + pepper breaded fish filet. They call it something else on their menu. We always order different things when we come here and they never disappoint EXCEPT for some beef soup that was so so. I highly recommend it if you want tasty Chinese food. It's not that spicy, so don't let the red peppers scare you. Annoying things are, they charge $0.35 for a takeout box which I find stupid. They also only have 1 waitress at a time, tops 2, so it's a bit slow.

Authentic Szechuan cuisine with lots of chili oil and Szechuan peppercorns. Not as good as Z and Y but you can be seated and finish your meal before the line gets into the door Z and Y. The other huge win is they are open till midnight.
One of my favorite Chinese restaurant, they cook Sichuan food and you can expect spiciness in their dish. Of course it's unfortunately not as spicy as in China but you still "have fun".

This was my favorite place for potstickers & green onion pancakes way back in the 70s when it was own/operated by 2 brothers. There was a dish that was chicken breast with snow peas that was good too. It's changed hands many times since then and the last time I went, it was disgusting. Some of the items on the menu was the same but the old cooks must be gone/dead. Come if you like American food. Ugh!

I have been visiting this restaurant on every visit to San Francisco for 20 years.  Never disappointed.   While some call this a tourist trap, I disagree.  It is a block off of Grant (the main drag thru Chinatown) and is very small.  Enjoyed the pot stickers as usual, as well as some spicy chicken and vegetables.  Lots of spice to this dish.

We had potstickers, green onion pancake, sauteed string beans and salt and pepper prawns.  All excellent all not greasy whatsoever.  Service was perfect.  Price was reasonable.  Definitely would return.
**Summary**

Really dug the food here although some was definitely hit or miss. Get the hot and numbing spicy pot and chicken with explosive chili. Also try garlic prawns but skip the string beans -waaaay too salty!

Despite the name of the place, which sounds decidedly americanized, the heart and soul of this place is Sichuan/chongqing. Avoid the "Mandarin" part of thee u and stick to the hotpot or Sichuan specialties. I had the shui zhu yu (broiled catfish in Sichuan chili oil). Excellent. Tender, flavorful, and numbingly spicy. Immediately brought me back to my trips to China.
Something different than the rest out there.

LOVE this hole in the wall place in Chinatown. Stopped here on our way out of San Francisco and it did not disappoint. Very straight up, classic Chinese food. Very sweet, attentive server. Would totally recommend this place to someone visiting San Fran who wants great, no-frills Chinese.
Not that good as other reviews, and it is apparently overpriced.
+ Attentive service. Our waitress was very nice and considerate.

We drove all the way into Chinatown for some great Asian food, and were sorely disappointed to have eaten here. The service was terrible, and the food was meehhh. We decided to come here because it was Szechuan, and spicy sounded great. Although what we ordered should have been spicy, nothing was - the beef had a little hint of spiciness to it, but not much. The sweet and sour fish had an ok flavor, but it was soggy. Our food came out one at a time and in an odd order. and it took forever for the lady to come by to take our order. I could also tell the couple sitting next to us were irritated because they had been waiting forever just to pay their bill. The place wasn't really busy, either.
Good, spicy food! Really decently priced as well. Get the hot pot, you won't regret it!
A classic since I was in college in the 80s and ate here weekly.

As a person who comes from Sichuan, I can tell this restaurant has pretty decent and authentic spicy food. The people who gave less than 3 stars probably dont know what they are talking about. I used to drive to a restaurant in Newark in order to get authentic Sichuan food. Now, I finally found a closer one. I brought my American, Mexican, Iranian, and Sichuan friends to this restaurant. All of them liked it so much.

I came here with a few friends to meet someone in downtown SF. I think the flavors were pretty good (could've been spicier!), but overall, it was pretty oily and heavy. We intended to "eat lighter", but we ended up ordering a ton of food!

Wow! No no no.   First they forgot my rice and wonton soup.  Mistakes happen.    But when they came back the soup was so bad (like lukewarm dishwater with soggy cabbage and mushy wontons) I literally had to flush it down the toilet.   The pot stickers were so greasy I had to blot them You'd think they'd get that one right since that's what they named their restaurant.  The chicken with string beans was bland and greasy.
I just moved back to the US after a few years in China and was craving some mapo tofu with rice.  The Pot Sticker did not disappoint.  Highly recommended.
Really authentic if u like Sichuan spicy food.  Highly recommend
Pretty authentic Sichuan food.  As hot as it needs to be.

A different take on Chinese food this place serves. This joint serves Hunan cuisine. I recommend their dinner entrees including possibly their hot pots. Most dishes are prepared spicy. The place doesn't skimp on flavor as evidenced by the overpowering smell of cumin as soon as you walk in. Unless your tastebuds are in the mood for adventure, you may be put off by the whole experience.

I don't really care for the food at The Pot Sticker.  The fish with chili oil and jello with hot sauce were decent, everything else was sub par.  We ordered cumin lamb, and they used super thin sliced lamb, the one you would use in shabu or hot pot.  The beef with pickled peppers wasn't great, the beef texture was weird.  They used baking soda to tenderize the meat, maybe a little too much.  The beef roll was decent, but not that much meat in this dish.

Finally reviewing this place! I'm a sucker for noodle soups and my coworker loooooves this place for noodle soup. I always walk by here and it always struck me as a tourist trap that serves Americanized Chinese food, but it's actually pretty legit Chinese food.
This really is a 3.5, but I'll round up to 4 because I was pleasantly surprised.

I was in china town an wanted something authentic, I wanted to go back to where I went on my prevous visit less than a year ago and I could not find it and was later told restaurants in China Town go and go very frequent here so it may be closed that is why I could not find it s I landed here and I was satisfied, I hope they are around for me to try again on my next visit to San francisco.
authentic Sichuan food but too oily and too salty
Good place for lunch, if you like spicy food.
Most satisfying Chinese food I've ever had in the US. Fish fillet in spicy oil and beans with pork tasted awesome.
Great whole fish special szechuan dish.  Decent mouth-watering szechuan cold chicken.   Mediocre tendon.

I was a little thrown off by the smell coming from the kitchen, but... the pork shoulder was to die for.  The scallion pancakes and the tofu with spicy beans were very good.  Tea smoked duck and some garlic and onion mushrooms were quite unremarkable.  The Szechuan hot pot seems to be the place highlight, but I didn't try it.
I took my wife here because she's from Northern China and was craving some comfort food. We had the Mouth Watering Chicken and the Spicy and Numbing Hot Pot.

My fellow coffee enthusiast friend from HK and I have this unspoken tradition whenever I'm back in town where we spend a morning doing yamcha and then visiting some up-and-coming coffee joint in the City.

Dol Ho is no lavish Yank Sing but if you want legit Dim Sum this is the real deal. If it's not in the carts you can ask for it to be made fresh. Yes you might have to share a table with a stranger but that's part of the experience.
Just ok.

I live in North Beach and I've been eating at this place for a couple of years. I love it because they serve old school steamed bar-b-que pork buns from the '80s and nobody else does and they taste awesome.
Filthy....dirty tables. Tables were outdated and need to be replaced. Not a pleasant eating environment. Nobody handling the take-out orders. Needs to be on Kitchen Nightmare.

That little place reminds me of the Hong Kong old style tea house where the locals goes to every morning for breakfast and tea. The older folks would sit around reading the morning paper while some catch up with their friends in between their market time. Many people stream in and out of the café to buy take-away breakfast.
Cheap, cheap dim sum. So cheap you get up and get your own tea if you're not willing to wait for a server, and no one will be offended.
Oh yeah, easy like Sunday morning, ordered the shrimp balls and fried tofu. Still waiting on the beef patty as we walked in at 0737. The place was 90% packed already as everyone was just sipping tea.

This place is a dive of a restaurant and the service is poor, but the food is outstanding.  If you can get past the dirty windows and floors and poor service you will want to eat here everyday. Yes it is that good.... p.s. you do not want to use the restrooms either.  But damn the food is good.
I often stop by here in the mornings before work for some quick breakfast -- usually a pork bun or vegetable bun, so I never got to try their famous pork over rice.
The spare ribs over rice are delish!  Definitely worth coming back here.

Love it!  My go-to place for dim sum in SF!  Small, strictly old school, but fine and cheap!  Taro pork balls : my favorite.  Har gow -usually good, although today mine were a little cold. Lots of older folks  enjoying their tea and a little something.  Been going here for 30 years in its various incarnations.  Still good. Not a dim sum palace and service is brusque, but get over it.  The food is worth it.

This has got to be one of the funniest dim sum restaurants I have been to. The quality is decent for the price you pay. It is no upscale restaurant, more run down than anything. We came here knowing what to expect after reading the reviews so we were just anticipating some decent dim sum and we got that. The service was quick. The server doesn't know much English. There is no menu given unless you ask for it and I think its just their items on an 8x11 piece of paper with no price. They reuse this piece of paper fairly often too. Every time our order came out, instead of marking the item on the sheet, she would just pull out another used sheet which had the designated amount of dishes that came out. It was hilarious. There are a lot of the older local Chinese gramps sitting around in this restaurant as well, but a lot of other locals dropping in to pick up take out.
This is my favorite place to eat in Chinatown. I love the pork spare ribs over rice.

Dol Ho is as legit as it comes. Located in the heart of Chinatown, DH follows the old-style dim sum tea houses, minus the birds in cages and spit buckets, but keep the 70+ year olds and brusque service.
Dim Sum here is hit or miss. Hac gao has plenty of flavorful shrimp. Xiu Mai is straight pork. Deep fried shrimp balls are fried to the perfect consistency. Spare ribs need a bit more flavor.

If you are used to Hong Kong style food places where the place is not exactly as clean as tidy as most of the restaurants in the US, I'd recommend you to give this a try.  It wasn't really crowded when we got there, but we had to share a table with strangers  (this is very usual in HK).

If you are not concerned about fancy atmosphere or decor, don't care too much about the service, but want to experience the true offerings of what Chinatown has, i.e., good, tasty dim sum, this is the place to come to.
San Francisco's Chinatown, the largest outside of Asia, provides streets of restaurants, grocery stores, and shops for a whole afternoon of fun. Which is exactly what we did.

I absolutely love this place. I grew up going to Chinatown every weekend with my family and my Grandma would always buy us a to-go order of their spare rib over rice or their beef balls over rice. It's just the right amount of food and it's so cheap! I love the spare rib sauce they pour over the rice and if you eat it right away, you'll notice that the rice is cooked really well. I would eat here everyday if I worked near.

Do you like cheap dim sum any day of the week?  Do you like when they bring around the little carts & you try to figure out what's in each of the dishes?  Do you like eating in dingy restaurants where you may be literally rubbing elbows with older Chinese folks?  Then Dol Ho is for you!

Very basic  dimsum place and the servers were very nice. They brought the shrimp dishes when they felt that we were going to order the seafood dimsum. I also requested the tofu dimsum which was quite greasy and not that fluffy. It was an interesting dimsum experience but I had super great company. Each dimsum entree was approximately $2.50. We had the shrimp balls, crispy shrimp balls, pork shamai, tofu with shrimp, and hot tea. We were the only nonChinese in the restaurant that Sunday.The dimsum was sort of salty as well.

Tasty dim sum takeout.  If you're not familiar with this kind of authentic Chinese food experience, you may take it to be a bit lacking in service, but I say, it adds to it's charm.  Crowded at times.  Go with someone who speaks Cantonese, if you can.
Dol Ho would be better spelled phonetically as "Daw Ho" in Canto.
lady is rude and nasty.

I came here and bought some Siu Mai ,beef ball and har gaw to go just eat  in the car when i ate the siu Mai &  beef ball it tasted disgusting ( so so ) it was not even good at all I had better dim sum at delicious dim sum and at the sunset district !

I walk past Dol Ho on a daily basis- once in the morning, and once at night. I think we all have those mornings where you just can't seem to pull yourself out of bed and don't have time to make yourself a good breakfast. I often have those days, so I've stopped at Dol Ho a few times to pick myself up some cha siu bao (bbq pork buns) for my trek to work. Meh- it's ok. The bun part is a bit too crumbly and the meat could be more substantial. I wouldn't come here otherwise since there are better bakeries just around the corner. But on those late mornings, it will suffice.

Disappointing.  Any dim sum in Chinatown should be held to higher standards than the unfortunate offerings that Dol Ho provides.  I've always considered midwest and east coast dim sum to be inferior to what we can get in California, but I can definitely say that you can get better dim sum in St. Louis or Salt Lake than what they serve up at Dol Ho.

Hole in the wall place in Chinatown. Please do not come here if you are afraid of bad service and needs a 4 star restaurant. I will be up front with you, you don't feel like this is a clean place when you walk in. You will mainly see old folks who will sit there with the spare ribs over rice(those silver looking bowls) and their newspaper. You will also walk in and notice there is a big crowd on your left.(don't worry, most of them are taking food to go) And be ready to wait for about 5 minutes without anyone coming to greet you. So if you don't mind any of that and do care for some good food with AMAZING hot sauce(not really spicy, it's the flavor), then please come try Dol Ho.

Delicious pork buns! Come for the food, not the service or atmosphere. Little English is spoken here. They seem to prefer you ordering the dim sum you want rather then bringing out items to choose from. I prefer dim sum restaurants with more frequent cart visits and more variety.
Absolutely great place. Here you can eat Dim Sum like in Hong Kong! Love it!! Come here every Sunday. And it's really cheap, two people can eat here for $15!

Good experience. Totally no frills. A Minimum Viable Chinese Restaurant (MVCR) definitely. Great dim sum, though some like the shrimp balls were too greasy. The spare ribs on rice were not great but the sauce and the rice were good. Foil wrapped chicken was perfect and the green tea very good.

Do not go here!!!  After reading the reviews, this place seemed worthwhile to grab some cheap dimsum.  It is cheap alright, but you get what you pay for.  We were seated next to the loudest guy ever, screaming in chinese to this other table about how to cook some type of chicken stew.  He literally gave me a migraine.  It was almost 90 degrees outside, but this place is so cheap that they didn't even turn on the stained and dusty revolving fans that they had on the walls.  We asked for ice water and they came back with tepid water straight from the faucet; they have no ice they said.  We had the usual dim sum affair: har gaw(terrible sticky thick wrapping), sui mai (awful chunks of fatty pork), bean curd roll (again fatty chunks of pork rolled in greasy tofu sheet, soaked in grease), chicken feet(just inedible), beef rice roll (gritty thick rice roll with unflavored beef).  We were trying to wait for the notable spare rib bowls, but after waiting 20 minutes for them to cook it, between with the deaf guy next to us screaming and the sweltering heat and atrocious food we already tried, we decided it was just not worth the wait.  We paid our $25 and went on our way; leaving Dol Ho was the best part of the experience.
Would be awesome if I knew Chinese..but even not, still great!

This is my favorite spot in the city, but it is not for the faint of heart, and they have many things that are excellent and many things that are mediocre. To be clear: this is "old Chinese man dim sum" as my wife calls it. It is the sort of place that you can imagine the old men sitting around reading their papers would be smoking if it were 15 years ago.

I grew up in Chinatown and I barely come to to this place. But when I did, I wish I came here more often. This hole in the wall may seem like nothing on the outside but once you get inside you will see a lot of locals enjoying their dim sum and newspaper.
Once you see the decor (and lack of tablecloths) at this place, then you know that you're not going to get 1) good "service" and 2) very very clean tables and dining ware.

This place is by no means amazing but it is great for cheap Chinese food. My mom loves this place and she is a pretty picky Chinese eater. She loves their spare ribs over rice bowls. I don't like spare ribs but everyone else seems to love it. It is cheap and hearty! If you have a regular size stomach one bowl of that and an item of dim sum is enough to last you the rest of the day. Probably cost you 5 bucks including tip! WHOA!
It scares me that I'm giving this place a 4 star just because it's a crappy hole in the wall, dirty, smelly Chinese restaurant and yet they have the most delightful $1.50 spare ribs over rice!!

I usually try to shy away from places like this. It's small, cramped with people, and by the looks of it is hard to talk with the waitstaff unless you know Chinese. Good thing the only bit of Chinese I DO know are the names of dim sum food items.
Oof. We wanted to love this place. My boyfriend raved about the bar it used to be. In its new incarnation, it was pretty sad.
Love this place for the decor and the bartenders, not so much for that crowd, at least on my most recent visit.
Unbelievable food. Jovial and warm environment. We had the roast chicken for two and it was easily one of the best things we've ever had. Incredible sauce, juicy and crispy--worth the wait!
Was seated as soon as we walked in the door! The dining room is small and allows for personal service.  The food was delicious.  Would definitely recommend Tosca for any special event.

I used to live in North Beach and loved the old Tosca Cafe for drinks.  When I returned to SF for a visit, I wanted to check out the spot's new life as a restaurant with a much talked about offering.  The interior has not changed much except for more lighting and a window into the kitchen as well as some wall decor.   I was hoping they'd soften the ambient noise some how but the dining room still has a dark diner feel to it.  They could improve on this.

Had an early dinner here with friends before seeing a show.  I love the atmosphere here - the booths tucked into the walls, the lighting, decor, etc.  I like looking into the open kitchen & watching dishes get plated up before being sent out.  This was probably my favorite dinner during a recent trip to San Francisco.  The caesar salad was very good - the waiter said he loved the presentation of it & felt it wasn't your typical caeser.  It had a nice hit of heat to it.  It was a bit filling & I might have considered splitting it with a friend after I ate the whole thing & was close to full.  The next dish was the lumaconi with prosciutto & lemon breadcrumbs.  Um, OMG that was delicious!  I don't usually love to order anything with cream sauce b/c it's just too heavy for me....but this was a very light cream sauce & not excessive.  I just wish I had not eaten so much of my salad b/c I just couldn't finish my pasta.  The cocktails were also outstanding - I had the whiskey smash & enjoyed it. Loved the music playing on the jukebox.  My only knocks on the place are (1) the service - I thought it was just ok.  The waiter was not really very attentive, empty plates sat in need of clearing, another cocktail was not offered.  Yet I saw a lot of waiters just kind of hanging around in the corners of the restaurant.  (2) The bathroom - I get that this place is a former dive bar that hosted celebrities & has a long history - but today I'm at a nice restaurant & while your bathroom might be considered kitschy, it's old & a bit on the gross side.
Echoing the underwhelmed sentiment.

We made a reservation 2 weeks in advance based on good reviews and hype.  Our reservation was for 5:15 PM, which we were told was the only available other than 11PM.  Despite how difficult the restaurant said it was to get in, we noticed many empty tables throughout our entire dinner.

My friends and I came here randomly on a weeknight and we loved it. Everything we ordered was delicious , especially the fried pig tails. The staff was also very friendly and great with drink suggestions. Need to go back asap

We had a large group and needed to push tables together but they were uneven. The manager insisted that we have even tables and moves their tables around to accommodate our group. We didnt mind but it was not up to us. Both our server and manger were delightful. I can't say enough good things about their service and professionalism. Raising the bar for north beach and booze coffee everywhere.

Perhaps my expectations were too high. Was really happy that they started taking reservations tho. My friends and I had wanted to come here for awhile. Checked in at the host stand for an early res (5:15) and was told they would come and get us when it was time. Sat at the bar and ordered a very delicious cocktail - so far so good. It was past our res time by about 10 minutes and no one came to get us so we went back to the host stand and were seated in a nice rounded booth. Service was nice - I don't know why others are so critical.
The mussels. Get the mussels. We refused to let the broth be taken away and ordered some focaccia to soak it all up. Oh. And the trouble in paradise...because who isn't a fan of that?

This has become one of my favorite places in SF.  I love the old school vibe and the food is awesome.  The best is the minestrone soup, quite possibly the best soup I've ever had.  I order it as my entree with some vegetable sides and the super yummy focaccia bread.  If they have meatballs as a special - those are a must have.  They actually take reservations and they're on Open Table..  It's a small restaurant though and there aren't many tables than can seat more than 4 people.  It's easiest to get a table for 2.

I'm obsessed with this place. Remains my very favorite restaurant in SF. I used to love THE SPOTTED PIG in nyc and this place brings the hustle of a nyc kitchen to an otherwise gastronomically impoverished neighborhood. The focaccia is crispy -- so good! And the salumi platter is great. Don't miss the Cacio e Pepe, really well executed. Great cocktails too!
Completely overrated - and a real shame it made Bon Apps list when there are actual amazing and worthy restaurants on the list (e.g., Estela in NYC).

Horrible service. Clueless hostess, absent waitress. However only reason in business is good food.  This year, we've been to SF several times and to NYC, Chicago, Philadelphia, New Orleans, Denver, LA, Phoenix, and Portland. Michelin-starred restaurants and hole-in-the-walls.  On this trip to SF, we ate at Tadich, La Folie, Akiko's,     Quince, and Mission Chinese.  Mission Chinese was awesome, even with service by one waiter at lunch for the entire dining room.  Tosca was the absolute worst for service.  No food is worth that experience at this kind of restaurant.

I have been visiting Tosca since the 90s! I drank tequila with our former mayor Willie Brown there. It is under new mgmt but it has not evolved. I am not an expert/foodie but I know good food. This is NOT it! Salt, salt and more salt. Let me break it down for you. If you want pasta, go to Tomassos. If you want a Pimms cup, go to Romolo. If you want to settle for mediocrity, go to the new Tosca. Just sayin

Expect a long wait.  We were told the wait would be up to 3 hours on the Saturday evening we stopped in.  Rather than wait for a table, we grabbed a seat at the bar.  I think if we go back, we'd do the same; in our opinion, the ambiance in the bar section is actually more inviting and cozy than the dining area.
Overall we did not enjoy our meal.
Delicious plates with poor service and inflated prices dragging the star level down to 3.
Excellent drinks.  Spectacular pasta.  Super cool vibe for the boy from Carolina.
Well I was underwhelmed. Hard to compete with all the press and live up to the expectations. We arrived, 4 of us, at 5:15. Drinks at the bar took a solid 10 minutes. Thankfully, they were excellent.

Well I ate here with my best friend after waiting for 3 months to finally have a night off together due to our crazy schedules. Ordered a lot because we like to go big. And heard from other chefs that this place is nice for late dinner (especially for industry people who get out late everyday like us). Anyways....like everything we got. Octopus was good. Cacio de pepe was too cheesy it was gloppy and not creamy. The tiramisu was perfect. The problem is here.....We got the chicken liver. We both love chicken liver. We are BOTH chefs here in SF.!! It came out and it was on a skewer. Took it off the skewer and noticed it was very medium rare.  Not the best idea to eat chicken liver so under done and we knew it. Not blaming tosca. We poked at it and talked about weather or not we should eat it. We ignored our better judgement and ate it cause we were so hungry. Finished our meal and went home. 5 days later I became extremely I'll from food Bourne illness aka food poisoning. To be honest I had no idea what it was from. I was in so much abdominal pain that I almost fainted twice. It lasted strong for 3 days. A couple days later after returning to work I texted my same friend and asked her when we can schedule our next meal together, that's when she said she has been bed ridden due to food poisoning. That's when my jaw dropped. I told her I had the same thing and it must have been our dinner from earlier in the week. We remembered the "if-y" liver we ate. I emailed tosca and told them what happened. Only seemed like the right thing to do. I wasn't blaming them And I wasn't mad or upset, but being in the food business I just thought it's something I should share. We would want someone to share that kind of info if it was our restaurants. It's been over a month and I haven't heard anything. No sorry. No thank you for sharing. No we will try to be on the look out for that. No nothing. So I took this time to write a yelp review to share my experience with people who actually care. Here it is. Enjoy everyone. Bed time.

The 3 star average is insane. I new nothing about Tosca Cafe until my buddy started talking about some bar he used to post at regularly that was a San Francisco institution reopening w/ a restaurant serving April Bloomfield's grub. Posted up at the bar for dinner. Here's the rundown:

First time since the re-do.  Looks great and I don't know that I've had Italian food this  good in years.  Had the meatballs (extraordinary, not your typical lump of tasteless meat, but complicated flavors and great sauce); bucatini (perfectly cooked pasta with a rich (not too rich) sauce with little bits of pork and crunch...superb); and a side of broccoli di cicco (if you're going to eat a vegetable, this is the way to eat it...again, perfectly cooked and seasoned, actually sort of complex).  Finished with buttermilk gelato, which was perfect.  The cocktails (negroni) were nice, too.  A tad pricey; but the serving sizes are just right.  We sat in the backroom (who knew?) and it was quieter, if a tad stuffy (air-wise).  Only complaint was that, while the staff are on the whole friendly and helpful, our waitress was a tad chilly...but we'll be back.

This place considers itself rustic italian.  Not sure what that means except it was interesting to try the pigs tail.  Also had a polenta dish.  Not sure why I got it since I am not a polenta fan.  Wanted to give it a try but did not like it.  Turnips however were great.

Came here for dinner on a Thursday night with the boyfriend. We shared the Crispy Pig Tails ($9), Rigatoni ($16), Linguini ($17), Hanger Steak ($25), and Crispy Potatoes ($7). We also had a Polo Cup and a Whiskey Smash based on the waitress's recommendation, which were both delicious and strong!
I want to like it. I mean Beyonce ate here. But alas, I felt like it was disappointing.

Took the family for dinner last night.  Good service, booth was a little small but was fine for us.  The food was excellent.  Adults loved the pig tails, kids not so much (too fatty).  Oxtail terrine was a hit and we LOVED the meatballs and foccacia.  Pastas were great and we really enjoyed the tiramisu and strawberry balsamic gelati.  Would definitely go back with friends, co-workers and or family.  Nice eclectic mix of patrons.

I am torn about this review as I wanted to like Tosca more than I did. Starting from the beginning, we were seated promptly. The space itself feels warm like it has history, but not old. However the banquette where we were seated was too small for four. The restaurant also was very warm and we all stuck to the vinyl.

Uneven experience. Other comments on the high salt levels were on point - on a few dishes the salt was overwhelming.   Service started strong but timing began to slip as the meal went on. I'd consider going back for snacks and drinks, but they aren't delivering a full meal that is legitimate at the price point.

After hearing that Tosca made Bon Appétit's top 50, we immediately booked a reservation. Having been to the excellent Spotted Pig and John Dory in NYC, we expected greatness. Too bad Tosca fell so short of our expectations. The restaurant's decor is charming and comfortable. They did a great job of maintaining it's original vintage feel without resorting to clichéd reclaimed wood and filament bulbs. The service was slow and amateurish. The waiter presented the wine to my husband to taste even though I had been the one to order it. There were a couple of interesting tuna appetizers on the menu. The egg tonnato was very good, the egg making a natural pairing with tonnato sauce. It was a great alternative to the traditional veal recipe.  The tuna conserva with radishes on the other hand lacked brightness that should have counterbalanced the heavy oiliness of the tuna and the creaminess of the crème fraîche. The crispy pig tails, while cooked perfectly and full of flavor, were over-salted as were the crispy potatoes many of which were fried to death. The turnips were so very average. There weren't many enticing secondi choices. We settled on the hangar steak because we wanted a meat dish and didn't want to wait one hour for the chicken. Had we known the service would be so slow we might have ordered it. The hangar steak was tasty if uninventive. Not all the dishes were uninspired. The bucatini with guanciale and chile was undeniably the star dish of the evening. We should have foregone all the other dishes and just ordered 6 of those instead.

after having changed hands Tosca Cafe cannot be held to their old standards. sure the dishes are more expensive but their quality has increased as well. April Bloomfield's people have done a great job keeping the menu simple and executing them well. i've read plenty of reviews that complain about the salt content but during my dining experience there the only thing that was overly salted was the fat fried potatoes. everything else from the succulent, juicy, full of flavor meatballs to the perfectly al dente bucatini and vegetables were well seasoned. i thoroughly enjoyed dinner at Tosca. the server was great and well informed about their wines and the hostess made sure to coordinate with the server when i handed them my credit card earlier in the evening so that i could force payment before my boyfriend's parents got to the bill. fantastic! no wonder Bon Appetit named it one of US's top 10 restaurants of 2014!
On the rare occasion when the culinary stars aline, walk-ins to the hottest restaurants in town are possible.
It was good not great.

I've been going to Tosca for over 2 decades.  I've had a birthday party here, I even had a photo shoot here.  So, I, like a million or so others, eagerly awaited the reopening; & very much appreciated the interior upgrade that did not sacrifice Tosca's integrity.  It's been almost a year since the addition of dinner service, so time to review...
This is a three-star place.  I really wanted it be better, but it's not.

I really wanted to like this place. After watching season 2 of Mind of a Chef on Netflix, we were so excited to try Tosca since it was featured on the show. I knew immediately we would order the meatballs made with guanciale, and the fried pig tails. We also had the turnips, the fried potatoes, the minestrone, the oxtail terrine, and the bucatini pasta. In the end, I could summarize my entire meal here in three words... TOO MUCH SALT. There was a consensus at our table and maybe even the one next to us. The flavors were there, and it breaks my heart because there was so much potential. Unfortunately, the salt rendered the food nearly inedible. Our table went through at least 5 or 6 pitchers of water to wash everything down. We most likely would not return. I gave 2 stars because the ambiance was decent, and the food was prepared well were it not for the salt. I also enjoyed the Tiramisu, if only because it was the one item that gave us reprieve from the salinity of the other dishes.

Atrocious service.  We showed up at 7:30 and were told we would be texted as soon as a table opened up.  We went to a bar down the street and received a text a half hour later.  After immediately responding and heading back to Tosca, we were told that there had "been a mixup" and that a table would not be ready for another hour.  We then waited an hour and a half during which time one member of our party was spilled on with a burning beverage by a drunk person at the bar. . . that the staff recognized and promptly ignored.  When we were finally seated, no recognition whatsoever was given to the fact that we waited as long as we did for a table.  To put a cherry on top of the lovely evening: the majority of our party ordered the steak, and rather than being asked how we would like it served, it was automatically served vastly undercooked. We couldn't believe the service would be so bad. As recent ex-New Yorkers, we can say that a patron at the Spotted Pig would never be treated so poorly.
How is it that they only have 3 stars?!
This place is really cool. Thursday closes at 4am, Friday, Saturday closes at 5am! Every other day close is 2am. Food served until 30 minutes to close. BRING A FRIEND!

I have an internship nearby so I thought I'd stop in for lunch. The food looked good and for the $5 cover it's a decent deal. That said I just ate salad and had some fruit. I got a lap dance from the friendly Malia, who along with having a nice personality was quite adept on the pole doing a number of advanced maneuvers. The dance was great and I had a good time during my "power business lunch."
Quite possibly the best club in SF!

I love this place ... Been coming here for years and always have a great time! Staff is friendly and girls are beautiful and fun. A little pricey on the drinks but that is expected for a place like this In this location... I'll definitely be back
I came here once and there was a monkey in the corner taking pictures with people....

I recently visited the HUSTLER Club in SF with some friends. We were greeted at the door by a great doorman, "Eric"  that offered "bottle service", for our group.  Though the pricing was a bit high, we went with it. Surprising enough, we got great seating and the service was great. The entertainers were beautiful and easy to talk to. Bought a couple of dances for some friends. I enjoyed the music and the stage show. Ended up being there all night and ended up getting another bottle. They even had food.. It was pretty good. Anyways.. The bouncers were very nice and overall we had the best of times. I enjoyed the night and will be back. Check em out and buy a bottle. Its all worth it. Cheers guys and thanks.
There have been some crazy reviews left over the past few... well, I've been dropping by here for a while now.  I drink, I hang out, I have fun, and it's all roses and singles raining whatever.

I went today at lunch time with a group of colleagues for our monthly lunch. We have been doing this for over 5 years, and we have been enjoying it very much. However,  It was very different today. The man at the door started repeating over and over again the same two very obnoxious questions in a very pushy manners: 1. "don't you want some singles back (from my  $20 bill) ?" . 2. "are you o.k. ?" I told him that he is getting too personal. As a result, he refused to let me in. The 10 of us decided not to come over your place again.
Pretty happening here on a Friday night. The girls are friendly. Some can really move on the pole! It is fun for both males and females to check it out. Love the music!

I came here on a Saturday for a bachelorette party. The cover was $15.00 (I was told the free admission Yelp offer ended at 11PM). This was my first "gentleman's club" experience. The music was great. All of the dancers were beautiful and very friendly, not in a trying to get your money way, they were just personable.

The stripper told me it was a 2 for 40 dance and lied to me and after said that I had to pay $60! It was my girl friend and I's birthday and they just fucked me over with money I didn't want to pay for the poor ugly women dancing on me! Awful service!!!!! My waitress messed up on everything I ordered and took for ever!!!!! Rip offs for sure!!! If u want hot strippers don't mess around just go to Vegas!!!!
i'd recommend this place over any other place off broadway to anyone that is looking for some adult entertainment.

Just got back to Oakland after my birthday trip to the Strip Club.  What a disappointment!  The one star was they let me in for free as it was my birthday.  I then sat there with my boyfriend for an hour and was not approached once!  After the first 30 minutes a blue haired and blonde haired employee  sat next to us and  started gabbing away.  I had to interrupt them to ask where the bathroom was. I was hoping that when I got back they would at least try to strike up a conversation with us.  but, no.  After another 30 minutes, I asked my boyfriend if we could leave.  This was supposed to be a fun night out for me with some lap dances and instead I got to feel like I wasn't good enough for the employees to talk to you.  Thanks for a crappy birthday :(

To me the best strip club in SF. There is a yelp offer for free admission, which they did accept before 11pm. I've seen mostly hot girls that were not too pushy and I even had good conversations with them. 60$ for a lap dance is brutal, but its San Francisco.
Worst gentlemen's club I have ever been in. Just price gouging and nothing better than a truck stop strip club. Strippers are junk along with the establishment. I would rather see a homeless stripper

Horrible experience went in during 'happy hour' gave bartenderette a $20 for $2 happy hour beer she gave me $14 in change back when I said what the hell she said , "you're a party pooper" (in essence soliciting me for a $4 tip.)   I had bought 3 happy hour beers and was asked to leave yet again an hour later for "not drinking enough" All right I wear heavy cologne but goddamn it's suppose to be a free country needless to write I shall not return I found another, better, Gentlemen's club that treats me with respect! Don't waste your time or money on this hell hole!
Not gonna lie, I was somewhat dragged here since I'm not much of a strip club kind of guy; having said that, I surprisingly enjoyed myself!

Great stuff.  The light show, as well as video show, was a great compliment to what can only be described as amazing women WHO CAN DANCE.  What I loved most is that each performer could really dance and put on a great show on stage.  Each doing they're own type of show.  Fun stuff.
There are great points and horrible points to this place. I will start with the great.

I have been here a few time now and Hustler is by far the best gentleman's club in San Francisco!! The service is great, the girls are all beautiful & the food is really good (not what you would expect from a gentleman's club) my favorite day to come in is Taco Tuesdays!!! $2 tacos & 2 for one drink specials!!!! Weekends are crackin Thursdays they are open til 4am & Friday and Saturday til 5am!!!! Perfect for when you're out and you're not ready to go home!! And if you do come for after hours make sure to try their breakfast menu, my fave is the breakfast croissant or steak n' eggs!!! All in all I'm gonna give this place 5 stars, love coming here and watchin the girls werrrrrk!!!!!

Love this place. Full Bar w/ TVs (I hate missing games). Attentive Staff. Late Late Night Munchies. Awesome DJ. and of course Totally Hot Girls/Pole tricks I never thought possible! I love that there's no pressure. You can chill at the bar or hang with your friends and the girls at a table. Everyone is just there to have a good time. The neighborhood regulars, the girls, the cocktail waitresses, even the guys in suits and managers have laughed it up with us.  It's clean and comfortable, not stuffy or trashy like other spots I've been to.  The drinks area little more than at a regular bar, but drinks are always more at strip clubs. I don't mind paying a little more for the scenery.  I like going during the week like after work on a Tuesday or Wednesday because they have awesome drink specials, It's also the the go to for after hours in the city. Awesome late night munchies and great scenery! You can go to Denny's or you can come here. I mean come on. No contest. Always have memorable times here. Love this place.

I have been here a few times. My first experiences were not the best. Why? The manager was being a dick to everyone and the attitude of the inside staff was a little off putting. Likely came from the top. My most recent time, I met the new manager, who is Frankie. He explained to me the club has under gone an overhaul of staff and is building a more friendly scene. I'll say! My night was beyond satisfying. between the wait staff to my private moments with my lap entertainment it was unforgettable. I've new spot for after work with my co-workers who like to party. We'll be back for Frankie and and the new crew. I don't yelp much but I do when it is deserved.

This was my first time at a Strip Club so I have nothing to compare it to. I actually had a great time. I went with two other ladies and didn't know what I was getting into. Keep in mind I've had two strong martini's. I'm not a lesbian , however I went with two of my lesbian friends and the staff was so sweet to us. We got our drinks quickly and everyone was friendly. The women were stunning. Our waitress was super sweet as well. (I wish I remembered her name)

I got seated next to a group of 5-6 dancers drinking and carrying on raucously WITHOUT customers. It's not that I don't believe dancers deserve a break and a drink, but it became increasingly annoying as the night wore on to have customers coming up to our table, hollering over our heads, negotiating prices for dances in our ears. It all felt really seedy...like I don't want to hear exactly what you'll do for him and his friend and for how much. These negotiations need to be discrete. Especially if they're going to be "exceptional."

MUCH BETTER now that there is new management.  Frankie Fusco is awesome!  He really picked the place up, and now it's being run the right way.  You can thank him for the delicious line-up of top notch girls as well.

Really enjoyed myself here. The staff is friendly, helpful, and they do a good job keeping the club clean. The dancers here are also not just very pretty, but they're genuinely nice and fun to talk to. What surprised me most however, was just how good the food was here. Definitely looking forward to coming back the next time I'm in North Beach.

We came this last Saturday night and were really impressed! It's much nicer of a club than the other strip clubs in SF. Great looking interior and pretty clean, not too dark inside, the music was great and upbeat, the food was surprisingly good, the girls were all pretty and dressed nice and the staff- bouncers and management were extremely professional, both with the patrons and in working with the girls (not a lot of bs flirting and obvious favoritism like other places, which can be off-putting as a patron). Really, they weren't concerned with how much money anyone was spending, they were concerned with setting a great tone for everyone, and they did. Impressive service there- the best I've seen in all the clubs I've visited over the years.
Great service and great Managment, need you know more... The evening only got better the later it got! Thanks Frankie
Always a good time at The Hustler Club in SF!
Best strip club in San Francisco by far!!!! Fun club, great music and beautiful girls!! We had a night we will never forget.
This place never fails. Awesome staff, good drinks, and late night breakfast.  My favorite after clubbin spot.

One of the best gentleman's clubs in the area hands down. The staff was friendly and the girls were hot! You can have cocktails at a table or go all out and have bottle service. They also serve a full dinner menu!!

What is there to really say?  Awesome service, down to earth girls who are absolutely stunning and a really classy place.  Their GM Frankie is definition of customer service and hospitality!  I highly recommend this establishment if you are in the city and want to have fun!
Not sure why my post got deleted but hustler is the best place to go for a great time ....liquor ......food and girls couldn't get better

I used to visit Hustler Club a while back, but left North Beach to check out other clubs.  I recently went back, and back, and back.  They have stepped up their game big time.  Not sure, but I think new management is in place, and you can tell with all the positive changes.  Great attitudes by the entire staff, hot dancers, and fun times.
What more could you want from a gentleman's club?!
