The experience has degraded this past year. Now there is a cloak room ($450, 30mins), in addition to a champaign vip room ($250, 30mins). While i was in the champaign room, i was continuosly hustled to buy drinks for myself and the girl, and to get a dance in the cloak room. Also lapdance is now 60$ for two dances. Dislike.
One of the classics in the City by the Bay, the Hustler Club continues to please.  You can count on good pours and beautiful hostesses.  Serious fun in SF.
Went here for a friends birthday. Got bottle service and had a blast. Full of beautiful talented ladies.

Lot's of porn stars got their start at the Hustler Club SF.  The swanky old Paladium SF is one of my favorite Gentlemen's Clubs in the city.  The staff is really friendly and not stuffy like at Mitchel Brothers.  They seem to want you to stay and have a good time.  The food is pretty good, especially their Prime Rib dinner .

I discovered this cafe about 6 weeks ago.  The aesthetic of the restaurant first piqued my interest.  It looked like a cool hipster Mission cafe out of place in the Financial District.  I next saw they served Four Barrel coffee and just-under $4 toast.  So hipster!  Setting aside my perpetual hipster/yappie (young asian professional) internal struggle, I decided to give it a try.
Great customer service! They let me use their bathroom without a problem and weren't even open yet! So sweet of them.

Excellent food! I was in town for a business training session and a friend suggested this place as she's been here before. Glad I went along. I had the sourdough avocado toast with coffee and the mango bar. Everything was excellent! Looking forward to coming back here.

I had high hopes for a place that draws a line out the door. An appealing chalkboard menu that lists all the trendy offerings one would expect at a downtown SF cafe (kale salad, gourmetified fried chicken, local and seasonal food, fresh juice, etc.) confirmed it would be worth the wait. The staff was efficient and pleasant, and the line went quickly. The food was a big let down. Last time I checked "kale salad" didn't mean 40% arugula, 60% kale. The salad was wilted and flavorless, besides the very obvious taste of arugula. To my soggy salad I added a "pimento cheese deviled egg" which was fine, but was obviously filled with a mixture of mostly mayo, a little egg yolk, and pimento. There was no such cheese element. The display of house-made treats begged me to try one palm-sized salted chocolate chip cookie (to balance out the kale, ya know). I was deeply saddened to bite into a seemingly molasses cookie, dotted with 3 chocolate chips. Had you labeled it the "heavily dressed kale and arugula salad," "the pimento-and-no-cheese deviled eggs," and "molasses-chocolate cookie," at least I would've been prepared to be let down by my $12 lunch.

It is lunch for take out and eat in where you buy at the counter. The nice décor is lovely and the food in fresh, local, and traditional that is inspired by the abundance of good ingredient choices. The Pastrami BLT is tummy, and I get the deviled ages every time I come in. The bread was fresh and light and a medium portion with lots of goodness in it. I go here as a treat. It beats all the take out that I go to in the union square/ financial district for me!
Had lunch here. Small place but mainly for take out. Had crispy eggplant wrap. Was really good. It seems like the menu changes everyday so will definitely go again to try vegetarian options.
Foundation is one of my go-to downtown lunch joints. No one doing the downtown workweek lunch scene should be skipping it.

Surprised by the crappy reviews .  I had the healthiest lunch I've had in a long time there last week.  It was the rice bowl.  Nice portion of rice topped with TONS of fresh veggies, raita sauce and chicken.  I thought that it was actually a good deal considering the quality of the ingredients and location.

While the food is quite good (I enjoy the Crispy Eggplant wrap, the deviled eggs, and the mini chocolate chip cookies), I have been incredibly disappointed by the service on multiple occasions. The staff behind the counter appears to be inexperienced and generally inattentive--for a cafe that is catering to the work day lunch crowd, this is particularly off-putting!

In the corporate lunch jungle that is Kearny, Foundation is usually on solid footing for a healthy, simple lunch option. Salads are the way to go here. Generous on the green but could give a little more of the filling. Servers, while friendly, have occasionally mixed up orders so make sure you get what you ordered.

I pass by the place all the time but I don't know why I never tried it out. Decided to give it a shot today so placed my order for Cajun chic sandwich added bacon. Also added a white bean w/ chard soup. Spent $16. After placing order I browsed yelp pix of this place. Immediately freaked the eff out when I saw that pic of the chic sandwich that was raw inside... Fuck, that's what I ordered.   Man, that was disgusting. Anyway, when I got my food, I tried the soup first.... Ehhhh nothing special.

I can only speak for the sides. I have yet to have a sandwich. However, the deviled eggs are SO good. Also I have had the brussels, which are also very good. I think I like the fact that there are veggie options other than salad... I get so bored of salad.

Best breakfast sandwich in the Financial District. Skillet-cooked omelette, aïoli, arugula on a fresh brioche roll. Bacon and avocado optional. Four Barrel coffee. Lunch is ok here but the breakfast really is a win in a desert of microwaved egg sandwiches in many other area cafes.

I gotta agree with the second Adrienne G.'s review way down below about the excessive oil thing. I ordered a crispy veggie wrap and should have been warned off by the oil film that had soaked the take away box but I was starving and wolfed it down. It didn't taste bad at all, but 4 hours later I feel sick and nauseous. The first time around I tried their chilaquiles, which tasted great, but I got the greasy feel there too... Like my arteries were soaking in oil.
The food is good, but expensive.

Check on my computer that the cafe closes at 3pm so at 2:40 I leave my office to get coffee (I come here everyday.) It is pouring rain. I arrive at 2:44 to this cafe and the doors are locked, but people are still seated inside. I get waved off by the employees behind the counter. I check my phone (still out in the rain) and see it says 2:44 and so I hold up a "3" to show them I know this is unacceptable. They don't close for 16 more minutes... not 6... 16. The waitress holds up her hands and waves me off again.
Their chilaquiles and eggs is the perfect way to start your day. Also having four barrel coffee without having to trek out to the mission is also awesome.

The mushroom barley burger is truly yummy and prepared with utmost care. Things don't feel thrown together here as they sometimes can at Box Lunch and Boulange. A squeeze of lemon would put it over the top.

Get here early because this place gets super packed. Got the fried chicken sammy w/ a little bit of bacon and sauce. It was really good and not oily. I will be back. Yay to another lunch spot near my work.
Kale and brown rice salad my foot.
Arrogant entitled staff.

I am taking this place out of my regular lunch rotation. I don't know how you leave a fried chicken sandwich 90% raw in the middle. I am now on salmonella watch. The guy at Foundation was at least nice enough about it--he offered to make me something else. I posted a photo of how raw it was to the page, but we'll see how long the 'information ministry' leaves that up.
One of the best Breakfast Sandwiches in downtown.  Essentially a fresh omelet on toasted sourdough roll.  In fact, I kinda wish they served them for lunch...
Definitely not the cheapest place to eat lunch in the area - - but I really enjoyed my manifested take-out order from here today.

I've been here several times. It's super cute and inviting. A great environment.  Their menu has some fun salads and sandwiches.  Their Tomatillo soup is awesome. Here's the problem - they haven't figure out their logistics.  I went twice this week - once during a super crazy busy time of day and their operations pretty much ground to a total halt and a second time early around 11:10a when they were slow.  On the crazy busy day they weren't able to handle it.  From what I could tell it wasn't the food prep kitchen staff; it was the listless, anemic staff that takes the food from the orders ready window to the customers. They're as slow as molasses, move at a snails pace and seem half comatose as they move from the food pick up place to getting the food to waiting customers (to go and eat in). When I got to my desk I found that the Kale salad that was advertised as having white beans had no white beans.  I came in later in the week, during a slow time with almost no customers and the service was equally slow, anemic and lifeless.

Stopped in here on my way to a conference. Delicious bacon and egg sandwich, and great coffee! The atmosphere is cozy and personable...and the staff is nice! Far cry from some others around the area. Definitely recommend this place!
I've only had one bite of my beefcheek sandwich and I'm hooked. Now I am obligated to try everything on the menu.
One of my favorite places for lunch in the downtown SF area. I would call this clean & flavorful food with great ingredients.
great new addition to the area.. awesome espresso and cakes as well as a surprising amazing lunch menu with awesome salads and sandwiches. . highly recommend.
Is it expensive?  Yeah, kinda.  You're in the FiDi, remember?

A co-worker and I went for lunch today and both ordered the fried chicken sandwich.  It was a very thin piece of chicken  - although the combination of the toppings (cheese, bacon, aoili and lettuce) sound delish - it was really lacking flavor.  Very moist - but needs rosemary or lemon or thyme to give it something.  Very bland and for $10+ it was small and no sides make this an expensive option relative to other spots on the same street.  Meh - too many other spots for me to return.  You're not missing out on anything if you dont' make it here.
Really not crazy about this place not sure what the hype is about.  Came here a couple times and will not be returning.  Furthermore, I wouldnt define its location as Chinatown, its FiDi.
This place sucks. I've eaten here ~5 times for lunch. Their food is POORLY COOKED, lacking flavor and pricey.

WAY overpriced. $14 for a "salad" that consisted of a few leaves of romaine lettuce and some bacon. Was hungry afterwards and had to get Fritos from the snack machine at the office = fail. Makes Mixt Greens seem like a great value. Best of luck to them, but I won't be back.
The food is good but expensive. The interior of this place is very nice -- it's a bit of a hipster oasis in the middle of the FiDi.

A solid breakfast/ lunch option. The rockfish sandwich is really good, the side dishes are seasonal and tasty, and the lattes are usually good (depends on which employee makes it). The salads are a little small and the prices are a bit steep.
Hipsterish joint with some decent food, but for the price I rather go somewhere else in the area.

They have a killer chopped salad, but its a tiny and expensive little spot. The wait is usually pretty long, the seating is tight, and they don't take Amex. But their food is good. It's just expensive. Did I mention that? Like $16 salad expensive.
I often get food here on my lunch break.

Lovely little city cafe in the Financial District / Chinatown area. Service was pleasantly uplifting, and the americano was earthy and brewed to almost-perfection. Breakfast here is great but overall a little bit pricey. Nevertheless, would love to come back in the future.

I thought our meals were average and not worth the hype on Yelp, but they weren't bad. If you're looking for no frills, big portion Chinese then you may like it, but I'm sure this isn't the best SF Chinatown has to offer.
We ordered hot n sour soup and chow mien and lemon chicken. The hot and sour was fresh with lily buds in it. The lemon chicken tasted good but still fried.
I've thought very seriously about keeping this place all to myself. But alas, that is selfish, and I shall share.

Always ordering takeout from here when I am around. I really like the lunch specials they have here. It's pretty affordable $7-$9 depending what you get. The light eater I am is able to have 2 meals with the lunch special. They give a pretty large portion. Taste is a little above average. I don't know why I like coming here though... Maybe because I'm too lazy to go anywhere else in Chinatown... One thing I hate is their soup containers. They poked a hole for it to breathe but since it's knocking all over the place, it spills... =[
Came by for lunch with some coworkers, and had a great meal.  The portions were large, prices were great, and most importantly, the food was good.

Very good food. Dim Sum missing from the menu. Price moderate. Service?!?! Very very very slow taking orders, not attentive, order was fast dispatched. Mixed feelings about this restaurant, I guess kitchen is great, main floor needs better management and customer service training.

A must try for spicy-lovers! We were a bit hesitant to check out this place since the price is slightly higher when we walked by seeing the menu outside, but I am glad we did. Instead of ordering water boiled beef, one of my favorite all time, I tried Mao xue wang. Waoh! It came to us by such a Huge portion that absolutely could stuff two starving stomachs. You could see beautiful Sichuan pepper cores joyfully swimming on the surface of red chilly oil, in which you got different pig intestines and veggies. Watch out it's so spicy that even I specifically told them to make it mild, it still pumped out sweat on my whole body. (Best way to cure a cold) Yum!!

I was looking for a spot to have a light dinner after shopping. The pot stickers and hot and sour soup were more than filling. Potstickers were perfectly crispy on one side and soup was great. Clean and respectful service. I'll be back!

This place is really good for lunch and dinner! Food r just awsome and defintely gonna come bk and try out their bbq cat fish and seafood. I had the couples delight ,lamb skewers, bbq oysters and the guiling rice noodle it's just the best i had before!!

This is a new restaurant. We had lunch. The food is very good. I had kung pao chicken and pot stickers, both excellent. Relaxed, quiet atmosphere. The staff could have been more friendly, but they were quick. I'd definitely eat there again.
Good food. Attractive Manu. Nice to sit around and chat with friends.  Hunan style is my style.

This location has a lot of history.  In the '60's and '70's, it was the Universal Cafe.  In the '80's until about four or five years ago, it was King Tin, a popular lunch spot for Cantonese cuisine and as Ken K. (
Brand new Szechuan style restaurant located at the heart of Chinatown. Great selections. Nice atmosphere. Very authentic.
Very consistent and solid lunch option in FiDI

Location location location. Pasilla is one of those restaurants where if they were located almost anywhere else, nobody would eat there. In the FiDi, now that El Faro has closed , there's almost no other Mexican fare. After my meal today though I'm definitely walking a couple blocks further to Chipotle for my Americanized sterilized tacos.
Personally I'm not a big fan of Mexican food but these guys make it really good. I've had nothing but good experiences with this place.
Consistently horrible service with only mediocre food.
Burritos are always decent and very filling. I usually go with the pork or chicken and been satisfied every time.
Don't let the location fool you. Although it's in Chinatown, the food is decent Mexican food. Good portion sized meals and tasty. I would give it five stars but it's a little on the pricey side.
the free Jicama salsa is what keeps making me go back- in addition to the yummy food!

Food ok, guac ok, everything is just ok, to me it tasted sorta like chipotle but with slight more flavor, but different flavor. It was definitely edible and fresh tasting, just not too good. I was not a fan of the rice, but the gripped chicken was good, I am slightly disappointed overall.

Nice spot on Kearny for a quick lunch or dinner for work. The portions are pretty large. Got a single taco and it was huge, can't imagine having three of them, as they normally come. My main gripe about the place is that things were really salty. I got the regular grilled chicken taco and it was too salty for my taste. But, do NOT skip out on the guacamole and chips here. Definitely worth it. Fresh and delicious. Sure, your breath will suffer, but your stomach will be willing to apologize to your coworkers on its behalf.

Honestly, the best $8.50 I've spent for a nice salad in the area in 5 years.  Delicious. Fresh.  The servers were great.  I definitely recommend eating here verses spending the money for less food at Chipotle.
Better than Chipotle but, not by much.
It's really a 3.5, but their salsas def bump it up to a 4.
Spicy chicken tacos, mmmmmmm.

I was impressed with the Burrito Bowl I got here. I tried the Spicy Chicken and was pleasantly surprised the used chicken breast. It was tasty, flavorful and very filing. I really like the jicama slaw on the salsa bar.
Got a steak burrito.

After working two blocks away for the past 6 months I never took a second look at this place. I am from Texas but Mexican food is not my favorite, but my new MOGL app made me try this place. I was not disappointed. I ordered the spicy chicken bowl with peppers and onions added and the flavor was delicious! I gave four stars because there was not as much rice as I would have liked. The bowl was really perfect because I am cutting carbs anyway. I will go back again and again!
the times I've eaten here, I end up with the worst digestive discomfort which includes the worst  heartburn... I'll be avoiding this place.
tiny but good price & a delicious burrito. definitely going to be going back.
3.5 stars
Hey this is the place on the corner on Kearny and Pine where you can go if you are tired of waiting 1 hour in line to get into that Ramen place 2 doors down.

I like the food here, but they have lost my order before and did not offer anything for the 25 minutes I had to wait.  Not even an apology.  Luckily I was with a group of people who all got pissed off as well and none of us will be going back.  You need to at least say sorry and offer a bag of chips.
RUDE!  I recommend going to Tlaloc
I had a sub-par burrito here for $10. Never again. Just go to El Faro across the street and save some money.

I Agree with Mark D. This place is tiny! it literally has 8 chairs! I counted. Definitely better for takeout than dine in. Luckily, I went at an extremely odd hour - 3.30pm. Most other food joints were closed or cleaning up for the evening so I stumbled on this joint by accident and laziness (didn't want to walk too far).
The marinated steak tacos are beyond excellent! .....perfectly seasoned...everything I had was fresh, and my 3 taco order was plenty to eat....I will be back!

I'll give credit where credit is due...the marinated chicken is muy bueno.  However, what do I look like having to pay $1.75 for guacamole on what's otherwise a super burrito? Why is guacamole only served on the vegetarian burrito? Can we say RIP-OFF CHIPOTLE?! Not to mention the teenie tinie "Salsa Bar"...smh I'll make sure to hit up the Food Court should I desire a burrito while at work!!!

I always love getting away from the chain restaurants and finding better alternatives, and I think that Pasilla is one of the best substitutes to Chipotle. Their spicy grilled chicken bowl is filled with my favorites, and the proportion of each fits my liking perfectly. The bottom is layered with Spanish rice, but it's definitely not a large amount. The health freak in me loves that this bowl is more high protein and low carb. On top of that is a layer of beans, either black or pinto that are not too wet so that the rice gets soaked. Finally, they generously pile on the lettuce, pico de gallo, and chicken. The grilled chicken is extremely flavorful and you really get the grill taste in every bite. They also have a great selection of different salsas to add that extra kick, however spicy you want it to be. Pasilla has definitely become my go-to place for burrito bowls, and I definitely suggest splurging on a little guac to complete the entire thing!
This is the best burrito in the Fidi area for lunch. I like the spicy chicken burrito. Food is fresh and served fast. Better than El Faro across the street and Chipotle.
Quick stop for lunch if you order a burrito, not so much if you order a quesadilla. Not much room to sit, mostly a grab and go place.

This place has one lame burrito. Pork was chewy and dry. Burrito itself was dripping wet with hopefully tomatoes or salsa, but halfway through it's almost inedible. The guy asked me if I wanted "spicy", so I said yes but it wasn't spicy at all. Sad state of burrito affairs in downtown SF.
I've said it once, I'll say it again. They make a well-distributed burrito. Don't have to worry about getting a bite of only rice or only beans--well mixed!

My officemate and I get lunch at Pasilla probably once a week, possibly slightly less often. I dig this place, it's like Chipotle with actual food. The chipotle adobo dressing on the salad is aces, and the salsas can't be beat. Everything I've tried at Pasilla has been delicious -- I am primarily vegetarian, so I can speak only to their animal-free offerings, but I am given to understand the chicken quesadilla is also excellent. Prices are average for the FiDi, service is fast and friendly.

Steak burrito was delicious with just the right amount of spicy salsa on it. It also had good amount of cheese, which I happen to love. The beans were flavorful and the tortilla had a nice texture. They have a fresh jicama salsa that cooled down the heat when needed at the lovely salsa bar.  Salsa bar had roasted pasilla peppers. I did not try them this time but other people did, so I am guessing they are good. You do have to purchase the chips separately, though. Much better and a bit less expensive than Chipotle.
Not totally authentic if you compare this with a taqueria, but it sure beats the Chipotle places that are dotted around the Bay Area.
the steak salad with guacamole is terrific.
I came for the first time and was impressed. Didn't know what to expect, but the flavors was flavorful and delishes. Also the price was fair!

i was walking around w bb after work looking for some food in an area that is noticeably lacking in good food imo.  we came upon this and thought why not.  its basically a local version of chipotle and prices are a little cheaper.  chicken bowl was decent.  plenty of chicken that was pretty tender.  could have been a little juicier.  veggies were fresh and ingredients were heaped on in the right proportions.
My NEW goto place for a burrito @ lunch.  Hard to beat.

The salad was huge but the price seemed a bit much.  I would actually prefer if they had a smaller/cheaper option.  Overall though the chicken in it was delicious and the salsa I got from the salsa bar and used as dressing complimented it well.  I would maybe return here if I happened to be in the area.  It really is another Chipotle without the chain and same price.
Another word to describe Pasilla has got to be PLAIN... Boring might be a close second.

I had the beef noodle soup and it was sub-par.   Traditional beef noodle soup base is made from bones cooked for a long time and it has that cloudy look in the soup.  I think they mainly use soup powder for their soup because their soup is relatively clear.  I recommend Gold Star just a block up instead.
T'was the day after the Giants won their third World Series in the past five years and I might have been, allegedly, really feeling it that morning.
Their Pho Ga soup is fantastic.  The noodles were so good, and the broth was fantastic.  Not too salty and with a depth of flavor that was surprising.  Plenty of veggies too.

Today 10/15/14 I went to the Worst pho in the world!!!!!! Don't go this place is horrible, the service, the food. The worst part is the people in the kitcken fighting with the poor waitress. Never ever ever again!!!!
Came here for the chicken noodle soup. Chicken was very flavorful surprisingly.  Their noodle is actually just ok. However, their service is way above average for an asian restaurant.
Service was ok. Spicy beef noodle soup was solid, but not great.
Omg, worst pho ever.  It was salty, so salty.  It was like eating a salt lick.
Tried out Joy Hing BBQ Noodle.  Matt G. said it's one of the cleanest restaurant in Chinatown, I'd say so.  It's also more expensive to eat there too.
Hole on the wall of many in China town. Has all the  glamour you need for an authentic taste and they serve you right away even when busy. Fairly inexpensive. Quick Chinese food fix while at work.
3.5 STARS for food. 4 STARS for service.
We use to visit the old location once in a while and have not been back since they moved.  They new space is nice.  It is clean and larger and new.

I am a huge fan of Turtle Tower, and it bums me out that they close at 5pm (TL location) so I can never get my pho ga fix on weekdays.  Then I heard about Joy Hing.  I  have been meaning to try this place for weeks but didn't get around to it until this past Friday.  Friday lunch, changed. my. life.

This would have been a 4 star rating but they jacked me on the chicken. I ordered a large pho ga after asking my server if the large size would be more chicken than the regular size and she said yes of course so I ordered the large. When it came, it barely had any chicken in it. It was even less chicken than the regular size. I'm giving it 3 stars because the chicken and broth was good. I'll definitely give it another try and if I get screwed the second time, I will update this review and give it a 2 star for lying to me about the chicken!

The bathrooms were in excellent condition and they decorated this place nicely.  Service was decent and so was the pho.  Can't say it was 4 stars as the beef pho was good but this place is hard to get to compared to the many pho places where I live in Pleasanton that I can drive up to the door and park easily.  Came here based on high Yelp reviews so I kinda expected something more interesting that what their menu offered.  Still a good pho place and it is a nice, clean place to enjoy soup.

What other place do you get a personal one cup brew of refreshing Vietnamese coffee right in front of your twinkling eyes? Here, buddy. Oh and lets talk about their food, absolutely clean tasting and left me full a little less than halfway done. Joy Hing gave me much joy indeed. :D next time, pho!
tip: the green onion ginger mixture is too oily and way too salty.

SF yelpers really let my family and I down with your glowing recommendations of this place!  Perhaps I should have ordered the pho because the chicken, rice, Mongolia beef and the Jasmin tea was dismal at best.  The people were nice, but couldn't understand or speak much English.  Very disappointing and waste of money..I was skeptical of Chinatown restaurants already and this experience further confirms it.
What a cute little Pho restaurant.  Gets my vote for best one in China Town!  Plus the staff is very friendly!

I've never really had pho ga prior of coming but after I came here, I was amazed. There aren't that many reviews for this place because the friend who recommended it told me that they've recently moved.  Let me note that I'm writing this review after having tried pho ga again at three other places (one including the famous Turtle Tower - not impressed, btw) so I'd stop by here if you're craving some Chinese-style Pho Ga that comes with the delicious ginger and scallions concoction!

do not be alarmed. that eye bulging, mind searing headache you have is just an MSG induced reaction from the pho ga. if anyone in your office is wondering why you are  walking like a dehydrated zombie, just tell them you're audtioning for "the walking dead". which is exactly how i feel right now.
My vietnamese boyfriend and I had springrolls and a beef pho here and it was a perfect lunch!
Got the pho ga that everyone raved about. The chicken and broth are both very bland. $7.50 for a large bowl. Extra star for an above average decor in comparison to other Chinatown restaurants.
Passed by on a walk to the mall and Joy Hing caught my eye. I looked it up on Yelp and since it had so many favorable reviews I decided to stop for a bowl of pho on my way back home.

This place must be new because it is clean & bright, unlike most other Chinatown joints.  The staff is pretty friendly & the menu is extensive.  But on a recent lunch outing in chilly SF we all knew what we wanted...pho ga!
I LOVE PHO GA!

Pho Ga large bowls are HUGE. The hanai chicken is DELICIOUS and their portions here are huge. No wait during a busy lunch hour. If you're looking for a nice, cleaning-looking restaurant, then don't come here. But if you just want good Chinese food and don't care for the decor, then come here.
Love the chicken pho here. Also this is the only place I know where they give you the green onion, ginger, and oil sauce to go with your chicken!

This hole in the wall family run place is the ones we like to seek out, the food was just good wholesome Cantonese and a touch of Vietnamese dishes.  Our server was very sweet and attentive!  We were a party of 5 and we ordered 6 dishes and the total bill came to $ 75 which was very reasonable for such a wholesome and tasty meal!
Pho bowls are large, but when you put the chop sticks inside the broth you realize you have just that; a bowl of broth.
Serves very good chicken pho.
Ma's Dimsum deserves a 4 for value and good eats (in the opinion of the eater obviously). many issues defer this designation.

I came here for the authentic Toishan clay pot rice.  I ordered the salted fish and diced chicken clay pot. This is the real deal. The best part is the rice at the bottom of the clay pot. It had just the right amount of crispness and best of all it wasn't burnt. My dish came with a bowl of bok choy and carrot soup.  Very refreshing and complimented my clay pot rice nicely. I'll be back again to try the other clay pots dishes.
Warning!  This is a rant!
I got very intimidated at first because it crowds real easily when busy.  But after a couple of orders from this place, I got hooked real quick!

A small venue packed with hungry Chinese people. I ordered their delicious pork buns and chicken buns to go for months before I had the nerve to sit down and try a meal. I ordered a sizzling clay pot of chicken and mushrooms. It took 30 mins to arrive, but it was fantastic. The chicken was moist and tasty, and the sizzling rice was all brown and crunchy on the bottom. Omgeezers. It cost 7 bucks. The place isn't the cleanest, but boy is it good. Gonna try the huge-ass bowl of soup next.

The pork dumplings are very good.  The chicken bun is absolutely gigantic and has a lot more and greater variety of ingredients than you find at most other restaurants in Chinatown.  The food has lot of flavor too.  The pork buns, however, could use more filling and less outer breading.  Whatever the aesthetic drawbacks of this place are, I don't give a f*** because the value for the quality of the food you get tops everything else.  I go to restaurants to get good food, not stare at the ceiling.
Had the cheapest meal of dim sum ever and it was really good! $9 total for two of us and we were stuffed. We were the only tourists in the restaurant as the patrons were local old school Cantonese.
I have very mixed feelings about this place.  It's not very clean, a real hole in the wall.
Bad service along with bad food. Place is dirty.
Dumpy Chinese place with cheap and delicious food.  Their spareribs clay pot is pretty good.  Cost like $5 for that and tea.
Best JIN DEUI* in the City.
Cheap delicious Chinese food.
Took us a while to return for dinner, turns out we ordered just about the same items!

Pretty straight forward in what you get. Cheap, no frills, CASH ONLY! Came here for the sparerib clay pot special--waited 20 minutes for it--and it was good, worth a try. Not mindblowing but if you're conveniently walking by, might as well give it a try.

Total hole in the wall score!  I didnt try their Dim Sum but instead ordered from their vast clay pot selection.  I got chinese bacon and spare ribs in the rice clay pot.  The spare ribs fell off the bone and did not have the fatty fat that a lot of spare ribs tend to have.  The chinese bacon was pretty good too!  The clay pot rice could have been a bit softer but it still caught the flavors of the meat.  I literally felt like i was eating in a Chinese guys garage.  IT was pretty small.  And i think everyone eating there was family.  Cash only, i believe it was around 6 bucks for the clay pot.  Super friendly people.  Just grimy enough to make you feel like you are in Chinatown.

This restaurant is the filthiest  restaurant I've ever been to. If you're going to eat here take it to-go the silverware is nasty, and the containers they keep their sauces in is also, nasty. I've eaten the food before and their clay pot was not bad, but still the entire restaurant seems very dirty. I just wanted to write a review for this place. I've heard they had been shut down due to Vermin infestations...
CASH ONLY.  Went to try Ma's Dim Sum & Cafe on Sat 9/10/11.  Read about this place from Jonathan Kauffman which made it sound pretty good, sorry it wasn't.

If you want decent and very inexpensive food and don't mind the decorations of a restaurant, you should definitely give this place a try. Many people come up here to order dim sum to go, but during lunch time, you also see most of their tabled are filled with people ordering this clay pot looking thing, what is that? Clay pot rice!! You will have to wait 15 min for your order, and when i was here, their specialty is frog leg rice clay pot! Yumm! Pour some of their special soy sauce, close the lit for another 3 minutes, and bam! You got yourself a yummy meal! Nothing is over 7 bucks(I think) and make sure you have cash!
My experience here was better (less stressful) than buying dim sum at Good Mong Kok (
I love this place.  Their red bean cake is the BEST!!  And all other dim sum that I tried taste good so far...

I grew up threee buildings down. Literally I grew up. It's on powell, and I do recall this place being opened for years. I use to buy their porridge on a day where I was super hungry and didnt want to walk although theres a few food places around my house. Their place is actually pretty small & Tidy good for you& a friend :) i think there is dim sum.. like those white powdery dim sum.. those sweet cake things. but then I like it here when you're on the go and in a quick need to chow down on some chinese food! :)

Ordered the Kung pow chicken over rice and ma's house pan fried noodles. I counted 28 seats, more room to bring the family! Too bad the food was pretty bland, goopy and miserable. The meat seemed undercooked and odd... this was kinda bad by even my standards coming from Seattle, and leagues away from NY or even MA.

So I actually returned here to try food from the real menu... I ordered eggplant and pork for takeout. Sometime during the 5 block walk to my friend's apt, the plastic container my food was in disintegrated, so I had to dump my food onto a plate and be careful not to eat the shards of plastic that were now embedded in it. But uh.. it wasn't bad! And it's cheap! Only $4-5 for most of their dishes.
3 entree's and I box of steamed rice. price= $17.49... YOU CANNOT BEAT THAT PRICE and their stir fry dishes are actually very good. Good firey wok flavor.

Since moving to the China Nob neighborhood my girlfriend and I have been trying different Dim Sum places on Sundays. While this place wasn't my favorite so far, it was perfectly fine. Not sure what people are talking about the bad service. This place is not Yank Sing. It is totally what I would expect for a hole in the wall Chinese place on a Sunday afternoon.
i love love love their clay pot dishes and the dry garlic pork chop (?).

Amazing. I call and ask about delivery, and the guy says something in Chinese then hangs up on me. Three times. Seems wendella a.'s review is spot on - if you don't speak chinese, they don't want to serve you.
Absolutely will inhale most food here!
Best dim sum in Chinatown!  I love this place!

I walked out - no - stormed out of here earlier today after experiencing the state of invisibility. I waited, waited, waited oh so patiently while the woman in front of me was served and two older men came in, sat down, were greeted and apparently registered as non-invisible.
I remember when I used to come here all the time during the summer.
It's price value can't be beat 3 huge dim sum for 1.2

I reallly love this best.  Probably the best dim sum in chinatown.  It's quite hidden though.  Not really where most of the people roam, as it's away from the produce shops.  That's even better actually...less crowded!
Word to the wise.

after a ride on 1 of the cable car lines, we opted to have a late lunch in this one.......had 4 orders of good dim sum here (shrimp & pork) which I enjoyed; also had a wonton & beef noodle soup which was filling by itself.  except for myself & my friend, plus a couple of caucasian guests, most of those who were in restaurant were the locals (which says a lot about the eating place as a good one).  service was OK (they'd give you the english version of their menu if requested).  it has a no-nonsense ambience that's augurs well for those who just like good food delivered in fast/efficient service style.  the restroom needs some improvement, though.

Dimsum at Ma's is but a memory of childhood. It satisfies a quick fix for dim sum cravings while leaving your wallet still completely full. I fully recommend the pan fried leek dumplings - greasy, full of flavor, and embodies everything about dim sum.
1/2 a block away from the best hole in the wall...my favorite place for take home dimsum. Prices used to be 3 pieces for a $1, but prices have gone up a little bit.

I used to come here a lot. $1 for three dim sum ! They reheat the dim sum for you which is a good thing because a lot of other places don't do that . Their turnip cake is the best I've had :) You can actually taste the peices of turnip . However, I don't like their chicken rice .. the chicken has stuff stuck to it that they should've removed .. I can't explain it but it I didn't like it . However, this place looks dirty in a way and I question if its sanitary like some other places in Chinatown . But otherwise, I would really suggest you make a visit to this place because it has the cheapest dim sum in Chinatown and it's very yummy as well :)
$1 for 3 dim sum! Cheap and tasty! I used to come here everyday! In the morning this place is loaded with people.
good for your heart, we love going back to this place
Great food and if you are seated by a window you'll get an excellent view of Chinatown!
Excellent service and great food. Can't say much more than that. A very good experience.
Came on lunch break for dim sum. Portion was very small and probably the longest wait for dim sum ever. After 20 min still no food.
Food here is not that great and they are really pricey!

If you are looking for a Chinese restaurant with good food, good service and a nicer ambience than the usual Chinese restaurant, I would recommend checking out Oriental Pearl.   Dinner is served on a real white table cloth, so you know right away you aren't at your usual chinese restaurant.  Interior wasn't necessarily chic, but it was nice and way better than the typical chinese restaurant where you better be there for the food only.  The food was excellent (tried seafood combination in potato bird's nest, along with shrimp and walnut dish).   Service was excellent (they were there when you needed them but didn't feel like they were constantly hovering around).

We do enjoy this restaurant.  It's clean.  That's sometimes hard to find in Chinatown.  The food was tasty and good.  We had the mini eggrollls, wonton soup and shared the house fried rice and the chicken chow mein.
They have a must Try pecking duck and the marinade duck chiu chow style are great also the service is great not that much of a long line but it's a bit pricey
We had lunch there twice during a business trip at San Francisco. We tried roasted duck, cod fish with bokchoy, vegetable fried rice and duck chow fun. All of them tasted REALLY delicious!!
Great service and we found the food fresh and tasty. Lot of options on the menu at reasonable prices. Clean with cute interrior. Definitely recommend. Enjoy.
I'm from Texas, so maybe I'm easily impressed by Asian cuisine, but this was the best dang Chinese food I've ever had.
I wasn't sure about the place by the entrance, but after walking upstairs (there is an elevator) was pleasantly surprised. They have a commitment to quality and it shows!
This review is for fish maw soup. The best. Also ask for chicken meat balls. This time they were out.

This restaurant was recommended to us by the Ritz Carlton and unfortunately my expectations were very high and the food was pretty good but nothing amazing.  Truthfully I would've given 3.5 stars for the food, however the service deserved one star.   This is a very authentic Chinese Restaurant and they have a huge menu.  We had reservations at 830 pm and were seated on time, however, the waiter didn't give us menus until 854pm--we were starving by this time.  We ordered a bunch of dishes to share among the 12 of us and the waiter said that he may make some orders half orders so that we can try a variety of entrees in case we were ordering too much food but that we could continue to add more to our order later on.  The portions are pretty small compared to most Chinese restaurants and everything came out at different times which was annoying but appreciated because I would rather things come out hot and fresh as opposed to sitting under a heat lamp.  My husband is a vegetarian and ordered a vegetarian noodle dish for his meal and I'm pretty sure the waiter forgot about it because all of the other food was coming out and I finally asked the waiter at 945 where the vegetarian dish was and it came out about 5 minutes later (he was watching everybody else eat for a half an hour).   We wanted to order a couple more dishes because we finished everything that was brought to our table and we were still under the impression that we had one more dish coming (we ordered 2 Mongolian beefs) and when we asked the waiter he said that we only ordered one and that the kitchen was closed. THE KITCHEN IS CLOSED?!  The waiter never mentioned that the kitchen was closing and we had no idea because we tried to order more food when they put an order of fried rice on our table that clearly, someone had just cooked.  We were told that we could not order any more food and they were sorry and would give us some dessert on the house.  They didn't offer us a choice of desserts, and instead brought out 3 martini glasses filled with lychee fruit, however, this group wasn't as fond of lychees.  They finally offered to take 20% off of our bill which was nice of them, but still didn't make up for the fact that half of our party was still hungry.  All in all it was ok, but  it wast the best experience during our short visit to San Fran.  Maybe it was an off night or something?

It was disgusting... Walnut shrimp tasted like I was eating shrimp with mayonnaise, was not sweet and it was cold. Combination fried rice was not good at all. Beef and broccoli was yuk. Beef was still red and it was way too tough! Will not recommend this  place to anyone and will not come back!!!
The Dim Sum was great!  I also enjoyed the scallops and mushrooms but David's duck casserole was not worth eating.
The food was 3 star.

Had lunch here yesterday.  The Peking Duck was wonderful.  Other lunch items were pretty typical Chinese food, but well prepared.  The decor is nice.  Not lavish, but not tacky either.  One big advantage for out-of-towners is the very close (and reasonably priced) parking at Portsmouth Square.

Great friendly service, warmly greeted as soon as we walked in.  Clean, quiet and well kept restaurant. When ordering dim sum stick to the dumplings.  All were delicious.  Don't get the Siu Mai (had better in many places which is odd because it's such a staple).
Took the kids to Chinatown so we could pick up cheap fireworks, and trusting the Yelp reviews, we tried the Oriental Pearl.  Very nice.

I loved this restaurant.  Chinatown is so fun in SF and this restaurant sits in the heart of it.  The entrance looks sketchy but once on the 2nd floor, the restaurant is really lovely with nice table clothes and napkins.  I had a simple but delicious lunch which was the sweet and sour pork.  That coupled with the soup made for a delicious lunch.

Must have been an off day when I visited this restaurant on a Monday evening. Dropped by restaurant while on a conference in San Francisco. First, the restaurant decor is nothing to write home about, though you would not expect much from a Chinatown restaurant.

Best Chinese food ever. So recommended. My husband is a very picky eater but he absolutely loved their food. We tried the beef fried rice and it was amazing. The Mongolian beef was supper delicious. If you wanna eat in Chinatown you should not miss eating here.
We had a party of 7. Out of the way GEM! The food was superb, the staff professional and the dining room elegant. If this place were near my house, I would eat there everyday!
Great Chinese food. No dim sum for dinner - for lunch only. Slow service so don't come here to eat in a hurry!

It's a good Chinese joint if you're from Kentucky and don't know what it should taste like. It gave the whole family gas. There's a reason you only see white people eating there, coming from a white man. Plus the water tastes like dirty diapers. Good service though.

It's upstairs and hard to see from the outside, but it's definitely worth it.  Service is exceptional even for non Chinatown standards.  The food was one of the best I've had in the area. Very classy and fancy inside. I definitely would come back anytime I want a place away from all the crowds and busy folks.
Unforgetable meal with a great crowd.  Attended this restaurant while in San Franciso for a conference.  The Peking duck is to die for! Super tasty and comes wrapped in a flour tortilla.

While visiting San Francisco I had the pleasure of dining here. I was walking through Chinatown and asked a local of an authentic Chinese restaurant and he recommended Oriental Pearl. Although it is a little pricey, it's worth it. My boyfriend and I spent $60 on hot & sour soup, a combination of dim sum, cashew almond chicken, sweet & sour pork and oriental pearl rice (combination with pork, chicken and shrimp). From the delicious food and great ambience, I highly recommend giving this place a try if you're in Chinatown!
recommended by a woman at the front desk of our hotel. The place was busy and a mix of americans and chinese eating there... we went for dinner. The noodles were a bit too oily for my taste.
Great place! Good service! And nice food! We picked it because everywhere else was full and very pleased.
I went here with my boss and my colleague while we were in town for a conference. While the steep hills of SanFran did have me winded, Oriental Pearl is worth the trek.
Best Chinese food!!!! Highly recommend the sweet & sour chicken, Mongolian beef, pot stickers, honey walnut shrimp!! Can't forget about the sesame balls perfection!

Oriental Pearl was recommended by the Fairmont concierge. We walked down the hill (remember - what goes down must go up) but it is very close to the hotels and a short walk, albeit steep walk, back to the hotel. I can not say it is authentic Chinese cuisine (of course this depends on everyone's palette) but we ordered a number of dishes and they were wonderful. The Kung Pao Chicken was my fav. I always order Kung Pao Chicken at Chinese restaurants. Some do it well and some do not. It is my test. Oriental Pearl hit the target! We did not order off the dim sum menu and after reading the previous comments, I wish we had. We were greeted immediately and seated at a table even without reservations. White linen tablecloths. Amazing service! Our waitperson was delightful. Our food came out quickly - nice and hot. The restaurant is super-clean. I think this is a popular place because by 8 pm the dining room was full of a mixture of families, large groups and couples. We will return because there are many things on the menu that will need to be tried on a future visit.

This place is the worst! They had no customer service, dirty and served us with cold food! This is very unacceptable and disappointing! While eating there, I saw rats running and droppings in the corner. Very disgusting! WARNING! Please think twice before eating at this place!

Great restaurant for a nice family dinner in Chinatown. Atmosphere is nothing to write about but food and service were excellent! We took our server's recommendation and tried the Mongolian shrimp and general chicken- delicious. I'm not a fan of won ton soup, but it's my kids' favorite- it was really good here- delicate handmade wontons. I even enjoyed it. We will definitely come back next time in SF!

We headed here for dinner based on decent Yelp reviews and a recommendation from our hotel's concierge. Unfortunately, our dinner was not great. While this restaurant wasn't awful, there just has to be better Chinese food in the area. This is Chinatown in San Francisco!!

Came in here on a Saturday for lunch with a small group. My daughter wanted fried rice with egg and sesame balls. I ordered off the dim sum menu. Told them that I wanted Chinese broccoli and otherwise gave them my eating restrictions and told her to pick for me. I'm glad it did. She brought me shrimp balls and vegetable dumplings. Delicious.
Amazing food and amazing service! After ordering two vegetarian appetizers, the owner came by and suggested the BEST vegetarian entrees.
Excellent service and wonderful food if you like Dim Sum arena. Out of the way location and unassuming from the outside, but quite causlly pleasant on the inside. Recommended.

Don't let Rachael Ray's photo fool you. This is not authentic Chinese food or anything close to it. It's not good, the only good thing about it is the price.. You get what you pay for. Cheap price, cheap food. The food was bland. Lean Cuisine Chinese food is way better than anything from Oriental Pearl Restaurant. If you want truly amazing Chinese food go to R&G Lounge!

Multiple visits to CZ.  The wine selection (assuming you like Coppola wines) is extensive.  Salads, pizzas, pasta have always been great.  Had the beef short ribs.  It is listed as a restaurant specialty.  Waiter warned that it was not the traditional slow cooked short rib but a made to order grilled variety that was fatty.  I tried and his description was accurate.  Would not order again.  Not sure what the attraction is or why it's considered a 'specially'.  Service is always pleasant and attentive.  Definitely will be back but trying another dish.  The Porterhouse on the neighbor's table looked good.
Was walking down Columbus looking for an excuse to stop, and saw this cute cafe with sidewalk seating. Ordered wine and a cheese plate, and enjoyed people watching. Very nice staff.
Yes, yes, yes, and yes! Perfect spot for a glass of wine and a little food. Close to Montgomery Bart station.

My wife and I both ordered their Caesar salad, as it was noted as made fresh daily with egg yolk; a personal favorite of mine! The salad was good. It had anchovies, which disappointed me as that is not tradition as people think ("There are no anchovies in Caesar Salad", Julia Child. From Julia Child's Kitchen) and I don't enjoy them.
We found the place as we were just walking past on our first night in San Fran. We decided to sit outside, after waiting for ages one of the group decided to go inside and order drinks.
Location good. Food adequate to good. Drinks delicious. Atmosphere busy and upbeat.

Pretty much a tourist trap.  We were in a rush for the movies so we said ah what the hell.  Wasn't as bad as we expected....BUT we got charged $28 for a bottle of wine we never saw!  I will certainly be going back for more than $28.  There really is very little that is authentic or unique about this restaurant.....sorry Francis but even you know that Ideale, Sodini's, Cinecitta up Columbus all serve better meals than your place.  Still, not terribly awful :  )

Very authentic Italian restaurant in Little Italy. Really fun location and great atmosphere inside. Was a little nervous that being owned by FFC would make it more of an attraction then good food, but the food was very authentic and great - one of the best Caesar Salad's we've ever had!

Interesting space, terrible food. I ordered chicken scarpiello. The dish had obviously been microwaved. The sausage that was sitting on top of the broth was dry and flavorless. Everything under the broth, including the chicken, was rubbery (and also flavorless). The vegetables tasted frozen, although it's difficult to be sure after they've been nuked. The dish was brought out almost instantly after ordering. There is no way they could have cooked any part of this dish to order.

We went there for lunch it was the most frustrating meal ever. The waiters were super rude and annoyed which made us feel uncomfortable. The food was ok they messed or order few time. However I would give the food a 2.5 stars and 0 for the service. Would I go back there again? Of course NO.

Came here for lunch last week on a short trip into the city. Service was mediocre at best & it was not crowded. Ordered $18.00 chicken cacciatore, pizza & the special of the day - a pasta with a gorgonzola sauce. Table bread came out almost 20 min after getting seated, which we thought was odd since our lunch should be coming out soon, right? Well, our food ended up taking a loooong time to come out, and 2 of the 3 dishes came out cold. On top of that, the chicken in the cacciatore was very dry, and the "lunch special" was certainly nothing special. After voicing our displeasure (have NEVER sent a food item back...this was a 1st!) they did take the cacciatore off the bill & even offered to take off the pizza. We let them know we were not trying to get free food, and our son was eating the pizza anyway - cold or not - since it was after 1pm at this point.

Yum, yum, and more yum!  My experience with the Cafe began with a simply telephone call to see if they could fit me in for dinner at the last minute--my request was met with open arms.  I walked over a tad early and they seated me right away.  I ordered one of the specials, spinach and ricotta gnocchi, and it was superb!  The service was amazing, friendly, and fast--without being over solicitous.  I felt right at home, which is something I crave living in a busy city.  Overall, my experience when visiting this establishment for the first time, was wonderful.  It will certainly become one of my go to eateries.  Oh and MY favorite sparkling is offered, Sofia's Blanc de Blanc.  Cheers!
talk about insecure.

My rating starts with the service level, which was superb. The second attribute is the ambience-fun, inviting, authentic, unpretentious. Third, the meal itself- prepared to order, served warm and timely.

The food and wine were fantastic however the service was not so great. We got there on a Friday night close to 8:00 and the host was terrible. We found our own seat (he said that  was ok with him) and sat there for quite a while before we got a menu which we had to ask for. When our waiter finally came to us he was good just a little slow in asking if we need anything. The really bad part is they weren't even busy. The host and waiters were just hanging out by the bar.  Again great food and wine. I would consider going back. Maybe if they were busy we would have received better service.

The food was great, but the service was the best. We had a reservation and when we checked in they called us by our names. Fernando, had our table ready with a flower that I had asked at the time of the reservation.
True tasty italian pizzas.

This place was an unexpectedly nice find!  We were able to get in last minute without reservations, and the host was quite gracious.  The food was good - we enjoyed the gnocchi special and Pizza Originale.  The Director's Pinot was also nice.  The service was solid and the ambiance was pleasant.

The building had lots of character and the ambiance was lively and fun.  Reminiscent of many of the cafes I have visited in Europe.  The pizza was authentic and fresh - our party had two different kinds and liked both.  One of us had a chicken dish with sausage and artichoke, which was the special, and thought it was excellent.  The cocktails were standard, but fine - I understand their focus is wine, but we did not have any.  The desserts were the best part - the panna cotta was fabulous!  We did not have pasta, but after seeing the spaghetti and meatballs delivered to the table next to us, I definitely want to try it!  I think I will be back.  The service was on the slower side, but very friendly and professional.
I believe Café Zoetrope started the wood-fired pizza craze in places that are not Tony's. Theirs is still the best. Also amazing is a simple bowl of pasta - I feel like I'm at someone's home.
Great Meal!

We stopped in for lunch on a Friday at noon. The restaurant was practically empty. We were seated quickly.  And then nothing. No menus, no water no nothing. A young woman came in and was seated near us. She was given water, menus, offered bread - all whike she waited for the rest of her group to show up. We were still ignored. We got up and left and as we walked out, the waiters didn't even acknowledge us. Guess we're the wrong demographic. We went up the street to Station and had a great, and welcoming, lunch.
Despite late notice, we managed to get Friday night reservation at 8pm for 4. It has charmingly quaint interior.

I did not plan to eat here but the hotel restaurant was closed and the much better pizza place up the street had a huge wait. I wish I had read yelp before going. My colleague had order a pizza which he had no complaints with and I unfortunately ordered the house specialty asado de tira. When ordering the asado I specifically asked the waiter well done (he should have enquired), to which he appeared to write something down for the order and had a quite dismissive look which should have been my clue. The steak arrived medium rare, the waiter was no where to be found luckily I was able to get the attention of who I believe is the owner and she sent it back for more cooking. The meat though tasty was not very lean. We also ordered two caipirinhas which were ok but not really special. The small fly that landed in my drink did not really like it, as it died on contact (at least it was not a weak drink!). We did not order dessert, but the cannolis looked good. I will not return.
Food was really good going down but exactly 8 hours later I've now got mild food poisoning. I'd be hesitant to blame this place were it not for the flies we shared dinner with.
First impresion without eating was a poor one.  My pet peeve is flies in a restaurant.  The entire dining experience was ruined swatting flies.

Bistro-like ambiance with reasonably efficient but impersonal service.  Decent food; would rate it average; nothing spectacular; soup was lukewarm.  Main attraction would appear to be ownership by Cuppola; but I in retrospect there are many other options at the same price point where you'll get better food/service/ambiance.

Went here for Valentine's and really enjoyed the experience. Fair prices, and great food. And, they didn't seem to mind that we sat and drank a long time after we ate. The gnocchi was amazing. With so many Italian options in North Beach, it can be tough to pick one. This place is a solid bet.

What an incredible experience!!! And,the BEST pizza EVER!!! Clearly, time, effort, passion, and love have been put into this restaurant - With the perfect combination of ambiance, food, drink, and service. Luke was knowledgable, offered great recommendations and made our night FANTASTIC - Great sense of humor! We can't wait to come back!!! Thanks, Cafè Zoetrope!!!

The food was good, we sat at the bar had pizza and soup, the bar maid who had zero personality opened a bottle of spirits for another diner and the cap flew off the bottle and landed right on our pizza, she just reached over and plucked off the food, never apologising even after we mentioned "you know sorry would be nice" very rude we won't be going back.

I walked past this place on my way to Soto Mare and almost stopped. Didn't realize this was owned by the Coppolas until I noticed the 'Lost in Translation' movie poster (it's one of my favorites).  On my way back from Soto Mare I stopped in for some better wine to cap my night.

So my first impressions of this cafe were that it was very small. I only had this thought upon entering because it looked impossibly busy and I was starving! To my surprise and delight our hostess greeted us at the door after a couple of seconds and was able to get us a little private booth for two in the right corner of the restaurant. It was a perfect little booth close to the bar but also with a window view to keep claustrophobia at bay.
I was disappointed in my experience here.
Good service.  Food is Just OK.  Classic pasta and pizza.  I was expecting much better. We came with a big party, tasted most everything.  Not worth a repeat visit.
Best place in North Beach for Italian food and wine.
Ambience: Five Stars

We're a group of about a dozen writers who meet here once a month on a Saturday afternoon, during the time when there are not a lot of people. It is after lunch after all. The waitress comes by and takes our orders. Some of us order beers, others order soups, some of us order entrées, and others are there just to talk about writing.
Amazing food, great wine, cute waiters and bartender....what more could you ask for???

As a San Francisco native, I've seen many restaurants come and go and Cafe Zoetrope is truly a landmark in the city!  I've consistently received excellent service and delicious food here!  Last time, the supervisor, Casey, gave me an excellent recommendation on a brunch item; the Ouvo al forno which was delicious!  I had a great conversation with him after brunch and will continue to return and recommend this place to all my San Franciscan family!  Keep up the good work!!
Came here on A beautiful Sunday for my fathers birthday and  had high expectations  that where not met .

I didn't know a lot of dimsum places in Chinatown SF are to-go only.  Places that had high Yelp rating did not offer dine-in so next best thing was New Asia Chinese Restaurant.  It was hugh and packed so we thought it would be worth trying.
Dim sum from carts, which was just what we wanted.

We went for dim sum in the morning and was luckily seated fairly quickly. We got the beef roll and the fried shrimp ball and the turnip cake and the shrimp in white wrapper and the beef in yellow wrapper and the egg tart and veggies in a white wrapper and a ball of slightly sweet chewy rice that had pork in the middle.
Boyfriend and I went here for "yum cha" last weekend.

This is where the Chinese locals go for weekend brunch, so you know it's solid. It's one of the few places in the city that not only still has carts but also has abundant seating. If you're looking for attentive service, go to somewhere like Yank Sing because you will not have a good time here.
Old school dim sum place with trolleys going around the restaurant. Taste was good but agree that some food was slightly cold when we arrived around 2pm. Go early and be ready to line up.

Overall, I was impressed with this restaurant. It's a very casual atmosphere, with great food. I would recommend the BBQ pork buns, the egg tart, and the shrimp dumplings. Honestly though, they have a lot of great options! Service isn't the greatest, but a good option for affordable dim sum

Ate here once and this dim sum spot is definitely where all the local Chinese people go and it's not touristy at all. Like a typical popular local favorite dim sum spot, there's a long time wait time for a table during lunch time.
Dim Sum is okay. Better than anything in San Jose. However, if you want to be ignored except when you tell them your going to pay and asked why you didn't leave 10% tip, THIS IS THE PLACE FOR YOU!
One word: Yuck.
crowded!!!!!especially new years!!!

Can't exactly comment on the food, but we came for dinner and arrived at 5, which is what time their door signs and website says. They were still sweeping, setting up tables, chairs, etc. so we just sat. It turns into 530 and we asked what seemed like a manager if they were open yet. He literally just grunted and walked away from us. Finally a nicer waitstaff walked by us and explained to us that they were not yet ready. We were too hungry to wait longer so we left.

We asked a very nice police office while walking around town where should we eat dim sum...he said this place was great. We got here about 2:45 for lunch and were served tea without asking (which we later paid for...and we did not drink)....so if you don't want tea say no thank you. We asked for pork shumai and we were told 4 minutes...10 minutes go by and we asked again...well wouldn't you know it we were told 4 minutes....guess what, asked again and guess what...4 minutes! We never got any pork. We asked for soy sauce three times...never got it. We asked at 7 minutes to 3:00 for noodles with chicken. Our obvious mistake was asking the rolling cart gals (which they wear purple and the waitress wears pink...who knew!) which they did not tell our waitress and 5 after 3:00 our waitress finally came around and we said we would like noodles...well, apparently they stop serving at 3:00. The reason hey stop serving at 3:00 is the entire wait staff sits down at tables around the restaurant to eat. No question of would you like anything else, just its break time.

This is one of the few restaurants in Chinatown that still pushes Dim Sum carts around.  It seems Dim Sum carts are a dying tradition and restaurants now want you to order off the menu and they deliver it.

Been here a few times. Once for lunch for dim sum which I thought was pretty good. Lots of variety and different plates to choose from. It was very crowded! Next time, we went for dinner and the dim sum was not offered. Thought we would stay and eat dinner anyways. Bad idea!  Food tasted just like the local hole in the wall restaurant that holds 25 people except it cost a whole lot more. Also, they had karaoke that was making my ears bleed and it was super loud. You can't even talk to the person next to you.

If you're not asian and you walk into this place for the first time, the thing you have to realize is that you're probably going to be in the minority. And this is a HUGE restaurant. But if you want an authentic dim sum experience, this is a great option.

Okay, most restaurants in Chinatown have become so touristy that none of the locals eat around here anymore. The same goes for all the dimsum places. THIS place, I hope it keeps its 3 star rating because this place is the best and I don't want tourists to come here. But then I guess I shouldn't write this review.
8 dishes 4 people $56 + tip

Good dim sum. They have delicious chicken feet, roasted duck and har gao. Though the quality of food is inconsistent, the seating service is quick and reliable. Located in the stomach of china town, this place is a must for dim sum diners.
One of my favorite places to have Dim Sum when in San Francisco! Great food with a free Chinese lesson ;-)

Came here for dinner with the family, and the food itself was quite good! Got the chicken in black bean sauce, sweet and sour fish fillet, beef with scallion and ginger, chow fun, salt and pepper calimari, and egg rolls. The tea (was supposed to be oolong) was SUPER concentrated--almost as if it had been out for a while and had been left to steep. The rice, too, was hard (like they didn't fluff it and just took the top part). Servers were nice enough and brought the food in a timely manner.

I had the worst Chinese meal ever at New Asia restaurant.  It cost the same as any other place up and down the street, but it made Panda Express look really good.  This is NOT what I come to Chinatown for.  And then there is the obnoxious Chinese karaoke and ballroom dancing.  I gather that it is not every night, but it was pretty bad the day we were there.  The dancers (older Chinese couples) were pretty serious about their ballroom dancing, but I notice that they also brought some of their food with them.  To a restaurant.  Not a good sign.
Another wonderful trip to New Asia. This time we brought 19 family members who were new to Dim Sum.  Our serving staff did their best to meet our needs. Everything was fresh and wonderful.

My parents and relatives love to drag me to this restaurant. Their food is bland, their shrimp dumplings fall apart easily (overcooked? or overwatered dough? Who knows), their buns are mushy, it's nothing special to write home about.
Horrible service and gross food. BELIEVE ME! They were cussing at each other in Cantonese and it made me very uncomfortable. If you want to wake up with a bad stomach ache, then come here!

I swore two years ago that I would never go to New Asia again. When I went a few years ago for dim sum, I got the bill and paid cash (cash only). Anyways, I picked up the change and I was getting ready to put a tip down and before I could put any money down the waitress yelled at me for taking money off the table. Wow. So I put a ten percent tip down cause they really didn't do anything. It's all push carts. When I put ten percent down she yelled at me again and told me how much more of a tip to put down. Because of this I swore I would never come here again. Don't like it when people yell at me for tips. Not cool at all.

This is kinda hard coz there's no option for ZERO stars!!! I searched for the best dimsum in Chinatown and this is what came up. We went and ordered from the first dimsum cart and they said there's no more after that cart. We said we'll jst order from the menu but every waiter/ waitress we called either ignored us or said "later". We decided to wrap it up and moved to another dimsum place. Asking for our check and paying took about another 15mins. Never recommending this place and never coming back here!!!!

I got gypped.  On Sunday, I went with my family of 4 to enjoy what I thought was decent low priced dim sum.  We ordered 11 dishes and the bill came out to $52.  Outrageous pricing for such a dirty joint.  The only plate that was out of the ordinary was this 3 piece Durian pastry.  I thought the last time we had it was $4 something and the cashier who came to resolve my billing said it was an extra special plate and it's $8.  $2 + for each piece.  Other than that, we had 2 plates of Beef Rice Roll, 1 Beef Meat Ball, 1 Shui Mai, 1 Har Gow, 1 ribs, 1 tripe, 2 egg yolk bun and 1 deep fried pastry with taro.  All ordinary stuff.  I am never going back there again.
I ate dim sum here after running the 2014 Bay to Breakers Run.
2nd time coming there and it never fails me!
Yes its true everyone. This place is certainly a dive in it's truest forms and can be chaotic.

The dim sum is mediocre at best but the egg custard and Chinese donuts are the best I have had in Chinatown yet. A very good place to go to experience the Dim Sum by cart service; however, the place is too pricey for me to become a regular patron.
Complete uncontrolled chaos at 11am on Mothers Day Sunday morning.

Upon arrival, the hostess gave us a number due to the long line. But she calls out the number in Chinese which we can't understand. Waited for 30 minutes to find out she's called out our number 15 mins ago. Good food though.

If you prioritize cheap, this place is for you maybe? I personally look for at least enough quality that I don't feel disgusted while eating but the grease... I didn't want to eat anything here. I tried at least 7 different dishes and they all felt like they were soaking in grease. Flavor was lacking still. I love duck and I can only think of a handful of places that can mess up duck. I felt kind of sick after eating here..
Come early and be ready for a wait.  Still one of the better dim sum spots here in SF.
It is okay, not bad, not good. The service was lacking and the prices were alright, not cheap, but not expensive either, just fair. Taste was meh, typical dim sum.

Not my cup of tea for dim sum. But it is decent when other options aren't available. They come around in carts with your typical dim sum dishes but they also have a menu you can order from. Food is mediocre at it's best, it sad but I think there are fast food dim sum places that do a better job than New Asia...and cheaper.

We came here for a wedding banquet dinner.  A-ok solid Chinese food -- our faves were the fish, beef, scallops and broccoli and shrimp with walnuts.  The lobster was a bit hard to dig out the shell.  Service was a-ok, very diligent in clearing the table.  They have a spacious stage and dance floor perfect for karaoke and dancing with your group of friends.
2 1/2 stars
This is my first review, but when a place this good comes along, you just have to. My friend and I are road tripping across the west and stumbled upon this place.

Decided to try the food at this restaurant and it was DELICIOUS. Love the Mongolian Beef and the Chicken Chow Mein. The staff's were really nice and very efficient, prices were reasonable. I would highly recommend the Westlake minced soup and the Walnut Prawn dish. One of the best Chinese restaurants in SF
The food was fine. We ordered sweet and sour chicken, orange chicken, and fried rice. The Mongolian beef seemed very fatty.
Some of the best Chinese food I've ever had. Stopped by on my trip from New York. Family style food at reasonable prices. Get the chicken fried rice.
"A person needs new experiences. They jar something deep inside, allowing you to grow. Without them, it sleeps- seldom to awaken. The sleeper must awaken. "

It's been four years since I wrote my first review and after reading some of the other reviews I think it's time for an update.  Chef Hung's has changed hands since last time and some of the wait staff is also different.  Nevertheless it is still a great value for the money.  If you go there on a Sunday (try to beat the church crowd) they have amazing values for individual plates that anyone would be hard pressed to finish.  I still go there regularly with my group -- probably about 40 times since my last review.  As far as parking is concerned, there is very limited street parking in Chinatown.  If you're lucky you'll find a place in back at the Waverly Place entrance.  I have only found street parking once in over 40 years of trying.  Where I usually park is the parking garage under Portsmouth Square about three blocks away.  There's also parking under Saint Mary's square on California.  For the person with the friend that had an allergic reaction to peanuts -- don't blame it on Chef Hungs.  I would strongly encourage you to never eat Chinese food in a genuine Chinese restaurant.  If you ask the waitress if they use peanuts, of course they would say no unless it's specifically a peanut dish but the pots and pans probably come in contact with peanuts from time to time as does every single restaurant in Chinatown and 99.999% of any restaurant that serves genuine Asian fare.  That's just the way it is.  Besides, the waitress doesn't always understand what you're trying to ask.  Bottom line, Chef Hungs is still a good value with large portions and tasty food.

The food was ok, but the concern I have is for anyone with peanut allergies. We specifically asked SEVERAL times if there were peanuts in any of the dishes we ordered. We even made sure that there wasn't peanut oil in the salad, and the waitresses assured us multiple times that everything would be safe for our friend with the peanut allergy to eat. But less than 10 minutes after we left the restaurant, our friend had a really severe reaction, and we had to call 911. It was very frustrating that the wait staff told us it was perfectly safe for him to eat, when really it wasn't.

Nice, little quaint back alley Chinese in the middle of Chinatown. Really good value for money, I was bloody hungry after walking the city all day and couldn't finish my main. Really nice, cheap food and good service.

We are her last night and it was fabulous. The service and food were amazing. We had the pork fried rice, Generajs chicken and BBQ pork egg foo yung. Very traditional and authentic Chinese. Best I've ever had personally.

First time here, not too impressed. I ordered three things and none if them were that good. First, the fried rice was made with cabbage. I've never had it like that and I thought it was gross. Next, I ordered the Mongolian Beef, which wasn't too bad, a little salty. Lastly, I ordered the Sweet n Sour Pork and the breading was hard and burnt tasting, the sauce didn't help mask the horrible flavor. Not a good first impression of this place, and there are a thousand other Chinese food shops within seconds I will try next time before returning here.
A mediocre meal. For less, there are better meals in China town.
I came here for brunch on a weekday.

This place used to be Great Wall of China Chinese Restaurant, but I guess they've changed it since the last time my family frequented the space. It's still underground and pretty dirty, so that much hasn't changed. Super greasy, MSG-laden, salty, and glossy. This is Americanized Chinese food at some of its worst. It's dirt-cheap, and the portions are great, but this is not an authentic meal by any means. They cater to American patrons, as can be seen by the super glossy plates and wrong meal order served.

Came here for dinner with the fam. My parents asked me what I was craving and I was on a seafood kick, so I wanted ginger scallion crab or steamed fish in soy sauce. They were out of both! So we ended up getting a bunch of clay pots. The dishes are a decent size and the clay pots were good. My parents love the rice pots with toppings so we ordered two of those. The rice had a nice crustiness to it and the toppings flavored the rice nicely. The roast pork and oyster clay pot we got had a good amount of meat, oysters and veggies. Service was like any other chinese restaurant. Quick and efficient. I would have given them 3.5 stars, rounded up to 4 stars, but since they didn't have two of the dishes I was craving, they go down to a solid 3 stars!

I love this place! Came here the other day with my boyfriend. We ordered the mongolian beef lunch special (which came with rice), and a beef chow fun. I like how they added fresh jalapenos with their green peppers and onions in the mongolian beef. The beef was also so tender! They also gave you a lot of meat in the chow fun.
