We really like this place! The beef chow fun was about $6.75 and the mongolian beef was about $6.50 I think. The portions were decent. I would definitely come here again!

Really tasty food and not very greasy (which is good). Hot n sour soup had a tasty umami flavor. Pork fried rice was extremely satisfying. We also got a soft tofu and stir fried bok choy dish that was the star. Their chow funn noodles were sub par but that was their only fault. Friendly service and cheap prices. Now I know where to get great Chinese food in Chinatown when I visit.

One of the best Chinese restaurant in SF. The staff is very friendly and the food is excellent. I recommend to take the menu for group where you can taste many different dishes with your friends or family. I recommend the Beef Broccoli.
We ordered quite a feast here.  The stars of the show were the Beef and Broccoli, the Potstickers, and the Curry Chicken with Coconut Sauce.  Freaking delicious.

Eat elsewhere!! well, I guess you can eat here if you want FRAUD!!! That's right, I said FRAUD and a hair in your food!!  My husband and I decided to eat here while we were in San Francisco for our anniversary.   I was having their wonton soup and I was almost done with the soup when I noticed a long dark hair on a wonton! It was so gross! All the waitress said was "sorry".   I was pretty disgusted and wanted to leave.  I didn't want to be to rude so I didn't complain a whole lot besides mentioning the hair.  Anyway, my husband handed the waitress the card and my husband noticed that SHE HID BEHIND A WALL.  He noticed, thought it was weird and different but didn't talk about it much after.   Well, 2 days later there was fraud done on his card and I'm like 95% sure it was them because the fraud was in San Francisco and we don't even live there! Anyway, GO ELSEWHERE!!!!! Next time, I'll be a bit more picky about where we eat!!

Cheap and Filling. Get a full meal with soup, entree, rice or noodle, and dessert for less than $8. Went with the Filet of Sole and it was a generous portion (of course frozen seafood and not fresh for this price).
Was in San Fran for work and loved this place so much I went twice in the span of 3 days.  The food was great and the people were very nice.
We loved the pot stickers, walnut shrimp, and fried rice.  I'm glad we discovered it!
SURPRISINGLY, not bad!
Yea real good!

The people are pretty nice here and the portions are pretty big. In my opinion I think the food is pretty good, though I only get clay pot rice. Get a small though. It's more than big enough for one person, and a medium is definitely more than enough for two. I'm almost afraid to see how big a large is..

Freaking Awesome Chinese food! With so many choices Chinatown can be a very confusing place to settle on where to eat at. Look no further than Chef Hung's. The food: absolutely delicious, cooked well, served hot, bursting with flavor and huge portions. The price: dirt cheap, I felt bad paying such low prices it was so cheap. We had 2 pot stickers, tea , 2 drinks, beef fried rice, pork chow mein, general chicken, Mongolian beef and soup for $40. FORTY DOLLARS!. I couldn't believe it. The Mongolian beef and fried rice were by far the best I had ever had. Now on to the only downside: Service. The servers were nice and accommodating however once they dropped off the food it took a very long time for them to come back. We had finished eating and needed some boxes and to pay and the servers were chit chatting away while stacking chairs (it was close to closing time). It wasn't bad enough to lower them a star but just don't plan on service being extremely quick.

Stumbled in randomly in the evening when we didn't know what to eat. Had a big plate of vegetables and chicken. The food was all right, nothing amazing. I wasn't really impressed by anything. I'm surprised I found this so easily on Yelp actually.

I loved it. For a while on our early Sunday afternoon visit we were the only English speaking customers in the place, and there were what appeared to be a couple of large families at round tables talking, laughing, and eating. I felt like we were getting a true Chinatown experience.
Dirty dishes and dirty atmosphere! YUCK!
I love hole in the wall restaurants, oops.. this is a hole in the ground restaurant - you walk down a flight of stairs from the sidewalk level to get to this basement level restaurant.

Great convenient location, but parking can be a pain if you're not already strolling about china town.   The food is tasty for inexpensive chinese food (especially the pork chow mein!), but the service has declined after this place changed ownership.  Still, Chef Hung's is a great restaurant to go with a larger group.
So so. Was disappointed
I needed a Chinese rest. that could hold 26 5/6 graders & 20 adults w/ a good selection & an out the door price. Tom the manager was marvelous.
This place blew my mind.

More like 3.5 stars.  After walking around Chinatown, we decided to try Chef Hung's because of it's name.  We figured, if he named the restaurant after himself, it must be good.  I was not disappointed.  The food was good, the prices were cheap, and the portions were very large.  This is definitely a hole in the wall place that can be easily missed.  It's on a side street and you have to go down steps to get to the restaurant.  I can't compare it to other Chinese restaurants in San Francisco, since I'm not a local, but I was definitely pleased with Chef Hung's.
I was in San Fran on business and staying in Chinatown, so I wondered out and happened upon this place.

Not bad, but not terribly exciting either.  I ordered one of the daily specials, fried sole, because it came with green tea and dessert.  Turns out, everyone gets free green tea anyways (which is good, but then it's misleading to list it as a benefits of ordering the special) and the "dessert" was a fortune cookie... wow!  On the other hand, it has a great location just off the the main Chinatown thoroughfare, and the food was good and cheap.  We all really liked the cabbage that came with our specials.  My sole also had a tasty and rich (but as far as a I can tell not very Chinese) spread / sauce.  This is definitely a place to go if you want to go if you want a big plate of cheap, warm food put in front of you.  After our meal, our party of five had some trouble paying the bill because it was written in Chinese characters, so we couldn't tell who owed how much.  When we asked the owner, he took a long time figuring it out and it became pretty confusing.  We should have all asked for separate checks... I never remember until it's too late!

Chef Hung's gets 4 stars for meeting (but not exceeding) my Chinatown criteria: nothing visibly gross / unclean, primarily Asian patrons, reasonably good food for the price, and didn't get sick later.
favorite dish - West Lake Minced Beef Soup

from outside it looks like a small hot deli, the restaurant inside is very small, not the kind of place to bring your family , not enough room for that. I ordered a rice plate with two items, on the wall it was priced at $7 but when I ordered to eat there the prices was more, with a soda it was $11 , but they serve it on a plate and include a small bowl of soup, so it's worth the higher price to eat there, they had all the popular Chinese dishes, but they serve more of the authentic home style dishes like the inards, the beef tripe, pig's feet, lamb stew, pork blood, pig skin, pig's snout in soy sauce, intestines, etc

just went there yesterday they seem to be cutting back on the flavor got my usual 2 in fact of the sam see chow mein humm..... maybe new cook or different cook don't know don't know about the other dishes but still the same amout of bbq pork ,mushroom and chicken still the same price.so that's good.

Me and my fiancee were on our first trip to Chinatown and we were looking for a place to eat. We passed by this place and saw all the good food on display by the window. My fiancee says to me "let's eat here" so we went in. It's kind of small in there but boy is it good. They have a special and I spent under $20 for both of us. The people working there are pretty nice. 5 stars. I will be going back next time I am in Chinatown!!!
3.5 STARS. I'm not quite a fan yet but it looks promising.

Tiny hole-in-the-wall Cantonese style restaurant located in the middle of Chinatown on Stockton St. We first noticed this place because of all the BBQ meats and other goodies they have on display in the window. Although there is limited seating because of the size of this place, the food and service was very good. We ordered a couple items from the window as side dishes (beef tripe and soy sauce marinated wings) as well as duck/rice and BBQ pork/rice combos. You can order anything from the window by the pound if you're taking it with you, or you can dine in and choose from small, medium or larger size orders (we were confused about this when ordering and thought we had to order by the pound). We ordered so much food that we couldn't finish it all and felt bad not taking anything to go with us, but we had a day of sightseeing ahead of us after our early lunch. Would definitely return next time I'm in San Francisco, but would recommend taking your items/meal to go since there are only a handful of tables and they were all full by the time we left. This place, just like most others in Chinatown is cash only.

This review started out fantastic as this Chinese BBQ restaurant had free tea and tables for indoor dining compared to many other BBQ places nearby which is take out...A day later we returned as we liked the fact they had seating for the BBQ foods we wanted to eat again and they declined to serve our party of 3 because they wanted every one to order a dish (not going to happen as only one person was eating that early in the day). Even though it was lunch hour they only had one other table occupied so it wasn't like they didn't have room. Honestly I have never been turned down seating at any place so its a first time but for that experience they get 1 star!!! Was the food any good...it wasn't spectacular and inline with the other places nearby.
its about a mile walk from my office, but I will gladly walk over!  lol, it makes me feel less guilty when i do a bit of exercise before i stuff myself to near death =P alright lets get on with it.
I only come here is to buy their sesame chicken and chicken feet / cha siu .

First thing you notice as you pass-by New Moon is all the roasted and barbeque deli foods in the window.  This is my favorite deli in Chinatown to get soy sauce chicken, boiled chicken, roast pork, bbq pork and ribs.  They also have roast duck, crispy chicken and the trays of deli entrees including soy sauce wings, salt & pepper wings, sweet and sour pork, mandarin chicken, tofu & veggie, tripe, chicken feet, pork trotters, and oxtails.

The best roast duck in SF hands down. Better than happy bakery out on Geneva ave and better than the cheung hings. The duck had very thin crispy skin- fatty layer was completely melted ( unlike others). Garlicky bok choy a perfect foil for the unctuous duck, all sopped up by a rice bed. The crowning glory is the special sauce made of duck drippings - a small bowl provided on request. This secret sauce is unbelievably umami. Surprisingly served stylishly on a square plate - totally unwarranted - darn overachievers were going for 110% after owning the competition on duck itself. Had three Pours of hot tea served with a smile as I write this note. Tab - Six bucks and change.
Tons of MSG. Just get the duck

Sure, the food was alright when I ate it but I developed a headache and KOed for a good 3 hours afterwards. No, I wasn't tired and no, I didn't eat too much (just some chicken feet, lol). I blame it on MSG overload. Fail.
I come here to get the duck feet - they are flavorful and soft, perfect for my soup rice noodle with tender greens.
Yummy, very authentic, Chinese food.
Definitely not what I expected, but my uncle wanted roast duck and wanted to eat here (after the place on the corner of Broadway and Powell was deemed too crowded).

I hardly eat in Chinatown as the quality over the years has declined. Most places I go to make the food too greasy and oily. This place is surprisingly good. They have a different lunch special everyday of the week. Today I tried their roast pork meal which comes with a tofu soup, massive amount of rice, and some cabbage on the side. All for $5. Granted the meat was a little on the fatty side but otherwise it was a decent meal for $5. I also ordered the broccoli beef which came with really fresh broccoli and the meat was a little on the chewy side but not full of fat. This was $5.25 and came with the soup and rice. The place is pretty clean and the ladies serving us processed our order pretty quickly. I would definitely come back again if I was in the neighborhood.

OMG, this place satisfied my cravings for fried tofu and pork skins! Even though we aren't locals, my wife and I knew that the busier the restaurant, the better it is; this place was no exception. Amidst the chilly weather (last week was SF's Winter Storm of 2011, which we thankfully do not have in LA), this place had the most foot traffic in the block. And the best part was the food is dirt cheap! I'm already wanting to make the trip up north to this place!

You know it's good when its busy! New Moon is busy but not too busy for you to get a seat and have a great meal. You also get served by really nice and friendly folks, not your typical abrasive chinese waiters!

This place has the best ja gee chicken in Chinatown...  The kind you get at restaurants with the colorful shrimp chips on top. The uncles that work behind the counter always chop it up for you so you can go home and immediately eat it. Plus they're the only shop in chinatown whose shopping bag isn't the generic pink or white!
Amazing! I don't live in SF, so I can't say if it's the best in the city but it's probably the best I've ever had.
Roast duck, steamed chicken, char siu, tripe stew....

Sure from the outside it looks really ghetto... sure, it's a hole in the wall and there's a whole half of a fried pig hanging.. but that's what you're going to get for some authentic Chinese food. Forget about panda express and all the other chinese food places you've been to.. beef broccoli and sweet and sour chicken is NOT chinese food.

I am Andrew Zimmern ..., I love to eat werid food around the world.  No, I am not Andrew Zimmern, I am just inspire and am a fan of Andrew ....  I am trying to expose what werid food you can get in SF China Town.   This is one of the place and ... how so ...  Well, you can get dicon raddish pig skin, chitlins and braise tripe and other cow internals (as seen in my uploaded pictures).  So if you are like Andrew, by all means try them out.  It's reasonably clean, you won't get sick ... but you might get sick because of other reasons.

I still love this place. But a word of warning: this is a complete hole-in-the-wall that caused my boyfriend to comment "I don't understand how you guys (referring to me and my sister) can eat there. Can't you see how dirty it is?"  Nope. It's delicious and cheap. My only two criteria.
The epicenter of the pink bags!!!
Food = good. We tried their gai jook (chicken watery rice soup) and their soy sauce chicken over rice.  Both were delicious, fresh, and not full of grease.
earth's new moon; hungry, i went in ... hot food prepared well in clean surroundings ... absolute find in chinatown, cleaned my plate, enough said

This is located next door to Yin Du Wonton Noodle which is highly recommended.  I decided to pop in here to try some of their bakery items.  Had a banana flavored dessert USD 0.6, a Green Tea Cake Roll USD 0.9, a Curry Turnover USD 1.2.  None of these really was all that good.  They look nice, but when it comes down to the quality and taste, it's badly lacking.  Did not try their egg custard tart which is 3 for USD 1.4, less than a third of the price charged for one at nearby Golden Gate Bakery which is USD 1.5.  This place is packed with customers, be prepared to share a table if there's an empty seat.  Cheap it is, good tasting quality food, look elsewhere.

We went to this location as Golden Gate bakery was closed. Hollywood bakery has quality pork buns and egg tarts. The rest of the baked goods are average. Seating is a bonus and the prices are very good!
The best pork buns in Chinatown.

Very underrated.   Egg tarts are just as good as Golden Gate without the wait time,  annoying hipsters,  and expensive prices.   I knew it was going to be good when I looked in and saw nothing but Chinese people.

This little hidden gem has the "Best BBQ pork buns" ever. You have to try it, then you will always come back here just to get your buns. It's best fresh, but it's still great the next day (wrap bun in slightly wet paper towel & microwave it for bout 45 seconds ) They also have a "Pineapple BBQ pork bun" ( it's a cross of a pineapple bun & BBQ pork bun. That is great but only make so many so if you're lucky & get there early you might get one)
the PORK BUNS mmm

The green onion buns here are good - for what they are. Nice soft bread braided into a a long bun and studded with green onions. Very nice light snack. Not too oniony - just a pleasant onion flavor. However it's really nothing to write home about.
Who knew how much joy could come from a grumpy lady seemingly annoyed at your english-speaking face handing you a plastic bag filled with the greatest tasting thing in Chinatown?

Yay green onion buns recommended by the lady behind us in the golden gate bakery line. I've been here maybe 3-4 x now. So it's a routine...everytime I go to china town, I haul back 20 green onion sticks for $14. 70 cents each. FRESH, delicious, buttery...

I was reading other Yelp's comments.  I was walking down in Chinatown a came across this bakery.  Reminded me of a 1950 movie - where everyone had their coffee and pastries/breakfast - and everyone lived in the neighborhood.  Walked in and found their egg tarts.  Great price so I purchased some to try...it was awesome.  I have given these to family members and they also enjoy them - especially their crust.  Golden Gate Bakery has a different crust - a bit more flaky - but I don't like standing in a long line and when I am in the mood for one - they are closed for vacation.
I came for one reason and one reason only - to try the green onion buns featured on 7x7's Top 100 Things to Try Before You Die.

I have been to restaurants in Chinatown, San Francisco many times in my life. This is another casual Chinese restaurant with a basic menu. I stopped by because I was in Chinatown and had pork and preserved vegetable rice stick noodles. It was okay. I also had a pearl milk tea. The service was fine.

I got the green onion bun for 70 cents. Do not have nothing too much to base it off of, but it was surprisingly crispy on the outside, and soft on the inside. Nice smell of green onion. Smells really good. Some bites have barely any green onion flavor, other bites with the green onions has the flavor but very subtle flavor explosions.
It's just one of the Chinatown bakeries. I tried the green onion braided bun. It's good and well made but I don't think I'd regret it if I haven't tried it before I die (7x7 100 2013).
Possibly the worst egg tarts I've had. After yet another Golden Gate Bakery fail, we headed to this place in search of egg tarts. The pastry shell was too thick, the filling very artificial tasting.

the New Hollywood Bakery is surrounded by  dine-in tables making it hard to get the bakery from the front door. (note: use the side door)eatery. very busy in the morning. clears out by 11 a.m. no idea what's on the menu.
My go-to spot for egg tarts, Golden Gate Bakery, was again closed for vacation so I decided to check out New Hollywood instead...
What happens when Golden Gate Bakery takes yet another unannounced vacation? Go around the corner to New Hollywood Bakery!
100 Best Things To Eat In SF Before You Die 2013
Green Onion Buns- #71 on the 2013 7x7 100 Things to Eat Before You Die list.

Green onion buns for the win! Best place to get that oh so crusty, pillowy, green-oniony chinese buns. They're super affordable and don't let the decor deter you. Buy a bunch of these guys and bring them home, heat them up in the toaster oven, and VOILA!

Had to try the green onion bun since it's on the 7x7 list and this place is so close to my apartment! Plus, every time I walk by, it's FILLED with Asian people...obviously a sign of a quality restaurant! Hehe.
Their Pineapples Buns and Raisin Wheat Buns are two of my breakfast staples. I crave for these all the time when I am away at school.

This is one of those spots in Chinatown that is always filled with Chinese people. This is actually what lured me in. They serve hot dishes along side their baked goods. I'd skip the usual Cantonese fare and head for their daily specials (catfish, oxtail) all of which are served with a home made soup which is made from scratch, low in salt and high in nutrition. Do know the ambiance is nothing for tourists or those seeking anything on the trendier side of under 65.
CASH ONLY.  After eating at New Lun Ting Cafe in SF Chinatown we walked over to New Hollywood Bakery for some pastries to take home.
The best egg custards I have ever had!!! Gotta get them as they are3 for $1.1 now. The crust is custy and not stale and the egg custard inside was warm and creamy!
Egg custard tarts, 3 of them for $1. I came here before, the food and service is good.
Food was okay. Don't use their bathroom!

New Hollywood Bakery isn't my favorite but their onion twists sure are delicious! They have tons of other breads and pastries here. I remember seeing chicken pie, curry pastry, bbq pork pastry, cakes, and your typical breads like pineapple bun, bbq pork bun, dinner rolls, hotdog bun, etc.

Meh.  Service was weak.  Had to ask for fork and napkin.  Steamed pork buns had skimply filling and floury aftertaste. Siu mai nothing special and a little gristly.  Would give two stars but taking one away to balance out the obvious shills.
3.5 stars - we are on a mission to try all places, regardless if they look appealing to us or not.

My mom would always leave with a big pink box full of buns because this place is TOO good.  Our favorites are the long green onion buns, raisin wheat buns, red bean pastry buns, and pineapple buns. Yum yum yum. The banana cake is a must-get too, along with the black forest cake. There aren't any placards, so you'd have to ask the ladies behind the counter :) The prices are reasonable. They also serve lunch dishes, like ramen and potstickers. :D
Was in the mood for a red bean paste pastry so I stopped in for takeout.
I like the vibe.  I like the sweet glutenous rice disks with red bean paste inside.  I like the rice porridge with pork and preserved egg.  I like the area.

cheezy name (but i fell for it anyway cuz it reminds me of my last city)... I went in at 7am and the boluo bao was fresh out of the oven.  Got that and a milk tea for $3.  mmmmm.... who needs Starbucks when you can get this?! that and iPod on a Friday morning kicks the weekend off right!
Any chance I have to go even close to Chinatown I have come here to get at least a dozen of the onion bun.  It is the best!

i think hollywood bakery is hands-down the best bakery in chinatown, simply based on their green onion buns. SO FRICKIN GOOD! i also love their wheat/raisin buns, sesame buns, cocktail buns and baked bbq pork buns. when i was a kid i used to like their hot dog buns quite a bit as well, dipping them in ketchup to get my own weird twist on the american hot dog. their mini cupcakes are also a nice treat, though hawaii bakery up on stockton has them beat just a tad because they have mini blueberry muffins too.

Green Onion Buns! I was with a friend in North Beach and I was hyping it up so much that he wanted to try it. He was fully expecting to be disappointed but he was very pleasantly surprised. Rich, buttery, just the right amount of flavor, fresh out of the oven. How can anything like that NOT be good?! They have a lovely bunch of buns(I'm about to burst into song... "Big ones little ones... eentsy bitsy teeny ones") and I recommend try them all! By the way, these buns are not displayed in their glass case but rather kinda hidden from view in the back in a hot box. Ask to see what they have. They have really good coffee too... plus it's CHEAP! Run, Don't Walk

This is pretty greasy and sugary. But I cannot help to stop in whenever I am in SF. I like how this bakery has miniature versions of their most popular snacks such as the wife's cake. As always, Chinatown bakeries are super cheap.

I come here for their buns. Onion bun is pretty good, except kinda oily but that's what makes it good! Lots of oldies come here to chill with fellow oldies. Families here also. A little on the dirty side, but hey it's Chinatown. What do you expect?

Pork fried rice was awesome!!, and so was the rest of what ever we ordered.  took a few stars off because the service sucks unless Tony is serving you.. This place is a 5 star food taste, can some one write me if you can find a place like this in San Jose as far as food prep goes. A little pricey at around $10 a plate but hella worth it! Yup really wanted to 5 star this place but I really dislike the old Chinese lady who served us, she's lucky for the $3 tip. I'll be sure to call and ask if Tony is working before we head to the snow Garden. I witnessed this Mexican guy and storm out after he and his small family were ignored for 18 minutes.
Reminds me of being back home in Hawaii.  Dishes are very tasty, servings are generous, and service was very friendly.  Salt and pepper pork chops, must have.

This is a great restaurant if your looking for some authentic Chinese food.The chow mein is delicious. My husband and I were greeted immediately as we walked in and seated shortly, then served fresh tea. The only reason I do not give this place a 5-star is due to cleanliness (bathrooms)..but otherwise it is a delightful place to dine!

It's a very tiny place about 30 people. The foods is very good. We order special fried rice, cao pao chicken, sweet sour chicken and walnut shrimps. The price is reasonable. The customer is very nice. I would recommend it to someone. The place is located in China town so it difficult to find parking. We went there on Labor Day around 6ish so we got lucky with parking.

Food was pretty good, no complaints there. Portions were acceptable for the price. Service was always on it. Only concern is seeing waiter cut raw chicken in back and not sure how much washing was done before he came back out to wait on patrons.  But you never know what happens in back kitchens; just happen to have direct view of this one. Rating a 4 as we would eat it again.

Snow Garden is my favorite Chinese restaurant in San Francisco.  I discovered it by accident on my first trip here as we were just wandering around and got hungry.  We went in because it looked cheap, but ended up having one of the best meals of the trip, and now a visit to Snow Garden is on the to-do list for every San Francisco visit.

I was on a trip to San Francisco with my family, anyways we ended up in Chinatown. My wife really wanted authentic Chinese food, so we thought we'd check Snow Garden out. WOW the food was so good!!!! We ordered Mongolian Beef, Sesame Chicken, Honey Walnut Prawns, and rice all around. All the dishes arrived hot and in no time at all, and after a while, I thought "Hey since we're here, let's order some Chicken Chow Mein" the waiter said "No problem" and it arrived lightening fast. I felt so bad for the waiter, because he was the only one working! People kept coming in, but he handled it with grace and ease. Next time we're in the City and craving great Chinese food, we will know exactly were to go!
Not fancy at all or big, but friendly and the food was good. I had egg foo young, which was really tasty.

Good food, good service! Had chicken chow mein, fried rice, others ate sesame chicken and chicken w black bean sauce. All great meals. Egg rolls (veggie) were so-so. I'd come back again, and recommend to others.
Food was delicious! But idk how I ended up paying $17 for a plate of food and a small wonton soup :/

We went in for lunch while walking around China town. Looked on yelp and saw it had good reviews. THEY LIED! For an appetizer we had fried dumplings. Not bad but the sauce was tangy and spicy. My wife ordered the beef with bean curd over rice. The beef tarred spoiled the bean curd was fine sauce was bland. I had the generals chicken. It was sweet and sour chicken rolled in a general sauce and was neither sweet nor spicy. We sent both dishes back and continued walking to find somewhere to eat.

Bland and greasy.  We had two lunch specials (sweet and sour and beef chow fun) and neither were good. The beef chow fun did not have much flavor and the meat seemed soggy. The pineapples in the sweet and sour had a strange taste. Would not return.

Great place, just what the fam and myself were looking for during our trip to SF! The BBQ pork fried rice was delicious as was the Sweet and Sour Pork and Sesame Chicken. Hole in the wall atmosphere was great and so was the service. Definitely visiting the Snow Garden again!
Small place with tile floor, a walk-in tourist clientele and old dilapidated decor.  I had a craving for greasy authentic Chinatown Chinese but this place wasn't great.

I was actually walking down Grant to another restaurant when this little hole-in-the-wall caught my eye. Rather than even check Yelp, I decided to be bold and walk in.  I ordered orange peel chicken and shrimp chow mein to go.  The cost was $24 and the cashier said she prefers cash to credit so I handed her $40.  She placed $6 change on the table.  I just stared and she didn't seem to see the problem.  I asked what the price was again and she finally "realized her mistake" and put down the remaining $10.  I'll guess I'll give them the benefit of the doubt on this one that it was an accident.  Anyway, the food was strikingly fast and the food was pretty good.  The chow mein was generously sized (though more shrimp and veggies would have been welcome) and the orange peel chicken was enormous.   The chicken was OK but I don't think I'd order it again.  I liked the chow mein better, and next time I might ask to pay extra to add chicken or beef and more veggies.  Overall I would give the food and service four stars, minus one for short changing me.
Visiting San Francisco for the first time. Was in the mood for Chinese so I stop by here.  The waiter was very reserved and antisocial which already created a bad environment..

My husband and I wanted good, authentic Chinese food on our evening trip to Chinatown. We settled on Snow Garden after reading Yelp reviews and were not disappointed! We ordered a combo dinner for two -- wonton soup, spring rolls, fried rice, cashew chicken and sweet/sour pork. Everything was sooo tasty. Best Chinese food ever. Definitely worth five stars. SG is a tiny place with no frills or glam and one unisex bathroom but, that being said, it's well worth the stop.

I expected better from a hole-in-the-wall on Chinatown's busy Grant Ave. My partner ordered Singapore noodles and I ordered shredded pork w/preserved cabbage.   The food was flavorless and disappointing.  The staff was efficient and friendly, but food was subpar.
food sucks, way overpirced. walk couple more blocks u can get better food for 1/3 the price. greedy owner dont go!

In the mood for Chinese food... Where better to go than Chinatown in downtown San Fran. This is my opinion of the following service 3/5, our server was a little overwhelmed with the lunch crowd but managed the one man show pretty ok. Cleanliness 2/5, a little soap & water will go a long way. Ambiance 3/5 definitely had the homey type feeling, but it was like being at my dirty aunts house that knows how to cook. Food presentation 3/5 simple as can be & straight to the point. Taste 4.5/5 this where I overlooked all the negatives and so-so's. To summarize this is a great place for take out, other than that u will have to be ok with being in a dive.

I discovered this place exploring china town in San Francisco I was looking around for some good egg rolls and I came apon this place  out of a few that I seen, I ordered 2 orders of egg rolls which you get 3 pieces each order.  Amazingly delicious and very crispy close to a spring roll and the sauce they give you with your order is sooooo good, next time I'm in San Fran china town I will stop in and eat here.

I'm giving this place 4 star because the owner is super nice, he is a one man team, he serves, he cooks and he busts the table. We had the roasted duck noodles soup which is not bad and also the beef and tomato with rice that is super yummy, and what makes it more yuuuummmy is the tenderness of the beef. Once I passed by Chinatown again, I would definitely come back here. =)

Chinatown is set up to attract tourists and their money.  Its tenants see out-of-towners coming a mile away, and are more than happy to cater to their expectations of what a Chinatown should be.  Impressive gate, check; illegible signs piled on top of each other, check; overpriced, mediocre restaurants that have only the appearance of authenticity, check.  The Chinatown in your mind is beckoning to you from Grant Avenue, and is ripe for the taking -- for the right price.
Food was tasteless. Got cold really fast. Some feels like it was microwaved. Seafood was barely thawed, definitely not up to the quality you would expect for San Francisco  .
The food was pretty good. The shrimp fried rice was my favorite.
The server isn't the fastest in the world but he was a nice guy. Food was good although the chow mane chicken was a little dry. General chicken was good

I saw the reviews on Yelp and decided to venture in. My food was quick in coming out and the waiter switched the beef in my dish to BBQ pork per my request.  It was okay food and portions were on the small side.  My pork chow fun was greasy and the pork tasted old.  Would not write home to Mom about this place!

Tried this place based on Yelp reviews - so much easier than just picking randomly, especially in Chinatown. Not much atmosphere, but we weren't really expecting that. Food was OK - certainly edible, but nothing special.  Prices were reasonable ($8-$10 for typical entrees) except for the eggrolls-3 for $6 -they were small and were mostly rolled wanton rappers.  We ordered 4 dishes: Lemon Chicken - it was OK, but not much lemon flavor.  Beef with Peppers - didn't taste like a Chinese dish or any version of this dish we've tried before.  The beef was soft and shredded (not slices of beef that would be expected) and was in a light brown gravy rather than a typical Chinese sauce.  It didn't taste bad, just different.  Orange Peel Beef - two out of three of us thought this was the best dish we had.  Shrimp Fried Rice - other Yelp reviews said this was great - it was good, but not great.  Had to pay an extra $1.50 for steamed rice - we ordered two and it came in small cups.  Considering how cheap steamed rice is, we thought that it was pretty skimpy.  Service was good (although they did bring the wrong order: Orange Peel Chicken instead of Orange Peel Beef, as ordered - the mistake was corrected immediately).  The hot tea was typically good, but we weren't offered a refill pot.  Soda is in cans.  They do have one restroom that is acceptable.  We were hungry so we ate everything, but we noticed people at other tables left good amounts of food on their plates.  Not a standout experience, but it was OK - no major complaints. As others have mentioned, if you want to pay by credit card, they tell you that they have to run the card next door.  If I hadn't read about this in other Yelp reviews, I would have been freaked out when they told me they were leaving with my card.  Weird, but at least they are trying to be accommodating since they obviously don't have the equipment to run the card in their restaurant.  Better than Cash Only, I guess, but still unsettling.
Good and priced right.
Good food, great prices. We ordered one neat and two bowls of steamed rice, more than enough for two.
The food served here is definitely not authentic.  They use too much salt and way too much sugar!  On the up side our waiter was good, but not good enough to make me go back.

Came here for lunch with a friend and had the braised tofu over rice dish.  The tofu was nice and tender, cooked perfectly.  The dish also had lots of bok choy and mushrooms and carrots.  The sauce was so so.  The size of the dish was very generous.  The place was pretty empty too so no waiting.

I was staying at a nearby hotel and wanted good but inexpensive Chinese food and this place was the bomb! It's a little iffy from the outside and even the inside was kind of a hole in the wall, but the food was great. I got the chicken egg foo young and it was light and flavorful and the gravy was great...my mouth still waters for it.  Sister got the grilled vegetables with prawns and she said it was some of the best she's eaten.  The chicken fried rice was to die for with it's yummy seasoning and fresh vegetables.  The total bill for  the three dinner dishes was just over $30.  I will definitely eat here again the next time I'm in San Francisco!

I ran across this restaraunt on accident while walking around the City by myself.  I absolutley loved it!  It was cheap, friendly service, and great food!  I decided to take my family there a month later.  They loved it also!  Very kid friendly and won't kill your wallet to feed the entire family.  I will definitely return. :-)
Definitely more like 3.5 stars.

I ordered the beef and broccoli dish here; maybe I had something else in mind but it didn't live up to my expectations of how it should have been. It was kind of bland and lacked the savory flavor I was hoping it would have. The service was pretty good though, and the sound of an old Chinese man playing an erhu outside added an interesting effect to my Chinatown experience.
ooooh, Chinese food the real kind, not like Panda Express.

One of my must stop at restaurants on chinatown, its a little hole in the wall place with only one server, but its reasonably clean and the food is really good.  they've got to go next door to run your credit card so thats different.  I like this place a lot better than some of the bigger restaurants that are out handing out  menus.  Low key and simple.  Not a lot of seating and there always seems to be people in here but there always seems to be space too.

I came here for lunch and ordered an orange peel chicken dish off the regular menu (it wasn't on the lunch menu) and thought it was alright. It seemed excessively bright coloured and I like for the peel to be visible in that dish.

We had an amazing late night dinner in Chinatown this week. We are from Washington State and just in town of one night. We headed to Chinatown as soon as we got to town about 8pm. The gentleman from Snow Garden was about to close for the evening. He generously let us in for dinner and the meal was awesome. We had great service and will fondly remember our delicious meal at Snow Garden.

Insanely strong and delicious Mai Tai.  Kung Pao chicken was bland and disappointing.  The private booths, drinks, and location are really the best things about this restaurant.  For flavorful food, I suggest you look elsewhere.

Wanted to try this place because it's been around for so long. The place looked run down. We came here for some dim sum but decided to order very little just to get a taste of the food. We ordered pork dumpling, shrimp dumpling, and chicken wings. The food tasted like to go dim sum. It was pretty bad, would not come here for dim sum but maybe to try out their dinner dishes. The waiters were very nice, but the food was not great.
I will be the first to admit that I have not had  authentic Chinese food like this before .. just what most Americans are used to at our usual take-out places.
Bad food!
The decor is fun but we really paid a premium for the equivalent of greasy Chinese buffet food.
Clay pot seafood combo was not very good. Jf stuck here try potstickers. Nice ambiance. About all is going for it.

Made me sick. Literally.  Held a family birthday dinner here in one of the charming private booths.  Had super service and enjoyed the Peking Duck as well as other items now forgotten.  The next day I had a luxury flight to Europe which was ruined by the constant need to go use the facilities, thanks to the previous night's meal.  I do wonder what their health inspection report is.  This occurred in August of this year.  Memorible, but not in the right way.  BTW, our family is part Chinese.

This is my second time here. The corn soup is great and the lemon chicken is okay. As far as service the waiter forgot our water two times. But was able to provide tea. I had to ask for water for the third time. The bill was reasonable. The front desk lady is super nice. She validated my parking saving $6 which is why I rated this a three star instead of two.

The restaurant has a old-time China feel to it and the private rooms looks interesting. You walk in and you feel like you're going to enjoy the experience you're about to have. That being said. This was one of the closest Chinese restaurant near I was staying and I chose the wrong place to dine. The dim sum was just salty and and the soup was below mediocre. Chao fun was extremely oily and it didn't even taste right. If I knew better I would have gone to another place.  To be honest it's a tourist trap and we fell for it.

My husband and I just held our wedding banquet at Far East Cafe. You might not be able to tell on the outside, but Far East has an extremely spacious second-floor. They can hold up to 64 tables= 640 guests. Which worked out for our initial guest list of 600. Fortunately, because we had picked one of the most popular dates to get married and considering that it was a holiday weekend, we were able to cut down to 46 tables. The manager is very friendly and honest, he was able to work with us on our menu which we had made quite a few changes. You cannot beat their banquet menu price listed on their website.
I just ate a wrostest dim sum meal I never had in my whole life.....and the dim sum here are over price too....don't come here and waste your money.
Forgot about this one when I went to SF.
I've been here twice--both times it was great. However--it's a bit dirty and dingy.
Ate here for lunch last week solely for their curtained booths!  Reminds me of a place in Florida when I was little.

OMG I wrote my review and gave this place a 4 star until I realized it was for the wrong place! So deleted that and now here's my "real" review for this place, the pictures are for a different review, can't seem to figure out how to delete them so please disregard pics!!

I went last night with a friend from China, and it was horrible! We ordered the Ying Yang Fried rice, and it was goopy and tasteless. The won ton soup was cold, the bbq rib appetizer, small and yuk, and we never got our soy sauce chicken dish, the service? What service? Horrible experience, will never go back.
$500 per table for wedding banquet. Ordinary and bland dishes with no dessert nor fried rice and chow mein. Killer stair with no elevator. Way overpriced and under delivered. Stay far far away.

My girl and I are from the east coast and were looking for some good Chinese food in Frisco.  We were told to go to house of Nanking.  When we got their the line was an hour wait.  We decided to travel thru Chinatown and stumbled upon Far East.
Food was ok

Packed. No service. Charged me $3/glass for water--no notice. Fatty beef and broccoli, egg soup consistency of mucus, day old Peking duck. Thought the crowd indicated a solid find...seems like just a bus drop off point.

This restaurant was highly recommended by two different Chinatown shopkeepers, so I decided to take my two friends visiting from Michigan, who wanted to experience an 'authentic' Chinese meal.  We ordered the dim sum platter and two family meals because of the selection provided.  The food was old and tasted like it was on the verge of spoiling--I could not eat it. There is no flavor to their dishes and I can't put into words how awful it was. Hostesses are friendly, but service goes downhill fast.  Waiter service was very poor and the restaurant wasn't even that busy.  I would make another choice and not recommend this restaurant.  Stay away!

We wanted to eat in Chinatown and happened upon this place. Unlike what was noted in some of the other reviews, the service was excellent.   We ordered the family meal for the two of us. We weren't fans of the Peking Duck but that might have been our palates and not the dish, but everything else was delightful.

Did not have a very good experience here... Service was sub-par, better food found in Cerritos for a much better price. To top it off, they charged us a 20% tip for our party of 12. It wouldn't have been an issue if we had received service worthy of it! Should stayed Far from this cafe!

The average 3 star rating is mostly for the service not the food; the food is outstanding, but the service sucks. These guys try to get you out of there with your plates still half full and continue to bug you with "Are you done, Are you done?".
Wow I was so sadly disappointed with the service and food. We were drawn in by the large party of chinese coming out. We figured it must be authentic and popular with such a large party eating here.

We have eaten in this restaurant in the past and so there was no reason not to return when we were in the neighborhood.  Never again.  The service was extremely slow, the pot stickers were cold, the chow mien just ok, and the shrimp dim sum we ordered as an appetizer came 25 minutes later, as we were ready to leave.

As usual I have patronized this restaurant for over 3 years and usually found it to be an enjoyable experience. However, seems that since the President dined here and gave it a big boost, their service has gone down the drain. They seem to think that we need their food and have become too confident and now have chosen to ignore their customers.  We reserved our table in January and when we arrived they gave us a hard time. To make it short they needed the seats for other people too, so take it or leave it attitude and not what you ask for, what we give you. Smaller incidents occurred as we dined. The food was good, not excellent anymore. But the big problem was as we were winding up the dinner, they wanted the table back for other customers so they asked us when we were going to leave.  They refused us the complementary desert because they didn't have time and again asked us to leave as others were waiting.  We complained to the management who gave us little notice, basically showing us the door.  We usually have a party of 6 or more.  But, no longer, we will find another fine dining restaurant down the street.  Sorry!!
Came for a fundraising dinner for Our Children Our City. Picked up dinner on my way home after this dinner. Enough said?
The interior was nicely decorated and the service was pretty good. I was disappointed with what I ordered though, the combo appetizer. It was flavorless; I would order differently next time.
The decor could do with an upgrade - and the toilet!! But the food was delicious and authentic.
Ok food. Small portions for large groups. Nice authentic ambiance. Being in Chinatown I expected more but I have actually had better food in strip malls in LA.
The food was really tasty, but I am sure it is possible to find a best place for less expensive. The average price was $15-16, and interesting complete menus were between 20 and 30.
Was walking through Chinatown, drawn by the Decor. The personal was very kind and helpful. The atmosphere entertaining.

I can't tell you how many times I've gone "exploring" and walked into somewhere looking for an authentic experience and ended up eating some not-so-delicious strange food that I'm not even completely sure is what, I think, I ordered.
I was craving Chinese and was walking around Chinatown hoping to find a good place to scratch that itch.

Best Dim Sum. Enjoyed every bite. It is more traditional Chinese food so if Panda Express is what you want, you won't find it here. Staff is awesome. Wilson the waiter is taking English as a second language and is great to talk to.

We rocked up at 9:50pm and were ushered inside with "we're closing in 10 minutes but there's still time". We were seated straight away, ordered in 3 minutes and served less than 5 minutes later. Incredible.

I don't know why we ended up at this place. My boyfriend and I usually don't go to anything with less than 4 Yelp stars lol this star rating must have gone down since September '13 : P. We were tired and hungry--I'll blame it on that!
The food was commercial and tasteless with huge chunks of onions and vegetable cut into everything. I was really disappointed with the quality and flavors!
An enjoyable experience. I thought that Chinese food was good in TJ & Mexicali, but this appeared much more authentic. We had & recommend the Kung Pao Chicken, Duck Noodle Soup, & fried rice.
Hole in da wall delicious Vietnamese food. Definitely bang for the buck.
Combo Banh Mi is good, Pho and Bun Bo Hue are tasty, their price can not be beaten by anywhere else and people are nice. What else can you ask for?
Used to be good, now it's all downhill after reopening at this new location.

I grew up on Little Paris sandwiches and sweet drinks.  When it closed for the construction of the Stockton Street subway, I was saddened.  We went out to the city and lo and behold, it re-opened at a different location!  Yay!
When I'm out with the fam bam, we make sure to eat at the cheapest place possible.

I am a fan of Little Paris. Staff here is nice, friendly, and helpful. My favorite thing to get here is the vermicelli plates. For $3.50, you get a slab of meat, a plate of vermicelli, and an egg roll. Egg roll is often very chewy because it's been sitting out (we all know it's best when it's straight out of the fryer). It's a quick and cheap fix so I can't complain.

I like the new location. It is still very cheap and has some pretty yummy options. However, it's not the best place for Banh Mi or imperial rolls to me anymore. Something has changed about the quality.
Avoid. One of the worst Vietnamese sandwiches I have ever eaten. I am writing this mid-meal.. It was so bad that I felt the need to take my phone out now to write the review.

I grew up eating at Little Paris's old location a couple of blocks away. Until last year, the Vietnamese deli closed because of the construction of the new Central Subway, which will hopefully be complete in 2019.
Though the space is a little cramped, the food here is amazing and the price is super affordable. I use to come here once a week when I had school in North Beach
This place is my childhood, mang. Even though this is a new location, the menu and set up is still pretty much the same.

I would rate their sandwiches actually below average compared to similar shops in the East Bay or South Bay, but this is SF so to survive the higher cost of doing business here I guess they have no choice to to price their sandwiches slightly higher and make it slightly smaller - seems like less meat in the middle compare to other Vietnamese sandwich places. $3.50 for a Vietnamese sandwich isn't bad but I just wish they didn't make it so small as I don't quite get full from it as oppose to the full size Vietnamese sandwiches from similar shops in San Jose.

5 stars because Little Paris is literally my childhood--like every other CT kid, especially those who went to Cameron House, aw yeaaaaaah. So yes, this review is kinda skewed--ok, it's EXTREMELY skewed. But this place is still a solid establishment from which you should definitely try.

This has got to be the best spot I've been to in Chinatown, ironic since it's Vietnamese. The Pho us 5.50, Sandwiches are 3.50 and there are lunches to go. They sell homemade pate, fresh ice coffee, coffee beans, the place is AMAZING!  They keep the shop spotless and the service is top notch, super friendly.

I LOVE Little Paris.  I'm from Los Angeles but everytime I'm in town, I always make a stop at Little Paris.  It's your typical Vietnamese shop but what I love about it is that the food, menu, etc is as straightforwad as you can get.  No gimmick.  They stick to the real deal and it's just like eating food from home!

Just your average Vietnamese shop in the heart of San Francisco Chinatown that serves banh mi and pho. Their pho was just okay, not horrible nor memorable. One thing that both me and my boyfriend enjoyed was their banh mi but in a croissant instead of your typical French bread! It was delicious which was something I wasn't expecting. I think the buttery-ness of the croissant gave it that little something extra to make it taste extravagant.

Boo. Nothing redeeming about this place, except maybe for its varied menu and its cheap, cheap price. But you get what you pay for -- pre-made, obviously not fresh sandwiches that are filled with wilted vegetables and dry meat. Bread is bad and almost stale. Never again.

EW! This place was horrible! I felt like some Banh Mi, and this was pretty close... so why not? I walked in and there was trash all over the floor (hmm). I ordered the chicken Banh Mi and a bubble tea. Not only was the bubble tea disgusting and watered down, but my Banh Mi was literally just chicken and onions between two hard pieces of bread! There was honestly nothing but chicken and onions inside. So I continued to quietly eat my food as the server lady told me "Excuse me miss, but can you hurry up to finish? My friend is coming and needs a seat." Umm WHAT? I am the customer, who gave you my money for your crappy food. I will eat my damn food as slow as I want! Terribly rude, dirty, and NOT fresh whatsoever. DO NOT COME HERE!

I tried their combination Vietnamese sandwich last week for the first time and it was yucky ! The pink meat in the sandwich really repels me from wanting to eat it , but I was hungry and was really curious how it tasted cause everyone told me Little Paris is great. The sandwich was lacking the fillings and it had way too much onions in it. It felt like eating a sandwich of onions with some meat texture. Right after I finished eating the sandwich my upper lip grew an itchy white-ish bump. I'm not sure if they are clean or not... never gonna be back

As a kid, I used to think the bbq pork and bbq beef sandwiches from Little Paris were the best thing in the world. However, as I've gotten older and have had much better bahn mi, the Little Paris sandwiches aren't so cool anymore.
Disappointed.  If only they can move back to the old location and kept everything the same.

I have been trying to find another Ba Le establishment that I enjoyed eating in Honolulu.  I have been away for a very long time and trying to find my beloved steam pork sandwich has been tough.  I had one of their sandwiches - a bit too dry as compared to what I have had in the past.  I ordered their chicken pho and it wasn't bad.  The seating reminds me of eating in Hong Kong in the neighborhood where you share a table which is something we did not have in Honolulu.  Still trying to find the flavors of Honolulu in the city.
Sandwich bread is harrrrrrd at 5:30pm.
I'm glad that they decided to reopen at another location and also still in Chinatown!
Just tried Little Paris today since the closing of the original location. Doesn't seem to be the same as far as the Chicken sandwich goes...
Another vietnamese comfort food spot is always welcomed in my opinion especially one that apparently has such nostalgic appeal for many folks in the Chinatown that remember it fondly from yesteryear.

Though I'm happy that this shop reopened and that they have a much larger and well-organized space, it seems as if their sandwiches are not as good as they were when they were at their old location.  The french bread roll that they use now is smaller and not as soft as the ones they used before and they don't fill it up as much as they used to with all the goodies (Vietnamese ham, pate spread, pickled carrots, pickled turnips, jalapeno pepper, cilantro, etc.).  The new sandwich is significantly drier and I find that when I bring it home, I have to add loads more mayonnaise to make it enjoyable.  Not sure, but I think their prices are a little higher too.  Their customer service has improved though.  The staff is polite, quick and efficient, which makes a difference in my book.
Food is good.but today's wear brown clothes waitress is too bad!!!Check out our consulting amount. She said, "do you think that don't need to tax?"

My memories of Vietnamese sandwiches from Little Paris have been ruined.  I ordered a fancy pork banh mi for myself and a BBQ pork banh mi for my mom.  We both took a bite and said... "where's the filling?!"  I don't know about you, but I think what makes a great Vietnamese sandwich is the nice amount of pickled carrots, onions, and radishes with a couple thin slices of meat.  I had three matchstick sized carrots, and a couple slivers of onions and radishes in mine.  We opted out for the cilantro as we both don't like it, but there probably wouldn't have been any anyways. I might as well should have just ordered a loaf of french bread..
Little Paris looks sparten clean here. didn't see/didn't look for menu. just went for the banh mi sandwiches.

Unfortunately this is a love/hate review. I loved this place cause it was always there for me when I was growing up and had only $2 in my pocket, which was too many times to keep track of. I would always be able to go and get a sandwich back when it was a few blocks up on Stockton St. and only $1.50. I grew to make cordial friends with the counter people since its family owned and ran. They were each other's cousins ,brothers, sisters, mom, dad, aunts or uncles and the young generation were always nice to me. The older generation had customer service issues sometimes. The sandwiches were always great and never skimpy. The hate part is having to review it with a disappointment. Years later(now) the sandwiches are $3.50 and less sandwich meat. I barely had any pickled carrots (which is my fav) and they even skimped on the pate. They had a large variety of packaged meals to go as shown on their picture menu board but yet, They didn't have my first choice when I asked for it, they didn't even have my 2nd choice when I disappointedly had to come up with a second choice. So I had to settle for a 3rd choice. And this was during the middle of the day not the end of the day as it may happen or expected to happen.  The price is higher than its worth but I will probably still go back in support of old times and the family who still owns and runs it. Why should you go? Cause the food is not bad and you're hungry.
review is for sandwich only.

This place has been around for decades and is a Chinatown institution as far as food goes. It's popular with kids and old timers alike.The new location is pretty cramped and crowded but you can usually find a seat towards the back somewhere. They crank out some of the best Banh Mi in the city besides a few of the Vietnamese joints on Larkin. They have a long counter/fridge running the length of the store filled with different meats, pre wrapped snacks and groceries. So Little Paris sort of functions as an eatery but also a neighborhood grocery with a lot of specialty items.  Im a big fan of the barbecue pork sandwich. The pork is thin sliced, lean, and seasoned well. Very smokey and savory which goes well with the minimalist approach to Bahn Mi at LP. The other elements are good as well ( cilantro, pickled veggies) but lets be straight up the pork shines through as the star of the show. The french bread is decent but not killer, gets the job done though.
Love the sandwiches...
There's some minor changes in their sandwiches now
reopen place. Price reasonable. Sandwich was okay. Meat Marinated.

December 30th 2012 - I came here with my mom and ate some pho it was pretty good i give that a 4 star and i also bought their Vietnamese sandwiches (chicken ) it was not even good I felt that their quality of Their chicken Vietnamese sandwich went down hill they have lost their passion , it was not as good as 3years ago I rather have my vietnamese sandwiches from lee's and little Saigon !

I was beyond disappointed when their previous location was closed, they moved to the Sunset district, I've never been to that location before, hardly go out to that district. When I was grocery shopping with my mom, she asked if I wanted one and told me they opened up a new location in Chinatown! Their sandwiches are just as delicious as ever. $3.25 for a really good filling sandwich? One of the best deals!! Of course, nowadays, they are a bit more skimpy on the portions but nevertheless, just as delicious as ever! The store looks similar to the previous location, semi-narrow and tables if you walk further in. The store is cash only.

Came back after their grand opening, now being on Stockton instead of Powell St. I got their combination, pork and their beef, the combination is the best. The sandwiches are lacking; the bread is a lower quality.

Bun bo hue time freezing!! I got a large and it cost me $7.05, that's expensive for Little Paris. The soup was tasty, I like the way they slice the pig feet into slices, easier to eat, some parts tender some parts dry though. Good amount of meat and soup but downfall, had So little noodles! It was all soup! Also for a few hours after my mouth was sooo dry! That means alot of salt or msg.

Wong Lee is known to be the sister bakery of Good Mong Kok on Stockton. If you want to the avoid the line at Good Mong Kok then Wong Lee is the choice to go. I come here for the usual Shu Mai and Har Gow as they are very big for their size and the wrap is made at the right texture. I am also a fan of their BBQ Pork Buns as they are also good to get. They also offer Pork with Thousand Year Egg porridge here but it was a bit watered down when I got it. They also offer boba tea here but it is not the best since they do not specialize in making drinks. The service here is very quick so you have to be fast in making your decision on what to order or else the server will jump to the next person in line until you are ready. Another tip is to order in Chinese or bring a friend who can speak Chinese as they can misunderstand what you want from time to time. Overall, this shop is also surprisingly clean considering it being located in Chinatown.

I was pretty disappointed in this place.  When I came in, there was one customer being helped by an attendant and another attendant standing nearby.  The 2nd attendant immediately asked for my order.  I ordered a honey dew milk tea, har gow, chicken bao and custard.

Wow! First off...we only spent $11 to feed the whole family. It was by far the best tasting dim sum we had thus far. I just can't believe how cheap and good the good was. It's an in and out place so be quick and know what you want because the other customers in line will jump in front if you....but wow...$11 though!
$2 for a big jok!! It's not watery either!! I always get the fish or 1000 year old egg with pork jok!

There were a couple people in line in front of me but it took forever because they ordered some type of fancy milk tea and there was only one person navigating behind the counter. Despite my annoyance, it gave me time to peer into the glass cases, but I already knew what I wanted: an egg tart. 90 cents later I was consuming layers of crust (which prompted this whole conversation about how things taste way better with butter instead of shortening), and shiny glazed custard that had a good texture but needed to be injected with some pizzazz. The whole thing was relatively greasy and flavorless. It wasn't the worse I had, but I do know of some bakeries that do it WAY better a block or two away. Can't imagine their dim sum is going to make it long, but their milk tea business might.

The usually I was looking for Golden Gate Bakery to buy an egg tart, yet they were on vacation.  Booo!  So I was wondering the streets of Chinatown looking for a place to make my purchase.  It seemed promising, their prices are cheap.  But I just wasn't in love with their food.  Lady did understand English, so I didn't have any issues with language barrier.  Just looking for more flavor out of the tarts.  It was a little on the runny side.  Going to keep on trying other places.
They got Chinese Deep Fried Breadstick, youtiao, for $1.25 and fresh ho fun for $1/lb - love getting this to cook at home.
Mantow (Man-tow) was a staple in my childhood and it's been YEARS since I've had one so when we went to Chinatown, I told my mom... I really, really, really want some mantow.
Walked by this place just as I finished eating dim sum across the street, and wow all the bright yellow egg tarts drew me in!

I happened upon this place early one morning when I was walking around Chinatown looking for an open bakery. I was really looking for egg custards (dan tat) but they didn't have any. I figured I'd try a few other things since I was already there and the prices seemed very reasonable. I got the sesame balls that are filled with red bean. They were quite good and fairly cheap at 3 for $1.50. I also though I'd try the pork bun and egg bun. Each were only $0.75. The pork bun was good. The bun to filling ratio was spot on! The egg bun was also very good- not too sweet. I got breakfast for 2 for $3, out the door! Nice.

Great place for cheap dim sum and chinese baked goods. I usually get the cocktail buns and siopao because it seems that they are constantly making them throughout the day and are always hot and fresh when I order them. I also love the green onion bun and the tiny noodle chowmein which is usually $2 for 1.5lbs! Crazy!
Amazing dim sum for great prices. Most items come in 3's. You'll want to try everything. The steamed BBQ pork buns are excellent. The shrimp dumplings are good but worth skipping.

Okay gone here this morning.. All the food looks really good in there..bought 2 pounds of vegi soy chow mein.. N 1order of fried wontons n 2 orders of fried tofu.. Jus heat up some chow mein.. One bite of it gross me out..!! So so much MSG..  My tongue and lip went whack !! Omg did I spell it right ?? Had to throw away the whole box..now I'm scare to try the wontons !!!
Cheap Chinese baked goods and dim sum.
So cheap!!! Huge portion for $1.80. We got the rice roll & fried taro to try.
The front of the store looked nice and the food looked delicious from behind the glass counter... Sadly, the taste was quite disappointing.

Loved this place when it was Yong Kee. They have cleaned up the front of the store and looks cleaner. But the "cooking areas" are still questionable but in the past, I was happy that they were much better with the turnover for the products.

Ok it looks like someone got the memo and rescinded the stupid and illegal 10 bag tax.  I know I swore up an down I was never coming here again since I got into a disagreement with the clerk about the tax but my mother wanted their homemade won tons (they come frozen so yes you do have to cook them).

Love love this place i will come here everytime i go to chinatown. The fried shrimp dumplings, and the crab rangoon is so good i had it two days in a row. The chive and shrimp dumplings are also good. The sesame red bean balls were stuffed full. It also helps that the menu is in both english and chinese and the ladies behind the counter are more than willing to help....happy dim sum eating!

Maybe people used to dim sum are used to these prices, but I was shocked at how low the cost was for 3 pork steamed buns and a mango bubble tea - less than $4.  What a nice surprise and everything tasted quite good.  Thank god I was doing a lot of walking around to work off all that sugar in the drink!
Was the food good? It was decent. Portions were a tadbit smaller than usual, but that's not the reason why I want to steer clear from this place.

It looked promising because it is clean and bright, unlike the real Chinatown places. I measure dim sum places by their har gow. Well, the har gow was smaller (I know size isn't everything) and there was less shrimp than expected.

I don't walk the streets of Chinatown as often as I used to so thank goodness for the reviews from two long-time Yelp friends who alerted me about Wong Lee.  In the past couple of months I've made a few visits each time trying different things, and although there are specific items I would not order again I must admit that I've actually liked the majority of the things I've tried.

after delicious dim sum we were still hungry so we happened to pass by wong lee and it looked promising because of all the people inside. looked at the bakery glass and saw my brown char siu bao but it was in room temprature. i was looking for a place that still had it steaming or in a warming oven but i did see they had some soy sauce noodles.
Ordered food: BBQ Pork bun; crab rangoon (4 pieces)
Picked up the following recently:

3 pieces of dim sum for $1.80! The siu mai (pork dumpling) was good but the other two pieces were cold even though one of the employees literally brought it out to the counter right before I bought it. This place just opened a month ago so I'm determined to come back and try their other dishes.

We accidentally came upon this place and we were definitely glad we found it.  Most of the dim sum pieces are 3 for under $2. The size of the buns are pretty big so you get your money's worth. Another plus is that the menu is in both English and Chinese. The bottom line is that it's cheap and a good take out place if you're on the go.

Wong Lee, a takeout dim sum business, has taken over the space of one of the best chicken bun makers in SF, Yong Kee. They have steamed chicken buns, plus dim sum, baked buns, sponge cake, tapioca drinks, etc. The basic dim sum (e.g., shui mai and other dumplings) is 3 pieces for a $1.80, slightly more expensive than average. The tapioca drinks are made with powdered mixes.
Did not know that this bakery had been opened under a new name. It looked very nice compared to the old bakery that used to be here.
My mom finally decided to check this place out yesterday and get some bread for the family.
I stopped by this morning and picked up:

Formerly the Yung kee located on Jackson St. in the heart of Chinatown. Its a modern dim sum -bakery place which also sells milk tea drinks etc.The baked goods are above par and the dim sum is just par . 3 for 1.80 etc . I would come for the baked goods and if i wanted dim sum I'll probably past.
WongLee set up it's counter like golden gate bakery.: showcase items just a few steps inside the door. room for only a few patrons inside at a time. only one or 2 customers can be serviced at a time

Had no idea what this place was called since the name was in Chinese characters. There was a line and people seemed really excited, so I joined in. Their baked goods were huge, fresh and golden, so I couldn't resist a BBQ pork bun. I normally don't buy those, but I'm glad I did. The bread was fluffy, sweet, and really good. The filling was plentiful and on the sweet side. Good barbecue pork filling.

In the past week, I've visited twice, partly because of their current grand opening special for 99-cent bubble milk tea, partly because of their delicious, cheap dim sum offerings. Let's just say that when my mom agrees that a Chinese restaurant is awesome, I'm not one to debate it since she's an excellent cook of Chinese cuisine.

I love this place , I started coming here when I was maybe around 4-5 (or from what my parents told me) and that was almost 13 years ago. This place holds a lot of childhood memories, but what I love about this place is really the cheap and affordable food. If you only have $5 , you're good to go ! As I grew up , I started coming here less and less and then I completely stopped due to my extremely busy schedule but from time to time I would always come back and reminisce . Great place to take your kids , the taste and service hasn't changed.

I've been here for the past year and it never disappoints. The prices are really cheap for breakfast and lunch. I order a special and it came with hot milk tea,soup,and garlic bread for $5.95. I would definitely recommend this place for a nice breakfast or lunch.
I think I got ripped off?

Yep, the food (breakfast in my case) is cheap, but the service absolutely sucks. Ten to fifteen minutes to place an order, same and then some to pay. If all you want is cheap, then here you go. If you need even the barest modicum of service, stay away.

I've been coming to this place for at least 6 or 7 years now, and I've seen it change throughout the years. For example, they've cleaned and painted up the walls, changed out the chairs, put in some new lighting to make the place brighter, and made the bathrooms at least somewhat more attractive. But that stuff is just fluff; neither the food nor the service have changed, and that's for the better.
My parents and I come here often for breakfast. It is definitely a hole in the wall and not a place where you would expect 5 star food nor 5 star service.
Food is not bad at all for what you paid for in SF! Cantonese style and old school cafe that I really missed when I was in Hong Kong. I am glad that I was able to bring back good memories!

My go-to place in Chinatown for a good, cheap breakfast. A simple eggs, sausage, and toast breakfast is about three to five dollars depending on the variation. I always get set C, steak with fried eggs for $4.50. Two stars off due to horrible service, I'm always kept waiting whenever I eat here. But you can't expect that much, it is Chinatown after all.
New Regent Cafe aka Sunrise Cafe has dirt cheap pricing 8a.m. to 11 a.m. (.e. 2 eggs, sausages, toast, etc. 2.95) 11 a,m, it's regular pricing.
Hole in the Wall but what an amazing hole in the wall it is.
I always come here with my mom for breakfast. Quick service, can get busy if you come too late. I usually order either the steak meal or porkchop over ramen.
Little hidden gem in Chinatown.  It's decor is stuck in the early 80's but hey, we're here for the food and not the wall colors.
cheap,simple!

There are a number of dining establishments that serves breakfast and it is generally served until 10:30 am or 11:00 am depending on which dining establishment you go to. However, there are diners like IHOP and Denny's serve breakfast all day. The breakfast menu here is very good since they have around 10-20 choices for breakfast combos which does seem very flexible. I'd definitely make a pit stop here for breakfast if I am in Chinatown!

I love this place when I was little and I still love this place it just sucks that I can't wake up early enough for their breakfast specials that ends at 11am. You don't come here for eggs and sausage or steak, you come here for their noodle / ramen! Satay pork chop over ramen is my favorite and they have really good hong kong milk tea too! My advice to you is not to get their watered down orange juice, its terrible!

after going there for a week with my honey.we were waiting when PLOP a cockroach fell onto the table OMG thankfully our food hadn't arrived yet but that REALLY gave me the ICKS. when i was paying the tab i had a nickle and 5 pennies for the $7.10 bill the waitress tells me WE DO NOT ACCEPT PENNIES and left the change there. WTF?! i guess my money is not good there she had a nasty bad attitude and i AM chinese & speak it fluently but she was rude! rude! rude!!!
$3.60 for coffee, 2 pancakes, 2 sausages, and 1 egg. Quick. Good service.

Let's start this off COMPLETELY honest.  This restaurant is in Chinatown.. Chinatown isn't the cleanest place to be.. therefore, this restaurant isn't SUPER CLEAN.  But you get what you pay for.  The breakfast & lunch is really good.  IF you are EVER in Chinatown.. give this place a chance. :)

This place is a crappy Hong Kong cafe.  The breakfast is cheap.  2 eggs and ham or sausage and bread is about $2.99 and comes with coffee or HK style milk tea.  If you're looking for cheap, this is the place to go to.  But I would've liked some hashbrowns with my breakfast.  My mom ordered noodles, and they don't even give you chop sticks to eat the noodles with.  Just a fork and spoon.  How do you eat noodle soup with a fork and spoon?

Not sure how you can beat an excellent breakfast for TWO adults for less than $10 (not counting tip). I've been coming here with Mom for years now, and it's always been consistently tasty. We always get two orders of the satay chicken rice noodles and then an order of either the pork chop rice noodles or preserved veggie/pork strips rice noodles. The latter order is obviously because we're fatties and the ladies who wait tables there have gotten used to the fact that there is no third person to show up to eat. :P
Aw, I liked New Regent, and I'm saddened that they aren't doing so well here.
This review is strictly for breakfast which typically starts at 7:30am (beware there might be a slight wait during the weekends, even at around 8:30am).
I eat here all the time,and I always order the same several plates. Never get sick of the garlic salmon though
Only thing this place offers is very very cheap price. If you are really on a budget, I guess this place is all right. But, I do not like this place.

So my dad used to take me here when I was younger. I loved their breakfast menu because it was SUPER cheap. I had pretty bad experiences with their drinks, so stay away from them. I do like their instand noodles with pork chop and egg. It comes with toast too and all for a cheap price of $2.75. They also have pancakes eggs and bacon/sausage for a more affordable price than most places. I would recommend this restaurant if you have a high tolerance for not-so-clean food because just about every time i went here, i was running for the bathroom not too long after (im forgiving and just hoped it will change the next time i go)
How come every place I go to gets two stars?

My intended target restaurant for lunch was House of Nanking. But the restaurant was packed like sardines and my empty-stomach had to settle elsewhere. I chose the New Regent cafe, in which it is located not too far away from the House of Hunan.

I popped into Banana House in the middle of a weekday lunch rush.  I've had this place, along with several other Belden Place establishments, bookmarked for months.  Although they were busy, I was determined to tough it out and try their lunch takeout.
Not worth it..! Rice $2 small serving of entree $13- why so pricey? What's so special?!?!
I knew I shouldn't have ignored the 3-stars on yelp.

I gave this place another chance since my friend was craving thai food. I told her no, but that was the closest place for thai. My before experience was gross. Gross customer service, gross food. Anyways, it has not changed, the water is not even cold, the waitress takes forever to bring me hot sauce. (Isn't the hot sauce suppose to be on the table anyways?) Now, the waitress doesn't even say "thank you" when we leave.  It's still a no go. Still giving us the check in the middle of eating!
