If you are big on being treated nicely, great customer service, and having and getting respect, don't go here!

I got their Papaya salad for lunch today. It was super liquidy. It had lumps of sugar or jaggery or something like that. The lettuce was soggy(ew!). The shrimp tasted a little stale. The salad was also very stinky. I have a cup of cinnamon tea on my desk to get rid of that smell.
We get there on a Sunday afternoon. The restaurant nearly empty. We sat and wait for the next 15 min for someone to come get our orders and bring us water. Nothing. So we left.

Came here for lunch with my coworkers and since we had a large group (party of 7), we got a table in the basement. I had the duck curry with brown rice which was decent, although the coconut juice left much to be desired.
I went to this place for a to-go dinner order. It was very empty but several people were waiting for their take-away food.

I probably should have verified when my order for one entree and a Thai Iced tea came out to ~$18, but they gave me shrimp instead of the beef I ordered (which right off the bat was an extra three dollars). Didn't bother asking them to fix my order because I had waited at least 20 minutes for take out.

this place is a DUMP.  it constantly smells like bleach or piss and if you sit downstairs it is like a dungeon.  two thai places around fidi closed and sucks that this place is open now.  always check your credit card statements because they double charged me.  place is totally shady.

I was so hungry and there aren't a lot of options in the area on a Sunday afternoon. I start digging into my food. And as I start digging more into my steamed rice, I see a little black thing. Hungry, I pick it out and toss it, and continue to grub. But no, I dig further down the container, and black pebble like things throughout the container. They don't clean their food properly. Gross! Waste of money!

Ew. The people are nice but the food is disgusting. I lived in Thailand for a while and am a huge Thai food fan - this is not good Thai food. Ordered the pad se ew - and it was burnt. Pieces of black char on the noodles and veggies. The summer rolls were literally pieces of tofu in this weird rice roll that was kind of grainy - not the typical rice wrap you'd see for summer rolls. Disgusting, I couldn't even eat it. And they charged me $3 extra for shrimp ($11 for summer rolls when you can get it for $6-7 anywhere else with shrimp included). They forgot to give me the rice with the pad ka prow....the only thing that was good (very good) was the mango with sticky rice.
I came on a Monday during lunch hour (12:30) and ordered take out.  It was bustling but they still got my order out in a very reasonable amount of time.
first time being there for lunch on weekday. pad kee maw with seafood (shrimp & mussels)
I had the banana house ground chicken special on recommendation. A bit different than what I've seen on typical Thai menus which is nice. Taste was good. Not the cleanest place though.
3 stars average sounds about right for this place.
Staff was very polite and helpful. Very cramped place so get cozy!

Good, quick service. Tasty food and reasonable price. In the Finanical District, Chinatown area, Banana House is a good option (and costs less than the "fancy" chain Thai restaurant that has bastardized Thai food and has much higher prices).

Pretty good Thai place on Kearny, Banana House offers food I usually crave for dinner at lunchtime. The restaurant is cute: white table clothes atop little tables, wood walls, big windows. The wait staff is nice, fast, and attentive.

Kind of just average. I ordered my usual Thai dish - pad see ew. I quite enjoyed the soup that they served with it which was pretty unconventional for Thai places. It was some type of onion/vegetable blend that was pretty tasty. The pad see ew wasn't as flavorful as I would have liked, but it wasn't as bad as many others that I've tried before. The chicken was very tender and they were generous with the vegetables in the dish. The decor and service were both average.
Setting isn't the most trendy or updated but the food is excellent and the price is good. We got the Green Curry Beef and Pad Kee Mow. Great choices with flavor and balanced spice.
There's nothing spectacular yet inherently bad about this restaurant. The decor is simple and leaves much to be desired - not much of a Thai feel can be found.

I don't know why Banana House only has 3 stars, I've been coming here since I worked in the Financial District and I've never had an issue with them. They're always really nice to me and make sure I have everything I need.
This place is not bad if you want some quick Thai food in FiDi. I always want to come back for more to support the friendly Thai family/friends that run this store. :)

Ordered pad see ew.....and didn't like it. I've tried this dish in many Thai places, so I know what to expect. The worst part: the meat. It was baaad... On top of that....small serving portions. I left hungry. The staff was friend tho. Not coming back.

I ordered my fave thai dish- the infamous Pad See Ewe with tofu and no eggs. It wasn't bad and the portion was just right for someone getting dinner after a nice workout. Nice enough people. Not sure if I would make it a point to come back.

Decent Thai food in the financial district.  But lots of competition around, and there is nothing particularly special about this place that distinguishes it.  They have everything you are used to, but if it were me, I would take the hike and go to King of Thai a few blocks away if possible.

Wow hate to break it to you but this was terrible.  I ordered the pad kee mao which was supposed to have broccoli, tomato, basil and bell pepper and tofu.  Instead, it had only rice noodles, broccoli (with the stems and leaves..that's not basil) and the worst tofu I've had in years.  There was literally a point that I was mid chew on a tofu cube and decided to forego and spit out my mouthful into a napkin to throw away.  No flavor, cold and disgusting.  Definitely won't be coming back here.  Sad because I love Thai...
This place is Ehhh!
This place really seemed like authentically cooked Thai food.  It didn't have that mass produced or frufry over-the-top chic Thai presentation that you see in Ohio or Pittsburgh.
This is the second time I'm ignored there. They are not 1-person table-friendly. I've tried to go for lunch, but in today's case, left with an empty belly and a scowl on my face.

2 Thai restaurants on the same block. I will give Banana house the edge over Bangkok Express. The food was much better. Against my better judgement, I ordered the fried rice and fried chicken dish. Yeah I know, not very healthy.  But it was pretty good. They did mess up my friend's order and got him the chicken pad see ew instead of the tofu pad see ew that he ordered. No harm, no fowl, it happens.
Stopped in on a whim on my walk to work. Reasonable prices, great Pad Thai and excellent staff! My glass never went empty, service was quick, and they were very kind. I'll definitely be back!

Huge, delicious crab rangoons. Prik Sod is scrumptious with a bit of spice from the jalapenos. Thai Iced Tea is one of the best I've had in San Franciso. I definitely recommend for lunch in FiDi or if you are feeling lazy and want takeout for dinner (as I did tonight, ha!).

Right when we walked in, it looked really dirty and disorganized. The waitress didn't understand English much and we had to ask for refills and utensils multiple times. Food wasn't any special. Never go back again.
Decent lunch portions. They're very flexible about the items you get (allowing for half and half of rice and pad thai).
The calamari is wierd.  It's all batter.  The food is really greasy.  I don't think I need to elaborate.
The pumpkin curry is good but that's about it. Their other food is average and you can get better quality at Osha's. It's always crowded so you need a reservation.

Stumbled upon this gem when the restaurant across the way couldn't seat us. Went with a group of 8 people. Everyone loved what they got. I got the tofu satay appetizer. Best peanut sauce I've had. Would go back! Again and again.
Not much spazzy flavor to Thai cuisine!
They are supposed to close at 8. I came at 7:45 and the door was open but the girl in the back said they were closed because she was waiting for her cousin to come pick her up? What?

Your generic Quickly.  Cheap boba, cheap food, small area.  Got the tiger milk tea (Thai tea + milk tea) which was pretty good, as was the spam musubi.  Definitely works when you need your boba fix and don't feel like dropping more than a few dollars on boba.

Shop is extremely small with maybe 3 chairs facing the window, so just order your items and get out of there. Only one person was working so of course the service was quick (they don't call it quicklys for nothing). Can't beat $1 milk teas! Ordered mine with large boba for an extra 50 cents. Yummmm
good deals and dependable chain.  we look for this place when we have those bubble tea cravings.

This is a particularly bad Quickly. It's dirty, the staff is haphazard, and they are often out of tapioca pearls. There are cardboard boxes strewn around the waiting area, making the already tiny space even more crammed. The tapioca pearls, when they have them, are not cooked well. Go to Sweetheart instead.

I tend not to complain about cheap food. Like super cheap food. The Quickly franchise is known for their $1 milk teas, and this location is no exception. However, I will say that it was kind of watered down. But again, for $1, I'm not complaining or expecting much. This is a super small store on the corner of the street, but I was surprised at the selection of snack foods here. They have fried chicken legs for $1.50, tea eggs for 50 cents each, Oreo snow, Fried Durian?, the list goes on and on. And they seemed really cheap too. The girl working there was also nice. This place is definitely a solid 3 stars.

It's a hole in the wall. The place offers a seemingly cheaper menu than what I'm used to. Nothing outstanding other than the one worker. Possibly the nicest Quickly's employee I've ever encountered. Despite the seemingly grungy walls, she continued to clean, ask how our food was, kept smiling, and offered more things to buy.
I went here 7:40 and he said he close already.....is he want to go home early? or the shop close at 7.30?

Love quickly's. Cheap bubble milk tea. What more can you ask for. The wait is a little long though because there's only 1 person working the whole store. The place looks dinky but you just order and take it to go anyways.

This location is absolutely disgusting. The seating are is so small and yet it can get like this. I'm honestly surprised this place is still in operation with all the black stains on the floor and walk. Just thinking about it makes me regret drinking the milk tea I bought here.

I was so happy to accidentally come across Quickly during my trip to SF. I've only been to the NYC locations, but this place satisfied my boba craving! I didn't get anything fancy, just a basic milk tea which I loved. Tapioca was the perfect amount of sweet, and the perfect chewiness. Service was super fast, didn't think it was particularly dirty or anything.

Tiny location, half-assed service. No tiger milk tea, which is the best thing ever and silly not to "have" since they sell both Thai and regular milk tea and tiger is just a mix or the two. But if you're desperate for your fix and don't have your heart set on tiger milk tea (I always do, unfortunately), this Quickly's will certainly do the trick.

This Quickly is in the heart of Chinatown and is very convenient in terms of location (buses galore). I came here on a Saturday afternoon with a couple of friends for a quick boba fix, and it was indeed the fastest boba experience I have ever encountered. (Quickly makes their drinks out of powder, so I guess it follows that everything is so fast.) I ordered a jasmine milk tea with boba (about $2), and had it within my hands in literally less than a minute. The drink itself was ok and slightly disappointing. The tapioca balls also did not have the chewy consistency. In other regards, the store itself was very dark, squished, and unkempt. However, I think this is an ok place to come (and the prices are pretty low for boba standards) if you're in a pinch. Otherwise, I would recommend Cool Tea Bar if you're in Chinatown.

Nice place to satisfy your boba cravings. I had taro milk tea (with no boba because they ran out. bummer.) which was magically delicious. The service was good. I feel bad because there were 12 of us in this group and the girl who worked there had to take all of our orders and prepare all the drinks by herself (because nobody else worked there). Despite that slight disadvantage and the fact that the place itself is small and smells greasy, it is an okay place to go to for drinks. Of course their basic milk teas are perfect.
the boba is typical, but....

This Quickly location is in the heart of Chinatown, so right off the bat, I had to reset expectations. It's very small -- only a couple of tables, probably 6 chairs total. I can get past that, but I can't get past the dirty floors and messy tables, especially when there's 4 staff, and it wasn't very busy.

This place is horrible. When I walked in to order a drink and water, the workers did not seem motivated at all, but looked like they did not want to work there. They were extremely rude since I would ask them for less ice, but they still gave me a lot of ice. I ordered a milk tea and a cup of water, and I cannot believe they would charge me a full price of a milk tea for tap water. They don't even make their milk tea from scratch, but it seems that it came from powder. Afterwards, I ended up getting a stomach ache from this Quickly's. I don't know, but Quickly's needs to hire more motivated workers, and serve milk tea that does not make people sick. I would just go down the street to sweetheart cafe and get my drink there, or if you're willing to drive, go to the sunset district and go to one of the teaways there. Please try somewhere else.

This place is not the worst quickly but it is extremely small. When I came in today, there was a large amount of obnoxious children who could not help but be loud and just kiddy. I asked the cashier about ices and slushed and she answered them fine. The main con about this Quickly is that they don't fill the cups up to the top. I know they have a machine to fill up the cup but still I could have five more percent of liquid. C'mon now. I hate when the volume isn't at least 95% filled. It's my personal pet peeve at drink places. Oh and another con, this place is smack dab in Chinatown and so by default full of loud Chinese people.
It's not good at all. Waste if money
Nice price of boba milk tea.but I don't know why it's difference price of no ice and add ice.and add ice is more pay than no ice.

Quickly sells everything, literally everything. Tapioca, snacks, fried Oreos, noodles....you name it! Their menu covers an ENTIRE wall and then some. I got a milk tea with egg pudding. Pretty standard except the egg pudding had the same texture as firm tofu (the ones with little spongy holes). Weird, but acceptable. Would I return the next time I'm in San Francisco? Probably not.

Terrible customer service. They close early cause the guy wants to leave early. Today I ordered popcorn chicken and they only filled 1/4 bag. When I asked for more, they gave me 4 more pieces, barely reaching 1/2 of the bag. They didn't even apologize for it. Super disappointed!!!!!
Slightly above average bubble tea. Fast service, cheap prices. Plenty of options. The taro and almost milk teas were good but not amazing.
Yay for $1 milk tea and $1.50 taro. I love Chinatown and cheap good boba
Dirty place and pretty rude service!

I always come here for the fried tofuuuu. It's the closest Quickly's to downtown, and though it's a bit of a walk, it's worth it. It's a pretty standard Quickly's, but I like this one because it's near a corner donut store, Chinatown/North Beach. I wish there was a tofu and vegetable rice bowl - just tofu and rice is a bit much.
I love this place. I can get an extra large Jasmine Milk Tea and Popcorn Chicken very close to work and get some exercise at the same time!
Tiny but tasty. I love quickly's large menu, but this space leaves a lot to be desired. Couldn't fit my whole family (6 of us) inside here for long, as there were other customers who wanted in.
Good, open late. You need to try the cantaloupe snow. It's boss.
I'm loving the Honey Milk Tea & Cheese Sticks combo! The tea and milk plus the flavoring is decent so I always leave the store feeling very satisfied with my experience.

The worst service ever. Enough said. I went in around 7:30 and the guy told me that they are closed. I pointed to the sign on the door with the store hours and said, "But it says here that you are open until 8:00 everyday. Is this not the case?" He just did not understand English or pretended not to because he clearly just started at me and didn't say anything. This lack of professionalism just gives me such a horrible impression. I don't think I'm going to come back here.. even if I haven't tried their bubble tea.

Great value and taste! However, this location is teeny tiny. it was quite crowded when I went in during the afternoon and all the people were just cramped inside. Only like 5-6 spots to sit. This location is more of a grab and go kind of boba place but if you're in the area, definitely go to Quickly for your boba fix!

Quickly is a bit like your rebound after a great relationship. Sure, it's cheap and it gets the job done, but it's nothing special and will never really linger on your mind like the REALLY GOOD bubble tea you had once upon a time.

Must be one of those places where you have to know the storepeople to get the best service. When I walked in, there was a group of old Asian ladies laughing loudly in a corner, sometimes darting underneath the counter to the back to say hi to people...I get that this is Chinatown, but it still makes me raise an eyebrow about having people who aren't currently working to go behind the counter where my boba is being made. I got the champagne grapes slushy with boba, and it tasted good though.

This place is crap. How can you make a drink and not  stir the drink till the powder fully dissolves?? My bf's brother ordered a drink here and didn't want it (we didn't know why at the time), he said the drink was really bad. My bf said he would take it, cause he didn't like money being wasted... soon he realized that he was sipping chunks of powder up the straw and into his mouth. He spit the contents out and then looked at the bottom of the cup... a thick layer of tan-ish color powder sitting there dry.... the lady didn't even bother to stir the powder let it dissolve. What a waste of money

Such a solid place to get my milk tea fix for only 99 cents. Since my fiancee lives so close, I always make it a point to stop here every weekend. Sure you can say it tastes generic but I can always rely on this place when I'm in the mood for milk tea.
99 cents for milk tea deal!! already right there, worth it. it doesn't come with the boba so in the end its really 1.49 but still, super cheap and worth it! 1.99 for a large :)

This was our first trip to a Quickly and it was great!  Super fast nice tasting milk, green milk, and taro milk tea with large bobas.  Unlike other boba places, the cashier knew right away what tea on their menu was not caffeinated for our little kid.
If you're from San Diego, It's exactly like Tapex, but Chinese.

I usually don't give two sticks if a place is a little dumpy, but this Quickly is distractingly so (compared to other Quickly locations in the city). I'll easily but up with it because 1) huge selection 2) cheap prices 3) they give you sealed cups, in case you want to stick one in the fridge and keep it for later. They also have egg pudding, which is like boba, but creepier and more convenient (goes through your teeth). Some people are just into that sort of thing.
Was really hoping for more than I got.  The burger was just okay, but shredded lettuce?  what am I?  a rodent?  The tots I had were good, but it's pretty hard to screw up deep frying potatoes.

This place is crapola.  Servers are rude, and they gave me the scarps out of the fryer for curly fries, all twisted crappy overfried gunk.  Burger tastes like cardboard.  410 bucks wasted, McD's is better.
I get that I ordered on an app and picked up not long before the place closed, but...
Custom burger made to order which was delicious! The new fries are WAY better, and the service was excellent. I definitely recommend if you are in the area.
Owner was very nice and made me a super customer burger salad without charging any extra.

I just have to say that today has been one of the best days for me in a while, professionally, but Bistro Burger was kind of a let down. However it did not squash my high spirits from all the good vibes coming my way from other avenues!

Best part for me was that they had a washroom. Messy but yummy, they forgot to put on my caramelized onions so I was a little sad about that but it wasn't a deal breaker for me. Their sweet potato fries were great! I went at a pretty quiet time so I can't really speak to how busy they get, it smells great sitting in the restaurant though!

This place used to have good burgers but the quality has diminished in the past year while the prices have gone up.  The fries are good but the burgers are bland.  And although is very close to my office, I'd rather go elsewhere for a cheaper and better meal!
My office is literally a 30second block from this place, so I gave it a shot.

I am not such a big fan of burgers but from time to time I fell that I should be eating one. I chose this place because I was passing by right one of the moments which I mentioned above. The burgers are just okay. The bacon almost tastes like regular bacon. The fries were well done but they weren't warm at all. Al in all, the mal was okay, having in mind the decent price.
An A-OK breakfast burrito.
3 stars because this place is just "A-OK" as Yelp puts it.

This place used to be great. Now it's about $12 for a burger and fries and the quality has gone down considerably. The onion rings used to be great and now they are awful. Plus I can't stand places that charge you for a bag even when it's a take-out order.
salmon burger was great. nice people-watching outside. faster than expected service at lunch.
My company ordered food from here. The burgers are pricey, but it's delish! Remember to order fries!!
Really great burgers cooked to order. I ask for medium rare and it comes medium rare. Great wheat buns, good beef, can't be beat for a burger in the Financial District.
Not bad at all, but nothing wow.
I made a mental note to come back when I saw a line going out the door a week or so again. It has got to be good if folks are willing to wait that long, right?

I was looking forward to the juicy & delicious turkey burger I saw mentioned in other reviews and came out pretty disappointed.  The food came out in 5 min, so I don't know how they managed to dry out out so badly unless they had the burgers sitting on the grill waiting for orders (this was during the lunch rush so I guess it's possible.)
This place definitely hits the spot whenever you feel like a juicy, well-made burger in the Financial District during lunch hours!
Food is good. Price is higher than it should be. Than again this is dead center in downtown Embarcadero-SF.

paty melt is flat. The meat paty take up one half of the sandwich the other hardly has any. The onion rings are way over cooked and taste slightly of fish (perhaps using the same oil). Nothing tastes good. Ehhh....disappointment. Low expectations, so whatever. Basement food court fare.
I had the california burger. It was good, but not great. For the price, I would have expected to get fries or something at least
Decent burger.  Had the lunch special for $8, pretty good for FiDi area.  The root beer float my wife got was NOT worth the $5.  If I was close I'd stop in again, but wouldnt go out of my way.

Was starving one day at work and in need of protein so decided to look for a burger. They have an early bird deal for fries a drink and a burger for about $9 so I decided to head here. Burger was ok... was falling apart though, and the lady at the counter seemed to think I was so odd for not only eating a burger that early, but also for never having been there!

I love me a good cheeseburger and I decided to check out Bistro Burger for lunch today.  I walked in with high hopes after reading some great reviews and I walked out sorely disappointed.  There were so many options, so many ways to customize my burger and in the end it was undercooked (more medium rare than the medium well I asked for) and flavorless.  When ordering, I considered adding the cajun seasoning but I didn't want to add another 50 cents to an already expensive burger.  I should have spent the 50 cents because my cheeseburger was bland and unsatisfying.
My first experience at Burger Bistro was a positive one as my
I used to be a regular here, before the remodel (more like un-remodel, place looks awful now)  in late 2012.
Ok fast food slightly over priced with the excuse of having "Bistro" in its name outside.
This is a small, made to order burger place located in the heart of the Financial District so expect to pay more than you do for a burger elsewhere.
OK Fast food burger.

I stopped by this store today excited to buy a grass fed burger.  I asked the girl at the register where they get your beef and she told me it used to be from Estancia (true 100% grass fed) but now its from Niman Ranch.  According to Niman Ranch's own website their beef is finished on grain (see below).  The term "grass fed" implies to those of us who care about the beef we eat that this beef has been 100% grass fed and never given grain.  This estaurant is misrepresenting its beef as "grass fed" when it is not on both your website and in the store.  I think they should immediately correct this as it is false advertising.
I just can't patronize this place anymore. After being a semi-regular here, yesterday was the last time.

A quick share: I've ordered catering through Bistro Burger for my company in the past, today was the 3rd or 4th time...they are fabulous!  The catering staff who delivers are highly efficient, the food is hot and fresh...we also ordered 120+ milkshakes and they are phenomenal!  If you have a catered lunch to order, I would definitely recommend them - it's fun, yummy and your staff will love it.  Enjoy!

I wasn't impressed and it's expensive for what you get.  The ingredients were sub-par, especially the veggies.   I had the Mexican veggie burger; it came with the saddest looking tomato, white iceberg lettuce, and two tiny pieces of avocado.

Decent sized and decent tasting California burger with avocado and sprouts, plus a side of curly fries and ranch-- all for about $12. As with any other place downtown, it'll be hard to find seating during lunch time. It shares a space with a taqueria too FYI.

My friend Marie who seemed to frequent this place for lunch made me very curious about this place. I told her I would be in the city and if she already had her lunch break cuz would love to meet up with her. She excitedly responded she would wait and would love to have lunch with me.

Around $12 for burger, fries and drink. Great burger, cooked to standards. The curly fries are truly my favorite. Usually busy around lunch time. Decent value in the financial, and if I am looking for the classic burger, fries and drink.

It's hard to find a good burger place in the Financial but I think this one does the job. The thing that I like about Bistro Burger is that they do not try to do too much with their burgers like other places. They give you the right amount of beef and the right amount of condiments to adequately quench your hunger. The ingredients are always fresh and the price is about what you would pay for downtown.
Very overpriced as burger, fries and drink came to over $12. Good tasting food, wasn't a huge fan of the staff. Clean inside which was good.
Come here for all of the best groceries in all of Chinatown! And yes, there are always deals to be had here too.

Like most stores in Chinatown, this store is not very spacious. My mom has been getting groceries here whenever she is out in Chinatown. I normally stand outside since it does tend to get crowded inside.

this is a generic review for the dozens of veggie/fruit  retailers on stockton street.  fruit city isn't too far from the ping yuen apartments where i visited my relatives many times nor too far from my home on grant ave when i was a toddler.
the fact that i can get my fruit for the week for about 4.00 is absolutely amazing (usually bananas, apples, berries).

I have a kid who lives in a land far, far away where good fresh fruits and veggies are hard to come by. She tells me she keeps dreaming about being on Stockton street with Fruit City and Little Paris within 2 blocks. Fruit City has enough veggies, meats, sauces etc. to make a whole meal with one stop. Their prices are as low as any of the shops on the street too.

I'm so shocked that somebody else reviewed this place! I thought that it would be another Chinatown gem people fail to acknowledge. But anyway, I'm pretty sure I've been inside many, many times. However, I'm not reviewing this based on that (because I sure didn't go in last time). I usually just stand outside on the sidewalk, waiting for a family member who's shopping inside. I try to stay away from the caos (not that the street/sidewalk is too much better). I just love the feel of this particular store and how there are heaps of people hovering over the fruits they have placed semi-outside the store. I love how the people shout out the cheap prices for the fruits. It also looks like one of the grocery markets on the cleaner side (for Chinatown at least).
The name of the store is Fruit City but they also sell meat and other grocery items.  This is one of my favorite grocery store in SF china town.

This is where my mom usually gets her roast duck to go whenever she is in Chinatown. I've gone a few times as well. Yeah it's not the cleanest but what do you expect from a busy butcher shop in Chinatown? They have the usuals but we really only get the roast duck and sometimes the pork here.

Clean store since it went through a renovation. Good food and good service. I tried the Hai Nan Chicken and BBQ Pork from here, they are both delicious. I am coming back to get BBQ/Roast Pork and Hai Nan Chicken when I am in Chinatown.
Good place to eat & go, the roast suck & roast pig is my favorite a must try!
A fav in Chinatown! A must try if in the area! Fresh had to get delicacies, the roast pig is my favorite!

One of my favorite places to come to get Chinese roast duck. When I was really young, probably before my teens, I would walk in with my mother to buy duck for dinner, right after I was finished with Chinese school. That's probably why I have a fond memory of this place. It's still going strong after all these years. Give it a try if you're ever in the mood for a good duck meal.

I can't decide if I like this place or not.  I came here simply because there wasn't a line outside the door.  I was in a hurry and craving for duck.  The duck was pretty on par with everywhere else...less fatty though.  Which I prefer anyway.  For $13/duck, I really can't complain.  :)
This is probably the least frequented location on Stockton.

My quest for finding good Chinese deli continues. I got the duck and honey roasted spare ribs to add to my noodle soup for dinner. The duck was a bit dry and the guy chopped it into small pieces that made it awkward to eat due to the bones in the way. The spare ribs however were tender, sweet, and fell off the bones easily. I wouldn't mind going back for those next time.
The best I have found. Beats anything in Vancouver (and I lived there 2 years).Don't miss this place.

Ugh, avoid at all cost. Ordered a bowl of won ton noodles with greens. Found a WORM floating in my broth as I was half way through my meal. I freaked out (quietly) and called my server over. I pointed to my bowl and she asked me if I put the worm in there. WHAT?! I paid my bill and dashed out to avoid throwing up at the table. While I can forgive the worm (it happens with veggies, though WASHING helps...), the server's reaction was jaw dropping.

Bad food.... I order simple instant noodles with pork hop and vegetable.   The noodle is soggy, the vegetable is wried totally like left over.    The menu said hot drink comes for free, but the choice only include hot tea or hot water or hot milk tea sweet less .     What a stingy combination.     I don't mind to pay more for the drinks, but the quality is not worthy!!!!    I won't come back again for sure, and not recommend to others.

If you can't read Chinese don't go there. I order two dishes they charged me two  to go boxes and two bags fee.  I ask why charge me two bag fee,  the lady said some people like separate two bag.  I'm not care 20cents,  but why they are not ask before? feel cheated.

Indifferent food, indifferent staff and a bathroom door that kept slamming shut, about 50 times. Seafood salad was store bought potato salad with a few pieces of shrimp and chewy squid thrown on top, couple of pickles and tomato slices. However, the pot stickers were good.

We were visiting San Francisco and felt like a hong kong style cha chan tian (western style food of hong kong).  We stumbled into ABC.  Food was good, especially the quality of the egg noodle that they used.  It was chewy and reminded me of the won ton noodle in Hong Kong.  Service was good.  We also like how a lot of restaurants in Chinatown give out free 2-hour parking in the nearby parking lot.  We will definitely go back again.
Open late and got a craving for Hoi Nam Gai Fan? This place is for you!
I love the one in Noriega. This one's food didn't taste the same as the one in Noriega, and the service need to improve.

ABC messed up my food twice. One older waitress that has been there for at least 10 years had the nerve to tell me that I was supposed to tell them to leave this or that out. Really??? C'mon! I've been coming here for so many years now. I've ordered the same thing countless times and I never had any problem. They shouldn't make it seem like I'm the one at fault when their waitresses don't even know their own menu! Please...

The meal is what you expect in the bakery cafe in SF Oakland areas. But the service is terrible here. The cashier is rude and the order was wrong. Getting them to correct something is like pulling teeth. If you want relaxation avoid here. If you don't mind self service and decent food come here.

Food was subpar, just wanted something to fill my stomach. Walked in and the floor was sticky. The booth seats and tables felt dirty. Half way into the meal we noticed there were a bunch of tiny flies all over the ceiling and throughout the meal, they were flying around us and our food. Just ended up loosing my appetite. Not coming back again.
Pretty good
Home of the best won ton soup west of Asia!

My go-to place to get the best wonton around. Humongous dumplings (compared to other won ton places), generous with the shrimp and if my taste buds are correct I can detect the addition of smoked pork fat and/or pork skin which gives the wonton a slight bacon-y flavor which also adds moisture to the meat in the wonton. I order the wonton without noodles because I don't think they do their noodles very well. I'm picky about the texture of my noodles. I've found their egg noodles to be "rough" - hard to chew and swallow. Their rice noodles on the other hand are too mushy like they've overcooked them.
When you know what you want and don't mind the wait and service, this is such a place. You see this is a locals' place and you'd know why they're here.
0 stars for service

Please do not come to this resturaunt if you are planning to have a warm meal and good lunch.  I ordered chicken wings with fries. Fries are burnt and cold, probably been fried overtime and left in the kitchen for a long time. Chef rejected to redo the fries. The wings are too salty.

Last time, I ordered Hannan chicken at this place with my friend, however the garlic sauce is moldy and the color is black. Later I complained to them with a phone call cause I ordered food to go, and the waitress doesn't believe me, she keeps going say that it won't happen in the case. Her attitude is bad. By the way, they don't give me the napkin and fork or spoon with my food! Bad services. Never come again!

HK Restaurant Food - feels exactly like Hong Kong. I go to ABC Cafe purely for their soup noodles. The seafood combination is absolutely delicious ("Say Bo Tong Meen"), and their wonton soup. On a cold day, or a day after drinking, both of the soups are an absolute must.
One star for the hainan chicken. Service doesn't exist at this place. The waitress seems to be there for 20 yrs yet don't give a shxt if customer will return or not.
Dirty, dirty and dirty.   I got hair in my food the drink are mix with half full of water don't want to come any more.

Be aware that if you don't finish your food after you dine in, they will charge you 0.50 for a cheap to go box. I can see that the pricing for these are selective because on some days if they like you, its free or 0.25 and other days, its 0.50. yes just a few nickle and dime but No principle whatsoever!

I think they spent far too much money to make the menu look pretty, and consolidated the uniformity of the layout, menu, and maybe execution of the SF Chinatown, Sunset, and San Mateo locations. While the San Mateo location is the cleaner and swankier looking of the three, the original SF Chinatown flagship still retains a bit of that old run down feel. But unfortunately the food has slipped even further down the slope with little hopes of recovery.

Food is fine, just regular hongkong style food. But what I want to point out here is the customer service, it's just Ok if u don't care. Most servers are Chinese mama, working relaxed, no expression face, just for work, so not enjoy eating there at all!

This is one of the worst chinese foods I've had...the pork chop rice, broccoli beef rice and just the rice in general was horrible.... the utensils were dirty and the bathroom didn't work... also the meat was really dry -.- so yeah I wouldn't recommend coming here....

Been coming to this ABC off and on for many years. You pretty much know what you are getting into when you step in through the doors; dirty floors, sticky tables, stinky restrooms. But the food has been decent enough to fill your stomach. Not great but three star decent. But on my most recent visit, it was bad, real bad.
I meant to post this awhile ago, but never finished it (and never came back after this one incident detailed below) so here goes!

This is my favourite wontonmin joint in SF. Wontons are filled with prawns and soup has good mild flavour. Only issue is they serve too much egg noodles which is a waste but after all, we are in America! Ask them to put less noodles if you aren't that hungry. Their milk tea is very nice too.
This is part of a chain of 3 restaurants. All 3 restaurants have identical menus, and the actual food you get is pretty much the same across all 3 restaurants.
I ordered the two most popular things there before I consulted yelp, so I'm actually really proud I made the right decisions.
Hate this place. It's safe to say I will never come back here.
The price here is quite reasonable.
Typical Chinese cafe, with its good and bad sides.

I trekked over to Chinatown late at night with a craving for Wonton mein. Not sure where to go, I was recommended this place. BIG WONTON and lots of noodles. Their menu is the typical HK Cafe, open late, and pretty good service. What is there not to like?
A not-so-recent meal here:
Very nice Hong Kong style tea room! We went there for breakfast. The breakfast selections are similar to those in HK. And they have the best Chinese pastries in China  town!
Classic Hong Kong diner food!!! What more can I say. I circle back here at least once every time I am in SF.
Ahhhh good old HK style food in the heart of Chi town!
First thing I noticed about this place is that it smells and it's kind of dirty looking... But it was so crowded so I guess the food was good?

They now charge 25 cents for a cheap take out container if you have the nerve not to finish your food and want to box it home.  Really?  I heard of charging for bags but for a cheap "Thank You Pagoda" take out box?

We were starving and it was quite early on a Friday morning, so we wanted breakfast. This place was open early so we ventured in, my daughter especially wanting something and coffee. (I figured we had a better bet to get tea but she did persist). They had some lovely offerings of pre packaged bakery items and what appeared to be a breakfast sandwich (looked like some egg in there but also lettuce, go figure). We decided instead to sit at a table and be served instead of taking a to go package. Should have gone with the to go package.

I had some tasty spicy garlic chicken at this Chinese diner in the Financial District. Apparently everyone leaves this part of town at night and it's more of a lunch spot. The service was attentive, as you might expect at a small family-run restaurant. Will return when I'm back in town.
Food is fresh & servers friendly.
Prices are low but portions are a bit small. Food has good Chinese taste.
+1 star for the price!
Cheap, fast, yummy food, and friendly service! I advise ordering family style and sharing.

Good food, good price, and good service. What else can you ask for more? Lunch here everyday!!! Never disappointed. Eat here lunch every weekday for more than 2 months. They even customize for the dish for us since we like our dish spicy. More than happy to come here again and again before my work is done in sf. Thanks young's cafe.

This place is cheap, good, fast, and friendly. They give you a free soup when you sit with water and tea. I've tried a few things on the menu and you really can't go wrong. Especially when you have a hour lunch they will get you in and out to accommodate you.
This place is cheap, fast, and darn good. I ordered an off-menu item: beef with asparagus over pan fried HK-style noodles. It was delicious, came with free soup, and was served with a smile.
The food is excellent with great flavor and portion. I had most of the food on their specials, very affordable. I come here every weekend on my lunch break.

Yay, pan fried noodles cooked served fast (less than 10 mins)! The pan fried noodles aren't on the menu, but they're available with any of the noodle dishes upon request. I usually order it with chicken and mixed veggies.

Teeny tiny place, food cooked to order. Got a special off the board, sesame chicken. I've never had such crispy chicken covered in a sweet glazey sauce in my life. I'm used to getting soggy meat. So this place is a def plus for making the food so fresh!!

This is a convenient spot to grab a quick lunch. The decor leaves something to be desired, but the staff makes up for that with their friendly and welcoming attitude. You also can see the chef go at it in the kitchen!

My rating is based on the relative excellence of the food, when compared with the price. Young's is a tiny, dingey restaurant on the edge of Chinatown, just one block from the Financial District. English is not the first language of any of the staff, but they are helpful with interpreting the menu.The basics are just fine: pot stickers, won ton soup with barbecued pork, chow fun etc. But they also have some interesting dishes as specials every day. this is a great lunch place!

I'm a food snob! An over the top stereotypical food snob, I even have an imaginary checklist that i would mark off every time i see something i did not like, but today was different. We were walking toward R&G lounge and we saw the line out the door so we just went to the first place we saw. I didn't even check yelp for the ratings until after i ordered.
Great food and service. The only place that will make Mu Shu pork and a side order of garlic sauce without question.
Loved the food here. Even tho i orderdered the wrong ish, I was complimented with different plates at no cost. Thank god I found this spot

Can't say one bad thing about this place. You walk in and sit down and they bring out the soup of the day either a hot and sour or egg drop. Both are awsome. But then you pick from there menu and you really can't go wrong with anything you get ,there all good. But I'm a fan of the spicy garlic sauce chicken over rice. I would say the best thing on the menu. But since getting another job out side of the city, I can't eat it all the time but when I do go back I always stop and fill my fix.

Mom from out of town -- where they have one Chinese restaurant -- of course, wanted Chinese food as we were shopping in Chinatown. Did a quick search on Yelp and found one a block away from where we were, Young's Cafe. (Dear Jesus, my mom at 82 and barely mobile was happy to hear about the short walk.) We were all fairly satisfied with our luncheon specials (good until 2:30), quite edible, but unmemorable. That being said, I would go back again to make sure I order what the guy sitting next to me was having! I might have given it a four instead of a three. Sigh, such is the roll of the dice.

Got a new job and the lunch period is thirty minutes.  What do I see?  Young's Cafe.  I order the spicy tofu with rice for $6.95.  Food arrives at my table very quickly.  Mind you, its 2:30 in the afternoon and the lunch hour rush is long gone.  Pretty tasty for low budget, economic crisis, priced food. Its better than a fast food joint for about the same price. The restaurant is small and the decor is strictly low budget.  But who cares?  Not I.

Had mixed experiences here. First time I came my Beef Chow Fun was very filling and satisfying. Next time I brought my co-workers and the Beef Chow Fun was without any meat. Probably won't be back here considering R&G is on the same block and is much more consistent.

Tried to get dinner at a fancy nearby restaurant -- left after 1.5 hours with a wallet $76 lighter and no dinner.  Stopped in for take away veggie fried rice right at closing time.  Served up with smiles.  Light, hot, not greasy.  Thanks!
Fast, efficient, somewhat reasonably priced Chinese food.

I just realized that I need to review Young's.  I've been coming here for more years than I'd like to admit.  They're dependable.  I like dependable.  The food is just fine.  No, it's not Gary Danko or R&G Lounge, but the servings are large, and they have a good variety of stuff.  The staff is always efficient and friendly.   The cook is friendly.  Poke your head in that little opening between the upstairs dining room and the kitchen and say howdy.  He'll appreciate it.

Sometimes, it's difficult to write a review for a place like this, as it's not easy to categorize it. I guess the best way to describe it, would be to compare it to both a Chinese restaurant, a takeaway and a snack bar. I guess it is a good place if you have a busy day and you need a quick fix for lunch just as I did when I walked in.

So disappointed.  I ordered the Chicken Won Ton Soup.  They charged me $7.05 for what should have been $5 at the most.  Watery broth, tiny won tons (used to be plumper), slim chicken (used to be big chunks)....they even skimped on bok choy.  They seem to have gotten greedy. I won't go back.  Staff is friendly.  I never sit down here.  The seating is too crowded and dirty.  Where can I get a good bowl of won ton soup in chinatown?  My goodness!
Portions and quality of foods that we ordered was not great.. we ordered a selection of beef, pork, shrimp, fish, and noodle meals..
I rarely pick Chinese food when I eat out because I grew up on it (being Chinese and all)

My custom, off menu dish: vegetable chow mien, Hong Kong style (crispy noodles), with black bean sauce, using minimal oil. Ummm, great and healthy. I have eaten here for many years, certainly 10's of times. Cheap, clean enough, reliable, very good (but not great). Thankfully, not the all-too-common cornstarch and grease experience. They do a good job for both tourists and locals, will guide you and customize if you ask. Good attitudes from staff. Community seating at peak lunch time, though they do have a 2nd dining room downstairs in the dungeon.
Small and cozy, great service, mediocre food, but it is cheap. Not great if you're in a hurry, but fine if you have an hour for lunch.
Quick service and cheap tasty food. Orange and General Tsao's Chicken are delish!
Came to Young's with a large work crowd and we ordered about 9 dishes covering the protein and veggie gamut pretty much.
Nice service.

Amazing tomato beef pan fried noodles.  The way I like is, without that much sauce, crispy.  I'm astonished by the variety of noodles, rice, dishes that come out of that little kitchen.  Those two guys back there, know their Chinese food.  Lunch here can be crowded as most places around FiDi are at that time.  There is a hidden downstairs eating area that sits another 30 people.  I don't recommend sitting down there as the wait staff will not check up on you.  For quicker service, sit upstairs.
yes its cheap and quick but the MSG was enough to make any return visit a moot point. bleech
Cheapest Chinese food we found so we went in and gave it a shot.

Best damn Chinese food I've found in the city after living here for 7 years. It's an open kitchen so you can watch them prepare your meal and all the fresh meats & veggies are on display. You can't beat the lunch specials for the price and I've not yet once been disappointed with a meal.

The base lunch specials are now $6.50 per dish, portions still tiny.  I had a quick lunch with my dad today - I ordered salt & pepper pork chops (six strips of meat) over rice and dad ordered oyster sauce beef over rice (where's the beef - lots of celery? in oyster beef??).  Food was still tasty restaurant was packed.  No service - I had to ask the waitress several times for the bill and again to settle up.  Don't be in a hurry here...

I was craving Chinese food today and didn't take the time to do a Yelp search.  Big mistake.  I set out from my office and popped into the first chinese place I saw.  Second big mistake.  It looked like a good value - entre plus rice plus soup for $6.50.  I ordered the Orange Chicken.  They don't take credit cards (all I had on me) for orders under $10 so I threw in an order of spring rolls.

I was craving chinese food today for lunch and since this is close to my work I thought I would try it out. I've always passed by for years but never went in. After reading a few reviews on Yelp I decided "what the hell". So I walked in and ordered food to go.  Having never been there I wanted time to look over the menu, but as soon as I walked in I got a "hi, to go? what are you having"  - Jeez ! I mean give me a little bit of time to decide lady!
About what I expected.  Fast, cheap, tasty, nothing special.  I got the beef chow fun, which was good but gummy, and certainly very well priced at $7.40 (with free soup)

You know this place is  kinda special. Why? Because, everyone who was raised in, hung around in, or used to frequent Chinatown, knows that over the years, "the best food," has by and large left Chinatown for other areas around SF and beyond. The reasons for the exodus are many, among which is the fact that as the previous older generations of Cantonese immigrants (mostly from Hong Kong) families matured, the later generations moved out, taking with them an economic base that sustained good restaurants and quality food. The present inhabitants of Chinatown which replaced them, are recent immigrants from China that occupy a lower economic rung and cannot sustain the big fancy Chinatown eating palaces of old, (Empress of China, imperial Palace, Four Seas etc. all now closed or closing,) causing a reliance by these restaurants on the tourist trade and therefore a decline in the quality of the food.This reality, coupled with the fact that after the Golden Dragon Shooting several decades ago,and the closing, then opening and  "shrinking" of that popular restaurant, people just stopped coming to Chinatown to eat. That created the present void in Chinatown for anything but "HK cafe style" food, or take home BBQ and rice plate places (on Stockton St. The "local marketplace" street.) that are popular and preferred by the new generation of Chinatown residents, primarily  from South China. So when we can go out as a group of friends, as we did recently, and eat well in Chinatown these days, (anywhere other than the mighty R&G restaurant, the present Chinatown reigning king of good food,) it's a cause for celebration. And celebrate is what I would like to do, at a place that has withstood everything I mentioned for decades and is still going strong, turning out delicious dishes and Cantonese comfort food consistently, from a huge menu, with creative food choices, including some seldom offered old time Cantonese country classics. I am talking about Washington Bakery and Restaurant, on Washington St. across from Portsmouth Square, (the Chinatown Park and Garage). Care to take me out on my B'day? Bring me here please! And we will eat well, for a reasonable price, along with a restaurant completely full of local folks and others from all parts of Frisco, that know how to eat well. If it's lunch time, we'll order from their extensive lunch menu, all for around $7.50 for huge rice plates, noodle and other dishes. If it's dinner like I'm hoping, we'll be sure to order their famous signature "Wun Tun, chicken noodle," (sam wo win run gai) and salt and pepper squid, seafood noodles with egg, "sam pan jook", (three innard meats porridge,) salt and pepper fried tofu, (tzao daoufu,) Tofu and Beef pork, fried egg omelette with vegetables, Beef liver and vegetables, chinese greens, ox tail stew and finally chocolate blueberry cake to top it off. (This is a bakery too after all! All kinds od Cantonese and other yummy sweets and bakery goods in the front. If you you do that for me, I'll be sure to dedicate sushi g's next hit song to you. "I adore you...ta ta ta ta ta taaa ta"....nah not you... sorry....I'm talkin about Washington Bakery ya'll...
Lady waitress used the restroom and didn't wash her hands!  Food was pretty good though....

I met a friend here for a quick weekday lunch. She told me it's a noodle spot that's pretty popular among visiting Chinese parents. That said, I wouldn't say it's a place I would bring my parents for a nice meal - everything has that almost-sticky quality of a stereotypical Chinatown restaurant and it's also incredibly loud inside. The waitresses mostly speak Cantonese, but you can get by with menu item names. Don't expect superb service, because that's the authentic Chinese restaurant experience. However, they do take credit card! Hallelujah! They also sell Chinese-style bread ($1-2) in the front bakery part of the store.

I passed by this restaurant couple times before, finally had a chance to try it out; and I have to say that I haven't had a chance to use the phrase "extremely disappointed" in a while to describe Chinese dishes that I eat.
4 stars for the food. But 2 stars for the after effects. The menu is typical of a Hong Kong diner - a mixture of Eastern and Western.
Oh geez, stay as FAR away from this place as possible! Seriously.

If you must have good service when eating in a restaurant, then don't come here. If you're hungry early in the morning and want a quick, cheap decent Chinese congee, misc. noodle & soup - then come here.  This is your typical Cantonese restaurant, so Hong-Kong style rudeness is expected.  Breakfast for 4 is around $20.

Washington Bakery has been a staple in my outside dining for well over a decade.  I've seen it go through a few changes, but the one constant is the excellent people that work here and their great service.
I always.... I mean always crave the wontons from here. To the point where I'm willing to drive from SJ to SF, if someone's willing to come along.
You would think Chinatown would have some of the best Chinese restaurants all around, not true!!!

I spent pretty much whole day in SF downtown.  Then went to chinatown for late afternoon tea.  I ordered a wonton with bf brisket yellow noodle soup, hot salty lemon drink, my wife ordered a egg tart and hong kong style milk tea, $15.50, not bad for energy recharge.  At least I hit the restaura before regular dinning hour ;-)
came here for breakfast and bad service like rude and mean. doesnt check what else you need when u dine in.

No star for this restaurant. I went for lunch w my family i had order a chicken w black bead sauce over rice and the chicken was not fully cook. I told the waiter and she say it's cooked the chicken is like that and she just walk away. The service was so bad I couldn't even get the waiter attention. And couldn't get the order right and food is not cook. So then I forget it, I asked for a check n I give less tips cuz the service was so bad. While I was walking out the cashier lady stop me and say hey it's not enough. I was like what are you talking about? She say u missing $1 dollar. I told the casher lady that I had paid enough she kept saying no it's not enough u need to put one more dollar. I didn't want to argue with her so I just give her the dollar n I just tell myself I'm not going back at all. Food and service very bad.

The waitress cheated on us!!! At beginning, we just wanna order couple buns and a milk tea, and later my gf wanna get the rice noodle as we'll. so we ordered all of them. For the whole time, the waitress didn't give us the menu at all, and didn't mention there's a special for morning breakfast. When we checked out, I thought its a bit pricy for eating here, and asked how she counted the money, she said that's right, nothing wrong. But when we leaving, we saw the menu says if we order rice noodle and milktea should be free. Which she over charged us 2 milk tea, 5.50 before tax and tips. And when I asked her why she didn't give us the special , she said you have to mention when you order, if you don't, then they will just charge regularly. WTF! You didn't even give me the menu, and how on earth I know it's a special!!! And she just have us 1 milktea which is 3 dollar back. I don't care that much he money, but the way how you do your business. It's terrible, and I'm absolutely not coming back

Had breakfast here a couple of times and liked it. Simple Cantonese fare but tasty. Price was good and there something for everyone on the menu. Had a couple of the egg custard tarts and the were very good.
party: 2
food is pretty decent.  we got the congee and bao zi fan but too greasy.  a nice cantonese eatery.

Of the bakeries in Chinatown, the pastry display here (I feel) is the most clean. I usually stop by here if I'm in Chinatown to get about a dozen Ji Bao Dan Go (Paper Cakes/ Sponge Cakes). They're fairly big in size and really nice and fluffy. Sometimes I would get the Dan Tat (egg tarts) if I'm craving them as well. They're not the best in town but good if you don't want to make multiple stops.

Typical HK cafe. Has a large selection on the menu, but nothing is really it's specialty or is especially good. Perfect place to go to if you are looking for a quick fix for authentic HK food (yes, all the food there taste authentic) and don't have any particular dish in mind that you are definitely looking for.
Mmmmm I loved the egg tart here .. Came here because Golden Gate Bakery was closed ..
Breakfast review only.

dan tat review only: They tried selling me leftovers at the end of the day another time at a discount, which I resisted thankfully, given their sad end-of-day appearance, but came back again at a normal time only to seal my disappointment. These are a little deceiving at first glance, but ultimately will only result in :(. Compared to GGB, these things are bland, lifeless. It may look like an ok flaky crust in the case, but one bite and you know you were wrong. The pale yellow custard and and more disturbingly light colored crust were my warning signs, but in the interest of the greater good, I ordered one. Yep, despite some sort of visible layers, it didn't flake apart with that toasted pie crust flavor and texture; no, it kind of tore softly - possibly underbaked? Anyway, the flavor overall was lacking. Skip this place for egg tarts.
One of my comfort places when I'm tired, sick, sad or homesick. (I also come here when I'm happy, haha.) Love the daily specials, the congee, and the "yin yerng" drink -- half coffee and half tea.
This review is for the cafe portion only:
Came in for a quick bite.  Got the wonton noodle (a staple to measure).  Not impressed.  They also offered HK style noodle but it turned out to be the SAME noodle, so false advertising....

First time here!  My bf discovered this place with his friend recently so we decided to go for lunch today.  I just got out of the gym so I was ready to eat!  I got the shrimp dumpling noodles and he got the kung pao chicken.  Loved the shrimp dumpling noodles - the dumplings have shrimp and mushrooms, which are my faves!  Warm and comforting!  My bf liked his kung pao chicken too.  Plus, we ordered hot tea and it comes in these cool metal cups.
they have a standing sign advertising cheap eats at lunch. when you are seated, they greet you but don't take your order.
Washington Bakery is an awesome spot in Chinatown for some really good Chinese food and some awesome baked goods.
Decent spot for a quick lunch. Washington Bakery & Restaurant is a HK style bistro with expansive menu items.

This place is not bad. If you want a quick lunch this is the place to go. But because of it's location, the place is always pack during lunch time. The food is kinda expensive compare to the other HK style cafe.
If you really love hong kong style milk tea you should try this place.

The lady at the counter refused to give me extra forks for my take out orders. Now I don't expect superb service in Chinatown but c'mon... she's going to try save on plastic forks? B. please... No wonder there was hardly anyone there during lunch hours. There are way better places in Chinatown with similar food.

Came by for a iced milk tea the other day and it was okay. Requested less sugar and it came out good. Requested an iced beverage and the room-temperature tea came out with a little bit of crushed ice on top...

A typical Hong Kong lounge with contemporary items like baked pork chop with rice, beef tongue with rice, iced horlick, etc.  Food here is tasty yet greasy.  Stay away from the portuguese baked rice as the yellow sauce lacks taste and the rice feels very heavy.  Extremely close to the parking lot combined with good prices so expect busy weekends.

This place is good for a fix of Chinese food. We usually get some combination of a chow mein, calamari, jook, or fried rice. The only time I've had to wait for a table (and only because we were already there and the wait was only 10-15 minutes) was a hot sunny Saturday.

Ok. When I gave this place four stars, it was for eating here on a weekday. Do not go to this place on a busy Saturday. They are so damn understaffed that we didn't get ANY attention while sitting there for 10+ minutes. Tried to flag down the youngest of the 3 ladies working and all she did was stare at me and continue walking off. When I told her we were ready to order, she simply said that she doesn't do that. No effort to find somebody to does take orders or even reassure that somebody will come over soon. They don't give a shit how long you've been waiting. We just got up and left. Their cheap breakfast is not worth sitting through horrible service for.
hardcore cantonese tea cafe place...
I wanted my friends to take me here but made it in myself it was rather nice because good food and drink at a very low price considering it being better than what I see in San Jose
good cheap chinese
One star for the veggie we ordered.  The rest of the dim sum was really subpar.  Not worth a return visit because there are way too many other options in Chinatown.

I've eaten here many times.  I usually eat the egg plant over rice plus the tofu.  Sometimes I eat the salted fish and wonder if I will die because I know it is from China.  I wouldn't take any of my friends here - and if you are looking for a good meal I would not suggest it, but there are reasons I eat here which I explain below.
Not yummy, not fresh, no nice staff.

This is apparently where the locals go for "fast food' type dim sum. Fast food and dim sum in the same sentence sound scary? Worry not my friends. Smallish, dive-ish, unassuming restaurant located off the main tourist streets in SF's Chinatown, Yummy turned out to be a fine spot to grab a super quick bite.

I hate to say it, but this place was horrible. The food for the $4.00 plates tasted decent, but it probably would've been better if it was served warm as opposed to slightly below room temp. The pork siu mai was alright, but the shrimp dumplings were horrible. First of all, the dumpling fell apart as soon as I tried to pick it up. And then when I took a bite of the shrimp inside, it tasted bad. I asked my friend to smell it to see if it was just me and he said that it smelled spoiled. When we separated the pork from the shrimp dim sum, we noticed that the shrimp ones were unusually slimy. We were so turned off that we just couldn't stomach eating the rest of our food and felt a little sick to our stomachs just thinking about eating the rest of it. I've honestly never had such a bad experience with dim sum, and I'm not usually picky about it. We tried looking around the establishment for its health score, but we weren't able to find it. I imagine if we did, it would be pretty low. And if it wasn't, it should seriously be reevaluated.

I had the steamed bbq pork buns, turnip cake, and sesame balls. The pork buns had more filling than I expected, it was a pleasant surprise. The buns rated good. I have had better, but this place was good for a hole in the wall. It is good to go to if you want quick and cheap dim sum. I had 2 pork buns, 3 sesame balls, and 1 order of turnip cake for $4.60.

THIS PLACE IS GREAT!!! CLEAN CLEAN CLEAN!!!  Great service!!! GREAT FOOD!  They serve dim sum all day!  The staff are quick and friendly.  And so easy on the wallet.  You can eat like a king!  For next to nothing!!!

Priced right, the dim sum here is great when you're on the go. I stop here when I'm in the Chinatown area, and heading elsewhere. Dim Sum: I'd say is just above average, but always hot and fresh. Not really a sit in kinda place, so if you do decide to sit and stay, be ready to wait a little bit. Most of the staff caters to the "to go" crowd.
Preface this by saying, don't expect Koi Palace quality dim sum here.
Great food.  Not the best service.  But then, again, these types of places (holes in the wall) don't usually have great service. People come here for the food.  Period.
Vermin Dim Sum, So Yummy, So Authentic

Not the best takeout dim sum in Chinatown, but a consistent performer at a cheap price point.  Lotus wrapped sticky rice and pork dumpling (shu mai )are both pretty good.  Shrimp dim sum (e.g  har gow and shrimp with chives) were acceptable.  None of the pan fried or deep fried dishes were good at all.  Rice porridge is super cheap at $1.50, although I have yet to try it.
Come here sometimes, the food is pretty good. Service is real fast, I'm always in and out of that place. Good to go in a rush.
Cilantro cherng fun looks good but in actuality it's pretty thick.  $1.00/roll.
I'm a shu mai junkie so looking for a new place in SF Chinatown stopped my Yummy's on Stockton.  Prices are right - about $1.50 an order of 3.  Bought 2 orders and some cha siu bau.
Their store name says it all. Can't wait to stop by again!

I arrived at 9:30am Monday.  There were a few people in line in front of us.  I picked up some sui mei, traditional sticky rice, and a cha sui bao.  The sui mei had some chewy pieces I didn't care for.  Flavor was good but it was barely warm.  The cha sui bao had nice flavor in the pastry and meat but it was at room temp.  The sticky rice was excellent just like my mom use to make it with peanuts, pork, and chinese sausage!  The price was $4 and an excellent deal.  I'd likely give this place a better rating if I knew when the busy time was so I could get everything hot and fresh.  I'd come back again and just get sticky rice!

OMG! We just happened to stop in front of this shop by chance, we wanted to go to the huge place next door but it was packed, thank gawd, you'll see why!  While we were contemplating it the waitress and the manager both came out to invite us all in. The place was a little cramped but very clean inside and they gave us a great table right in the window (wink wink) and the service was awesome. We got help ordering, the waitress was a little hard to understand but when you caught it she was chatting us up and making jokes, super awesome. Our first dishes we ordered showed up lickity-split, and she gave us two free dishes, freakin' awesome! We ordered Shui Mai, Potstickers, Sweet and sour pork, Steamed pork buns, a bowl of rice, and got chicken vegetable rolls and vegetable shrimp dumplings and it all tasted awesome! The waitress asked us how everything was several times, she knew what would taste the best and I haven't had such a fun meal in ages. The waitress went home before I could give her the biggest tip that I have ever given, but when we got the check it was only $24 to fill up 4 people, with a to-go box for dad! Crazy crazy awesomeness! I'm sorry but everything was perfect, best happy Dim Sum I've ever had! When we left the Yummy Restaurant we passed by the other Restuarant we were considering before and heard the most annoyingly awful Chinese Karaoke blasting all the way out into the street. Boy were we lucky that day!  Yummy Yummy Dim Sum!!!
Yummy is small with just a few tables for eat-ins. it's very evident with that this is a popular place for seniors et al. who order the various under $5 items here:

This place is so great.  3 pieces of dim sum for $1.50.  I know a lot of the other restaurants on Stockton/Chinatown have similar prices, but I just can't get over how cheap that is.  Wow.  I ordered a steamed BBQ pork bun (yum), a shrimp dumpling (yum), and a pork dumpling (probably my favorite).  The woman behind the counter was really friendly, and I saw others in the back making more dim sum.  There are maybe 5-6 tables to eat inside, and it was really a great experience.  I went around 5 pm on a Sunday, so she heated up the dim sum in a microwave (minor meh point) -- wondering if I came back during prime time if it'd be piping hot.  Recommend it!

This place has the best maan tous you will ever find. I used to get them by the dozens. They have wheat maan tous now which is better for my waist line...but I still prefer the original ones. The laap churng bao (Chinese sausage bun) is REALLY good!

Loved their steamed buns. The texture was perfect and it wasn't too sweet as I imagined it would be with the pppork buns. Customer service was good; no complaints Herr. Definitely coming back for more steamed buns!

Great dim sum! Open early! We were looking for some dim sum to go and checked out Louie's in China town. It is a great shop with hot, fresh dim sum. Very reasonable prices. The employees speak minimal English, but were patient with and worked hard to make sure they got the order right. Everything tasted so good, we went back for more to take on the plane for our dinner a few days later.

Best steam buns ever! Not sure about dim sum but steamed bun is good !  You can choose plain white or whole wheat bun.  Although whole wheat is the healthier choice, the plain white one is slightly sweet, chewy, and just delicious!

I want to like my neighborhood bao shops, but it's tough to give more than 3 even with the local bias. BBQ pork, meh, at least I was given a warm bun. Also had a zong zhi; it was standard fare, nothing to warrant a return visit.
I tried the steamed bun with custard inside. The custard filling was quite thick but overall ok.
Louie's pricing for their dim sum isn't in plain sight. it's in chinese opposite the dim sum counter. unless one has eyes at the back of your head, you can't see it when facing the counter lady.

It's been ages since I've came here. I do remember there were times when I came here steamed chinese sausage bun along some other pastry and dim sum items. I was still in elementary school the very last time I came here for dim sum and pastry items. Also, I consistently walk by this shop whenever I walk down Stockton St. I'm definitely going to make a stop here one day for some dim sum items. There are other nearby restaurants that serves dim sum as well and this basically gives Chinatown consumers a flexible choice in dining options. The menu items are appropriately priced so it is pretty much designed to fit anyone's budget. Anything I see is delicious, I would just go get it and eat it.
Came here because of all the positive review. Major disappointed. The items are small and kind of pricey.

This review is only for the steamed buns.  Every time I tell my parents I am going to the city, they ask me to pick up a dozen of the wheat steamed buns for them.  They are about 0.45 cents and worth every penny.  You can heat them up at home and spread some butter or peanut butter on them for breakfast and they are super delicious.  Or, you can just eat them by itself and savor the natural sweetness of the bun.  And, if you can't finish them right away, you can definitely freeze them and re-steam them at a later time.

This place is known for their "man tou" (plain steamed buns) and I would have to say that it is better than most places that I have tried. They used only offer the traditional white steamed buns, but now they have the wheat ones (I personally don't think the wheat taste as good).
Walked from our hotel on 3rd and Market intending to have some pasta down in Little Italy, but we ended up at Louie's in Chinatown instead.  Bought one order of each:
I have two words for you: man. tou.
It's all about the man tou here.

UGH. Well, okay. Maybe not completely ugh, just... maybe 65% ugh? I suppose it wasn't THAT bad, but paled considerably to Delicious Dim Sum just down the street which unfortunately set extremely high expectations of all Dim Sum joints in SF Chinatown... tourist mistake!).

For years, my family and I come here mostly for the mantao because they make THE BEST! I also like their bak tong goh and my parents love the veggie buns. Louie's is not the cleanest place but it's expected in good ol' Chinatown.

Let's face it people, your in China town, your kind tipsy, you DON'T know Chinese....sooo what the hell walk in to Louie's don't even try to ask the ladies what they are just pick a few dim sum and eat away...nom nom nom
This has an ok variety and is super cheap, so it's fine if you just want to try some dim sum. But there are great places down the block-see Mong Kok Bakery

Great dim sum bakery. Like everybody has already said, it's got the best mantao not just in town, but in the States. Tastes just like it does back in your hometown. I"m not sure why ppl are bitching so much and being so fussy. After all, the prices are dirty cheap. Do you ever go to a donut shop or coffee shop and get anything edible for $.50-.80? I don't think so. Have some respect and be a lit' grateful. If you guys have a problem shelling out chunk change like that, make your own damn food. That's what my parents would say. I missed the desserts they used to have. They used to have 2x-3x as much stuff but the past few yrs the demand for man tao was so great, they had to cut back most of the desserts. I love the sticky rice bao they have. Yums. That's my fave. I also like the spare ribs rice plate they had before.
For Lunch:

For all the reviews claiming this place is ghetto, dirty, and lacks English in their menus...it's all true but this IS Chinatown. There may only be a few English descriptions but you can see everything on display so just point and choose.

Louie's is a staple for me, both because I rarely have time to actually sit down for cart-service dim sum, and because it is such a short walk from my house.  The specialty here is anything steamed, and I'm a big fan of the pork buns and man tou.  I've heard talk of there being off-the-visual-menu items, such as something involving shark fins (ILLEGAL), but I don't speak Cantonese so I will never know. The dim sum is nothing special and a touch on the greasy side sometimes, but the nice older woman who owns the place ALWAYS throws a couple extra pieces in with whatever I order, which makes me feel undeservedly special.  This may not be the best place in Chinatown, but it's my place.

My family recently came to visit me from Ohio with an empty suitcase to fill with steamed buns from this place and Vietnamese sandwiches from Saigon Sandwich. That's how good the buns are here!  Hmm, I'm starting to think the only reason why they visit is to bring home food... Well, the mini veggie & pork buns are excellent and my parents say the plain steamed buns (with nothing inside) are just like the ones in Taiwan.

I was wakling on Stockton street looking for some cheap and good dim sum. And as I walked past Louie's Dim Sum I just had to walk in cause of the smell. Even the stranger that walked past it to did the same thing!

I am not a major fan of plain steam buns (man tou), but this would be the place I would go to if I ever crave one. You can tell they are good when ppl from all over the place known of this little dim sum shop just for it. They really know it too, they make batched and batched of them every single day! I have tried their usual plain steam buns made with regular flour before, but this visit, I was surprised that they offer it as well in wheat! I admit that I am not a healthy-eater. I don't like veggies, salads, white-meat, and so on...but wheat is something that's healthy and I don't mind. So, of course, when I saw there were wheat ones, I must try them! It's exactly the same in size as the usual ones except that it's slight brownish. It didn't taste bad, but it wasn't great. However, it's good though considering it's wheat. It was a nice try, but this is a little something that I'll prefer non-wheat. It's just something about a Chinese steamed bun that it has to be white....LOL.

Just had a sticky rice (tzong tze) from there. Pretty good for $1.90, it had pork, tendon, chinese sausage and peanuts in it! I bought two mantou for my boyfriend since they are his favorite...we'll see what he says about them!
I dropped in here thinking it had been renamed. Nope, still Louies, and nope... not better than GMK down the way.
Do you know what ManTou's are? they're these plain white buns that look like bricks. they have a subtle type of sweetness in the bread bit not as sweet as Hawaiian bread.
This place has gone downhill consistently for the past couple years and they have finally reached the bottom.
