It's a tourist trap so don't even bother. They usually have one or two waitresses standing outside who would convince you to come in by showing pictures of their food. Picture looks okay but check out the prices!  Way too overpriced for Chinatown! Go two more blocks up, hang a right on Stockton where all the yummy dimsum and bakeries are at. Got my fix at Good Mong Kok. It's the one with the long line outside :)

Beware!!! They add tips to your bill!  I thought that was too funny!  Food was okay, not anything exceptional that would make me say oooooh I will certainly back HOWEVER this is the second time of coming back here.  I just didn't remember until I asked the lady if their restaurant was on the second floor and as I was walking in that's when the déjà vu hit me.

ONe of my fave spots in chinatown . Of course Sam Woo was my number one fave. I am sorta lost with Sam Woo gone, I know for sure this is a place I will frequent tho.   I don't quite no where to place this place on the list but it is a really great place.    They even had this place in some scenes in the rush hour movies and one of leo dicaprio's movies.

Place is pricey as hell. $17 for Mongolian beef?! $12 for kung pao chicken?! Like WTH ITS CHINATOWN!!! I COULD TOTALLY HAVE BOUGHT THIS ELSEWHERE FOR LESS THAN HALF THE PRICE. the only rain we came was because my mom won these two $10 "gift cards" we decided to use them... Big mistake! They charge 18% gratuity on each dish... OH AND THE BOX IF FOOD WAS PRACTICALLY EMPTY. Disappointing prize...
Careful with the killer pigeons!!!

Very clean, quiet, food was wonderful. Had the snow peas and broccoli which was different but so flavorful. Potstickers were great and the chefs fried rice. Green tea ice cream was a nice ending.  I recommend.
Total tourist trap! Avoid on principle - they change prices after you order then slap on gratuity without agreement- food okay but not worth the money-Panda Express for $50 for 2 people ...grrrr
I would give this place a BIG ZERO if I could. FOOD POISONING ALERT! DONT EAT HERE!!!
Majority of food was really greasy. Though it was flavorful, the quality was not great.
SANITATION!!! I saw a rat scurry across the restaurant and promptly lost my appetite. We informed the owner and all he did was observe the general area we pointed to, then walked away.
Food was good but service was bad. Guy told us that it's mandatory to tip 15% in sf . What a bunch of craps. We just ordered the spicy crab n our bill came out to 60 bucks. Not worth it
Food are very pricy but not that good, very disappointed.

I've always liked this place even though every time we've gone we are the only ones in the dining room which is so weird. My husband ate here yesterday. We were the only ones, again, and we ate the spicy crab and beef chow fun. The food was ok, however the service was awful. Service plays a big role in the dining experience and can damage any further promise to return.

When I miss Singaporean food, this is where I go. The nasi lemak (coconut rice with fish, peanuts, and veggies) and gado gado (mixed veg with tofu, eggs, and sweet peanut dressing) are the closest one can get to authentic Singaporean food in San Francisco... 3 stars +1 star for uniqueness.
Pretty average Singapore/ Malaysian food. This is coming from a true blue Singaporean.. there's definitely much better options around in the South bay!
I came here because I had a mad craving for Hainan chicken, and this sufficed, but I'll probably be on the lookout for better places.

Average  service.  Was really looking forward to Singapore Char Kway Teow and  Laksa.  the CKT tasted like beef chow funn with some fish cake thrown in.  The laksa noodles were overcooked and the broth more if a curry sauce than a coconut based sauce you get in south east Asia.  Very disappointed.

I've been craving for Asam Laksa for awhile now, and although I knew that I really can't expect to find Penang street food as good as the ones I can get back home, I decided to go for it anyway, not putting too high expectations on the dish. Unfortunately, it was a little worse than I had expected... the laksa tasted like it was noodles cooked in broth made out of canned sardine, with too many chunks of pineapples :(

The food was good, but the service was poor. We split the sarang seafood, some stir fried noodles with chicken, and Chinese broccoli. I absolutely love sarang seafood - I get it every time I go to a Malaysian or Singaporean restaurant. It's a fried taro nest (so delicious!!) filled with veggies, seafood, and cashews. I liked that the seafood was not drenched in sauce like it is at some places. The stir fried noodles were decent, but nothing special. The Chinese broccoli was good though! The vegetables tasted very fresh and they were not too oily.

It's always bothered me how under-appreciated Malay and Indonesian cuisine is in the US. Maybe it's just my own personal tastes, but there are so many excellent dishes from the region that are overlooked. Plus, try finding a Malay restaurant... The Bay Area has the most of any other part of the country. I know, because I always look for them when I visit other cities, and they're really rare to find.

Great place. I come here all the time with family. The manager, Steven, makes an effort to make you feel comfortable and sometimes even offers free desert. The food here is great, especially the roti canai. One of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.

I frequent Penang when I am craving Penang food. Usually the restaurant is not too packed, so it's very easy to get a table or host big groups. Also, the prices are somewhat reasonable for city food near the main tourist areas. It's a great place to eat lunch/dinner if you're touring around San Francisco.
Food: The roti prata was great!!!!!! Very nice  and tasty sauce.
Back from a recent trip to Kuching Malaysia, I was searching for laksa. I ordered the curry laksa and santan lamb.

I went the other night for the first time.  It was my friend's birthday party and the staff kept accommodating our growing, disorganized group, all evening long.  Every dish was delicious!  When the check came I was amazed at how inexpensive all of the unique, yummy food was.  I will go back!!

I was looking for a Malaysian restaurant in d area and found this on Yelp. Chicken rice and satay were just average but roti canai was pretty good. Not bad but I've had better Malaysian food in d East Coast.

Taste: I was here yesterday and the taste of the famous crab was good. It's sort of odd since it's sweet and a bit spicy. It gets spicy over time. The bread that comes with the crab is okay, could be better.

A favorite little spot for lunch or dinner. They have cute decor and excellent food and drinks. Malaysian/Singapore food is slightly different than Thai food and here it is definitely a mixture of Malay, Singapore, Chinese and Thai foods. Some dishes I love:

after trying to go to 3 diff places but only finding out they were closed  (we joked it was karma for my friend being uber late to meet up their friend so we could grab lunch ;P) we settled on this place bc it was near where we were
Tried out Penang Garden after the SF Lunar New Year Parade.
The roti appetizer isn't bad, but definitely not authentic indian roti

I have just tried Penang Garden & thought that it was just over rated. The Chief on the food network does not know what is talking about good food. When you advertise "Hot & Spicy" then cook it like you advertise it & not make the crab Sweet & Sour. They should rename it to "Sweet & Sour" crab, whoever said this restaurant is the best in town I don't think so but I understand everyone has there own taste of food...

I came here knowing Penang only has 3 stars, but the huge banner of the hot & spicy crab reeled me in.  While I don't regret the meal, it once again reaffirms that Yelp rating are usually accurate.  Penang is an "A-OK" place -- good selection of pan Asian food that is relatively authentic, ok tasting, and all slightly overpriced,

This place earns the recommendation from Food Network. I love this place and had been going here for years. Highlight dishes are Yingyang fish, which half fried and half steam tilapia fish, ginger lobster, spicy crab, coffee flavor pork ribs. I always bring friends and out of towners here.  Decoration is nice, odd bar location, but they can serve drinks if you care.
Just saw a rat running across the kitchen floor. The restaurant is relatively clean otherwise. Food is americanized Malaysian style. What do you expect, this is Chinatown after all.

I am from penang, so I ordered char kuey tiow. I would not recommend it because it is way too off standard from Penang style. The hainan chicken rice also not taste like one, since lack of aroma. Other than than, the price is good and the service is good too.

Last time I came here was 2008. The food was very good, but now I guessed they changed a bit. Small proportion. The Dom Yum Gong noodle: almost soup only , had little seafood. Roti Canai: it's good, must order. Mango chicken: hmmmm, nothing special.

We were here for an event the other day.  The first three appetizer are yummy.  The satay, roti and shrimp lettuce wrap.  The rest of the meal was just blah.  Nothing special IMO.  I would only go back to try the crab that was on the food network.   But I have a feeling that it is overrated.
no any service, and not a fresh crab with hot and spice i think, it is not really worth to eat, beacuse it is very expensive. however, satay tasted good. i will not go there in the future.

A friend visiting town wanted to try Malaysian food, so we did a Yelp search and found this place.  We were happy to see it was bustling busy on a Friday night, and we ordred soup, noodles and a rice dish....my friend thought the soup was tasty but everything else seemed rather unauthentic.  The service was rude and not helpful so that overshadowed our dining experience and made me not want to come back here again.  Thanks, but no thanks.

Don't ever come here on a Sunday evening. I have been here 3 times and there has always been a party that takes up the entire restaurant. You have to sit near the front, where the servers forget about you and its cold.
Every time i come here i get so happy, the food is so flavorful and its a great location

I was meeting a colleague from the advertising industry for lunch and she was elbow deep in work so it was best that we met up somewhere close by. I had no idea what was good in that area, so she called it and chose Penang Garden. We had some important things to discuss and I was so focused on the conversation that we were having, so I really didn't have my head in the game when I ordered.

We like to eat at this place every time we are in Chinatown. The food is always well seasoned and tasty. We usually order a few of these dishes: Roti Canai, Penang Asam Laksa, Malaysia hot and spicy spareribs, and eggplant and garlic (off menu). Steps away from the Portsmouth parking lot helps.
Great Singapore chili crab, pricy but worth it.  Not sure why this place gets such mixed reviews we liked everything.

Good value, especially for lunch. The place was pretty empty when we got there and the decor is a little bit much for my tastes. Though the food was good, it's nothing special. If I'm back in chinatown, I'd rather try something different.

My tour guide decided to take me here, since I haven't really tried any food places in SF Chinatown. He said he usually comes here once a month and has a specific order of dishes he usually gets. I decided to join him during his monthly visit, to see what keeps bringing him back here.
Italian soda was good, not too sweet.  Just a random ice cream/soda shop.  Didn't try the food.  Service was fine.  Interior could have been cleaner, but lots of seating.

Since the reviews are so low, almost afraid to post a 3 star review.  The food was very good for being in a food court, and I thought the prices were fair a for food court in a city.   The servers were friendly.   Food courts in general aren't my favorite type of food,  or I would give this place even more stars.

If I could leave a zero I would. We had to use the bathroom, so we came in and bought two drinks. A homeless man came in and berated me and my mother for 5 MINUTES. the staff did nothing, didnt even tell him to leave. I know how to stick up for myself, so we were fine, but I was appalled at how everyone acted. This man walked up to us IN THE RESTAURANT and started verbally assaulting us. Another man came to our defense, but not a single employee. If you need to take a dump, this is the place. Nothing else.

This place is HORRIBLE don't come there. So I need to use the restroom so me and my friends decide to go in n buy something so I could use the restroom cuz it be rude of us if I use the restroom without buying anything. As I rush to the restroom my friends was looking at the menus to order something n this rude lady that work there yell at us she told us " you have to buy something or else it $1 per person to use the restroom" the outside of the restroom may look clean but the restroom disgusting. There were flies every where n the toilet set so dirty I was affair to sit down. My friend end up buying ice cream that taste like the place disgusting n horrible.

The most horrible customer service in the world! My friends and I came in wanting to use the bathrooms, and yes we were looking to buy something. When our friends went in the lady from the register started yelling at us saying, "the bathroom isn't free! You have to buy something or pay." Well excuse me miss, that's exactly what we were going to do? why else would be browsed around your store? We ended up getting something, and not surprisingly it sucked. My friends and I left really unhappy... Expensive ass food with horrible service. They should at least pretend to be nice...geez. You can't have bad food and be mean at the same time, that's just horrible!
Total dive for Chinese and Vietnamese food.

This place is absolutely awful. We came in here to use the bathroom and of course we wanted to buy something so they don't get pissy. I was looking at their menu's and l was decided on what to get. My friend went to the bathroom and the lady behind the ice cream counter started bitching at us about how we had to buy something. What did she think I was doing when I was looking at her items?
Horrible horrible service! OK, it's cheap and food is not bad, but wow, can we give negative tip?
The food was cold. Don't go there
Don't do it!  Hard sell and the food is absolutely repulsive.  If this wasn't a tourist area, it would be still be there.

Unless you're into your banana smoothies tasting like watery milk, stay away. Bland, blah. After buying and dining there, I asked for them to break a $10 bill. They made me buy another item off the menu. Lame.
I went to Chinatown Food Court a few days ago, lured into the restaurant by the pictures of pho displayed outside. Not a great choice, as it turned out.
Prices are a little higher than other Chinese restaurants in SF but the portions here are small
OMG, ick.  That about sums it up.
Horrible food.
Overall the only word I have for this place is Disastrous!
REVIEW ON THEIR VIETNAMESE SANDWICH!

GET THE PHO or don't go. OK, this 2 star review is for the Pho only - a giant bowl of decent pho soup. The food on the panda-express style cafeteria counter looked disgusting and none of the customers getting it looked happy, the place is dirty and workers seemed confused and clueless.

Avoid this place.  I filed a complaint with SF Public Health after unfortunately eating here today.  Let me count the ways.  No soap in the women's bathroom (all women food workers).  Ick!  Worker at the cash register alternately handling food and then money.  No gloves.  I observed no food workers wearing gloves.  One worker came from the food prep area to receive a shipment of goods in a delivery, carried them back to the kitchen, and began to prep food without washing her hands or gloving up.  If this isn't enough to convince you to skip this place, check the public health website for their food inspection score.  High risk due to rodents/roaches
Dirty pigeons inside the restaurant and walking on the tables. Food was just plain crappy... 'Nuff said.
I'm writing this review as a reminder to myself that this place is the worst. WORST!
This place is disgusting.  It looked okay when we went in.  After walking up and down Grant without finding anything, the kids were complaining so much we decided to go in.

Woman was nice, but boba tea was soooooo expensive. Besides, everyone knows you just come here to buy something so you can use probably the only bathroom in Chinatown aside from the one in Portsmouth Square.
Tourist Spot or more like Tourist Trap...
Worst bubble tea I've ever had.  Their watermelon bubble tea tasted like chalky Pepto Bizmo.  Had to throw it away.  This place must only stay in business because of it's tourist trap location.

The place is exactly as the other reviews describe. Pretty dirty, a pretty questionable kitchen, and the food is barely edible and probably not going to kill you.... but I wouldn't bet on it. It was a couple dollars more expensive than comparable establishments with clean kitchens in the same neighborhood.

Stopped in for some quick take-out during dinnertime.  I should've turned around and left when nobody else was in there, but I was craving some beef noodles and didn't think there would much of a wait.  After what seemed like 15 minutes of waiting after ordering, my food finally came.

I'm not giving this place any stars.  What ever they are selling ... not real chinese food.  I'm not even sure if that was real chicken they served.  We were on our way out of china town.  I wanted to bring some won ton soup home.  Yeah.. my wontons were sour.

1. The only other people in this place were a guy who was on his lunch break, and a tourist family that included a handful of loud children and two visibly weary moms who probably just chose this place because it was the first place they saw.

If I could give this place 0 stars I would!  We had been walking around and were super thirsty, I was in the mood for a pearl tea, so we bi-passed Starbucks and came here.  I guess I should've figured to leave when my friend asks for shaved ice, which is on the menu, and the lady rudely tells her they don't have it....ok on to the next one.  Watermelon juice, it's on the menu, again, rudely told they don't have it, she had the demeanor of, "why are you asking for stuff we don't have?" I'm thinking, really, you're getting mad at us because you don't have what you advertise?  Ok so she puts up with the lemonade, which she says tastes like a cheap version of Crystal Lite.  Friend 2 and I got a pearl tea.  I got Thai iced tea, which in itself was mediocre, the pearls however, tasted old and frozen.

This place used to be a McDonalds. It is located in the heart of Chinatown. Chinatown Food Court is basically a poor imitation of Panda Express with the exception that it sells ice cream and yogurt. Overrall, I was pretty disappointed. I wish the McDonalds came back. True, the Mac Donalds seemed grossy out place, but it provide a consistent causal dinning experience. Chinatown Food Court does look nice on the outside and inside.  However, the food is a different story. The sweet and sour pork was soggy and bland. The meat was dry and stringy.  I regard "sweet & sour pork"  as the Chinese fast food restaurant concept's  bell wether dish.  If they can't do this right, then this place has some serious problems. The curry chicken was better, but there was nothing special about. It was generic curry sauce with small pieces of chicken. The Kung Pao chicken was disappointing. It tasted like spicy soy sauce.  The chow mein was OK.  But there was nothing special about it. Panda express is much better than this place, even the one in Japantown. I guess if you are a European tourist who do not know the difference between a burritto and a spring roll, and do not know where Kearny Street is, then  you might be attracted to this place like fly is attracted to a Pitcher plant.  Also, customer service was mediocre.
I was under the impression that any place in china town will have good pearl tea, but they proved me wrong.
This place used to be a mcdonalds.

in this building are two "food" stands,  a chinese fast food one  at the front and the other to the right.  the other sells double rainbow ice cream, cookies,  tapoica drinks, smoothies, beer, and froyo. the young lady that operates this stand also works at the chinese food stand.

F-  !!!! In case you didn't understand, that's F minus. I've never been to a restaurant this horrible. I never thought that such scores existed, but.. now I do. Yes, we fell victim to those tourist traps in San Francisco, what a pity. The food was hideous, the demeanor of the server was horrendous, and the prices were totally unacceptable, based on the type of food they served. DO NOT COME HERE!!! THEY ARE totally not worth the money. If it weren't for the fact that we were super hungry, this place wouldn't squeeze 1 cent out of me.

I'm torn between 2 and 3 stars. Stopped in here after the Chinese new year parade. First off its not really a food court because there are only two types of food: generic old Chinese and a cookies and coffee stand.

My friend says that they have the best spicy tofu here (ma po tofu). It is okay, I do not get why she likes it soo much, it is just drenched in a lot of chili oil..I will just put this review up for her.

I've only ever come here for the frozen yogurt as this place positively SCREAMS tourist trap. That said, it's the closest place to my apartment offering frozen yogurt, so in spite of myself I find myself frequenting my around-the-corner "food court" more often than I'd like to admit.

Fro-yo girl here.  I found another odd spot for fro-yo on the edge of Chinatown.  It's not a food court with multiple vendors/stalls but there are two separate counters.  The one in the back has Chinese (and Japanese) fast food (many fried items, warming trays, 2 items for $5.59) with steamed and baked buns (savory items).  To the right the sweets counter has 8 flavors of Double Rainbow ice cream, cookies, tapioca drinks (made from powders and syrups), smoothies and fro-yo.

ok. first off, the only reason we stopped here was because we were starving. the food was not cheap. 7 dollars for 2 plate entre. mine consisted of chow mein, which tasted like a pile of... absolutly nothing, as it had no flavor what so ever. the sesame chicken had a good flavor at first. untill i bit into it and could barley swallow it down because of how dry it was. the one thing i did like was that the place was pretty clean, and they had some decent music. thats about it. would rather do panda any day. oh and credit cards are a $10 limit to use them.

The food isn't too bad, but the customer service is pretty bad. The lady taking our order was giving my friend attitude when we were ordering. Also, they demanded us to tip. That's ridiculous. Never coming back here.
The food was plentiful and good.  I'd go back when in SF

The bad reviews? We saw clean restrooms for ourselves and enjoyed a very delicious dim sum lunch with good service.  Must try the CREAM BUTTER BUNS!!! Also - cash only!  My boyfriend was able to get to an ATM while I waited.  :)
It's a pretty average place with pretty decent food.  I'm sure you can get the same quality on the next block, and the next block, and the next block, and the next block.

i went in to try out their $5 clay pot special posted on their sign - all their other clay pot items are priced at $8 and up.  well, after a few bites, i discarded the rest.  i know im can be a bit picky when it comes to food but there really wasn't anything special about the clay pot.  the food tasted bland and the vegies weren't cooked all the way.
We went there on a Friday night at 7:30.

We were roped in by the waitress. She was very efficient and direct, but nice and accommodating. We asked for take out, and she had us sit down and offered us water. I'd love to come back. Not sure what I'm eating is chicken.

I am going to give this place a 4 stars, it is not their service, it is their food, 100% authentic Chinese Tai Seng style, I like it and so does my friends.  The place can fall into a hole in the wall category but the food is pretty good!

Gawd, this place is so crass and ghetto.  They try to dress it up as New Asia's fancy kin but with long cafeteria style tables, it isn't shouting high class here.  I prefer a small table that seats 4 rather than sidling in the cafeteria table with the rest of the masses (so China dining!).

I feel bad leaving a crappy review, but the dim sum is not great. The paper is way too thick and it just wasn't good at all. The only thing that was good was the own ton soup- not amazing but good. The service was ok, and they have some very authentic items on their menu, but it just wasn't good.

Came here on a Sunday night after a busy afternoon at the Flower Fair, place was half empty and we were seated immediately. Place is relatively neat, chairs are all wrapped still, and the table is clean/not sticky. As with all Chinatown restaurants, service is non-existent. But onto the food!

The food is three stars but service and friendliness is FIVE stars.  First time here and they greet you like you're a regular. Will definitely be back. I did like the chicken feet with black bean sauce. It's  different from most places so it was a nice and tasty change.
Robbed!!
Cash only. That was the biggest drawback of this restaurant.

Ok, there were a lot of locals in the place, the service was good and the Dim Sum was tasty. The only problem was, my niece found 2 gnats or small flies in her food. They were very nice about it and gave us a replacement dish. The price was reasonable and aside from the little problem, it was fine.
Yummy Yummy looked clean, semi-busy, mostly elderly patrons wtihin. dining room had a medicine aroma/ambience. small hole in the wall eatery.
The place was completely deserted during dinner time, and food was at best mediocre.
I said that I was going to give the items in this restaurant a try and provide a review update, so here it is.
We come here often mainly because I haven't been able to find a decent Dim Sim place since my favorite one closed (Chinese Hospital Admin office is there now).

Cute place. The service is not great, though. They have a two person couch for waiting customers. Since that was full (and I couldn't stand up because I had been walking all day), I had to sit on a stack of newspapers.
Pork bun was not great. The pork was cold and gelatinous.

Shrimp dumplings were amazing. Potstickers were also very good. Decor was very authentic. Definitely caters to authentic chinese people. I went with my adorable godson who is kinda picky eater and his extra picky mom from Manhatten.

Trace, the waitress there was amazingly sweet! I promised that I'd leave a review for her. Even with the language barrier, I pulled out my phone to show her what Yelp was all about! She was so appreciative!

Worse customer service ever!  This place caters to tourist.  A lady is outside trying to attract business.  But once you're inside you're forgotten.  We went on a Saturday night and it was pretty empty...  Now we know why! Order 4 entrees for the 5 of us.  First we said the meat tasted funny and it was explain to us that is the way they marinated the meat.  OK... so my girls didn't like the two orders of noodles which contained the meat so we decided to take one of the two orders of noodles to go.  My girlfriend ask for 2 containers so that the noodles didn't get soggy.  What we got was one container filled to the max with all the noodles and hot soup.  We asked for another container to transfer the soup out.  The waitress brought us an additional container and preceded to open the full container.  In the process, spilling hot soup on my GF hand, on the table, and all over the plastic bag it came in.  Asking for another bag was also met with a lot of hesitation and mean looks.

I was attracted by the well done food pictures in the windows and as I stood in front of the place an employee came out and asked me to come in and eat.  Inside was empty except for a family of tourists.  Bad omen I should not have ignored.  Only one block from Stockton St. : Ground zero for Chinese fast food, Friday afternoon, Yummy Yummy should have been at least half full of Chinese diners. Anyway, I wanted food to go and I asked what was quick. Combination fried rice, she said. How much, I asked.   When she said $12.00 I thought, well, it must be super-gourmet...or maybe she thought I was the 1%.  I asked for a menu and eventually chose General Tsoa's  chicken.  Took about 10 minutes, I paid $10.00 and left.

Walking along pacific ave in chinatown in attempts to locate a appealing yet reasonably priced meal(since its chinatown, might as well be cheap), a lady steps out onto the busy street and in a very nice and unforceful way asks my girlfriend and I to step inside and look at the dim sum menu, and we did.
I went here two times for dinner and for dim sum.

Yummy Yummy, I have a weird feeling in my tummy.  Maybe I shouldn't have been adventurous and gotten the Spicy Pickle & Pork dish?  ...but there wasn't much pork, so it must have been all those darn pickles?

The service here is good and they open an hour ealier then new asia.  They don't have alot of choices put kinda pricey.  The bring out the stuff fast.  I guess it in the warmer in the back.  They seem to care about being on your good side and they smile alot.
Honestly, not all that amazing; pretty mediocre dim sum. My mom seems to love this place for some reason but I think the only dim sum place that has my heart is "The Kitchen" in Millbre.
Very good food and helpful waitress for us  dumb Americans.

Excellent dim sum! The rumor is the chef is listed in some compilation of the top 100 Chinese chefs. If true the honor is deserved. In my 25+ years eating dim sum in Chinatown, I have never had better service. The restaurant is spotless, the wait staff is courteous, attentive. Even the restroom is clean. I almost had to pinch myself! We had five different vegetable and shrimp steamed dumplings, each better than the preceding one. The stuffed eggplant was amazing. We were asked several times if there was anything we needed. Our tea was refilled, our empty dishes whisked away. Dessert was sesame balls and a delicious, fluffy egg cake slice. The food was truly outstanding. Everyone spoke some English and raved about our very limited, clumsy Chinese. I am not saying anything about the chairs just to leave something to surprise you. We have known about Yummy Yummy for three days and have been back twice! We haven't tried anything off the menu yet... the carts are too tempting!

Stopped in for a quick dim sum lunch. Very nice. Nothing we had was deep fried so it was pretty healthy too.  Try the onion/shrimp dumplings. Very food. This is a nice little treat of a restaurant. The wait staff and owner were very kind, prompt, and professional.

Walking the Chinatown Chinese New Year street fair and getting hungry.  Saw Yummy Yummy and remember reading they serve dim sum.  Looks like a decent space so we walked in.   There were only two large tables open - a rectangular in the front and a round one in the back.  They were speaking English to us and asked if we mind sharing a table - we said no worries and were lead to the back round table.  I also told them in Chinese, no need to speak English to us - we saw a big smile and a look of relief.

Was as surprised as my parents were that they decided to open a 'yum cha' place by New Asia in this dinky little storefront, so we decided to come here for lunch today.  As much as I'd like to say it was good, I don't see this place surviving very long given the quality of food they have (especially since their prices aren't terrific).  They have the usual walk-around with platters of food service, and since the place is a bit small, you get a good selection of food even if you're far away from the kitchen area.  Considering how much they seem to rely on their rice, noodle, and porridge dishes to make money (kinda pushy on ordering something of the sort), they have a good selection of dim sum.  None of my favorite (chive dumplings), but all your regular steamed goods and not much of the fried/pan-fried stuff.

Yes, another Dim Sum restaurant can be added to the ongoing list for Chinatown. This restaurant took over a former Vietnamese noodle house so it is definitely not your typical decor for a dim sum facility. The place was full when my dad and I arrived but were seated within about 5 minutes. The service still needs to adjust but that can be forgiven since its so new. We sat near the back and they serve dim sum by the tray from table to table. They even have a menu of the items that they serve on your table with the prices written out. The service was quick but a little flustered. We were served tea but no stamp card given.

You may be asking yourself, is this place pho real? The answer is yes....stop in around noon on a weekday and you'll be greeted with a packed dining room. The community table option means you won't have to wait more than 15 minutes, even at peak lunch hour. There's nothing cozy about this place, except for the feeling a big bowl of pho leaves you with. The chicken pho comes with a rich and satisfying broth, the accompanying limes, mint, and jalapeños are always super fresh, and the chicken meat is surprisingly tender and completely skin- and cartilage-free. The vegetable pho is slightly lacking in flavor, but makes up for it with loads of fresh vegetables. The imperial rolls are so-so. The waiters are brisk, but pleasant enough. At $7.50 for a teeming bowl of hearty pho, this place can't be beat. They also offer generously portioned pho take-out. I also find it convenient that you can walk in at the odd hours of 10am or 3:45pm, for example, and order take out or eat in.

This place is right in the heart of Chinatown, where all the Asian cuisine you can pick with all your fingers are there awaiting and I must admit, a warm bowl of pho is tempting as any on a chilly San Francisco evening. Then why the one star less? One less shining star makes all the difference between a tasty bowl of pho and a delicious bowl of pho.. I had my very first bowl of pho here when I was a child and the first owner was an amazingly genuinely kind and welcoming woman who must've boiled her water with love and secrets. I'm a fan of this place, but since my last bowl of pho, maybe more in memory but I love pho nonetheless.
One of our favourite Vietnamese restaurants to go for a bowl of phò. Huge bowls,  nicely seasoned and not to salty. Friendly staff.
Holy Pho, Batman! This place is great.  Ran into it by accident and it was amazing. Great prices, service, and amazing food.
I was about to head to San Sun nearby with my parents but decided to try Golden Flower instead.

Service was good, but the food not so.  I ordered chicken pho and found a huge gnat it with wings, antennas and everythjng.  The pho itself was ok. Kinda looked watered down. The bowls were big, but didn't have enough noodles or meat. The chicken itself was real tough as if it's been sitting out. My fiancé ordered bbq chicken rice plate & he mentioned that it was sour and not good.  He barely ate 4 bites and couldn't eat anymore.  My daughter had spring rolls which were ok. Don't think I'm coming back here again.

We had lunch on 9/24/2014. We really wanted Dim Sum but came upon tHis gem. Small but cozy and the staff is friendly and swift. I had the pork with rice and noddles. My wife had the egg rolls. Both were fantastic. The prices are low and the service excellent. Would definitely return.
Found this place by accident, really tasty pho, and practically empty. Surprising, since there were lines out the door for other places just around corners.

This is a very inexpensive place. They have the pictures of the food so that you don't have to think about what you want. It's right in the middle of Chinatown you have to really look for it because there are a ton of competitors and you might miss it. The imperial roll is just ok.

Wow, we found this hidden place as we looked around the corner when we were touring china town. This place probably has some of the best pho I've tasted in the bay area!! I was really pleasantly surprised.

I've realized that Yelp is not so reliable for certain types of eateries, so the 3.5 star rating for Golden Flower was reassuring. Chinatown restaurants need not be clean, just cheap and good-tasting. Which Golden Flower is: I decided to branch out from pho and get the #36 cold rice noodles with shrimp and pork. One of my friends and I also split an order of imperial rolls. They tasted freshly fried and very crunchy, thus yummy, though I couldn't quite distinguish what the fillings were. The noodles come with a sweet/sour/spicy sauce, same as the dipping sauce for the rolls, but I also added a bit of soy sauce for saltiness. One can easily get a satiating meal here for less than $10, so Golden Flower is a win in my book.

Best vietnamese sandwich ever! I got the BBQ pork viet sandwich and it was BOMB AF. I love how the bread is super crunchy and the meat is roasted to PERFECTION (not too burnt or overcooked as some places make it). Theres also alot of carrots that make it extra yummy and some jalepenos to make it just spicy enough but not too spicy. The portion was also pretty good and filled me up :)
A pretty small place with pretty good food!
Reminds me of good old times with mom when she use to take me to chinatown. BUT the food isn't all the great, average pho. Staff was attentive though.

Been here 2x.  The owner, Kim, is a sweetheart.  She even gave me tea while I wait for my take-out dinner.  I ordered Bo Tai Chanh (raw beef salad) each time.  It was good, but the quality isnt consistent.
Not bad.

Very modest but INCREDIBLE vietnamese food made traditionally by an immigrant couple with nothing but  great inherited home made recipes.  Every plate we ordered was amazingly full of flavor... Thank you.

Really good Pho. Came across this place while exploring Chinatown. The portions are really good for the price and the food is really good. The beef broth they put in their Pho is some of the best I've ever tasted. I would recommend if you are near this place and are craving something warm on a cold Bay night, go to the Golden Flower.
The first Pho Restaurant I've been to in San Fran and it was really good.
Well just like the Koreans taking over Japantown, the Vietnamese are taking over Chinatown, just more slowly.
Wonderful!! The plates were large enough to share, but too delicious and I didn't want to share! They had a large enough vegetarian menu with wonderful options. I wish we lived closer!

First time in china town! And this place was amazing- we had pho  that's soooo good. I believe the owner was serving us whom was super friendly and just gave us a homie / cozy feeling!!! Best pho ever!
Best Pho in SF, hands down.

We ate here last week and it was awesome. You have to dig deep into Chinatown to get here and it's worth it. I got #36 (can't remember the name) but it was basically a huge bowl of awesome noodles and healthy stuff topped with shrimp and pork. My word - so good. Definitely give this place a try!

Their foods are really Delicious. I fall in love hue spicy beef noodle, it's maybe one of the best in SF. Located in Chinatown and next to 2 awesome Chinese restaurant, Golden flower Vietnamese restaurant is not a wrong decision for people who love Vietnamese food
Solid and cheap Vietnam kitchen. Big ass Pho for only 7 bucks! Big but not really intense of flavor. Worth the price but that's it.

Worst place ever. Horrible service never coming back again. To the short haired lady wearing pink floral shirt today you are the rudest waitress i ever met. Telling us to move when we are in the middle of eating...hell no gtfo can't we eat in peace just cause theres a bigger party coming in doesn't mean you shove us to the corner. And i wasnt even done looking at the menu so why would you take my menu without asking. We didnt do anything and you dont even give us the stuff for the pho wtf...
Decent pho. Excellent prices. Comes out fast. Takes credit card!

Wow. Portions are really large. Family run Vietnamese which is charming. Vietnamese coffee is nice and refreshing on a hot day. The place is full of Vietnamese and westerners. A good sign IMO. Not as authentic as a dirty local restaurant in Hanoi but that's being picky. We left satisfied.

food: Bo Tai Chanh Lemon Rare Beef!!! its oddly in the salad section of the menu. if you can stomach the idea of eating slices of raw beef, this is the dish to go for. it comes in slices topped with cilantro, peanuts, and some nuoc mam sauce. the meat is tender to the bite. it has a sweet and a hint of sourness to the crunch and the aromatics of the herbs used. not many places have this and if they do they cant replicate this simple dish. ***5/5
Stopped by this relatively spacious place (for chinatown) for some pho and bun bo hue. The pho was pretty good and lived up to any other pho I've had.

This place is phenomenal. I don't know why there are negative reviews! I'm korean and I've had a loooot of pho before and I've even travelled to Vietnam and had authentic pho there. This place's pho is BURSTING with flavor and is so filling! Even the smaller bowl. The pice point is perfect-suuuuper affordable. The Vietnamese coffee is also fresh and obviously just as delicious.

I come hear for lunch some time the is very busy but the food is the best in the city parking is heard but they a parking lot and it under the prak and just walk 5 min and your hear it gets busy mon to fri at 12 noon to 3 pm it lunch time for the business around the area they long line sometime will injoy
This is a small family run Vietnamese restaurant on a side street in Friscos china town

my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in ct. There are a lot of restaurants in Chinatown. They also have a lot of Vietnamese restaurants but I find that Golden Flower is most authentic. Whenever I'm in the area and I'm not getting dim sum, its Golden Flower! I tried a lot of dishes here and they have never failed me. Cold days i prefer Pho Tai (steak flanks) and when its hot, I usually get their Bun dishes, Usually the one with imperial rolls and Thit Nuong (i think it's pork?) and Viet Coffee :) yumm
Their Pho Ga is no good. Go somewhere else for Pho Ga

I had a vegetarian plate that consistef of sauteed vegetables in curry sauce, fried rice and some tea. The curry sauce was excellent and I normally don't like it. I would come again. This was my first time here. Oh and the bathroom was very clean.
I love this place, I am such a picky eater.. I am vegetarian, and thankfully they offer a vegetable noodle soup not quite sure if that is pho or not but I just love that its not a meat based broth!!
Got a number 1 and it was so small. It was literally a small (compared to other stores) in a big bowl. Don't even want to think about the size of medium or small.
I Liked this place, didn't want to review it cause didn't want to share this place to anyone, haha

This place is crap. The staff is rude. The food is crapy. I ordered one sushi pIate of 12 pieces and fried banana and it turned out to be $19! Plus I had terrible stomach pain a couple of hours after I ate their sushi. I should have known better as there was only one person when I came in. The place itself is not the most neat and clean. Never coming here again.
Like many of the previous reviews, I would give this place a negative star if possible.

This was a bad experience for many reasons. One, the woman working was rude and abrupt. Some of it can be attributed to cultural difference, but mostly she was just unfriendly and had no customer service skills. The sushi chef, meanwhile, was talking on her cell phone which was right next to our table. The food is overpriced. We ordered pork spring rolls (3). They were the tiniest things I've ever seen. Seriously, like the size of baby carrots. I cost $6. The sushi boats themselves looked very unfresh and they were not cold or refrigerated. All-in-all, this is a tourist trap.
I love my kaiten, and the .99 special on the sign outside made me think quick and cheap snack.

1st off, avoid the bento boxes for this place is primarily for sushi. 2nd, most bad reviews were looking for the cheap stuff. you really don't want to eat cheap sushi-you know what I mean? I always keep an open mind and know that the signs posted are teasers to get you in, like used car lots. Sushi in Chinatown? You betcha. My expectation low for many eateries in Chinatown are mediocre at best. this place would be a hit if it was closer to the financial district lunch crowd. the ika and tako was the freshest I have ever tasted. not like other places where the stuff sits there in room temp. sushi chef will make you anything you request.  ashamed to say that after moving away from SF, I discovered a place I would have frequented if I was a local.

Flies on the sushi boats...yuck! Saw the same pieces revolve the entire hour of dining; who knows how long they were there before we arrived. Rude servers...seated at the bar and five minutes later gave our drink order and food order after flagging down a waitress. Not a long wait for the food was a plus. The wait for the bill was ridiculously long...my boyfriend walked to the bakery down the street and back twice before we even saw our bill! We walked it up to the register to pay because it seemed the waitress didn't want our money. Not a place I recommend coming to if you're in a hurry and want fresh food!

This place doesn't deserve a star in any category whatsoever. My boyfriend and I stopped here because r&g was packed and we wanted sushi, not being from sf we had no idea what mistake that was. I ordered the beef & chicken teriyaki, which came out cold and the beef was all fat! Not only was that 16$...ridiculous for teriyaki, but the 'waitress' never got us water or wanted to reheat my food. Then when it came time to pay, SHE AUTOMATICALLY ADDED GRADITUITY. Are you joking? Infuriated to say the least. This place is a health hazard and needs to be shut down.

We were both suddenly hungry and with the mid-autumn festival winding down, we stumbled upon the Floating Sushi Boat. Neat idea...sushi floats by on little boats as you look and see what you like, take and pay by the type of plate it is on. There was good variety, not expensive, moves quickly so many options, and there is ordering from the menu as well. Good meal. Quick and comfortable space too.

On August 10 at 4:00 PM, I took my mother to Floating Sushi for a lunch date. Let me start off by saying that the workers here are all RUDE. I didn't even bother to tip them, it was really that bad. Let me elaborate.
Frankly, I don't get the unfavorable reviews. Food & service are quite good. And I love the watermelon juice.
Absolutely awful. Wish I had checked Yelp before we sat down. Wish I could give this place zero stars. Ah, but a wish is a wish. Hold on tight folks, this review is going to be wild...
nice place, good food, but not enough to put 5 stars. it s close to china town and it s very tipical of this aerea. the plates are in the boats that sail into a channel around the chef. amazing!
After our food was delivered, the staff never came by our table again. We got the waitress's attention after just sitting there for a while to ask for the bill. She said "okay" and walked off.

The formula is very easy: 1) you can take the food from the floating boats, and then you pay for what you eat according to the colour of the plate (from 0.99$ to 4.99$ a plate), and 2) you can order directly to them after have seen the menu! The basic rolls start from 6$ and the special ones cost about 14$. A plate of yaki soba costs about $10
Wish I can give this place zero star.

This restaurant do not deserve any rating.  The food was so bad and the sushi not fresh!  You do not want to eat anything raw in this restaurant for that matter.  Stay away from this place.  I went to this restaurant on Sunday and after a bad experience with the food and the poor service, my bill showed up with tip already added.  There were only 2 of us and one 5year old child.  We asked why tip was added and they said because it is a touristy location in Chinatown and they feel that tourists do not know that they are required to tip so the restaurant added the tip themselves.  I asked them to remove the tip because i am a resident of San Francisco and i know about tipping.  I am only in the restaurant because i was showing a tourist around Chinatown.  I asked for the tip to be removed and I was told that they would do so and will credit the charges.  Instead, today in went onlne and saw that my credit card statement shows 2 charges, one with tip included and another without the tip.  They did not refund anything and instead charged me twice.  Avoid this restaurant at any cost.  I now have to deal with them to get a refund or call my credit card company and record a FRAUD!  What a bad experience for me and my out-of-towner.
Disgusting.  PERIOD.. If zero star was available, that's what I would give them. Place is nasty looking and dirty as hell
If there is a zero star that would be it. The waitress acts like you own her a mil bucks. Food is terrible, and expensive for an average place like this. Hope they shut down soon
I like to stop for lunch when visiting but it is expensive for average sushi and a wait staff that orders you around, "sit there," "more beer."

Horrible establishment with rude servers, gross food, and dirty everything. I didn't expect the greatest service considering we were in Chinatown, but this place literally set the record for worst dining experience ever. We came in at around 2pm on a Sunday and were not greeted at all. The waitress directed us to sit at the bar and quickly and unwillingly explained to us how the system worked. I saw a bug crawling on the table but didn't even bother to point it out because of the waitress's attitude. The plates are differentiated by the design of the plate that corresponds to the pricing. All the dishes looked like they had been sitting out for a while and everything just looked very un-fresh. All the sushi is premade and stored in these disgusting boxes. Every once in a while, the waitress will transfer the sushi from the box to the plates on the boats. I was so disgusted that I only had one plate of eel nigiri. After we ate, we went up to the register to pay and ran into another problem. My plate was $4.40 so I handed her a $20 bill. The corner of my bill was slightly ripped and she said she couldn't accept it and even argued with me and asked if I would accept a ripped $20 bill if I were in her shoes. That was literally the tipping point for me. I didn't have any other cash on me so I was about to just walk out because I was so fed up. There is a $10 minimum on credit cards but she ended up making an exception and let me use my credit card. Never in my life would I ever come back!

We were looking for a place to have dinner. We must have went in and out of this place 2-3 times trying to decide if we should or not. Nothing about the place really appealed to us. The deciding factor was just the idea of sitting at the bar and having the sushi float by and grabbing what you want.  We should have #1, went with our instinct and fled, and #2, checked yelp!!

Strange that nobody mentioned about automatic tip charge. Food was bad, service was horrible, and what makes it worse is that this place automatically add 18% tip to the bill. I asked why, and The reason is? They told me that because they are in the tourist business! Hello! My advice? Do not go there. Total waste of money.

OMG I WISH I HAD READ YELP BEFORE GOING HERE. The service was terrible and the food even worse. Was in the mood for sushi and thought--hey--why not! I had walked into one of the Chinese restaurants nearby and walked back out bc nothing appealed to me, and I had already seen this place and thought--sushi!  I got the combo A, bc i thought that would be fresher sushi then was going around on the boats since they would have had to make it, but i'm pretty sure they just took it off of the boats. It was way worse than supermarket sushi, which is like the bottom of the barrel for me. So gross. Don't waste your money.
I should've read the Yelp reviews before I came to this place.
The server was very rude, had no patience, would disappear for a long time and never came back to check if I wanted anything else. On top of it, the food was bad.

Sooooo HORRIBLE ! Came exploring to Chinatown with friends and we were super hungry, and saw .99 / piece sushi advertisement outside, we weren't so sure about it but we thought why not ? Let's try a few pieces and if not we'll leave.

I wish there were negative stars. Worst sushi of my life. Day old grocery store sushi is a million times better. Prices are not as good as advertised out front. The people who work there are some of the nastiest I've ever met. They just don't care. It's a tourist trap. Wish we'd checked yelp before going in. Don't let the kitschy floating boats fool you. If you want a miserable experience, look no further! With sooo many good food options nearby, run as fast as you can away from this place.

Loved what I had...BUT THE SERVICE IS AWFUL!!!  They acted like they didn't want us in the place.  Prepare to get what  is only in the boats.  They are not in the mood to help you.  Stay away from the udon...in fact, just don't go.
Slow service is a understatement, overpriced crappy food. Party of 6 and they add $10 tip? Never again, waste of $80

I went here because I was in chinatown and was really hungry and, was craving for sushi. This is not a place to eat sushi. For the first time in my life, I went to a restaurant here in san francisco, and was absolutely sure, that I will give them 1 star....

The sushi on the boats was so old that the rice on the top was dried out. For some reason my fiance kept on eating. Sushi roulette, perhaps? He is a daredevil. I ate a couple pieces and then the red alarms started going off. Our wise friend stopped at the nearest liquor store to buy a tiny bottle of whiskey. Flawless reasoning: Kill it with fire. He only got a little sick. My fiance, on the other hand, was out of commission for a good 24 hours. Five days later and he's still having issues. Avoid this place at all costs. It is not even good sushi and you will most likely end up in the bathroom for hours and breaking out in the sweats.

Avoid this place at all costs, and unbelievably it is costly. The waitress is obviously the spouse of the husband and wife team that run the place. It's costly, she's unfriendly to militant, and the food is mediocre. The boat gimmick is arcade-like and a real miss.
Ive been here a couple times in the last several years and today reminded me why I didnt want to go back.

We were planning on going to a different place but they closed early.  It was late and we were hungry and this was one of the few options still open near by.  This place should be avoided at all costs.Sadly, since this place probably lives on tricking tourists into thinking they are getting good and authentic Japanese food they do not care what anyone says.
Walked with no expectations at all as I believe it's a tourist trap. I'm in Chinatown, San Francisco, go figure :P
This is the worst Sushi in the city. Not only is the service bad but also the bad service comes with a huge portion of  bad attitude.
The food was ok but there was TERRIBLE TERRIBLE customer service. Two thumbs down.
HORRIBLE customer service. If there zero stars I'd give that.

The first time I was there I had a ramen. the food was not bad and the price was okay. One problem: it was "fish cake ramen" without fishcake. After I requested the owner took out two tiny pieces of fish cakes without apologies. It came direct from the fridge and even tasted like the fridge. I won't say the owner is rude, but she is definitely very cold. Not even smiling back when I pay.
EWWWW.               DOUBLE EWWWWW.             TRIPLE EWWWWW!!!

I came in with low expectation since Chinatown isn't really a place for sushi, or rather just a general lack of the joints in the area. The reason my friends and I came here this afternoon was because of the long lunch lines at that time of the day at other places.
Yokohama does not get enough credit.

I'm just going to start with the bad stuff and why its not a full 5 stars. Went here last night after a crappy day at work and didn't feel like making dinner so we got sushi pick up. they charged me for the BAGS. Granted its only $0.20 but still can you ask before charging me and i think this is the first time a restaurant has charged me. They also had a snafu with the bill as well. ok done venting about that.

We went there for dinner on a weekend and ordered a spicy tuna roll, and a spider roll. When the food arrived there was a serious funk emanating from the spicy tuna roll. When the waiter came by to ask if everything was alright we told her that we thought the fish might not be fresh. She pointed to other tables and told us that those people didn't have issues with it. We pressed the point and she told the chef who brought out the dish with the spicy tuna and explained that it was fine and in fact had just been eaten by a regular there. I tried to explain that I didn't care what other people had, and wasn't trying to insult him, just inform him that the rolls smelled foul. We hoped they would take something off the bill, since we left a plate of mostly uneaten food but they didn't.

We had take away for lunch. Sushi looked like I made them myself (I tried once for myself years ago - not very succesful) and fish was too thickly cut and in a way that even made the tuna chewy. Did not enjoy them, would not recommend.

In the past I've gotten a nigiri set and some other time(s) chirashi.  Both were fresh and good.  Usually now I'll just order steamed rice, miso soup, and seaweed salad to-go which is a delicious, satisfying meal.  Wang to try more things there!

I come here a lot because I have cravings for sashimi and udon quite often, and this place is only a couple blocks away from my home. AND, they take Amex. Well, I think you have to buy over $10 to use a credit card. A little bit on the pricier side though. I tend to call my order in, and it is ready within 10 minutes. If I show up too early, the lady will give me a hot cup of green tea to drink while I wait, which I think is really nice.
I've always ordered pick-up and it's very speed every time, no more than 10 minutes from when I order it. The portions are large, 8 instead of 6 to a roll. Highly-recommended.

I'm very critical of all the restaurants that i go to and after numerous visits to this sushi restaurant, I can enthusiastically say that its superb. The food is delicious and the price is so reasonable that its almost a steal.

Great sushi. Huge rolls. I just had one specialty roll with a seaweed salad and it was plenty. We came late..about a half hour from closing. That always makes me a little nervous. But it was all still really fresh. The bathroom wasn't the cleanest but like I said, we were there at the end of the night.
Omg, thisplace is infested with  roaches. Dont ever go here!

Went here for lunch with a group of coworkers. I was about half-way through my sashimi when one of my coworkers found a cockroach crawling out of their rice. At that point, everyone at the table lost their appetite and no one finished. We showed the waitress the cockroach, and she didn't seem to horrified at all. She offered to bring us out another plate...yeah, right. Like we are going to eat more from this place.
Do not go here.

I've been to this place many times and have enjoyed it as a nice restaurant for special occasions. No longer! Last night one friend had a baby roach in his miso soup. He told the waitress who seemed unsurprised and eventually brought him another bowl. YUCK! I imagined the soup tureen full of bugs! In the course of the meal we had 4 more roach encounters right on the table. I was gagging, and I still can't believe we stayed. I would have thought that the restaurant might have comped us something for the disgust factor, though none of us would likely have eaten it. I'll never go back; I'll probably try Sushi Hunter on nearby Union. Another thought: the last several times I've been there (for roach free dining), my party was the only one in the place. Everyone but me must have read reviews on Yelp! Being there alone, I always had the feeling I'd just walked in on an argument between the waitress and the chef. Just an impression. but uncomfortable. Sorry to see you go, Yokohama!
Roaches every where. Do not eat here!  My coworkers found two while eating there then came back to the office and brought one back!  Sick!

Stopped in for lunch. The place was full of business professionals getting their sushi fix.  We sat down and right after a lengthy wait to order we spotted a mid-sized cockroach on our table. Not being afraid of ONE cockroach, we continued on.  After our food arrived, we had cockroaches crawl out from under the sushi dishes, rice and yes my fish.  3 in total. Not going back.

I took a coworker there.  There was a cockroach climbing up and down the wall next to us.  It was distracting and disgusting.  I finally used my napkin to hit it hard, and killed it.  Everyone turned to look at me when they heard the loud whack.  The next table said, "Oh, we had a cockroach too."

There were bugs in the menu between the plastic sleeve and the paper - and when i showed the waitress, she just squished them inside the menu!  Then when I tried the spicy scallop roll, a few bites in I literally almost threw up.  Something was seriously wrong with it.  I tried to nicely tell them that something may have gone bad and they basically told me they've never had a problem (ergo, I must be wrong).  I felt sick all night and threw up the next morning too.  I tried to be extraordinarily nice about it at the time, and hoped they would have at least comped that roll.  They didn't.  The rolls were also sloppily made (the avocado was sticking out of the end and smooched so the whole side of the roll was covered).  This place seems to be really in a bad way right now. I would not recommend anyone go there until they handle their bug and bad fish problem.  Yuck!
The service is disgusting! the waitress is arrogant and really vary rude. The miso soup doesn't come with any tofu. They said they don't have. Ridiculous.
Disclaimer: I've only had takeout that was comped by work (workin' late has its perks, I guess...)
Good sashimi, but a little pricey. Had the $17 sashimi plate and it was less than filling. Baked oyster appetizer was fantastic.
Innovative rolls (take a look:
OVERALL:3.0   FOOD:4   SERVICE:2.5   AMBIANCE:2.5  VALUE:3
We came in for dinner after cocktails at the Bubble Lounge down the street.  The place was nearly empty which seemed a little odd for a saturday night, but we went anyway.

portion size is good. I ordered the rainbow roll and tempura roll and it was delicious! Most of the time when I order sushi to go and drop about 12 dollars on a special roll... the roll is so small but this place has good portion size and the food tastes fresh!

I like it here! Nice lunch deals. My favs are spicy tuna roll and broadway roll. Mmmm... deep fried goodness. They also do to-go and every time I drop in to pick my order up they also offer me a cup of tea. :) Their bentos are huuuuuuge.
Pretty good food, great prices, and with a purchase of a large hot saki, you get a second for 25 cents.

Good quality nigiri, rolls and tempura, below average teriyaki, salad and edamame.  Really a mixed bag.  Good ambiance, prices were good for the area.  Avoid the bento box as this plays to their weaknesses.

I used to spend quite a few lunch hours here.  The sushi chef was always friendly and the waitresses as well.  The food is pretty good and the price is right.  They have the typical nigiri and maki and the regular old bento boxes, nothing to write home about.  I usually got a bento of some sort and another roll or some nigiri to round it out.   I never found anything to complain about.

Why don't more reviews mention the AWESOME deal that this place offers???  Buy one large hot sake, get the second for a mere 25 cents!  Does that make me sound like a total boozehound?  I happened upon this place while walking with some friends after a Friday happy hour at Cigar bar.  We were starving and cold (translation: not picky whatsoever, I mean, I didn't even YELP this place before I stepped in, that's how hungry we were.)

This is a wonderful Japanese Restaurant and everything seems to be reasonably priced. I always order the bento whenever I visit, which includes rice, teriyaki chicken, salad with very yummy sauce, tempura, and slice of orange with a side of miso soup. The bento is quite filling. My brother usually orders the California roll and they aren't cheap about the ingredients, which I really appreciate. My mom really likes the tea that they serve.

I was up here this past weekend for business.  Came here with my good friend who is an actual Toji (sake brewer) and sushi aficionado from Narita, Japan.  We sat at the bar and asked for the chef's favorites.  With a nice bottle of Nihonshu (Japanese Sake) we feasted away on fresh, delicious fish.  After a couple of bottles of sake and some ornate arrangement of nigirizushi our stomach was full of content.  My friend Naoki was impressed with the artistry and delicacy of the chef's stroke of his Yanagiba sashimi knife.  (i have no idea ).  Funny thing happened next to us.  Some clueless debbie was asking the chef for some plum wine.  Naoki was telling me that plum wine is a Japanese digestif.  Too sweet to complement sushi.  Good for after meal drinks or cocktails.  Stick to beer and sake ladies and gents.
Food was decent, but man, horrible service! We sat in the middle of the room but was ignored the whole time. We had to ask for refills when everyone else didn't. Did I do something wrong???

i try to eat maybe once a month but it's been awhile (on a budget)..i only work about 6 blocks from yokohama..The service and the food are good, i usual get the raindow roll & dragon roll.. sometimes udon, the owner is very nice also, check it out for a quick sushi bite

Sushi for one, under $20.00...excellent.  I had the sushi combo (1 california roll of 8 pieces and 4 pieces of nigiri sushi) for under $10.00 and an order of their Yokohama roll (shrimp tempura, cucumber inside, eel, avocado and tobiko outside/top) for under $10.00.
A little expensive, not that great.  Decent sized portions at least.  Too much teriyaki sauce on chicken teriyaki.
This place has good sushi. I ordered the shrimp tempura roll and deep fried spicy tuna roll and by boyfriend had a lunch box. The food was between 3 and 4 stars for me. The service was about 3 stars.

Don't bother. Just don't bother. Came here today, famished after yoga. This place is a one-man band. The sushi chef does it all. Wait tables, make sushi, cashier. You name it, he does it. Hope he washes his hands... I didn't notice that. There were only 2 other people in the place when I came in at about 6:30. Seeing it from outside, something told me, "walk on by." But I didn't. I should have listened to my gut.  Walked in, sushi chef greets me and motions me to a table, drops a menu in front of me. KOIT radio is playing. I look at the menu, see that Japanese plum wine is offered. When the sushi chef returned bringing me a hot tea, I asked him "what kind of umeshu do you have?", using the Japanese word for plum wine. Sushi chef looks at me like I am from another planet. I repeat myself and he still doesn't know what I'm talking about. Okay, I think. This guy is obviously not Japanese, as he doesn't even know the Japanese word for plum wine. So I finally asked him what kind of plum wine do they carry, red or white? (I wanted white). He told me that there is no such thing as white Japanese plum wine. I'm like, "Excuse me?" He kept insisting that there was no such thing as white. I asked him if he had ever been to Japan, Osaka especially, where there are a plethora of many different kinds of plum wine. Then he said, "Well, they only serve white wine in Japan. Not here in America." I'm like, "Have you ever heard of choya? I can get that at Nijiya market in Japantown."  He didn't answer, and walked away. I thought that was so rude! If he didn't have white wine, he just should have SAID so and not try to give me a BS story about the non-existance of white plum wine period, and then about the non existance of white plum wine in America. I've eaten at a lot of Japanese restaurants and many of them offer the white variety! I do not have stupid written all over my forehead.  I wanted to call him names in Japanese (not that he would have understood me.). Two other patrons left and I was the only patron left in the building. The chef gives me cold looks, which I return. He finally comes over to take my order, and I order the salmon teriyaki dinner with rice, salad, and miso soup. He briefly pops into the kitchen, shouts out my order, and then returns to the sushi bar. The kitchen is partially open at the bar, and to my horror I see a Mexican cook in there. Okaaaay... so much for Japanese authenticity. While I was shuddering about the non-Japaneseness of the cook, Celine Dion's "My Heart Will Go On" comes on the radio, and the sushi chef comes back out carrying my salad and miso soup on a tray, and sets it down at my table. Then as he retreats back to the bar, decides to start singing along to Celine!!  I'm like, come on, this can't be happening!  Of course he sounded terrible! Thankfully he shut up after a few bars, as I'm sure my looks were piercing him to the core.  The food took way longer to come out than it should have, being that I was the only person in the restaurant. Presentation was good, but the pieces of salmon were tiny tiny tiny. I did, however enjoy the mixed vegetables (Carrots, onions, and mushrooms, yay!)  that were sauteed along with the salmon, but the salmon itself was bland, bland bland. I finished it all, but overall my experience there left a lot to be desired, and I made sure to express that sentiment when I tipped. There is no reason to go here for un-authentic, mediocre food. If you crave Japanese food while in North Beach, go to Sushi on North Beach Katsu instead, and you'll have a much better experience!

I came here over Thanksgiving weekend with my family that was visiting. When my sister and I first walked in, we were greeted very politely by the sushi chef who I think probably co-owns the place with another woman. She was also really sweet and was really apologetic because it took a while for a table to clear up for our family of seven.
I like this place the sushi is good and the sake/beer is fairly cheap.

We love this restaurant! We came to the hotel nearby for a conference and had dinner here and the food was delicious! We're not vegetarians and we loved the food. The place was immaculately clean and the wait staff was super nice. On the way out we bought the sticky rice wrapped in some leaf (banana?) and it was the bomb!  The wait staff took time to explain to us how to heat it up (it's sold from a refrigerated case). What a great place!
GO ELSEWHERE.

I love eating meat, so one of my criteria when judging vegetarian food is how much is doesn't make me miss meat. I don't necessarily need the protein to fool me into thinking it's meat, but it should be hearty and savory enough to satisfy. But in both flavor and texture, I thought Enjoy fell way short.
Truly amazing food. If you don't try their tofu and hot sauce, you're missing something special.

Great food. Im vegan and my friend who is an omnivore invited me there. There were a good choice of tofu and vegetable dishes as well as soy meat and fish. Recommend the soy chicken with string beans, and the eggplant. Very affordable too, two dishes were enough for the two of us plus leftovers to take home.

Actually, I got terrible at being my own chef since I've lived in San Francisco. There's just so much to try out. But I also have an obligation to all my friends that opt on visiting SF, they need to be able to get food at the best places and not be disappointed.

Decent selection, although I'm not a fan of all the "faux meat" selections.  Opted for the spring rolls, dumplings, and lettuce wraps.  The servings were large and the free tea was a nice touch.  Service was excellent.

Not at all recommended. Not the worst, but worse than any food court. The green curry tasted EXACTLY like a dirty kitchen towel. I mean, exactly like a dirty towel. The chow mein was pretty good, but all noodles and no veggies. The noodles were cooked nicely and the flavors were mild but good. Far too many menu options, hundreds in fact, that made me certain that food is not fresh. Take the Muni to Wonderland instead.
Unimpressive.
Simply amazing!  Wonton soup was out of this world!  Dumplings were great, as was the spicy basil soy chicken and Lotus root plate!

I ordered a lunch special #36 and asked them to make it spicy. And boy, it was spicy! The service was good, and my dish arrived fast. The portion was generous. I will definitely be back to check out other dishes for sure.
Yes that's right Enjoy! This food is absolutely delicious!
Family recommended this place and as we were walking down Kearney we decided to stop in and give it a try. The missus enjoyed the food, I on the other hand was neutral.
Great food, quick service. Friendly staff. What more can you ask.
Clean restaurant with good service and a large $7.99 and $8.99 lunch menu.  All lunch dishes come with an Egg Roll, Entree, and choice of White or Brown rice.
Pretty good lunch deal.  They have a $7.99 section and a $8.99 section.  Lunch comes with a spring roll and either white or brown rice.
Delish!!! I chose eggplant with tofu n basil. It was fast,hot, flavorful and a decent portion. The service was pleasant. I'm a foodie and pretty picky so, I would come here again.

I am a meat eater that loves vegetarian food. I'm so happy that this place exists! It's really great to have a restaurant around that makes so many vegetarian versions of classic Chinese and Asian dishes.
I'd go here if I was vegetarian, in town, and wanted Chinese. (Which I was.) Enjoyed the atmosphere, menu variety, and the way my food was prepared (not too crazy).

This place is amazing! The menu is very large and they bring free green tea to the table. Would definitely come back again, also the customer service is wonderfully pleasant. The special fried rice is my favorite item on the menu.
The fatty pork belly with cabbage and mustard greens was pretty awesome. Soy and yam, yumm. Fast and friendly service, nothing to complain about!
The vegetarian dishes are authentic.  The taste is good, not too oily.   It's a restaurant worth trying even you are not a vegan.

Although there are plenty of vegetable options in Chinatown, this entirely meatless restaurant is a welcome addition. My daughter and I had lunch here, and we both enjoyed it. I had Soy Beef & String Beans and she had Mushrooms, Broccoli, & Soy Chicken. We shared the Golden Dough Balls for dessert, though I expect that the Sesame Balls are also quite good. We would definitely return.
Ok, I like meat, so I had put off trying Enjoy Vegetarian. I jog past this almost everyday so my curiosity finally peaked. I have to admit their their faux meats had some novelty value.
Their menu has different types of dishes than your average vegetarian Chinese restaurant. They have pretty good service here. I recommend this restaurant.

I'm sorry to report that my experience at Enjoy Vegetarian has significantly declined.  The food, more or less, is the same, though they have increased the prices.  The problems that I have experienced on more than one occasion are with the service.
Their bean curd, soy ingredients and vegetarian dishes that looks like meat, are deceiving to the eye and tasted mighty fine!
This place is what I expected of Vegan Chinese Cuisine in Chinatown.

Great vegeterian Chinese food - they have meat imitations of all kinds :) Very clean, super friendly, bright and colorful. Also pretty cheap and lunch is a decent portion with a spring roll. I try to eat there every time I'm in SF.

After juggling for several days to eat vegetarian with a couple of meat-eaters friends I was craving a place where everything was vegetarian. After walking around a lot in SF area I was starving, so I yelped a place that was close to where I was and had only vegetarian food. This place was listed in the top and had really good reviews so I decided to give it a chance. It felt a little awkward initially because I was there super early (5 pm) and probably the first and only customer. I sat down and the first thing they brought was jasmine tea :) I then proceed to get a plate of dumplings as entree and then sweet and spicy "chicken". The dumplings were soft and juicy. The "chicken" tasted good and the sauce was what I was just looking for. The food didn't taste extraordinary but it was a nice change. the soy sauce that came with the dumplings didn't taste good and the main plate didn't have the "it factor" that would have give this place 4-5 stars.

let me get a non-alcoholic beer .. that just sounds gross, but not the vegetarian mongolian beef! i came here during my week long vegetarian journey and it was not bad. I was a little weirded out ordering mongolian beef and char siu chow mein.. It was'n't bad and the service is not your typical chinese restaurant. I guess eating veggies does make you nicer. Late.
Descent Chinese vegetarian food. I liked it. And their dessert menu is nice.

Let me first establish being quite the tyrannosaur; practicing vegan behavior is not naturally in my nature. My attendance was honoring my date's annual Buddhist vegan recognition. However, I was surprised how convincing their faux meat items tasted in comparison to the real things.
Great find!

This place has great food, at a great price. First, the menu is huge and all vegetarian/vegan, there is no MSG and guess what... the food tastes great. We have been here many times and the staff goes out of there way for the customers. We ordered here at closing time and they went out of there way to stay open and make our take out order. If you go you I strongly recommend the lettuce wraps and dumplings. The chow mein and curry is also a standard order.

Wow! Delicious. What more can I say. Coming from Florida, I am easily impressed by vegetarian restaurants, but this place stands out even in Bay Area California. Wonderfully cooked soft and tender "pipa" stuffed tofu is not found in many restaurants, but it is delectable here. The "spare ribs" were also quite interesting and delicious. Most dishes are very healthy with vegetables, but of course there's fried delicacies too - just gotta have that fried sometimes. The fried taro cake was different from what I am used to - here it is a lot more taro than at many other places.
