For dessert, crispy sesame balls with red bean filling were crunchy and just sweet enough without being overly sweet, and cute size at it (small but tasty! In this case, size doesn't matter!) And if that weren't enough, you can get to-go "tzong tzi" which is banana leaf wrapped sticky rice with filling such as mushrooms, chestnut, and veggie-ham, to take home to eat the next day - just steam or microwave. Mmmmm. Yummy.
Great food, service and hot tea. The sauce for the spring roll is fabulous!

We came here on a Sunday night, August 4. This is the Kearny St location in Chinatown. It was past 8 PM when our first choice restaurant had over an hour wait. We found yelp's review of Enjoy and decided to give it a try. There were only 3 tables with customers when we came in. We were the last to leave before they close. The service was good. Waitress was helpful and answered all questions. We ordered 2 dishes and were very happy with our choices. All items are vegetarian. There is no MSG, garlic, or onion. Imitation meat and fish products are made of soy, yam or wheat products. Dishes are perfectly seasoned, not greasy like some Chinese restaurants. We had #45 Eggplant with seabass and # 54 lotus roots, lily, vegetables, snow peas, ginko nuts. Both are not the usual dishes made in most Asian restaurants we've tried. If we go back to SF we'll definitely come back to this place again.
Yum.  We ate here twice on our recent trip.  Wings and nuggets were hits with our kids.  My wife and I liked the cashew-chick-un dish.  Friendly staff, good service.

Originally my friends and I had planned to go to the Loving Hut in Chinatown, only to find out that it's being closed down. Vegan places aren't difficult to find in San Francisco, so this little change of plans ended up being a nice surprise visit to a new restaurant fave of mine.
Chinese urban family restaurant on Jackson above Jackson Square. This is a locals spot for lunch populated by neighborhood color.

I am not a huge dim sum fan but this place was good and the service was great. We went here for my buddies birthday and ate our hearts out and it was only $25 each with tip which I could not believe. Har gow was good, shu mai was my favorite. Mongolian beef was also good.

Like some others on here, saw Chef and have been craving a Cubano since then. Was reminded that Paladar is down the street this morning, went in for my fix and was reminded why I haven't been there in a while.

Had Cuban Pork platter with Cuban rice and beans plus plantains for my lunch with my client. This establishment was another great pick at keeping a client happy as the meal was not just perfect, but had enough character to make it memorable. The meat was fresh and well seasoned and nothing overcooked. I will definitely want to return. Service was on top as well.

For me, this is a nice, small spot to have lunch near work.  Food prices are around $12-$15. There are not huge portions but are just right for lunchtime. It's a really small spot but there is downstairs dining that hold many more. Overall a good quick spot.
What can I say. Paladar is just Yumm!
yummm, what a delicious & unique lunch spot. the cuban sandwich is amazing. this isn't the healthiest or cheapest or least greasy spot around, but it sure hits the spot..
Nice place. I tried Camarones al Ajillo and it was Delicious. Price seems to be on the higher side though.

I really wanted to like this place. I spent $13 on a miniature shrimp sandwich with like three pieces of shrimp in it and like a gallon of mayonnaise. I felt sick after eating it. Furthermore, it came with flavorless plantain chips with sweet chip dip in a cup that was too small for the chips! You'd have to snap the wide chips in half before it'd even fit in the dipping cup.
I had Picadillo Cubano estilo Elena and it was really good! flavors are great and tas
Customer service needs lots of improvement. I got takeout and was given a wrong order! Makes me not want to go back there. Seems like the price is too high for the quality of experience.

I've been craving a Cubano since I saw Chef earlier this month (Challenge: name how many times I've mentioned that movie in my recent reviews? I mean, this is just getting silly!), but my homegirl Miriam B was under the weather, and she's my go-to lunch bud for all things Latin, so I had to wait until today, when everyone was feeling footloose and fancy free to indulge!

I've been to Paladar several times now and each seems worse than the last.  For some reason I always want to go in to give them another shot because I think of them like I do of Sol Food, but there's no comparison at all.
The cuban sandwhich was soooooooo gooood...I have to come back.The sauce the plantano chips came with is delicious...I dipped my sandwhich in it...Perfect meal!

People rave about the large portion but I thought it was actually on the smaller side. Ordered the roast pork plate with black bean rice and plaintains and tho it was delicious, it's smaller than I thought for $13. Hubby got the Cubano sandwich and that was definitely too small for him. It seems to mostly be bread. As far as meat goes, yes it is good and flavorful. Chips are also bomb, all 8 pieces of it.

Its a quaint interior haha, i dunno if it makes the feeling more authentic?  Doesn't matter bc its cuban food in the fidi, and its pretty damn good!  With all the organic stuff that's offered these days, i need a splurge of the not so healthy.  I've had the cubano sandwich before and I found that I don't like that kind of layering - so not the restaurants fault.  The salad and the PLANTAIN CHIPs were awesome though!  I'd eat just that.  Then there's the shrimp salad-wich that I couldn't stop eating.  All their plates are so filling and yummy, def coming back for more, but only if I know I'm gonna be brain dead for the rest of the day :P

This place makes a nice Cuban sandwich. At $12.78 however the sandwich is a bit overpriced in my opinion. Particularly when you can get a much better sandwich for around $10 at working girl right across the street.  The sandwich was a bit on the small side for $12.78.

Excellent little spot to have lunch on a work day. I stopped in with a co-worker and we were able to grab a table on the sidewalk in the sun which was nice. Getting good Cuban food outside of Miami is tough, but this place has it down. I ordered the classic Cuban sandwich and it has to top my list of best I've had.

I came here with my friend Talia last week.  Now, I've been here a few times before, and I liked it, especially the Columbiana sopa--it's a light stew with chicken and beef.  I thought my friend Talia would like it because girl is from Cuba.  Well, the owner (?)/hostess was rude to her, and Talia spits out, "it's not even real Cuban food!"  But Talia, the sangria!!

Vegetarian friendly! For $11, enjoy a delicious grilled cheese sandwich with manchego, arugula, and caramelized onions, and don't forget to spread that kickin' garlic mojo sauce on your bread before you start noshing. Each sandwich comes with a side of greens and plantain chips. It's a decently size lunch compared to some other places in FiDi.

I love the soup and sandwich combo! You get a 1/2 sandwich of hour choice and a cup of the daily soup with fried plantains. It's not the cheapest lunch, but it is my favorite place in the area for lunch.

I've been here at least 3-4 times and I would have to say it's a solid three stars. Although I can't really be sure what real Cuban food tastes like since I've never had it......I've gotten either the choripan or the vegetariano and they're decent sandwhiches I suppose. The best thing about this place is the fried plantains and whatever dipping sauce they give you (which is never enough!) If you're trying to eat inside, I highly recommend getting there before 12. Otherwise fat chance.

I've had the cuban sandwich twice, and was disappointed twice.  Today's was overloaded with dry pork, and I couldn't taste any of the other ingredients.  It's also a bit pricey... there are so many other places around with better food at lower prices.  So overall I felt like it was a waste of a meal, and a waste of my money.

This place will definitely cure your hankering for a good Cuban sandwich. The cubano has some quality ingredients. Not super pressed down, but still nice and toasty. And the plantain chips it comes with are awesome especially with the garlic sauce.
Short answer: Good, but not great, Cuban food in the FiDi. All the food is enjoyable, not awesome.  The rice dishes and sandwiches have good flavors, but won't blow you away.
Stumbled on this cafe. The picadillo n platanos were delicious. ..just like home. Happy camper here!!

A decent little place in the financial district. A friend and I came here for lunch, and we ordered the shrimp plate and the pulled pork. The food didn't blow away any taste buds but it was fine and I finished most of my plate.  I did find that the portions were a bit small for the price.  If I'm shelling out $20 at lunchtime, I better be full - otherwise I have to unleash a grumpy, hungry Janet on the world.

I am disappointed that Paladar had a "$10 off" offer made available through the PayPal app, yet when I paid for my meal (this was in early January), I was told they no longer supported PayPal.  I wanted to pay as soon as I placed my order, but they asked me to wait until my food was fully ready.  That meant that when I found out they no longer supported PayPal, the food was done and I couldn't really turn it down or change my order.  If they had let me pay at the time I placed my order, like I wanted to, then I would have found out right away they didn't support PayPal and I could have changed my mind or changed my order.  Or at least, they should have offered me the $10 off my meal anyway, given that I specifically went to try out the restaurant because of that coupon.  That would have been the way to make up for the misleading coupon and to win over a customer.  Now instead, I don't want to go back.

It's a cute little spot for a sit down lunch, but nothing too special about this place.  Came here with a few friends with the PayPal deal; basically download the PayPal app and they had a promotion.  Spend $10, get $10 back.  All in all, I spent about $2 for a lunch here.  Sounds like a good deal to me!
I've had lunch at couple of times at Paladar and I love it. I was a big fan of Charanga on Mission street before it closed awhile ago and this seems to be an offshoot of that place.

This place has really solid cuban food. I loved their cubano! It was a huge sandwich and absolutely delicious. I also ordered some of their yuka fries with chipotle aioli. Cooked perfectly, and held up well. (I took my order to go.) This place gets super busy at lunch time, I recommend the take-out option!

Being that Cuban is my fav! On my way to get a salad I ran into this place and could not help but try instead.  I had the lechon azado entree .. For lunch :) and in a few words , over priced, small portioned , not great ! Pork was not just dry, it was too dry, congri ( rice/ beans) no flavor. The maduros , well you really can't messed this up too badd. I even got a side of fried yuca to try and that was also okay.  I'd say this place would be good if your absolutely starving .. But then again you find everything as that point.
This place cannot go wrong!

Good Cuban food is hard to come by in San Francisco, and especially so in the Financial District. Paladar, unfortunately, doesn't stop the search. For price of the dish,  the portions were quite small. The Choripan, the sandwich with a fairly sizable piece of Spanish chorizo, was delicious, but was disappointingly small.
I ate here at lunchtime. I got Picadillo Cubano Estilo Elena and it was really tasty! Plantains were cooked right. The touch of green olives in the food was yummy.
I had chicken sandwich, it was good, something different. I loved the yucca chips with dip
Food: 3
A few weeks ago a co-worker and I passed by this place and we put it on our list (yes we have a list) of places to try for lunch.

I can't wait to go to Paladar again!  We went to celebrate our co-worker's birthday.   If the upstairs is crowded, or full, there is also a downstairs area.  The 3 of us were the only ones down there and we loved it - was like having our own private dining room!   The sandia drink was very refreshing; it's non-alcoholic and has lime, mint, cucumber and watermelon.The menu had quite a few options.  We ended up going for lunch plates which were really filling and hit the spot.  Great comfort food and really friendly owner.

This place is pretty good. Not great, just pretty good. I've had the cuban sandwich twice now, and it is pretty scrumptious. I just wish there was a little more meat to it, since it is 11 freaking bucks. The pickles are perfectly thinly sliced, adding a nice taste and texture without being overpowering.

Got the Piccadillo, which came with rice and fried plantains. Smelled amazing, tasted just as good. Got my food less than 2 minutes after I ordered. Only downside, it is a little more expensive than I would expect.

Pretty decent restaurant for a lunch time during the work week. Well located at the Kearny St, next to a bunch of offices, this is an easy spot to stop and grab a nice lunch with a co worker for example.

Sabra Grill is really the only authentic Israeli restaurant in San Francisco. It's good, but not great. It's definitely expensive, even more than the usual Kosher place and it's not the portions I'm used to in Los Angeles with all the endless side dishes. Nevertheless, it's the only place you can really find in the city for home sick Israelis.

As a local, native San Franciscan living in Nob Hill, I am constantly on the lookout for solid, cheap, vegetarian food that isn't strictly marketing to tourists. I checked it out when I recently heard the restaurant changed owners. The restaurant is kosher, and I ordered the falafel sandwich. Super quick, awesome friendly service, great local vibe, and amazing art!! Authentic grub, and in a super great location.

My friend and I wandered in here at the foot of China Town and shared the combo salad (think appetizer sampler). It was exactly the right amount of food and it was DELICIOUS. I'd take a photo, but we scarfed it down so fast you'd just get a photo of an empty plate. Oh, and it came really, really quickly!
Only kosher restaurant around so did not really have any other places to eat or compare.

I was excited to stumble upon a real live Kosher restaurant while on vacation in San Francisco. As someone who lives in a city without any Kosher meat restaurants, I was enthusiastic to grab a swharma to go to eat while walking through town.

Came here tonight for dinner. It was perfectly located! I strictly eat only glatt kosher & it was really nice to have a glatt kosher restaurant in San Francisco. Thank you Sabra for the delicious food!

Staff is incompetent. Delivered one entree 40 minutes before the rest of our meals. Food was cold and tasted bad. They microwave the top pita so the plate appears warm but underneath is a frozen tundra.
My wife and I had lunch at Sabra's and it was really great !
Living in Israel has made me have very high standards for food.

This is a hole in the wall amidst the kitsch at the entrance to Chinatown. You don't go for the ambiance which is horrible (unless you're into Jewish paraphernalia overload). You don't go for the service, which can be good to downright rude depending on who waits on you. You don't go for the prices as they're on the high side, especially for dinner. That said, do go for the very solid food. The chef knows his stuff. Babaganoush with pickles,  chicken shwarma and falafel. This is clearly above average for the Bay Area.

Sabra grill is the only kosher meat restaurant in SF, so I tried it out while visiting. They claim to have schwarma, but it's just cut up chicken in schwarma spices. Very disappointing. Service is also slow.

The worst experience ever. It's 2014 sabra grill it's ok if a non Jewish woman walks in to eat. They ignored me for 10 min gave the worst service and the food was something I wouldn't even give to my dog. Very bad.
Too spendy for what you get. Wish I'd have eaten elsewhere. Service here kind of blows. Soggy, messy food. Meh. Very mediocre.
The only reason to come here is that it is the only place in town.
Excellent kababs and falafel. True to Israeli food and atmosphere.
Was here for Lunch. Food is tasty. Decor and ambience could be improved vastly. Little pricey too.
I lived in Israel for a year, and ate falafel every day there, and iv finally found the best falafel in the US.
So came to San Francisco for the first time and wanted to try kosher as well.  Our Hotel was close by so we walked over for lunch.
I really want to admire and like this place but a lot of reviews discourage me from going here.
Superb mixed grill with fries.Attentive and prompt service.Will return and bring guests especially  for excellent kosher food.
I really don't like this place. Everything about it sucks.

I was visiting San Francisco recently, and got two of the combo to go meals.  I ordered one with a grilled chicken breast, and one with a salmon steak.  The chicken breast was cooked well, but lacked flavor.  The salmon steak was overcooked and had a lot of bones that made it difficult to eat.  Both came with rice, salad, humus, and pita.  For some reason, there were beans on the rice.  The price for the meals was outrageous.  $25 for a grilled chicken breast or salmon and some rice?  This isn't an upscale restaurant.  It's a run-down hole in the wall in Chinatown.
Had dinner at Sabra last week while I was in San Fran.

Only kosher rest. I seemed to find in San Fran so I had to try it. I tried this place out at the beginning of the year with a couple of friends because I wanted to introduce them to Israeli food. Although the food was over priced - they really enjoyed the food and the atmosphere. I would recommend the chicken breats and babaganoush!

Amazingly good! I can't understand the bad ratings. Loved the Baba ghanoush. The pickles were almost as good as what my grandmother made. Almost. It looks like some are annoyed at the service, but that's part of the charm!
Food is authentic Israeli - and fresh! Friendly staff and quick service.

really the worst food.  I had serious doubts as I entered the doors looking at the grimy walls and food spattered carpet....I was wanting some authentic middle Eastern cuisine....I'm certain the grease that my food was fried in could have been saved from the time of Moses it was SO old. The smells inside of this stuffy grungy eatery rival a machine shop think essence of crank case oil.  The pastrami was slimy yet dry...how does that happen? The waitstaff was really unfriendly....I felt like the plates were plunked down in front of us with grunting and grimacing....I miss the joy of having food around my Grandmother's table...the fresh cucumbers,tomatoes,home made yogurt....hospitality felt lost at Sabra Grill.  My husband worried about food poisoning....The food was grey looking...grey.

Horrible place!!! Avoid at all cost! The service was horrible. The waiter is the biggest ass you will ever meet.  The food is disgusting and overpriced. I'd rather starve than set foot in this place ever again. No stars would be better.

This is an authentic bad Israeli restaurant. Reminds me of the restaurants in Israel I would never set foot in. It's what you might find if you try to find a restaurant in the middle of some ultra-orthodox neighborhood in a small town out in the boonies in Israel, except maybe 4 times more expensive, and with a local low-cost take on Israeli cuisine such as iceberg lettuce with GMO carrots instead of cucumbers and tomatoes.
One of the best otentic middle eastern  resturant I been in the states . Very worm place feeling in a different country .

I'd grown accustomed to hearing terrible things about Sabra, and I'd poked my head in once to see the lack of ambience, but whatever, I'm an Orthodox Jew and if someone comes to town to visit, we can eat at my house or eat here. We're kinda stuck.

I get it, it's the only kosher restaurant in this area with zero competition and orthodox Jewish tourists will still come here regardless of the bad reviews. But I feel the need to warn non-Kosher diners not to come here just for an "authentic Israeli" experience. Seriously, DON'T come here unless you must eat kosher food!

I am surprised by the poor ratings. We came here for lunch on a Sunday afternoon. My friend ordered us salami omelets, potato cigars and pita. The portions are extremely generous, the service was prompt, respectful and accommodating. It was a slow start to our day and he allowed us to eat a leisurely meal that lasted almost two hours. The omelet wasn't like anything i have had before, not a traditional omelet, it was fried with delicious pieces of fresh salami - and it was heaven. It was served with French Fries that were equally as delicious. The tahini sauce that was served with the fried potato cigars was delicious. Like my dining companion said, you really can't go wrong with mashed potatoes wrapped in phyllo dough and deep fried.
My boyfriend (who is Israeli) and I had very high hopes for true Israeli cuisine at Sabra Grill, but we were sadly and dramatically disappointed.
A mixed bag. Charmless decor/service/ambiance, some of the menu items OK, others lacking. If you require kosher, it's a tolerable option, but don't expect fond memories.
It's unfortunate that this is my first review on here - I started writing it a while ago....

Okay, so I have eaten at this place before and don't get me wrong, the food is standard for Kosher/Israeli but the SERVICE is horrible! No plates to eat the dishes off of... you must share (mind you it was a table for 6), waiting more than 10 minutes to get something you ask for, and the owner is inconsiderate!

Perfect home-cooking for this Shiksa and her fabulous Jewish boyfriend. SO GOOD! The pita was fluffy and warm, the combo platter was abundant and had excellent roasted eggplant, falafel was crisp and savory.
one guy that keeps kosher, one bad jew, two california godless hippies. lunch. low expectations (the key to success in life).
This place reminds of what kosher restaurants were in the 70s and 80s in Toronto.  Greasy, quirky, overly expensive, and cheesie decor.

I've eaten food from street vendors and filthy hole-in-the-walls in third world countries (including China), so I'm not anywhere close to being a food snob, but this sh*t has gotta be the most disgusting food I've ever had in my life. It's the only time I spit food out and threw it away because it was too nasty for me to tough it out and finish it.

Came here cos I was craving for some dim sum and other restaurants were so crowded. I won't recommend anyone to eat here as the food was terrible. The shrimp dumplings didn't look or taste fresh. Their $1 natural soy drink is not home made. It came from those instant soy milk powder mixed with some warm water. Worst food I've ever tasted in Chinatown. I will never come back.
The xiu mai was okay. Price was so affordable!!! So come here when you are craving of xiu mai only. Not recommend for other things
I love this place. Though it looks sketchy it's really a good deal. My man and I come here for dates often!
The sign by the door says it all "no refunds after purchase." Many of the dumplings had raw meat. The cups and dishes were dirty and sticky.
Very disgusting food

Ratings are contextual--this is a $5.99 buffet in the most expensive city in the country. Go in, devour, leave "fat and happy" as one other review wrote. If it looks strange, don't try it. This is deep Chinatown, not Panda King.
This place sucks, worst dim sum I have ever had. Although $5.99 price may seem good, $30 doctor fee at kaiser after makes it a total rip off. I feel bad for whoever gets tricked into coming here.
bad chinese food. as a chinaman I adwise you to stay away!!

sure 5.99 all you can eat may sound enticing, it sure did to me but eat here if you don't mind dirty food and food poisoning. by far probably the worst dim sum (chinese food) ive ever had. and i'm chinese. instead, walk past this place for about 4 stores and have some quality dim sum, at a better price.
Don't eat here. Unless you want to experience ghetto china. lol

This place scares me... but I wanted some  tea on a cold, rainy Saturday and a quick snack. Plus my co-workers and I had just had a whole discussion about how germs can build up your immune system more than living in a bubble will... so I decided to try a few dumplings. They weren't bad but they weren't that great. The staff is extremely nice and friendly, but the pricing for non-buffet items seems somewhat random and arbitrary. Several of the people I was with decided not to tempt fate with the buffet but instead get relatively safe, non-meat items. We all got fairly similar things but somehow paid a anything from $3.00 to $4.75 And then there's the health rating score.of 57...

A couple friends and I went traveling around Chinatown over the weekend, and we were attracted by their $5.99 "All-you-can-eat". We were greeted by a very nice, kind, sweet, and informative Asian lady who gave us on some insight about the deal. We were fairly surprised when she handed us a Styrofoam plate and bowl, but what can you expect for $5.99? Although the restaurant itself was fairly run down, old, and on the unsanitary side but i came to appreciate the urban/3-rd world country ambiance.

I unfortunately came to Chinatown on New Years looking for dim sum. Unfortunately all the dim sum places I knew in Chinatown were closed on New Years (now when does any place in Chinatown close on any day ?!) and I guess this was the only dim sum place I found that was a sit-in and not to-go. So I unfortunately went here.

God awful!  You walk in and the lady offers you a styrofoam bowl and plate then you go down the buffet line.  I see fried rice and lo mein, they look familiar, egg rolls, soups, something that looks like sweet and sour and a lot of scary looking things I don't recognize.  The food was cold and very greasy.  You get to the end of the buffet and realize you have no drink so you have to go back and purchase bottled water for $1.50.  If you decide you need another plate of this crap, you don't get a new plate, you just eat off the same one.  The right side of the buffet is not heated so all your fried veggies, egg rolls, soups, etc are not kept warm.  I learned today a couple of things:  if the restaurant is nearly empty on Saturday at noon, you shouldn't eat there.  Also, you CAN get terrible Chinese food in Chinatown.  I've never tried Dim Sum before but that stuff was awful, it was like eating soggy white bread which had some flavorless goo in the middles.  Bleh!  This is probably the worst food I've eaten in my entire life.
*DO NOT EAT HERE*!!!
I have to agree with all the other reviews. but yes, $5.99 all-you-can-eat buffet sounded too good to be true. Maybe I would have given it 2 stars if it were cheaper...

Ick! I regret coming here. This place is no bueno, at all. I got food poisoned here yesterday and will now have nightmares! Decor is awful and no joke, the food tastes like dung! Several other people could not finish their plates due to it being so gosh darn awful! I have formally lodged a complaint with the health department.... Eat here at your own discretion, but be forewarned! PS- do not give in to their recordings on the street telling you to come in, I know it's enchanting but please, please for your own benefit don't do it!!!!
YUCK YUCK YUCK YUCK.

Just got home from what was probably the worst dinner of my life....  I wish I had read some of the reviews here before even setting foot in that restaurant! Seriously, the food they serve there is not even fit for animal feed..  most of the items there have likely been sitting out in the trays for a week (no exaggeration) - the omelet and veggies were one step from being mummified.. and the shrimp dumpling was so putrid that I had to spit it out (yes, putrid as in a decomposing sort of stench!) This is the kind of establishment that would most likely fail an inspection on the spot should health officials care to drop by. Forget that it costs $5.99...  you can't even PAY me $5.99 to eat it again! Please save yourselves the horror and steer clear of this place.
I'll probably die of food poisoning from the terrible Chinese food served at this establishment.

After reading the countless 1 star reviews, I couldn't wait to get to this place. Perhaps everyone on Yelp is new to the country, but I'm not sure what they are expecting for a $5 buffet in Chinatown.

The food made my cousin cry. It was foul! Like spit out and vomit foul.  Do your stomach a favor and save your 5.99 for McDonalds!  If you like greasy slimy fried cold food...then take your chances...if not run!!!
Horrible. Probably the worst things we've ever eaten. They should be out of business soon.
Please give me a barf bag.......
Yelp needs to give an option for "no stars."
I pretty much could just ctrl+c & ctrl+v every other review here...

Seriously, it was totally awesome.  So greasy.  Some douche-bag chinese dude ordering around the waitress calling her a bitch.  The waitress shouting back "I aint your woman, go home."  A bunch of white peeps totally freaked out by the whole debaucle.  I loved it.  As for the food--it was fucking $5.99 for a dim sum buffet.  What do you expect?  Totally rad for 6 bucks.

If I could, I wouldn't give it a star. This place is a no go but friends and I were hungry after a long day of walking around the city and the "$5.99 all you can eat dim sum and bbq" got us hooked. If you really like msg, a buncha greasy, tasteless leftovers from three days ago then this is the place for you.

This is the worst ever place for dim sum. We pay at the door before we started the buffet and immediately I regreted choosing this place to eat. However, I selected a few items and sit down to eat since we were hungry. I literally could not continue the second bite-- the food is terribly poor in quality! It was like left overs from days ago. I went to the cashier and complained about it. To my surprise, she told me there is nothing she could do about it and that I was complaining to the wrong person --she is not the owner. I told her honestly the food is so poor in quality that I could not continue the second bite. She told me basically "tough luck" to you. We left the place immediately after that and I will NEVER retern again!

For $5.99 all you can eat, definitely not worth it. The price was too good to be true at first, but after seeing fried chicken not cooked all the way, that place needs Chef Ramsey from Hell's Kitchen to come put the smack down!
This place almost ruined dim sum for me... it was so awful that i left and got a dumplings up the street to remind myself that dim sum was still tasty.
Had to do it!!!  Couldn't resist the 5.99 all you can eat buffet in Chinatown.  You ever heard of the expression..........if it's too good to be true..........

After a hard day of walking around acting like tourists....well, you're gonna be hungry.  The various options of foods in China Town is mind boggling - multiple dim-sum joints, seafood restaurants....a fast food joint like the MacDonald's is nowhere to be found.
Fortune Star Cafe isn't here anymore. Yummy Bakery  is. the food offerings are the same, with a slightly higher price.

I would have given this place a zero star if I could have. Employees wore nitrile gloves the whole time-- the same pair as they handled cash, removed dirty plates, and walked out of the bathroom. They splashed water on the dirt glove and wiped them dry on a rag. Wtf.

While on my hunt for good dim sum in Chinatown, I came across Fortune Star. The restaurant was dark and the food that was in the glass cases didn't look too appetizing... but I had already walked in, what could I do but give Fortune Star a try.
Another great find in Ctown for Chinese Home-style cooking takeout  (or dine in) for CHEAP!

Best deal in town.  Good quick food.  I asked them to make curry tomato beef fried crispy noodles and it was not a problem!   I think they were afraid to make it spicy, so next time, I'll ask them to make it with more curry.  They are accommodating to me.  I've had their rice dishes and they are great.

Dishonest :-(. Nice waiter, but when you get a $54.65 bill for two meals and ask for a itemized bill and it comes in Chinese it's discouraging. One meal was $8.50 and the crab was seasonal. And I understand "seasonal" variates, but at least if he would of given the price it would of been nice. Instead of just stating "tip is not included" when we asked about the prices. Food wasn't bad, but not worth about $35 for a deep fried crab legs that were obviously from a bag and not fresh.
New Woey Loy Goey has been a long time fav. haven't been back mush lately.
Yes, dishonest restaurant!!!!!
Dishonest restaurant!
The server might be a little grumpy, but no need to worry about the good, good portion and delicious as expected. Good value and has free WiFi。
If I happen to go to chinatown, this is the place I love to go to for comfort chinese food. It's authentic, and the service is okay. It's more like a dive than a restaurant.
While roaming the streets of chinatown for the first time, I came across this restaurant. I have to say I was very impressed by how authentic their Chinese food was.
Wow what a find ! so if you want the real deal and great prices check this place out.
They seated us right away they had something on the menu for everyone we enjoyed the family meal. The food was wonderful and highly is recommended and everyone went away full and happy.
You can tell food is good here cause it's one of those hard to find spots when you walk down the stairs you find packed with people. Had the spicy eggplant clay pot, tasted great.
Solid place for real Chinese food. Good and efficient service. Always more than one waiter. Seated right away and served tea. Food comes out quickly. Free house soup. Great lunch special deals.

I first ate here in late 1963 or early 1964. Every time I am in San Francisco, I have one meal a Woey Loy Goey. I saw one person mentioned in thier review the Panda Express. They know nothing about Chinese food. I have taken my family there and they too enjoyed the food and the homey atmosphere. I am lucky, I worked with Chinese people from Taiwan. I have eaten in Taiwan and enjoyed just about everything that was put on the table. I have eaten with my co-worker in Texas and at thier homes. All good. Bottom line, I seldom ask what I am eating. In Nam, I was afraid to ask. They might tell me. I liked that as well. We have a Chines restaurant in the small farm commuity where I live in IL. The lunch menu is simple stuff you get at any
excellent food, i love this underground restaurant, they have good prices and free wifi.

Had some good old taishanese dishes that brought back memories of days past. Waitresses very friendly and food was good. That combined with the great value and low prices made for a memorable experience. If I find myself in San Francisco again I will go back for sure.

This place is surprisingly decent and fairly inexpensive. Been here twice for dinner with a large group and ordered a variety of things (Asian style dishes and not the ones you find at more Americanized Chinese restaurants).
beyond bad！！！I  will never go back.
Ate here with my 15 year old daughter, she does not like Chinese food....she thought it was "really good".
Wo Hop, my favorite restaurant in NY's Chinatown is located in the basement, as is Woey Loy Goey.  Wo Hop has been open for as long as I can remember, perhaps beat by Woey Loy, which opened in 1934!

Me and my family wanted to visit china town and get something to eat. We didn't know a specific place and seeing that it all looks dingy and uninviting ( although there was some lady calling us into her restaurant. Literally inviting any non Asian/tourist looking people from across the street. [we didn't go there])we decided to go for the name that stuck out. We went down a few stairs and entered a run down dining room with worn out linoleum and dirty fish aquariums. On one side of the dining room was a long counter where old Chinese men drank tea under a muted tv playing an Asian soap opera . The tables were crammed together and all full of people (and not just Asian). So we figured it didn't only serve weird non Americanized food. The menu was non confusing and the server was a very nice and patient lady. Not only that but even though the place was packed, our order came out quickly and correctly. I didn't go crazy. Got the beef broccoli and a couple egg rolls. It was sooooo tasty! We were all very satisfied and would defiantly go back. I recommend this place to anyone who likes Chinese food but also for those who aren't sure about it. The whole staff was nice. Great experience!
Delicious chinese food. Pricing was very cheap and the portions were great. Dishes were seasoned well, and I had absolutely no complaint about individual dishes.
We have become regulars here.  Free wifi is awesome but of course not the main reason but doesn't hurt!
Whenever my sisters and I stop here for lunch, we always go for the snails (escargots, anyone?).  The French aren't the only ones eating this delicacy; the Chinese do, too.

Do not come here ever! The service is beyond bad, the dinning era is dirty, the food is nasty! Really regretted to come here. And when I was paying the bill the cashier, he yelled at me about the credit card limit but I was using a debit card... he didn't let me use my card either way and I had to get cash from a ATM nearby... Just Don't Wast Your Time And Money Here!!! Trust Me!!!

We are family of 10. Two parents and kids ranging from 16 years old down to two years old. This place was exactly what we were looking for! I wanted a place that had food that was different from anything you could get back home in Arizona. Hopefully, something better than you would get back home. But not something so different but the kids hated-has the mistake last year when we got dim sum in Chinatown and the kids simply stared at the food.

We wandered around Chinatown looking for something to eat. We had our trusty Yelp App out as we passed restaurant after restaurant. Finally, it came to a boiling point. We were hungry and getting anxious to find a place to sit down and put something into our stomachs. Most places seemed to have either poor or varying reviews. We then came across New Woey Loy Goey and a restaurant a few doors down. New Woey looked a little sketchy, as we'd have to walk down the stairs to a below street level area. The place down a few doors had images of Obama eating there on the outside widow and a long wait. Nope. Back to New Woey. What a surprise! When we entered, we there are only a couple people inside. We were greeted graciously. By the end of our meal, the place was packed with locals. You gotta figure, if the locals are eating there in droves, they know where the good food is.

This might not be a five star Chinese diner but service was sincere. Owners tried their best to serve every table with patience and sincerity . Dishes were surprisingly yummy and close to authentic! Given the fact that it is Chinese food in USA, it's taste is very well pretty close! If clueless what to order, feel free to ask the owners for recommendations!
It's one of the places that my family been going to since the 2000s. Their food all have great "wok hei" and I'm continually impressed by their consistency.

Very impressed! Wow. Woey Loy Goey restaurant is truly a hidden gem. Me and my friend were wondering around the streets of Chinatown, searching for a place that had good noddles for a VERY cheap price. My wallet had only $10 and my friends wallet only held around $5. Thanks to one of those ladies who pass out pamphlets advertising their restaurants, we would of never stumbled across this place. The lady handed us a pamphlet to a different restaurant, but we told her the prices were too much for us. We told her we were looking for a place with amazing noodles and rice dishes for a cheap price. She told us about Woey Loy Goey and that we would like their menu. She proceeded to give us directions and we listened carefully.
Went here on a Sunday for a late lunch and the experience was terrible.
What can you say about a place when the service is bad & the food is mediocre at best?
Great black bean sauce snails.

An underground hole-in-the-wall restaurant that serves authentic, first-rate Chinese food with reasonable prices and quick service. Make sure to try their beef chow fun. It is the best! I will definitely eat here again the next time I visit San Francisco.

Not for the faint of heart. This menu serves the tourists and the community. So don't get ethno-phobic. Walk down those stairs and have a great meal. The food is solid (minus egg rolls). It's a nice change because you will see a nice mix a tourist and locals. And if the locals eat here you know they've got the goods. And they do.

Basement Chinese restaurant in SF Chinatown!  One of the best dining restaurants in Chinatown whenever you and your crew want to dine in Chinatown!  This place conveniently holds large, dine-in gatherings!

We went to this restaurant on recommendation from some locals. The Duck Wonton Soup was amazing, the fried rice was very good and the prices were great. It was a nice change from the touristy restaurants in Chinatown.
Great place to eat!  We were recommended there by the people at the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie place and the whole family loved it.  Good prices & great food!

The best snails in black bean sauce EVER!  The salt & pepper chicken wings and braised quail was awesome too.  The place is non-pretentious, reasonably priced, and family atmosphere.  I will definitely woey loy next time as the name says.
when you are broke this is a great restaurant to just get full plus take to go.

I've eaten here once in awhile during the last 35 years. We are a mixture of Filipino, Chinese, Spanish, and white and I am the only one to speak a little Chinese. So did we sometimes get our food later than some others. Yes. Did the waiter have crummy Engerish and we had to be very clear? Yes. When it is busy, and it can get full on weekends with 80% or more Chinese people, in small and big parties 6 to 10.
This place is horrible!!!! If you don't want to die from food poisoning, do not eat here.
The duck is really good. The dumplings are all tasty. Everything is seemingly clean. For being in the middle of China Town, this place is the best of authentic, clean, and meeting most health codes.
I went here for just one item in the Grant Place bakery: the egg tart. It was incredible. Better than any I've ever had in all my years of growing up in New York City's Manhattan Chinatown.
I don't want to give them any star, the food was horrible, look like them forgot to put the salt, no flavor T_T

I'm not sure why this place has such a low rating, but I enjoyed my visit here last week. I've had a lot of Chinese food throughout my life, and although I've never been to China myself, I think I have a pretty good idea of what's good and what's not. The bbq roasted duck and house special pan fried noodles were really tasty, portions were large, and they had been brought out in a timely manner despite the restaurant being busy. I wasn't a huge fan of the dim sum sampler since it didn't seem that fresh, but some of the items were better than others.

Our late Sunday evening stroll through Chinatown left us with very few dining options.  We for no particular reason chose here.  Once we saw what appeared to be local Asian patrons seated...we felt good about our choice.  The service was great and the serving sizes generous.  One downside to this joint was that they only have one shared restroom and long lines can form as a result.
I wish I could give negative stars.

The Siu Mai and Xian Shui Jiao are delicious. The dim sum and dumplings are perfectly moist and fresh. The fried vegetables are so fresh and perfectly fried. And the duck is cooked just right and not overly sweet. Usually restaurants tend to overlook the duck.

I should have known better when I saw that every waiter had filthy clothes. But I realized only too late. At one point, a waiter waddled thru the dining room lugging a food grade container filled with dirty water. Let's hope it was run off from the air conditioner because heaven forbid if it was fish sauce or something they intended to cook with. The food was 'meh' at best. I really must blame myself for not looking up their Yelp rating.
Unsanitary and disgusting food. Salty, greasy, horrible, dirty.
Sigh. Like many others have said..IT'S A TOURIST TRAP!
NASTY NASTY NASTY.
Tourist trap at its worst.
Inexpensive but you get what you pay for. Not the best dim sum place. Ordered soy bean drink and was so watered down. BBQ pork was a little hard. Duck rice is pretty good though.
The Dim Sum was tasty, cheep, and easy to get in China Town.

Ew... dinner was pretty nasty and the place is dirty.  Dim sum plate tasted like greasy microwaved bits of bread with who knows what inside.  Kung Pao was eh...  My boyfriend had a shrimp pancake - we packed it up and gave it to a homeless guy.  Wait staff was not friendly at all, no eye contact, miserable.  From now on I'll be checking Yelp ahead of time.  If I saw all these reviews I would have never gone.  Totally $45 bucks wasted.  And what a shame... there are so many Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, but now I can't think of having Chinese again any time soon.  Positive - the tea was quite good and so was the chicken fried rice.

Was pretty good for a walk-in restaurant. Able to seat 8 easily. Food was flavorful. Had the dim sum plate. Great variety. Rest of the party had Peking duck, orange chicken, General tsao's chicken, sesame chicken. Very enjoyable. The beef curry low main was dry. The only negative.
This place sucks! Like horrible.

My friend got flagged by the restaurant manager while I arrived to Chinatown with him. We were under the instructions by family members that any dim sum restaurant in Chinatown is good, and that we could go to any and expect the best of the dim sum.

passing by and see couple of roasted duck hanging on the rack and wanted to get half. went in and told the lady I want half of the roasted duck and she asked me if i want anything else, roasted pork, dimsum. I said no, just half of the roasted duck. she said $9. when i got home and open the box, WTF, she gave me all neck and head part and the back, no leg drumstick and only 3 pieces of the breast. what a rid off, i will never go to this place again. I think the lady is the owner, she speaks to herself, I think she is crazy.
You know, I only ate here once and had their beef noodle soup.  But I thought it was quite good, if a tad small in portion.   It was priced right, however, and the service was fast and efficient.

Extremely disappointed by seafood bean curb - which is apparently tasteless, and namely half "Peking roast duck" which is about 1/4 of a whole duck. Not to mention the sanitary was done poorly as well. Heard none of other dishes are decent either.

Wandered around forever and a day going uphill and downhill and back uphill trying to search out a dim sum place that's not just a takeout joint with a couple tables and chairs. Came across this place and was more than happy to flop down because they have waiter service.

Never again, That is for sure. If it was not for the fact that we were in town for the Chinese New Years Parade and just happened to be hungry, it wouldn't have turned out to be the Restaurant of choice. We walked in and it was pretty packed, so we got the seat right next to the kitchen. Very appealing...not really! When we sat down, I had tried to pull up Yelp to see if the ratings were as bad as I has suspected, took forever to load Yelp, so we figured we'll just go for it...I find out later that it doesn't have very good reviews..big surprise, not really.  We ordered the combo A and substituted the pork for chicken. The food came in it was subpar chinese food at best. We noticed that the bill had all kinds of hidden charges, guess that's to screw with the tourists. Lesson learned. Not going back to that little dive.

Tourist trap ! Never go to 1-2 star rating Chinese restaurants in Chinatown , I just don't understand why are these 1-2 star rating restaurants still open there are ok Chinese restaurants or probably even better Chinese restaurants around Chinatown , and the sunset district , san Bruno , silver ave , Geary blvd area ! I know the people work there just trying to eat but they if they are running a Chinese restaurant they should at least run the places better with good costumer service , cleanliness , better food since they are not doing neither of those they might as well close down the restaurant .
Very UNSANITARY ! Although there's too many negative reviews, I still chose to give this place a try which I shouldn't have.
The place is dirty and smells of urine. In terms of the food, the crispy pork I ordered was the exact opposite of crispy--it tasted like rubber.
Delicious Dim Sum! Especially love the pork dumplings!

You know, this is your typical somewhat-dirty, poor-service Chinese restaurant.  HOWEVER, the food is delicious, authentic and fairly cheap.  If you grew up eating in places like this, you ignore some of the faults to enjoy the food.  It's conveniently located just up the street from the parking garage, so it was our first stop before shopping in Chinatown.

DO NOT EAT HERE!!!! This is the worst food I've ever had in SF. 1) found a rubber band in the mongolian beef dish 2) the apetizer never came 3) exceptionally rude waiters 4) flies everywhere--gross! 4) smelled like sour washing-cloth 5) The food was NOT freshly prepared, the vegetables came straight from a can and the sauce was the same in both dishes.
Hole in the wall served us high quality potstickers and baked BBQ buns. Sizes are generous. Fresh ingredients. Recommend this place!

After making numerous promises about no longer eating at a restaurant in Chinatown, I digressed and found myself walking up Washington Street. After a short walk from the financial district, I came upon Portsmouth Square which looked like a disaster scene. There were about 10,000 old men and women chain smoking and yakking God knows what at each other. It looked very unruly and potentially dangerous. Reminded me of a scene in an old movie about one of those middle eastern port cities where literally thousands of people congregate in inhumane and unsanitary conditions to engage in commerce. Little did I realize that the scene that I just described to you is not far from the truth when it came to my food in this little dirty spot in Chinatown.
long story short:

A Negative star rating if possible. Figured we'd try some new places for dim sum whilst walking down grant and finding myself and my family being quite literally held hostage and literally dragged into the restaurant by the woman shoving menus and flyers in anyones face who dares walk past. You'd think any self respecting restaurant that serves even decent food wouldn't need to bother to such tactics.

Desperately craving Chinese food one night at 11 pm, I wandered into Chinatown like a crazy person. I looked at every restaurant with big eyes searching for the "We're Open" neon sign. Luckily, I stumbled upon three elderly Chinese men, two holding a ladder for one that was changing a light bulb. (Joke: how many Chinese men does it take to change a light bulb?) I shouted to them "excuse me, where can I find some good Chinese food at this time of night?" One of the Chinese men left the ladder and beckoned his sister down the street. She ran over to him and said "come here, eat at my restaurant." LOL.. My tummy said, "hell yeah."
Don't waste your time or money here.
Avoid. This place has bad food, worse service and overcharge you.  There are many 4-5 places nearby that will make much happier.

Got pulled in by a lady with a coupon stating that the food was cheap. We were in the mood for some dim sum so we decided to go in. She dropped off some mystery potstickers, or at least what I thought were pot stickers. Server never really came around except when he dropped off a pot of green tea which we ended up having to pay for. I didn't really get that, but anyway...finally got someone to get me some veggie spring rolls. By this time we were ready to leave so I got them packed up. They tried to charge us for the potstickers so I gave up the explanation of everything and paid the $6 just to leave.

The food in this restaurant is greasy and salty. They also did a bait and switch of the seafood dish by replacing the rock cod with talapia. They even added 15% tip to our bill automatically for party of three and said this is the requirement of California government.
I guess I liked the food but the service was horrible. The place is dirty, the restroom is atrocious.
Hmmmm, mixed feelings. My burrito was too much of a wrap. I wanted the Mexican feel... and there was nothing Mexican about it. Everything was fresh, though!

OK, I got that healthy chicken burrito - you know the one - with the dry chicken and a big leaf of romaine. And the tortilla comes in different colors -you can't really call them flavors, can you? Of course its dry and tasteless but I found a cure for that:  not just 1 or 2; but 3 containers of salsa verde.  Now you got a decent burrito.
Yes ithe syrup is corn sweet but that is the style...
Rude staff who always make me think that they are messing up my order on purpose!

Was in the mood for a wrap so I dropped by to buy a chicken wrap.  BTW, they are no longer called "360 Burrito"  it's now "360 Gourmet World Grill."  I guess they changed the name to appease those who took issue about the food not being a "burrito."

They ain't burritos, but they ain't bad. It's basically "choose the things you like, we'll throw it together and heat it up." Which if you work in the fidi isn't the worst case lunch scenario. It's cool that you can get a tofu breakfast dish. I don't know anywhere else nearby where that happens. Prices are a bit high for what you get, though. Especially for the unspectacular drink selection.

Crap, I should have read the reviews before I went out in search of lunch.  I hate the menu format...why can't they make the matches for me?  I went shrimp and mediterranean and it was just plain bad.  The right thing would have been if the cashier had said, "um, no lady, that will suck".  And it was insanely messy.  When your clientele is all work minions, you have to make it so I can eat at my desk.

To call what is served here burritos is a bit of a stretch. Yes, the contents are wrapped in a tortilla. These contents may or may not be beans, rice, cheese, and some form of meat depending on your selection. The resulting combination, though, is never a burrito.
It's Friday afternoon...
I went in today for the first time, and ordered a chicken and spinach burrito which sounded rather interesting.
If could choose no stars, I definitely would.

this is almost as much of an apology to Yelp as it is a review of this burrito joint.  First off, the apology . . . I'm sorry Yelp for trying this place without first consulting your wise sages.  A co-worker and I just decided to walk around, and decided that hey, maybe a "gourmet burrito" might not be as bad as it sounds . . .
Tofu in a burrito?  Fire the chef who came up with that!
I had the grilled-gristle burrito with corn syrup sauce.

Talk about horrible. They slather up 12+ ingredients and pile it all onto what has to be THE weakest tortillas on earth, which then gets held loosely together by a single-ply sheet of tinfoil. It's strong enough to contain everything until the exact moment you unwrap it at your desk, whereupon it falls apart in your lap.

Uh, yeah. Do a 180 and walk right back out. Gourmet my ass. They do get an extra star for that awesomely bad early 90s logo and decor. The marketing department, was like, 'Screw it, we're staying in the 90s. Where are my parachute pants?!'

I heart burritos, and my quest to find a good one near my office has so far been a bust. The chicken burrito I got here was okay, but not very good. Even if it had been delicious, there's no way I would go back - too damn expensive! It's worth the walk to get to a cheaper and more authentic place.

You have work really hard to make a nasty burrito. I applaud you 360 Degrees! Your "gourmet" burritos leave little to be desired. Seriously - how do you f*%^ up a burrito?! First of all, you use Romaine lettuce. WTF is that about? And then you have this strange pink "special sauce". Pink is a color that should never make an appearance in a burrito unless it's sweet, succulent prawns. Your meat is gnarled. Your rice is overwhelming in abundance. And your lunch crowd is nasty mean!

I've eaten here a couple times when I worked downtown and I regretted it every time. For the price of one undersized "360" burrito, you could get two burritos in a Mission taqueria. The financial district lunch crowd can afford to get burned... burn baby burn.

I hate "Gourmet" burrito places.  It is not a burrito if it has pesto chicken, asian seasonings, or roasted red peppers or curry....sorry.   They are "wraps" which is basically a health nut's answer to burritos...

Had to get a quick lunch today so hit up this joint close to work.  In my entire life I've never had to actually run to the bathroom to avoid a gastrointestinal mishap and I've eaten at taco stands with guys cutting from rotating pigs in Tiajuna with flies buzzing around the carcass.  Today, I had to make the dash about 2 hours after eating a steak quasedilla from here.  Extra star because it actually tasted ok and I can't be certain they are to blame (though it was the only thing I had eaten all day).  I used to get the Thai Chicken burrito from here and that would rate a 3 normally, but I got tired of all the rice and now after this experience, I won't go back for some time.

I guess this is the equivalent to rolls in sushi. Americanized "gourmet" burritos complete with marinated artichoke hearts are listed on their menu. But I have to say that although snobbish compared to the mission burritos, they are pretty decent. I had the salmon buritto, and it was alright. I went during non-peak lunch hours, which is really bad in the financial district cause nothing is fresh anymore. BUT I was starving so I think that's what made it better. The salmon was a bit dry, and the rice had no flavor. But they put this sauce in it... dont know what it is, but it is what made the burrito. really.

I never thought the day would come when I would choose a "gourmet" burrito over an "authentic" one, and yet here I am eating a so-called gourmet burrito from 360 degrees. It's by default, really. I love burritos, it's Cinco de Mayo, and there are only two taquerias with close proximity to my office. This place has what you would expect from a modern burrito joint.. various meats, tofu, fancy vegetables and pre-packaged tortilla chips. No choice of beans, only black and the rice is not much better than Uncle Ben's white rice. A basic burrito with chips and soda runs you about $6.50. It's mediocre, but it'll do in a pinch, and it's better than the El Faro across the street.
Appauling...their chicken tastes like slimy mildew and their beef has so much fat in it that you need to spit half of it out from not being able to chew it.

fairly good food but portions are a little small. some of their photos on the wall were larger portions but overpriced.  i liked their water chestnut desert. little dissapointed the taro veggie fish was a little oily and sauce wasnt that great. have had more authentic versions before.

the filthiest restaurant I've ever been in.  the food was greasy and unappetizing.  we sat by a door inside that was literally black from dirt.  i've been a vegetarian for over 40 years, this place is horrible.  better vegetarian food can be had in almost any decent chinese restaurant.
Cheap food, big portions!  Hit the spot :)

We had our favorite minced bean cake, tomato and egg plant with soft bean cake, fried rice with vegetarian chicken, gluten combination (appetizer) which you can't get anywhere else as good in the Bay Area.  The appetizer is as good as the one in Hong Kong that I grew up with.  The chrysanthemum tea is superb.   We don't taste any sodium or MSG from the food.  We also had the last and the best dessert which is the walnut soup.  Just enough sweet with richness from the walnut without any additives or artificial flavor.  Overall the restaurant is homey and cozy. Service is very personable.   The place and utensils seemed pretty clean to us.  Highly recommended.
I heart this restaurant so much!!! Thank you Lucky creation for feeding me, and all of my friends. YOU have the best food, and i love eating it, and i will always return to you :)

This place always feels cozy. Friendly people and delicious veggie food. They also have perfect brown rice. The food is reasonably priced and the portions are a filling size. They also have the tiniest bathroom I have ever seen. :)
It is a sad day when your favorite part of the meal is the brown rice.  Too much cornstarch left the dishes flavorless.  The gluten pufff was too chewy and strange.
The waitress was very nice, and I wish I could leave a more positive review. I've had a lot of Vegan Chinese food in my life, and this was the worst.
Little restaurant in Chinatown. Food is delicious and very kind service. Dishes are plenty of food. Better to have a dinner before 21:30. True chinese taste. Gluten free food as well.
3 words: vegetarian pork buns !!!!!

The first full vegetarian Chinese place I have been to! The prices are cheap and the food is good! They have done a great job making everything vegetarian and sticking to Chinese cooking! We ordered 4 dishes for under $30 and the portions are huge!
Oh man, I don't know how to write this review without squeeing all over about it.

LOVE the sticky rice sushi rolls and the puffed wheat gluten sampler. Both of those you can get at the counter as a take-out snack. I will definitely be stopping by here whenever I'm in the area for some of this goodness.
I had to get TOGO the last time I was here (went with carnivores) or else I would have taken my time to sit down and order.
Overall, I think I was conned. And you could be if you don't pay attention here.

My friend and I came here twice in the three days we spent in San Francisco this month, to get the sweet and sour pork and the spring rolls. The service was quick and friendly and the loose leaf tea we were served was more flavourful than most complimentary teas I've had at Chinese restaurants. Also the air inside smells of incense, which was a plus for both of us.
Have always liked the vegetarian food here.  The restaurant is small and unpretentious.  The lemon chicken is delicious.
Two words to remember:  CASH ONLY

This place is horrible. Trader joes frozen fried rice is much better. The kitchen is disgustingly dirty, prices aren't that cheap, and service is rude-not to mention the food is slimy and gross. Just because it's vegan doesn't mean it's good (or healthy).
This restaurant makes me think I could go vegetarian! And that's saying A LOT already!

Delicious vegan/vegetarian food at low prices. The atmosphere is not that conffy, the place is to small and tight. They try to rush you to get out  for the other people to come in since there is not a lot of tables to sit.

I love this place! They had vegetarian dumplings, which is something I have been looking for in Chicago for a long time. During my visit to SF my friend took me to this restaurant and it was delicious. We enjoyed tons of food, and took delicious leftovers home! :)

I came to this place and have dined in before. I like how the dishes were simple. The dishes are on the healthier side. I thought that the dishes we ordered was very simple to the point almost all of them taste the same but just different ingredients in it. Some dishes maybe oily, but overall on the bland side.
It's not glitzy, it's not that exciting, but the food is quite good for vegetarian Chinese food.

Very good delicious vegetarian food at reasonable price. It is a hole in the wall restaurant hidden among other Chinese restaurants in SF Chinatown. There are about 5-6 tables in a small room. It can get little crowded around lunch time. Sometimes you might end up sharing a big table with other guests.
Yum!
I am a meat-eater that loves vegetarian food.
Went here last night and ordered the following:

As vegetarian/vegan in SF goes, this isn't the best, but it's a decent option and one that has been around for a long time. I guess that's why I keep coming back. A few years ago, I would have probably given it a higher rating, but there are so many other great veg places in the city. This is worth trying, but it won't be a fancy or especially pretty experience.
The food was good and the portions were plentiful

Short and sweet, what I had was average and I think there was a slight misunderstanding.  I ordered a vegan beef and broccoli dish, but received a dish just consisting of just broccoli which tasted super healthy.  The ladies who ran the business were really nice and the tea served was good.

Lucky is one of two places my local guide recommended in Chinatown. It'sa hole in the wall with 5-6 tables inside. The place smells of five spice powder and has a small deli counter where locals pick up faux meats by the pound. You know this stuff is good and cheap because there is a constant line at the counter.

The good reviews here don't lie. Personally this is my go to vegetarian restaurant in all of San Francisco ! Great place to take friends or to introduce friends to the vegetarian lifestyle! The menu is very wide ranging portions are massive! The brown rice is sooo tasty as well as all the entrees !  Authentic powerful Chinese cuisine. Bursting with flavor!

Loved the food here. A small place, but awesome food. We thought we had ordered too much. But everyone loved the food so much, everything was cleaned up in no time. We have lived in china before and this food felt very authentic and brought back fond memories.

Tucked away on Washington St, this is a neighborhood gem of a hole for me. Every veggie dish I've had is awesome, with soy-based meat. I can scarf down their chicken fried rice as a meal in itself. Sometimes I'd brave the Chinatown push and shove and hill climbing just to go here.

I was a tired, out of town tourist walking the hilly San Francisco streets on a Saturday. It was about 3 pm, I didn't have lunch yet. I found myself in Chinatown, making questionable decisions with spending money on random stuff from one of those tourist trap shops. Looked to yelp for vegetarian recommendations that wouldn't burn a hole in my wallet and decided to go here.

Meh. A bit too dirty, hole in the wall with terrible food. Nice to see a veggie option in Chinatown but it wasn't really about celebrating delicious vegetables but rather about lots of pretend tofu-meat substitutes and viscous sauce coating everything (Shanghai style). Yuck. Never again

I've been coming here for a long time, and keep coming back. My favorite vegan restaurant in SF, and fav of any kind in Chinatown. Show up with $10, eat amazingly well, and leave with change in your pocket.

Absolutely fantastic hidden gem in the middle of china town. What hooked me here at first were their freshly made vegetarian steamed pork buns. But after a few visits bay was of just stopping by for a few buns I decided to sit down for a change since they are normally very busy during the lunch hours. The taro stuffed deep fried tofu really are to die for. That and the perfectly crisped honk long style pan fried chow mein noodles with a side of their veggi sweet and sour pork made satisfying my taste buds nearly impossible there after. Not only was the food delicious but came out rather quickly. I've never say down, ordered, and had my food come out that fast before at any sit down restaurants. Then again I was there after the lunch hour rush when things have already cooled down and less people around.
Filthy restaurant, foul food,
DPD is short in cantonese for dai pai dong, literally means big gathering of stalls/vendors aka street food-hong kong style.
Quite surprise the amount of reviews written for this place: "one".

Got the Hot Chili Sauce Chicken for $4 and it was excellent.  Loved the sauce, chicken was very plentiful and good quality and nice green peppers and onion.  Rice and tea also, though tea was cold which was only negative.  Place is tiny but tidy place at corner of Jackson and Kearny and they recently got a new paint job so it looks nice.  Very affordable and they had Average White Band playing on the radio in the kitchen real loud when I walked in which really hit the spot.

Just a great job on the BBQ pork wonton noodle soup. Earlier I got it and the quality of pork was sub par, but every other time has been excellent quality so they get a few more stars from me.  For less than $6, this is a great bargain! I also enjoy getting an order of potstickers for less than $6. They serve it with a vinegar sauce that was surprising at first (it's a red sauce and most Americanized places serve potstickers with a sweet red sauce) but I'll admit the vinegar paired well with the potsticker filling
Delicious food, amazing duck; really enjoyed our lunch here.  We will definitely return.

I now consider Yee's Restaurant as one of my favorite go to restaurant... When I am at the San Francisco Chinatown Area!!! My most favorite rice plate that always like to order when I like sit back and relax and just forget about everything else!!! While eating my Mince Beef W/ Raw Egg Over Steam Rice!!! And I have mentioned this on my previous yelp review of Yee's Restaurant and I say it again... I have eaten at Yee's Restaurant so many many times over the years and I have never never experience any stomach aches or diarrhea when I finish eating at Yee's Restaurant...
Roast duck and Char Sui (BBQ PK) quality is worse than 99 ranch... Cold and dry, microwaved twice.
An ok chinese bbq shop in c-town

Like many Chinatown restaurants, it ain't fancy looking but Yee's Restaurant offers family style dinner (3 dishes, rice, and soup) for under $20 as well as a plethora of roast meats that are the subject of many tourists' photos on Grant Street.

Don't be frightened by the roast duck and bbq pork hanging in the window.  My first time here I watched a group of tourist pointing towards the duck hanging in the window before scurrying off into the night.
My wife and I decided to eat here on a whim based on our hunger.  We ordered the soy sauce chicken, roast duck, and Chinese broccoli.
Wandering around chinatown and found this place. Ordered roasted duck - 80% of the duck they gave us was fat and bones. Skin wasn't crispy. Also ordered fried squid, too much batter, too greasy.
Amazing roast duck, roast pig, Mongolian beef, egg rolls etc.  Server was upbeat and nice, and the 24oz Tsingtaos are only $5.
There's no denying it. I love BBQ Pork. So when I was walking down Grant in Chinatown and saw Roasted Ducks and Pigs through Yee's Restaurant's front window, nothing could stop me from walking in.
Great food, nice service! Locals eat here so quality is high and the price is right. I'll come back again

Saw this on Shirley Fong-Torres's website; it was one of many restaurants she took one of her tour groups to and well no frills, it makes up for it in the low prices, friendly but brisk service, and simple Cantonese food.  The pot stickers are crispy golden with a wonderful ground pork, cabbage, and ginger filling; perfect with the rice vinegar.  The beef ly fun is to die for with tender marinaded beef and light ly fun with that golden wok taste.  The kung pao chicken is tender with mushrooms, peppers, celery, carrots, and peanuts in a chili sauce that packs a bit of spice but not like at a Szechwan restaurant as this is a Cantonese restaurant.  I would definitely come back.  So, for excellent simple Cantonese food at low prices with brisk but nice service in a friendly no frills atmosphere, Yee's cannot beat beat.  Keep up the good work guys.

Closes at 9pm as we happen to make our way thru chinatown and stumbled into this restaurant after some bar hoping adventures. We ordered and with lighting quick reflex the food showed up on out table in less then 4 minutes. great Food will be back for sure!!!!
I'll make this short and sweet.  This place is amazing!
Compare to other restaurants in Chinatown, the services here are decent.  They're actually nice.  Their portion are huge.  The prices are decent as well.

This place looks  like a foodies paradise with the ducks being displayed at the window but shall I caution you that the food isn't that great. I would suggest Hong Kong Clay Pot down the street. Cheap prices, horrible service (waited 40 min for my food ) and  food wasn't good. I ended up taking most of the food to go and giving it to a homeless person. They get a one star for multiple reasons... First being they brought out a wrong plate, but after waiting I accepted it Bc I was starving.... Secondly, the cashier told my husband he better leave a tip on the table... For what? Horrible service, wrong order and nasty food? Needless to say, we left without tipping due to the pushy cashier.
We like coming whenever we're in China Town because service is decent, food quality good and prices per dish are very cheap.

Abundant tasty food - inside a busy establishment. The menu seemed inexpensive (and it was) and the food was tasty and plentiful for the price. We had the Snow Peas and Prawns, the Kung Pow Chicken, Spring Rolls and Shrimp Fried rice - and soon realized that we had enough food for at least 4 HUNGRY people.  Good value and would go again to try other items.

We were told to visit this place prior to visiting Chinatown in San Fran.  I suppose Yee's has been around for quite sometimes and the older generation seems to know a lot about them.  There is even a counterfeit restaurant with similar Chinese name around the corner on Broadway St.
The food is ok for its price, but the service sucks. NEVER COMING BACK

Very VERY authentic. Probably a bit too authentic for my taste and I'm a fairly adventurous eater. The roast duck was phenomenal but the beef was mushy, slimy and fatty. Steer clear of pork & beef. Pot stickers were good and doughy.
I saw this place on Food Network after we went there. Great food..owner a lil suspect, but great food. lol.
The Cantonese Roast Goose at Yee's is excellent.

cash only. bad service. BBQ duck is too salty. CHEAP, very CHEAP, of course don't expect 5 star quality when it's that cheap. They have afternoon special with chinese BBQ dishes, I think its $2.70 a dish. YES dumb ass cheap... but very greasy and salty...

One of the best Chinese food restaurants in Chinatown. The thing with this area is you gotta weed out the restaurants that are just purely attracting tourists and the ones that have genuine good authentic Chinese food

After walking around Chinatown for a while on our 1st day in San Francisco looking for a place to have dinner, we stumbled upon this very reasonably priced cantonese style BBQ restaurant. You can order the BBQ meats hanging in the window by the plate ($8-9), or order 1 or 2 meats over rice ($5-8). The food was pretty good and this place did get crowded on the Saturday night we were here. This place is cash only, like most of the places in Chinatown so don't come with just plastic! I would definitely return again if in San Francisco! We actually tried coming a few days later but it was too late in the evening and they had already closed (8:30ish pm)

Excellent food.  We tried the pot stickers, several noodle dishes, a fresh fish and veggie dish, a noodle soup with duck and egg rolls. For seven people, each with their own dish, one beer and a soda. Incredibly the bill came out to $40!!!

Our family stopped here yesterday on a quick trip into the city.  I found this restaurant via another site's recommendation (I felt guilty for cheating on Yelp, of course) -- it fit the bill for location, price range and ratings, and if we go somewhere unfamiliar without a destination in mind, we tend to wander aimlessly until we finally turn on each other in a low-blood-sugar rage, like crazed jackals.

Not special or anything, just plain humble blue collar Hong Kong style Chinese food. It is tasty and filling, but not spectacular or even special in any way, but then again, that's part of the appeal of this place. This is a good place to have an inexpensive lunch in the city, portions are big, food is 3 stars, but value is 4 stars. I wish I cold give half stars.

Great place- no idea why food listed as bland, salty, etc. Had greens and prawns, noodle and beef, BBQ and tofu, peking spare ribs and crispy pork intestines- all hot, fresh. tons of food, quick service- what is better?
I was reading the menu outside...

Came here for family dinner and the food was complete crap. Bland. Flavorless. & Leftovers.  3 words that literally summed up ALL of the dishes. The best thing I had that night were the oranges they served.
It is correct to call this place authentic (dirty, walls plastered with menu items but written only in Chinese). But authentic is not always a good thing.

My boyfriend and I spent a long weekend in San Francisco and on the top of our to-do list was to go to a great little hole-in-the wall Chinese restaurant in Chinatown,  We found Yee's and were very hopeful considering it looked like it catered to a lot of locals. Inside was very simple and kinda dirty.  We were seated right away and everything sounded great on the menu. We were really bummed when the waiter came around to take our order and we were told that almost everything we were planning on getting was sold out or they no longer made it.  No big deal, we just ordered the Mongolian beef, pig intestines, half of a duck, and shrimp fried rice.

Went there with three other persons. We shared a soup with duck, a rice dish with pork and shrimp sauce, a rice dish with beef and fried noodles with shrimps. Everything was delicious, service was very friendly and quick and above all the price was very competitive (ca. 50 USD including tip). I had the impression we got pretty authentic chinese food. The interior is not very fancy, if you want that, go somewhere else. But if you want to experience great chinese food you won't be disappointed.
It's in Chinatown +
My wife and I took a time out for a day in Chinatown in San Francisco.  As always,

We got the cooked dishes, rather than the bbq, which was a big mistake. The fish was tough and overlooked, shrimp was also tough and not how seafood should taste, and the pork ribs were flavorless. Would only recommend/ come back for BBQ and not anything from the kitchen.
I was glad my friend and I happened upon this place after walking all the way through Chinatown! The ducks hanging by the window were a draw since I was looking for legit Chinese food.
