When the legendary restaurant "Sam Wo's" closed down in 2013, I was heartbroken to say the least. Afterwards, I was in desperate search of an authentic, great-tasting, and comfortable Chinese restaurant. Much to my surprise, I found it right across the street at Kam Lok.
Food is ok.

Waited over 45 minutes after the order had been taken, nothing arrived on our table.  Tried to talk to the waitress to check on the status of the order, and they ignored you like you are an idiot.  Service is extremely poor.  I would not come back again to this restaurant mainly because of the poor customer service, and the place is stuffy and not that clean after all.
Love this weird place! The food is always good.  Today we had amazing honey walnut prawns.
It's always a good sign when 90% of the patrons in a Chinese restaurant are actually Chinese! We got the $38 set menu meal with lobster and the 4 of us were stuffed. Good food, excellent price!
This place was a pleasant surprise the first time we came here. We got the

if we're talking about food, this place is pretty authentic...everything really has that "wok hei" (as my mother would say) and prices that don't make your wallet cry. my mom loves coming here even though the place is dirty and the staff is rude, but honestly, its a chinese restaurant what else would you expect in Chinatown. We always get three dishes which comes with a soup of the day. Love watching the old chinese guys bring in personals of hennessey and getting crunk. Loud kinda obnoxious atmosphere, but if you don't mind its awesome! When I gather enough people I'm definitely coming back for that $38 dinner deal.. a variety of dishes with soup.........AND IT COMES WITH sauteed LOBSTER.

Was in Chinatown looking for a new place to eat that was good for the wallet. A family member suggested me to give Kam Lok a try. I did not notice this place existed as I grew up in the city as this is located in the basement of a building. I was quickly greeted and seated as I walked down the stairs. I got their Bean Crud Ox Tail Clay Pot, Snow Pea Sprouts, and the Salt and Pepper Chicken Wings. The Ox Tail Clay Pot was very good and flavorful with a lot of meat. The Snow Pea Sprouts tasted a bit old as it was a bit hard. The Chicken Wings were very standard and were not to greasy. The service was very fast on a weekend as we went late in the afternoon. Overall not a bad place to eat in Chinatown as the people working here are nice and attentive. I will return later to try other items on their menu, possibly the crab as it is recommended by many people.

I love hole in the wall Chinese but I really didn't care for this one. Service was really bad - I know that's part of hole in the wall Chinese but this one was worse than normal.  Food usually overcomes that issue, but not here. The generals chicken was the worst I've had.  Definitely some questionable chicken parts. The shrimp fried rice was ok and veggie egg rolls were the best part. I think it may have been too authentic for me.

Walking around china town we decided to check this place out .this place is pretty cool because it's underground basement type restaurant but that's where the coolness stops .... The service is bad ... The lady who served us was very unhappy  and gave us the menus and walked away after a while she came back and asked for our order , so even though they advertise dim sum ...THEY DO NOT HAVE DIM SUM so instead I ordered beef won ton soup and my family ordered pork chow mein and beef with oyster sauce and rice well the rice didn't come out until we were halfways done eating and even though we had asked her twice , once when she had got done talking to friends she finally brought out the rice and the rest of the food had no flavor and was bland especially the soup . If the service doesn't keep me away from this place then the food def will . There are plenty of good Chinese food restaurants in china town and this not one of them

five minutes after ordering we discovered that instead of being a party of 7, we were actually a party of 8. There was a cockroach under my sister's chair. not a dead cockroach, a wriggling, squirming, very large cockroach. we should have got up and left right then but my stupid family is too polite.
It's taken almost a year for me to post this review, but the facts remain the same.

Easily the worst Chinese food I've had in my life. Went in there during lunch break to have some authentic Chinese food... Well as it turns out "Chinese family cuisine" stands for: no spices whatsoever an barely any chicken in a meat dish...  Just go somewhere else, there are so many good restaurants around.

Walk downstairs to this restaurant, this place gets packed on a weekend night.  $38 for a set lobster meal for 4 people, cannot beat that!  Includes soup, fried chicken wings, Mongolian beef and tofu with veggies.  You'd need to order steamed rice separately.  They also have a crab version of the set meal for same price.

Seafood pan-fried noodle for $6.99 was off the hook. Gotta try it. Black bean sauce beef chow-fun was great too for $5.99. The food is great and cheap. You will never walk into this restaurant unless you were searching for it, as it is a basement. Give it a try, everything on the lunch special is around $5-$7. Dinner is relatively cheap too. Large portions too. Oh, don't whine about the service, it is not bad service, you get your food and tea, basic Chinese restaurant service.  Go for the food, that's what matters, right? Oh please don't try pot stickers and egg rolls and complain about how bad it is. All westerners do is try the crap at Chinese restaurants and complain about it being crap. Most Chinese restaurant don't make them from scratch, and they will laugh at you for ordering this crap behind your back. You are better off buying some ling ling pot stickers from Costco.

took a walk over from home for a late lunch. chose this place on the strength of yelp reviews. to those of you who rave about this place: are you serious? I had the potstickers, salt and pepper fried tofu, Mongolian beef, white rice and tea.
Tribute review

This place was a great find! It can be really easy to miss as its storefront is just an a door with stairs leading to a basement. Order one of the dinner specials. For $11/person, you will have a very delicious feast.

Seafood is fresh, crabs lobster and fish pulled straight from the tank. Crabs looked delicious. This is a place for the local Chinese community. The portions are substantial and the menu is very extensive.

You can get a whole lot of food for under $40 here. They have two dinner sets to choose from that include five different dishes for only $38. One set has baked crab, and the other has lobster. The food is also quite good. The service is very good for a Chinese Restaurant. The place may look crummy, but you can't complain. The food is cheap and delicious. What more can you ask for?
I found this hole in the wall place a year and a half ago and have been coming back every so often for its food.
Four stars because it's pretty decent good food for such affordable prices.

I give them 3.5 stars. I never even knew about this place until we had a work dinner here. We ordered the mystery set dinner that's written all in Chinese. We got clams, steamed catfish (we substituted didnt feel like crab), the good soup and the free soup too, fried chicken wings, vegetables, fried fish. I thought all was very good, some of my coworkers complained it was a bit salty. I've had over salted disgusting food before and it didn't taste like that to me. My favorite was fried chicken wings, clams in black bean sauce and fried fish. They sure can make good fried food!
The only bad thing about this place is that the bathroom doesn't feel too clean, but it's way better than most Chinatown joints across the world.

I tried to escape my company but after a month hiatus they talked me into returning.  I'm glad I did because my coworkers welcomed me back with a lunch at Kam Lok, by far the best Chinese food I've ever had.

Came here prior to starting a bar crawl with some friends, we chose it at random because we liked the air of mystery a basement restaurant held.. well it turned out to not be very mysterious - but maybe that is a good thing when it comes to Chinese food!

Not only Yelpers but also local people recommended this place to us and it didn't disappoint me. The $18 for 3 dishes deal is fantastic. We could pick up any 3 dishes from a variety menu and it truly satisfied our craving of SF seafood. Free rice, soup and tea came along as well. I have nothing to complain and would definitely come back.

As others have pointed out, if you're looking for ambience, you're out of luck. This restaurant is in a basement. It's also the best damn Chinese food you will ever eat in a basement. The service is always fast and no-nonsense and the locals in Chinatown obviously eat here as well. The hot tea is great and I've never gone wrong ordering my two favorites; curry chicken and Mongolian beef. The portions are HUGE and for $5.50 at lunch you will be walking away full and with money still in your wallet.

My dad and I stayed in San Francisco for a week, and we were trying to find some good food at a reasonable price. We went to other restaurants before we found here, but it didn't went so well. My dad somehow picked this hole. I consider that was luck. The place doesn't look decent if you compare to all other restaurant in the states. However, I'm from hong kong, this place is acceptable to me. The food tastes excellent. The price is great! I will recommend here.

Complete hole in the wall. Prices Are dirt cheap, food is decent-good . The staff if you can call them that were mediocre at best. Basically if you want cheap good food and don't mind the waitress treating you like her first born and only daughter go.

I can't add much to what the other posters have written.  Good food at a good price. The combos for for 4 people ~38$ are a pretty good deal.  You will not walk away hungry.  It is possible to find cheaper food up on Stockton but most of those joints close real early.  Kam Lock is a real standout from the glut of other Chinese restaurants in the immediate area.  They take credit cards too....
This is one of the best HOLE IN THE WALL joints in SF! (for chinese)

After the CNY parade we stopped in here (a little hidden underground) for dinner. Busy night for them since there was a tourgroup in there too. The food was good (of what I could eat, cause I'm a vegetarian) & the service was ok, but it was very busy. Everything came out pretty fast and hot. Not sure how the price is and the bathroom was decently clean. Would come back here again with my family.

After walking around SF during Chinese New Year we stopped by this restaurant for dinner. It's not particularly big and is underground, sort of. You'll have to go down stairs and voila, the sitting area appears! We ate family style so I got to try a lot of things, a lot of which I can't recall their names. There was Beef broccoli, a mushroom dish, fried flounder and a few others. Everything was really good and the vegetables were fresh. For Chinese food it was very flavorful and surprisingly inexpensive.

You have to walk down the stairs to get to the restaurant. Solid family style dinners and good food. It's pretty clean even though it's on the basement level. We used to come here often for dinner when we lived nearby.
We had beef and broccoli, Mongolian beef (bomb), pepper fried  fish, chow mein, and some veggie dish with lots of mushrooms.
Best hole-in-the-wall noodle soups, congee, and crispy roast pork!

Kam Lok is a hole in the basement chinese restaurant located right across from yucky Sam Woo except that it is 10x better. Just order the salt and pepper crab ($17) and Singapore rice noodle ($7) and your taste buds and wallet will thank you. Another big star for taking credit cards and waving good bye thank you when we left.  I will be back for more!
Nothing special, but not two stars either.
After our club meetings, we often get together and come here.....

Ordered via seamless for dinner and I was pleasantly surprised. Their spring rolls (summer rolls) with shrimp was so incredibly fresh and delicious that I was inspired to go back home that night, learn how to make spring rolls from my Vietnamese mother, and then eat more spring rolls that same night. I cannot say I enjoyed the Chicken Satay at all (very dry and zero flavor). Despite only taking a bite of that chicken and throwing away the rest, I would come back only for the spring rolls.
Food was delicious. Totally made up for the bad service. Price was great for the portion sizes.

I've only ordered delivery from this restaurant on Seamless Web. I got the spring rolls with prawns and the five spice chicken with vermicelli noodle. The spring rolls were very overpriced and had very little shrimp. The five spice chicken with noodle was very good though. Chicken was tender and had good flavor.

Ordered here via Seamless for lunch, and the food was pretty good! Pricey for what it was though-- I ordered honey pork with garlic noodles (kinda sad there was no option to get white rice instead), and my friend ordered garlic fish with garlic noodles, and our total was $25 before tip. Our quoted arrival time was 45-60 minutes, and it came right on the dot at 45 minutes. The food wasn't as warm as it could have been, but hey, it's delivery.

I don't know why reviews are bad for this place?!  We always order for delivery at work &  food is freshly prepared, & delicious!  Now for the first time, I finally get to dine in with my fam & everything we ordered on the menu (surprisingly had a great choice of both Vietnamese & Thai cuisine) were all scrumptious! Come & try for yourself!

Another horrible delivery experience similar to those below.  Decided to order through Seemless.  The delivery window was from 30-45 minutes stated by A Taste of Vietnam Noodle Bar & Gril.  Placed the order and waited and waited and waited and waited some more.  I gave them a ring after an hour and a half.  I received an abrupt "Oh the delivery guy just left.  He'll be there in 15 minutes."  Nope.  Another 35 minutes later we receive our food.  It took us just about TWO HOURS to receive our delivery.

Ordered from seamless and the food came late, and not worth the wait. The spring rolls were tiny and greasy and the 5 spice chicken was more skin than I could handle. I'm not giving it 1 star, as it was passable. Won't be ordering again though.
i seriously don't know what the other reviews are about.
This place is appropriately named.  While it kinda tastes like the Vietnamese food I know and love, something's a bit off.

Ordered in again. Not great this time around. Food tasted like it was sitting around for a bit and the steam effected it. The noodles from my honey pork tasted off. The honey pork was good but a bit tough. The vegetarian rolls weren't crunchy but a little soggy. Disappointing since the first time was so good.
Quite good fast delivery in the middle of the day (3PM) via seemless.
The food tastes like Thai food.  King of Thai is cheaper and better even without the 20% off coupon from seemless.

Kan's chinese restaurant in san francisco chinatown is such a bad restaurant. There is a lady holding a signed that their  dim sum is 2.95 to 3.00 a plate, i said its reasonable let's try it. so we order three kinds of dim sum. the calamari was ok and shrimp dumpling super bad  and the chinese chicken wings was so dry and no seasoning at all just salted and deep fried. so i decided to order the dinner menu. i order a 1/2 a duck for 21.00 and chow fun for 15.95 and a vegetable fried rice. 10.95 .the duck was cut in small pieces and the thigh of the duck was missing and all there is was the ribs of the duck and it taste like blood. the chow fun is okey and the rice is just like plain rice no aroma of fried rice. so we did not complain about the yacki food but when the bill come to me it was 98.oo dollar for two person which i thought the dim sum is 2.95 to 3.00 a plate but i notice that the tips was 11.50 but i was so upset about the tips that i did not even think of the price of the food but when i got back home in colorado i keep thinking why i paid 78.00 for the food that i did not even eat.  RED FLAG  avoid this restaurant it will ruin your vacation.

Dim Sum was not dim sum... Definitely have experienced better. Huge red flag when they have to try to usher you in from the street. Shoulda known. You can get better Chinese food at Panda Express. Everything was too salty...
Overly salty, greasy fried dimsum. The added sugar put it over the top in terms of being unpalatable. I won't be returning.
Haven't been here in a few years and I was around the neighborhood so I decided to grab a bite to eat.
Great service. Nice atmosphere. Dim sum was very good and reasonable priced. Shared the wonton soup. Very tasty!

ITS ALLL true I am a host for couch surfers and I never allow anyone to go here!! its overpriced everything is 14.96 they never give you complimentary tea and they always trying to get you to buy more food. . .  travel tip 101 #- if you go to a restaurant and they don't have a lot of people..  . . LEAVEEEE

Love the dimsum! The restaurant is clean and nice inside, in contrast to the outside Chinatown. Food selection is great, all delicious! My boys loved all dimsum I ordered. The people are friendly as well. I am glad we went upstairs when the lady downstairs offered to dine in here.

Listen to the other one star reviews!! $14 for a plate of chow mein I could get in a mall for $6. Rip off place. I was still hungry when I left. There was no music playing in the restaurant either which provided a weird atmosphere. Just do yourself a favor and don't go here.

Watch out! This place is a fraud! They try to catch you on the street with "best food, cheap" and afterwards you get tremendously bad food for unreasonable prices. We had appetizers, moo-shoo, fried rice and roast duck, all frozen and microwaved with no taste and strange textures. The food came out in minutes, very unusual for such kind of food. We complained about the bad food and asked for the manager. They also tried to rip us off with including the tip on the check (we had no big party). Also they rip you off with beverages. 4 dollar for a coke with no refills.

Avoid this place! I had the worst restaurant experience EVER at Kan's! It was so bad that I had to write a yelp review months after my experience. We felt scammed and it was traumatizing. I'm original from the SF Bay Area and have had plenty of great Chinese food in the area. I was visiting town and came to Chinatown with my mom and girlfriend. We really wanted some dim sum and were originally going to a different restaurant that we tried in the past, but they were closed.
The pork dumplings,shrimp dumplings,and Spicy Thai Noodles with Chicken and Shrimp at Kan's Restaurant are just delicious. Don't leave San Francisco without eating here first!

I have had some of the best chinese food living in NYC for a good portion of my life. When I moved to California, KAN's was my go-to chinese restaurant in the San Francisco area. Yes, be careful with the over pricing of the dim-sum, but the FOOD was AMAZING!! Portions were big and sharing was perfect. Don't expect 5 star service the workers are a little rude but the food and experience was perfect !! Nice views so get a window seat if you can!

Don't go here.  Terrible Chinese food. Worst I've ever had.   The hot and sour soup lacked flavor, the spring rolls were horribly greasy, and house fried rice and chicken with mixed vegetable were mediocre.  Had plenty of these dishes in the past so know good from bad!  There's a reason they have such a low rating!

STAY AWAY!!!!!!!!!!!  In our recent trip to San Francisco we visited Chinatown and naturally we were in the mood for some Chinese food. Little did we know that this place was going to be such a nightmare!! We had not read up on Yelp reviews of this place because we pretty much just ran into this place as we were walking around and were really hungry. First of all when we arrived upstairs into the restaurant it was completely empty - not a sole. Should of been our first clue. The lady stood there already ready to take our order for drinks and food. So we felt pretty pressured. Little did we know that each plate had a price tag of $15+ per plate. In order not to be rude and just leave we decided to order 3 plates....our bill for that plus 5 drinks came out to $62.40 PLUS 15% TIP!!!!!!!! Are they nuts?!?!?!?! We were 5 (3 of which we children)... My husband tried to ask the lady why we were being charged a gratuity % if we were only a party of 5 and she said that we at least weren't being charged 18% as they usually do. Food was bad, service was horrible and their prices are OUTRAGEOUS!!!!!!! How they remain open is a total mystery!!!!!!
there dim sum are horrible, thats why no customer there during lunch time on sunday!!!!!!
Remind me to look at the yelp reviews before eating somewhere. The place was beat down and I've had better Chinese in Lodi.
TERRIBLE FOOD AND SERVICE!

Of all the places I review on Yelp, I admit that I did not check this place out before walking in. In fact, I should have recognized some of the signs immediately but walking for hours and just hungry for some Chinese food, I went in blindly. First off, there's a woman in front of the street entrance (I say street entrance because you have to walk up a flight of stairs to get to the main restaurant door). This woman is on the street trying to get customers through the door and I understand this as SF Chinatown is a tourist location, there's a lot of Chinese restaurants and you gotta do what you gotta do to get customers; it's business.
HECK NO. Stay FAR AWAY!
Food was tasty! Seems like a nice quite locals place. Almost hidden if you don't see the door way with the stairs.

If zero stars were possible that is what they would get. Everything is pre-cooked no to order. Cold dim sum was brought to our table the minute we say down without asking us what we wanted to drink. After eating whatever bland food we could we left. Within 10 minutes both my wife's and I stomachs were in knots. don't waste your time or money. Listen to the previous yelpers. They were right!

We tried this restaurant during lunch after a nice walk around Chinatown. We saw the pictures and the lady on the bottom of the stairs gave us a flyer that says dim sums are cheap. So we got up and ate, food was just OK. Second time we tried it again and brought a friend with us, we paid our bill in cash and just gave them a few cash for a tip. We were about to leave when the waitress came rushing to us and demanded some more tips!!!! WTH?!?!?!? I did not gave them additional but our friend gave them additional tip cause she did not know that she didn't have to give in to the waitresses's demand. How rude of them to do that!. We will not be eating there again and would not recommend it to our friends. I guess only in Chinatown Chinese restaurant they demand what tip you've to give to them for this happened to us twice on a different restaurant. Bad service, not so good food, rude waitress. If there's a no star rating I would give it to this restaurant.

Food was very average. It didn't taste bad but wasn't very good either. It was pretty empty when we visited during lunch. Its a really traditional chinese restaurant and we paid about 12 per person which was alright.

The lady server was not nice. We were only customer in the restaurant and she was rushing for us to take the order. The food was not that good. I try my best behavior with her but she sounded very rude. She finally became nice when she was about to drop the check. We were 3 person and she added a gratuity. I was wow seriously!! If the service was good, i didn't mind but look at her guts. The place looks fancy but people are not nice.

food is good and the service was great BUT NOT HAPPY....i was under the impression that is was getting a lunch special for 9.99 which suppose to include dim sum.. well when i got my bill it was about $22.00.. i asked about the dim  sum which was 9.99 also plus tax they said it was a mis understanding they meany dim sum is extra charge..grrrrrrr i was about to blow up but because the service was good i decided to let it go.... i may not come back because i was ripped off

Horrible experience. We were rushed to order. We had just sat down and three diff ppl asked us if we were ready to order in less than a minute. When we asked about the menu, the waitress very nastily asked us if we know how to read. We ordered an appetizer, an entree each and shared pork fried rice. I ordered a glass of plum wine and my hubby ordered a bottle of beer. We were still eating and we were continuously asked if we were done and if we wanted to order anything else. I think throughout the whole dinner, we were interrupted about 10 times if we were finished eating, or if we wanted to order more food. They even took away my glass of water and then returned it when they realized I wanted more water! Once we finished eating, we were rushed out bc we didn't want dessert.  The waitress asked us if we were ready to leave!!!!!! The food was pretty good, but the service was horrible...and the price was waay to expensive.

I'm not really sure why this has such bad reviews.  Was it that much better than standard Chinese food? Probably not, but the decor is nice, service was good, and there were some different things on the menu.  I would give it a go if you are passing by.
The place is visually appealing. Service was really bad. Food was really bland, lacking seasoning. Chicken was over cooked. Shrimp fried rice looked awful. Most of the vegetables looked canned.

Ugh!  Awful dimsum with a LOTof MSG. Tiny selection too. I should have known better. "This is Chinatown?  How bad could it be?"  Nevertheless, restaurants in Chinatown where they have to have someone outside with the full time job of pulling in customers are usually pretty bad.  My mistake was in thinking...

Dim sum here was awful. They didn't even have chili oil for the soy sauce. What dim sum place doesn't have chili oil? My sister in law was so incredibly disappointed that this ruined the whole experience for her. Also, for the very little amount of food we got here, they were way overpriced! It cost $95 for basically eating an appetizer amount of food!

Against my better judgement, I decided to enter this establishment which has 2 yelp stars overall. The Yelp rating were wrong! 2 Yelp stars was too generous. The service was horrendous, the food was horrible (I generally like good chinese food), and they had the nerve to add the tip into the bill for a 4-person party.  Thank goodness this not my hometown.  This place deserves recognition in Gordon Ramsey's "Kitchen Nightmares."

We had a fast errand in Chinatown, found a one hour parking meter, and decided to stretch it into a fast lunch. With limited time, we took a chance. Once up the stairs and inside,  I remembered this place as I had been here years ago, and it was mediocre. But we didn't have time to turn around find another lunch place and get back to the meter. The waiters look sharp in their bow ties and sour attitudes. The ceilings are tall, as from another era.The service was so bad that when my wife's dish was served more than ten minutes before mine, I said nothing.  Afterwards, she mentioned her hands seemed to swell from the food. Was there MSG in it? I forgot they still serve that in some Chinese restaurants. That was our mistake. We should never have ordered food there.

Overpriced. A typical family dinner will have you paying in excess of $100 here and honestly, it isn't worth it.  Noodles and fried rice were so-so and the dim sum was merely average. Server was attentive and kept our drinks fresh and plates cleared. Completely shocked when we received our bill... We also didn't appreciate our server adding an additional 15% gratuity to our bill for our party of 5, three of which were small children. Please, spare yourself the annoyance and find a better place to eat. I'll never return to this place.
The food at Kan's restaurant was not that good, and the service was horrible! Worse my cousin and I totally got scammed at this place.

Well, after more than half a wonderful day in Chinatown we decided to stop and eat.. The lady on the street lures you in with her cheap price menu and points to upstairs. After walking upstairs I got an uneasy feeling that this place may be out of our price range. They try to exude a first class restaurant.
go elsewhere!!! beware of the woman yelling at the entry, she tricked us into going in!!
Loved their service, dim sum (vegetarian) was decent. Tea was yummy (made w/ loose tea).

We got to Chinatown around 5 and found parking. My kids were so hungry and they didn't want to walk around. The lady downstairs leer us in. We ordered half a Peking duck, fried rice, walnut shrimp, gai lan, and potsticker. The food was mediocre, but it was too expensive for what we got. They added own tips for 4 people. Service was ok cause there were only 2 tables occupied. Never coming back

So we stopped here for a little bite because it was still too soon for dinner.  There is always a lady with menus at the bottom of the stairs trying to bring in some customers.  They had sushi so we thought a roll would be enough to get us by.
Great food if you want to take a break from all the city walking.
Pearl CIty is one place you can't forget after eating here but do. thus you repeat the same mistake again years later.

This was sadly my second dim sum experience ever (the first was visiting a family friend in SF). Thankfully I had my first experience to know that dim sum has potential to be superb. My subsequent experiences elsewhere have confirmed this case, and that good dim sum can easily be had on a budget.

This was the worst restaurant experience I have had in a long time. We went looking for dim sum and found this place still open. The dim sum menu is small and is not a full dim sum experience. It took 10 minutes for us to be seated in the nearly empty restaurant. We should have taken this as a sign and hightailed it out of there. The server was incredibly rude. She largely ignored us throughout the meal and never refilled our drinks. It took a long time to finally get our food, and it came 15 minutes apart. The server seemed to resent us for eating at her restaurant. The food was serviceable, but the wait staff was atrocious. With all of the other options in this area you should avoid this mess. In the future I'll just pick up some dim sum from a to go spot.
Pearl City is CLOSED.... it's now Peninsula Seafood Restaurant. Gone are the women wait staff replaced by men who swear  alot
Decor = hellllo, 80's...cheap tables, barely white everything. Lots of stainless steel plates/containers.

Don't come to this restaurant. The service is ridiculously poor~~After we finished eating and leaving, we saw a sticker outside that we could get a stamp for parking. Then the woman asked so madly " Did you eat in this restaurant? " We were like "Yea....we just went out and saw the sticker" She gave us a face for that. My cousin was next to my boyfriend and asked for the stamp too. She said " only stamp 1 for 1 table!!!" We said we had two large tables. She still didn't want to stamp it. My boyfriend is a really easy-going person but what he said was that restaurant was just asking the customers not to come again.
I am a bit surprised by some of these reviews, I love this place. It is my favorite dim sum restaurant anytime I am in San Francsico.

Made the mistake of coming here after attempting to go to Yee's. What attracted me to the place was the location and the family special. $11.95 a person for what seem to be a good deal. The place was on Jackson Street which is known for locals to hang out on.
Lukewarm, sub-par dim sum? Check.

It's been a long time since I've gone for dim sum at a genuine sit down restaurant. My aunt took us here and then I remember we did used to come here more often. I could not remember if I liked the food then but I thought the food was pretty good today.

Dim sum was great here!!!!  They even had that  white, triangular, sticky, sweet cake that I love so much!!!!  It's a smallish place without the traditional carts of food I'm used to seeing, but it was still good.  Service was OK with the food coming around, but Heaven forbid you actually ask for something specific, like a spoon, or water.  I don't think they understand English so well, but I think it could be because the clientele that comes in is local, and THEY speak mostly Chinese.  I think there could be something to another review I've read that unless you speak Chinese, you're SOL with regards to service.

The place was OK, the service was OK. No problems, no issues, nothing was terrible.  The problem, the reason for just two little stars - there really is some GREAT Dim Sum around San Francisco. I'm just not going to settle in and call Pearl City "my" Dim Sum place, my pick. I'll keep searching and exploring. So, give it a go but don't expect to be blown away.
This place was ok. I would only go back for one thing, LEMON CHICKEN. I thought it tasted great. Dim sum was alright, nothing special, the prawns in lobster sauce was also good.

3.5 stars - Chinatowan appears to be the only happening place on Christmas.  Cold, raining and windy but there are still people everywhere...  Long lines at the more popular dim sum places.  Not wanting to wait, we ended up here since there were tables available.

I used to love this place! I'd come here with my family all the time but seriously this place has gone way down hill! First was the dim sum. It used to be my favorite place in all of sf, but now it's just cold and soggy and simply not presentable. Next was the carpet....does no one bother to clean it now a days? Dirty and sticky. Gross.

i've gone here a couple of times with my parents when we're in the city. the food is alright. not the greatest but not the worst. service is fast... but the dim sum doesn't have much variety. my mom ordered some lobster noodle dish was so bland too.... so i would just stick to the dim sum if you're looking for taste.

Biggggg disappointment. I've been here a couple times before and didn't realize how much this place sucks until now. The food sucks and if you dare tell me its good here then you should have your review license revoked!

I can understand the bad reviews... this is not one of them!  Yes, the service is horrid.  But the dim sum is consistently good IF you go there during lunch.  If you get there after 1:30, you get what's leftover from the lunch crowd... cold, soggy, not so very fresh.  If you go on weekends (which we do often as well), you order off the menu and of course, it's all freshly cooked and delicious!  Awesome price, consistently delicious food (at the right time of day).  Again, yes, the service is horrid... I think because they know us by now, they're better than non attentive.  :)  We still have to ask 3 times for forks and water, but it's ok, it's all worth it.
This place is only good for dimsum. I don't like anything else.

The food here is not the worst but I have ate better elsewhere. Nothing really stands out when you eating and don't expect world class service. I asked for water and it took 3 times of asking or waiter before actually getting my water. That's just crazy! I also noticed that this place does I've special treatment if you are non-asian. I guess the workers are trying to get the stereotype of better tip from foreign customers?  Overall this experience was not the greatest. So sad to see this place go downhill so fast....
ugh...GROSSIE JOSIE!
BEWARE DO NOT COME HERE!

I totally agree with all the other Yelp reviews.  The restaurant service is by far the WORST.  The wait staffs were rude even when we are able to speak Chinese.  They are not the typically dim sum place with pushing carts.... so you can ended up waiting 15 mins in between each dishes.

I'm in search of a good solid dim sum restaurant.  I decided to try Pearl City after peering into the window and seeing a good number of Chinese people dining.  I'm only half Chinese and can't speak conversationally unless ordering food, which for this restaurant was perfect.  They didn't hand us menus, nor order cards and there aren't any push carts but what they do have is a waitress that comes around with a little tray which has 2 or 3 different offerrings ands she asks you if you want any.  If she doesn't have you like right way just ask and they will bring it to your table.  Trouble is you would need to know in Chinese what food items you are seeking.  Definetly not for Dim Sum novices or for those traveling with people who have never been to dim sum.  Food quality is ok, I have had better in SF Chinatwon.

I don't get all the negative reviews of this place. We've been coming here for dim sum for 10 years, both when we lived in the Bay Area and regularly since we've moved away and have never had a bad experience. Yes it's not as flashy or new as some places but the food is great. It comes fast and is plentiful. Service has always been fine for us.
This restaurant was super horrible. I came in with my cousins & sisters and they seated us. We were meeting our grandma there but the waiters didn't know.

I was on a quest for good authentic dim sum in Chinatown, and I would not let up!! The place I found on yelp that sounded delicious wasn't a sit-down place, so with the recommendation from a local bookstore owner, we came to Pearl City.

Possibly one of the worst experiences I've ever had in a Chinese restaurant in the 31 years I've lived in San Francisco.  Not to say that the food was bad....cause it wasn't . It was HORRIBLE!  In Chinatown you expect there to be a language barrier in the really good restaurants.  Sometimes mis-communication to lead to trying some tasty new dishes, if you're adventurous.  I am, and the food was still crappy.

Do you enjoy eating in a cave and paying a little more for a little less?  This is the place for you!  The wait staff are quite friendly though... you may learn some Chinese - and see what you get there by looking at my video.
oh how the mighty have fallen!

I thought I would never eat in Chinatown again. I grew up eating on Jackson Street restaurants 2-3 times a month. Old school Cantonese from the 60's just doesn't exist anymore. Believe me, I've been searching. Those cooks are long gone, just like the stainless steel elevated dishes the food was served in. There are only two types of people who eat in Chinatown... locals without cars, and tourists.

ok, this place is not as good as New York's dim sum by far.  However, my bf and I wanted to look for a dim sum restaurant for breakfast (and why was it so hard to find one in chinatown? most dim sum places were more like the "To-Go" types) and we have tried those to-go ones and their dim sum were COLD and tasted nasty.

i went there in a group of five once, and also once with a group of nine. both times, we were seated quickly, and the service was fast and courteous. the food is a solid a-/b+ and when offered at c- prices, i feel like its a win. i like the red bean sesame balls and the steamed bbq pork buns and shrimp dumplings, and also these deep fried red bean bun things that i couldnt get the name of. my friends all really liked the scallion buns and those little bundles with chicken and rice inside. its really easy and dependably pretty good, so if i need to sit at a table, this is my go-to place. if not, there is a take-out only place at 750 jackson that's slightly better though theyre not dependable.
Want great dimsum in Chinatown? Go someplace where the waitstaff speak little English and the patrons are predominantly Cantonese.

"This is your total. This is the cash. These are your two credit cards. This is the leftover amount for the cards. Yes?? NO!!!" She slams her hand on the table and waves her arms in the air, because through the troubles our group had with the whole lost in translation thing, that was the only way she could think to explain to us about a credit card minimum. I know, I know it isn't her fault that we don't speak her language, but slamming your hands on the table? And this was after we gave the cash and our credit cards, and I swear half of the restaurant's staff had to meet together to discuss us and our evil table supposedly, because they kept glaring at us after we tried paying them!
If it weren't such a depressing experience the experience would almost be comical.  I've had better service in the Soviet Union for Christ's sake!!!!!!!!!!!!
Started off well...decent price..we were craving for Crabs! We walked in, the place was empty, perhaps 1/4 filled so we thought, hey...quick n easy!
So so dim sum in the heart of china town. Go else where, there are a lot better places than this.
I will make this simple...what Shelley B said is true.  I was there at the table with her.
As mentioned by Geoff G. (
Oh my god! Worst restaurant at Chinatown ever. Better save yourself a pleasant day by going somewhere else. Rude service for horrible food.

Terrific, authentic place for (menu-based, not cart) dim sum (ask for the dim sum menu).  Honey walnut chicken was super flavorful and tender-plump.  BBQ steamed pork buns a bit small but served hot and delicious.  All the steamed buns and potstickers were incredibly flavorful and fresh. Quick service.  Loved it.

I came here for late night food close to closing time. I I got the Bow Hon special, which included pork mushrooms and seafood dumplings.  Service was fairly fast, the price was okay, and the food was super middle of the road. Not great, not terrible.

When my husband and were looking for someplace to eat in Chinatown, we were directed to the restaurants down Jackson St. While we were walking to Jackson St., a lady literally followed us 3 blocks telling us to go to her restaurant and how it's so good and a whole bunch of other broken english. It was quite annoying! So we brushed her off and went down Jackson and perused the menus of several restaurants. My husband really wanted to try claypot dishes so we went into one place to put our name down on a list. The list was too long and it was getting crowded in the waiting area so we decided to just head away from Jackson St. and look for other places. Problem was that we were there quite late and there weren't that many places anymore. So after awhile, we settled on Bow Hon and I'm glad we did!
Average Chinese food

Absolutely HATED their dim sum. For the quality they had, they were ridiculously priced. For 3 pieces of any dim sum, it was $2.65! Didn't order anything from their actually dish menu, but it looked over priced as well. The dim sum lacked seasoning. The rice paper they used to steam was overcooked and too soft, it was like eating a soggy fruit roll up. Do no recommend coming here for their dim sum.
Really hospitable place with really good food. Roast duck was a treat! Other good stuff we ordered. .scallop and prawn dim sum and singapore noodles. All round great experience !

Bow Hon was definitely a pleasant surprise!  Don't be fooled by the outside of the restaurant.  We looked at the menu and saw the wonderful dishes and knew this was the place.  Inside - clean and smelling so appetizing!  We had the dinner for 3 which was very reasonably priced for SF.  I have to say, the spring rolls were the best I've had in a long time.  The mushroom chicken chow mien, beef broccoli and pork fried rice were delicious...  wash it down with ice cold Tsingtao - even better!!!  I think Bow Hon restaurant is a diamond in the rough.

Place is OKAY!!! Nothing special!! Food is authentic but that's it. If you need to go to the bathroom, be prepared to walk up 3 flights of stairs because the bathroom is upstairs!!! On a side note, there's no toilet or bathroom tissue in there!!!

This place was our last resort-considering everywhere else was closed for the night. Walked in and was seated right away. My friends and I ordered the BBQ pork/roast duck platter ( mainly all fat), congee( so bland), fried rice (had better) and steamed bok choy. Besides the horrible food, everything else went downhill. The chopsticks were sticky, and our cups were dirty. When my friend requested for a new one, our waiter stood there rolling his eyes at us. I didn't even bother asking him for a new pair of chopsticks- I just wiped it off with some tea and napkin. When our food arrived- waiter made no eye contact- just placed the food on the table and walked away. Then when our bill arrived- we were charged little over 20% for gratitude. Seriously? For party of 3!!? Thanks for telling us ahead of time!!! Won't ever go back.
Came here several times for their clay pot rice, and every single time I left with a happy tummy.  So order the right dish...clay pot rice.
Ordered take-out: sweet and sour pork:

Just because it's a Chinese restaurant situated on Grant Ave does not mean that it will cater to every tourist's need for chow mein and egg rolls.  Bow Hon has been around since the 80s (maybe even longer?).  My mom used to go here back in her college days.  They've specialized in claypot rice for years and it's such a good deal!  One giant claypot for 2 (can easily feed 3) also includes lao huo tang (a healthy soup of the day which is usually comprised of veggies, Chinese herbs, and chicken/pork/beef) and a plate of veggies.  My favorite claypots are the chicken (or frog if it's available) and mushroom and the ones made with preserved Chinese sausages, smoked pork, and smoked duck.  At the end of the meal, they pour in a ginger soup to mix with the burnt rice at the bottom of the claypot which makes for a great end-of-the-meal treat.
Not terrible...but definitely not good.  The food looked and sounded good, so we figured we'd give it a chance despite its tourist trap potential.  We chose poorly.
Had the steam chicken, spare ribs with Chinese broccoli , pan fried noodles , thought it was OK, nothing special

Wandering through SF Chinatown can be pretty daunting. Stretching 8 blocks long and 3 blocks wide, my friends and I were in awe of everything around us. It sure got us tired and hungry quick. We, then, had a difficult task of choosing from the endless number of restaurants. Since we could not collectively agree, we chose the restaurant that was right in front of us. What a f*cking mistake... haha
Really good food and at a good price.

I honestly do not understand people who come to an authentic Chinese place that specializes in clay pot food, order something like egg rolls or sweet and sour chicken, and leave unhappy. I have 5 words for you. Go. To. Chinese. Buffet. Seriously. You will get the right stuff at the right price. Trying to get Chinese American food here is a grave mistake and a waste of your money. And yes, dim sum portions are small. And expensive if you get them not in a dedicated dim sum restaurant.

Clay pot rice takes 15-20mins in the kitchen so I skipped it in lieu of faster stuff.  Ordered the steamed minced pork with egg yolk......TO DIE FOR!!  It is so super delicious with rice, the taste will totally take you down memory lane to your little old chinese grandma's kitchen.  Steamed dim sum dishes are also excellent.

As awful as Chinese food can be. I ordered Hong Kong iced tea or something and a lady brought it to the front door. It wasn't even prepared on site. Is that legal? Our server had a really bad cold and kept wiping her nose with the back of her hand. I never once saw her wash her hands. Our food arrived and the only word to describe the 5 dishes is oily. We could barely eat it. Just awful. We paid the exorbitant bill and limped out of the place smacking ourselves for not knowing better. Later that night I experienced chills, stomach cramps and malaise. We ended up missing a live show we had tickets for because I couldn't make it off the sofa. This place robbed me twice. Never again.
CLAY POT RICE!!!
Hands-down the WORST CHINESE RESTAURANT IN CHINATOWN!!!

A golden standard of SF's Chinatown for clay-pot cooking. The atmosphere could be better but it's pretty typical of no-frills Chinese--especially Cantonese--places in Chinatown and has been around for decades. I don't think people should judge Bow Hon on atmosphere because it's simply not the type of place you come for a posh atmosphere: if you want that, go to Tommy Toy's.

Great little gem in Chinatown, went here during Thanksgiving and went to multiple places before settling to eat dinner here.  The frog legs clay pot is the main dish here.  The frogs were fresh and not frozen, the meat literally was like fish, super soft melt off the bone meat.  The waitress gave us a clean lettuce dish for free, which was great to add the greens into our dinner as well.  Sorry didn't update this earlier but definitely will come back to visit again.
The price is way too steep for what they serve.
lotus root with veggies: it was decent.

Came here because a friend of a friend was already inside. The place is fairly small. I looked at the menu and noticed the prices were kind of high for Chinatown, but still ordered a few plates. Each plate were tiny, about the size of a standard serving plate. The cheapest plates were already $9.

Got totally ripped off.  $6 for a few bites of rice noodle (the cheapest item in the world) and veggie dumplings (come on.. there's not even meat in here!).  I could get more food at the overpriced dim sum restaurant City View. see photo ~

This place was AWFUL. The service was horrendous. It took us forever. Also, the beef was overcooked (it seemed to have been cooked a few days earlier, and just reheated every day) and the pork was RAW we discovered after diting into what seemed a fully cooked piece. Upon further inspection, almost every piece we had was almost completely raw. DO NOT go here. I had Sweet and Sour Pork of some kind, and also Mongolian Beef.
I got the preserved duck clay pot rice. It's very good and comes with meat and veggie. Portion is good for two people or one with super big appetite.

I went here with friends and their one-year-old daughter. I had the pineapple sweet and sour chicken and my friends had the chicken and snap peas and the chicken and broccoli. We also ordered the sweet egg custard.

TERRIBLE! The service was awful. After sitting for 30+ minutes with absolutely NOTHING to eat in front of me (all I ordered was steamed rice, not a difficult order) while my husband finished his fried squid, we asked for his Mongolian beef and my rice to go. It took saying "excuse me" about five times before our waiter acknowledged us and he ran off without even letting my husband get the words "can we get our food to go please" out of his mouth. 10 minutes later he brought our bag. We got back to our hotel room and though they had given us napkins and forks, they gave us no soy sauce.
This is family dining but not any family you really want to eat at...  This is the aunt in your family who "can't" cook and is husbandless.

I went here a while ago (...okay, three years ago) and they were just horrible. The hostess sat us away from everyone else--I felt like it was a racial thing because we were the only non-chinese people in the restaurant. The food took forever to reach our table (and it wasn't even that good). When we walked up to pay, the hostess said that we didn't leave tip and we were supposed to. Um...we don't have to do shit; especially if the service and food was horrible.

I love this place for it's clay pot rice.  I see some of the reviewers gave a lower rating because they ordered food like beef chow fun or fried tofu, but when you walk into a restaurant in Chinatown, you really need to know what to order depending on the restaurant.  The clay pot rice is the best in the Bay Area.  I would suggest anything with Chinese sausage or bacon.  Their taste goes right into the rice and really brings out its flavor.  Each clay pot comes with a dish of veggie, which I think is enough for a meal, since your main dish should be the clay pot rice anyways.  After the meal, they will make a delicious claypot rice soup for free.

We came in because it was half busy for a Monday which is a good sign. Ywife liked the food, some of which we she hadn't had since hong kong. She thought it was above avg though more costly than it should. I thought it was quite fine considering.
Bottom Line.

What was once a family-owned, traditional restaurant has certainly changed. For the high prices, the portions have been considerably reduced. Bow Hon appeals both to tourists unfamiliar with Cantonese cuisine as well as the locals who know how to order. Of all their specialties (dim sum being mostly a tourist gimmick), their clay pot rice is absolutely phenomenal for the winter time. The portion, while still small, is quite flavorful (the mushroom, chicken, and chinese sausage as my favorite), and it comes with a plate of veggies. The added bonus is the burnt rice soup that is added afterwards, which is flavor to be experienced for oneself. I definitely do not think the quality has stood the test of time, but Bow Hon is worth visiting if you're in Chinatown.

Terrible service. The waitress disappeared half way through the meal & never returned. The bathroom and kitchen was filthy. After finishing a pretty pricey meal that consisted of bad wonton noodle soup, chicken wings, and mediocre dumplings I had a COCKROACH walk across the wall next to me. DISGUSTING! I shared the stomach-turning news with an employee that I had to FLAG down, and she kinda just shrugged her shoulders about it. Eat here at your own risk! Needless to say, I had quite a few strong cocktails to disinfect and settle my stomach.
My go to spot in SF for dry fried wings and scalloped fried rice.
'Chinatown' Good for tourist...Good for locals.

Once upon a time, I used to come here at least once every month or so with my family after I finished Chinese school on Saturdays.  However, I have not been there in over ten years.  Anyway, my boyfriend and I decided to go to Chinatown before watching the July 4th fireworks at the Pier.  As we were walking by Capitol Kim Tar, I noticed that they had all you can eat hot pot for $13.99.

For Chinatown, I feel like Capitol Kim Tar is a tad pricey for noodle soups. However, they're good at what they do and I have yet to find a better Curry Chicken Noodle Soup. It's delicious, spicy, and the chicken is boneless thigh meat. YUM. Whenever I have that Curry Chicken Noodle Soup craving, I know I can't go elsewhere. The sinus-clearing curry is soupy but the perfect consistency. The only problem I have is, that over $7 for a bowl of noodles is ridonkulous especially in Chinatown, but it sure hits the spot, and seriously, it's hard to find a place that does it right.
It has been a very long time that, I have not eaten at Capitol Kim Tar restaurant until on a very beautiful sunny monday in the San Francisco Chinatown Area...
No complaints here.

They used to be pretty good or maybe they tasted good to me as a kid.  As an adult, I came back last Friday and it tasted nasty to me.  They advertise super big outside w/ chinese characters saying that they sell traditional Chiu Chow noodles (noodles like Hai Ky on ellis) but they do not.  I've not tasted anything less close to that type of noodles.  They also sell chinese food as well like chow fun and fried rice.  They may have many selections, and the pictures may look really good, but in reality, it does not meet any of the promises they make.  I will not come back again.
Haven't eaten here for a long time.  The review is for their homemade fish ball and fish cake that they sell at $8/pound.

they use to make a really good (4 star) seafood (wet) chow fun.   Now it's more a 2 star quality seafood chow fun.  They use to make this wonderful dish with mushrooms, broccoli, fishcake, shrimp, and crab.  Now it's made with some cheap carrots.  Yuck!
This restaurant was recommended by a local.

I used to go to this place when I was a kid and it was called the Golden Dragon.  Since then it's not as great.  My wife found a hair in one of her pork buns and the fried rice came after the check.  The service was good but everything basically tasted the same.  It seemed like a reasonable price for five people.  It's super loud you can't hear yourself talk.  Too many tables too close together.  I think next time we are in china town buying blow guns and ninja stars we'll go the Cathay house.

I didn't think this place was bad at all. I'm not Chinese but I've had a fair amount of dim sum in my life, plus I was eating today with two guys who just arrived from Guangzhou and Shanghai and went to college in Hong Kong (street cred-they know Hong Kong-style dim sum).

My wife and I came across this place while visiting Chinatown. The outside looked nice so we went in to try it out. We were seated promptly right next to one of the kitchen which I thought was great since that's where the carts came out from.

The manager was fucking rediculous. I went there for breakfast today. The service was so bad. I have to wait for an hour for some of my order. What really annoyed me was that the manager tried to charge me 15 percent tips when I thought it was supposed to be 10 percent. But he stopped us and asked us for extra tips. I will never go to that place again.

By far the worst food experience in SF.   The help was very attentive but i think because they just thought we were going to get up & walk out.   Had MSG headache within 25 minutes of leaving the restaurant & honestly only ate 1/10th of what I was served.

I would NOT recommend anybody to this restaurant. WORST service ever!! Treated us like we were unwelcome to the restaurant. Walked away in the middle of ordering food.  Asked to split our check, first server gave attitude and throw the check onto the table. Second server spoke in Chinese saying" what a hassle!". Manager was sitting at the table next to us, and heard the whole thing and didn't do anything.

We came here with my father who lived in Hong Kong for a couple of years and has gone back a couple of times since then.  He knows Chinese food pretty well and claims that this place is authentic.  We went in with a group of 6 and were quickly seated.

NEVER EVER EVER! We had alarm bells going off as we were ushered inside a near empty restaurant as the rest of Chinatown was buzzing with people. The lady that seated us though was lovely so we stayed; mistake number 2 (number 1 was walking in there in the first place).

This place is actually gross.  The food is terrible and barely Chinese.  I have eaten here twice only because my grandfather made us go here.  Both times everything was subpar and not appetizing.  Do not waste your time.  Disgrace to Chinese food.  If I could give this restaurant negative stars I would.  But it requires you to give one star.
I have never been to a dim sum place like this one!

Wouldn't even give it any stars if I could. My family and I was traveling around SanFran and wanted some dim sum. This lady was giving us flyers, and it said dim sum, so we went to it. We sat down, and the waitress asked we wanted to drink, this is how it goes:

This food was disgusting.  My daughter and I had lunch there last Wednesday and it was literally unedible.  The potstickers were not cooked, the dough was raw and the pork fried rice had RAW PORK in it.  Horrible experience. Beware
Service is non existent. No serving spoons come with the entrees. Fried rice is not fried.

My husband was getting too "hangry" for us to continue walking around trying to find a restaurant I've visited in the past, so we stopped in here. It's noisy and they are really high pressure when the dim sum carts roll by. We split an order of Kun Pao, which wasn't anything special. - not anything special and I wish I had had a chance to check on my fellow "Yelpers" first!
Smile and grin at the change all around

I don't set my standards high for great customer service when I go into Chinese restaurants. I just expect good cheap food. This will be my one exception because the service here was the worst service I have ever encountered in my life. The waitress doesn't speak English very week which I have encountered a lot, but I don't mind. What pissed me off about this waitress, is that every time I tried to make an order, she would literally turn her head. It's not that she didn't hear me, she chose to not pay attention. Then we ordered food and she declined to take the order and changed our order to something else. She didn't suggest it, she just changed it without our consent.  So we had to cancel some of the items all together.

Stay far as much as u can they were nice until we sit on the chair with word "yammyyammy".no sever take care of us. Only pork dim sum was ok. Plus even they charge us 2$ for hot tea. Oh man I feel sick...

For dim sum in Chinatown, this place is definitely catered to mi changs.  There was one occasional cart that would come around and the dim sum items were very limited, it was typical Asian service and overpriced for dim sum.  Food quality was okay though, so it wasn't a complete loss.
Very good food.

Had dim sum for lunch today and it wasn't too bad. I didn't like any of the pork dumplings, they tasted kind if weird like hot dog juice?? Ghem shrimp dumplings were good. Our table didn't finish the jellyfish or BBQ pork, didn't taste fresh at all. The best things were the spring rolls and salt pepper calamari.
I don't know why this place got a low rating! This place is actually Not bad at all!!
Awsome, this place was where you wanted to go for dim sum when I lived in SF! The food was great and so was the service, things may have changed over the last 15 years.
One of the waiters was being rude because my family of four got sat at a bigger table.  The is not good.
STAY FAR FAR AWAY!

Today, we arrived early for dim sum- it was not too busy- and we were happy that we beat the brunch rush.  The dim sum was very good-- made in Cantonese style. The dim sum was hot, and I sampled almost everything. I really liked the dim sum that I ate-- but the selection was limited. All the popular plates were brought out- but that's it. Maybe we got there too early- too bad for me!?!?!?!
Tourist trap! Avoid it! Trust me the worst Chinese food I ever had! Plus over priced and service was terrible!
The owner was so stupid, it seems that he is so rude, especially to those from China Mainland. Never go to this restaurant unless you want your mood ruined by this stupid guy.
My experience seems different than those I have read.  Went with my wife for dim sum lunch, as most places were not serving dim sum on a Tuesday.  We are in town for a conference on Nob Hill.

I went on a field trip with my Chinese class to this restaurant. The food was alright, but throughout the day after eating there, I was pretty much strapped to a toilet for the rest of the trip. The food was alright in terms of taste, I expected a bit more since it is Chinatown..
This is the one of the worst Chinese restaurants in SF. I can promise this as a native Chinese.

I would have given 0 if i could. Came here with my girlfriend and this place is a tourist trap. When we came in, there was only one family eating. We ordered 3 dim sum dishes and waited over 45 minutes to get everything. At the same time more people came after us and were served their food while we were still waiting. Also saw another non-white couple come in after us and not get served. They ended up leaving. Wish we could have left too. The food wasnt good at all and we both had indigestion the next day. Stay away if youre local and not white.... They wont treat you well.

So I have to be honest, I have never had dim sum before, but have heard plenty of good things.  We decided to stop here .  The menu was a little confusing, mainly because the dim sum menu was separate from the main menu with descriptions and pricing.  After getting shrimp chow mein and pork fried rice we decided to ask our host about dim sum.  She told us two choices, the #11 and #12, were pretty popular.  We got the #11, pork dim sum.  Utterly spectacular.  The pricing of the dim sum is not on the menu, but on the green ticket which the server writes your order out.  When the dim sum cart goes by they will put a circle in the pricing line.  Four incredibly large pork dim sum for $3.30???  Yes please.  Had I understood the pricing and ordering I would have gotten one side rice dish and 100 dim sum :). Food was great either way.  If you are here and confused ask the host or the owner who was on the floor the whole time.  Also, if you want parking validated you must spend $50, but the Portsmouth Garage on Kearney is only $3/hr.
(dim sum) The food was average quality. I know I would not bring someone to this tourist trap ever again.

Pretty interesting reading the other reviews. I was there for a late lunch, 2:30PM Plenty of open seats. I had two dishes of dim sum and that was it. Carts just kept passing me without any interaction from the staff. Since I was by myself, they just kept serving the other guests with larger numbers. Bathrooms were not very clean either. There must be better places in China Town for Dim Sum.

Bummed about the bad reviews here, not sure why.  Walked in and immediately noticed we were the only Americans.  Right away knew it was a good spot.  Service is just OK but the experience is awesome.  Make sure to be looking at the menu with all the pictures to get an idea of what's coming around.  Great dim sum experience at a very cheap price.

I ordered four plates but she only brought out three, and after waiting forever, she brings out two of the wrong orders.  I told them to take it back because they weren't what I wanted.  While waiting for my orders, a cart woman comes to offer me more plates, I decline.  I've had dim sum numerous times- I know what I like and what I don't.  I came in knowing what I wanted, I ordered and they did not deliver the service I expected from any restaurant.  I left them a quarter as tip and the lady had the nerve to run up after me as my friends and I were leaving asking that I pay more tip.  Excuse me? The food was great, and that's what I paid for on the bill.  The service was horrible, so I chose to not leave a good tip.  That's how the restaurant business works.  Sorry, but I will not be coming back here.

So I have to be a little honest here....I was walking in China town and a woman runs up to me and says are you hungry?  She had a menu in her hand and of course while in ChinaTown you have to eat Chinese! I said yes and she led me to this place.  Boy o Boy did I talk to the best random lady the food was amazing!

Terrible food with no taste.  Only went because it was not crowded and we could get in without a wait.   We tried to cancel a dish when we realized how bad the food was and they wouldn't cancel even though it hasn't been made. They try and get you in very aggressively.

Decent dim sum, and unlike some of the other reviewers, we had excellent service. The hosts couldn't do enough for us, and the cart girls were very quick and helpful, getting us a couple of items from the menu. The majority of the other guests were Chinese and seemed local. We seemed to be the only tourists.
While visiting "Chi Town" My parents decided to have some DIM SUM. The decor looked much like a traditional chinese restaurant, typical meaning a bit run down, dirty and OLD.
Do not eat here!!!

Well, this is what happens when you don't check Yelp before entering a restaurant. My friend and I were looking for a cheap/good place to eat, and well, we got half of what we wanted. It was certainly cheap, but just awful.

The owner was nice. All I got from here were egg custard tart and sesame balls to go. The egg custard was not good at all. Really gooey and without true egg flavor. The sesame balls were a bit better, but nothing special.

I was looking for a dim sum place that was open past seven that serves seafood, veg, and sweet options since I do not eat meat.  The all you can eat sign lured me in and the owner kept me for about an hour.  He was cheerful and super accommodating - made separate dim sum for me so I could have my share of seafood/meatless options!  I loved the taro and lotus bao.  There was plenty of food put in front of me -including noodles and rice - and I left satisfied.  Glad I stumbled upon this place!

I disregarded the bad Yelp reviews for this place and gave it a shot. I have to say it was pretty dang good for what you're paying. $5.99 for all you can eat which includes fried rice and noodles. Sui mais we're pretty good, probably because I got them fresh. The egg rolls could use a little more heat. The fried rice had no flavor, but not to worry because there was plenty of soy sauce, chili sauce, vinegar and white pepper available.

Dick Lee is a whole in a wall place, its pretty much street food in a small cramped building. The selection of dim sum is large and cheap. As with all street foods you to have a iron stomach , its more of a local thing. If you've traveled to third world countries youll see that this style eating is the norm. I usually grab some to eat while i am there and a few boxes to bring home to share with friends.
Big mistake stopping in here... don't be fooled by the allure all a 5.99 all you can eat offer... you can't eat any of it, because it is awful. Dirty plates, dirty cups.
$6 all you can eat dim sum only gets you 2/10 edible "food" items, a hearty stomachache and sustained bathroom visits for the next 24 hours.
This is a prime example of what happens when you don't have internet to Yelp places to eat on vacation. YELP PLACES BEFORE YOU EAT, PEOPLE.
This place is one of the larger dim sum establishments in the Chinatown area, in terms of canopy and frontage size.
This place.... Ugh. Pls, DO NOT stop and look, DO NOT go in, DO pass by it quickly, or rather.... RUN.
ugh, I hate to say something nasty.  The lady at the counter is so nice.  But this time around, I had an awful taste in my mouth for a day. TONS of better options for dim sum in town. Gross.

After a long day, on our way back to the car, I noticed that Dick Lee was still open and had to stop by for baked pork buns and egg tarts.  I ended up also picking up some frozen, steamed red bean buns.  Everything was good, and for a good price.
As you may have noticed the Yelp site was experiencing technical difficulties yesterday. So for about two hours, I wandered around Chinatown without my favorite city guide.
Dick Lee Pastry Shop offers all you can eat dim sum buffet (9.99?)

I was in SF Chinatown wanting to get some egg tarts. I knew Golden Gate Bakery was really known for its egg tarts, so me and a friend waited in line for 15 minutes without the line moving at all. Since time in SF is precious for an out of town tourist, I couldn't waste any more time.
WOW....I wondered if this place would have reviews. It would rate -1 if Yelp allowed it.
Be aware of the businesses you are supporting.
Awful Chinese food!

This is a hole in the wall mom and pop shop. I always like to support these kinds of places. I've been here many times when I'm in San Francisco. I always make a stop here for lunch or dinner when I am in Chinatown. Today, I had dinner here and I enjoyed it. The worker/cashier is friendly and there are many authentic chinese home cooked hot items to choose from along with dim sum selections. Dim sum includes pork dumplings, egg tart, pork shu mai, shrimp dumplings, a variety of buns(bean or BBQ pork), congee(rice porridge, 4 different kinds of soups(hot sour, wonton, stewed beef or pork soup egg flower soups), fried chicken, roasted chicken, chow mein, fried rice, bok choy, tofu with meat sauce, BBQ pork, lotus dish, mixed vegetable with meat dish, and many more. Selection is great! For the price of an All-You-Can-Eat of $5.99 per person, it is a great price and the best in town! Especially if you are on a tight budget. The food is pretty decent  for me and for the price, you can't beat that. I would definetely come back again not having such high expectations like some of these yelpers have. I also have to say that somedays the quality is better than other days. Today, I found that the dim some quality was better than the last time I was here for lunch time. If they are really busy, then the food is more fresh as they try to replenish it more often. Hot tea used to come with the meal but today, they said they would charge an additional .50 cents. I've been here for years and this was the first on that. It should come with the meal like it always had. Also, the place is not all that clean(hole in the wall). You get a paper plate and a bowl. You can order a la carte and get real dishes. I always prefer the AYCE because I like selection and there is no waiting for the food, especially if you are in a rush to eat and go. Like I said, don't expect much. Food is decent and for the price, you can't beat that,especially on a budget.

NASTY!  Sorry but this was the worst food experience ever. where to start?  My picture I will post here should be enough, not one but two dead bugs swimming in hot sauce. All items were room temp, Egg rolls were soggy and inside stuff was unrecognizable, Curry was all potato-no meat, all vegies were mushy and looked faded,  BBQ pork was mostly fat, Dim sum was older than the Rolling stones. It was difficult to find anything edible.  The City of SF should shut this place down. It was my 1st time eating in Chinatown now I think I have been psychologically damaged by this experience and doubt I will be back.

Went to Dick Lee's at 11:30 on a Sunday morning.  Should have known the food was not up to par when we only saw one customer.  The establishment is advertised as an all you can eat dim sum and BBQ buffet for $6.99 (tea is an extra $.50 per person).  Also that they had 50 items.  Counted everything including the cookies and came up with a total of 25.

Just read the rest of the reviews, it's all been said already. Friendly service, atrocious food. I though I might as well try their 6.50 all you can eat dim sum. Nothing was edible. Everything tasted as if it had been siting out for a week. Luke warm, cold, dry, soggy.

This little take-out dim sum shop has been on Chinatown's Jackson Street for ages. Unfortunately, they have not taken their culinary skills into the new millenium even though they've been in business for decades.  I stopped by whilest in the area and wanted a little snack...I ordered a few items that looked like they've been in the steamer for a few days and I asked if they were rubbery.  The counter lady said no and they were tasty.  Knowing otherwise, yet a little hungry, I paid for my order.  All the items I had were tasteless and the won ton skins on the Hai Gow were rubbery.  Even if it's only $6.00, all you can eat, why would anyone subject themselves to eating such crap?  Never again.  I think next time I should just settle for a bag of chips instead.
GAH the dimsum here.......frozen dimsum that you can buy from TJs or Ranch 99 tastes better!

Let's face it. I was lost in Chinatown and I was living off of the "Bay Area Guide" magazine. My family was hungry because we've been going around and around. Of course, the "All You Can Eat Dim Sum for 5.99" was appetizing. Once you got in, it was sort of a different story. It looked like a fast food buffet sort of thing. It looked pretty old, and the food seemed okay.

Stay far away from this place if you care about your health.  Tried the $5.99 all you can eat dim sum after looking at what was available.  Nothing at all tasted like the dim sum dishes they looked like.  We ate one bite of a steamed dumpling with sweet filling and the filling was rock hard and brownish color instead of the yellow it was supposed to be.  I tried almost everything available on the all-you-can-eat menu in an attempt to find something enjoyable but was disgusted at every single thing!
$6 for all you can eat dim sum?  Gotta try it, right?  Well, it was worth trying once.

Gross! gross! gross! Food is terrible, it's not all you can eat, it's all can barf. The owner is having a lawsuit against him, mistreating his workers, under paid, make them work long....hours. Read all about them in sf examiner.
Yeah, if your planning on dining at a nice place forget about Dick lee..it's a no frills dim sum spot, speaking Cantonese helps...

It's a shame I don't know the names of the dishes I had but I will upload a picture of my plate.  One friend didn't care for anything while the rest of us ate till we were stuffed.  All you can eat for $5.99 and well worth it.  Small, quaint and friendly.

I finally stopped at this place because I was in search of Egg Custard Tarts and with the Chinese New Year parade about to start, it was too packed to even decide where else to go. The streets were packed with people.

Dick Lee is a great deal, It's an all you can eat Dim Sum spot that I checked out when my girlfriend and I were starving and kind of broke. But the dumplings, wontons, tofu and eggplant were pretty good. However, I do not recommend the desserts they were dry and tasteless with exception of the cookies. I think what I enjoyed most was the Jasmine Tea...it was the most flavorful and sweat tea I had tried even though it had no sugar. Lastly, the owner and employees where very friendly and kind, also the Sesame balls are pretty good treat on your way out to explore China Town some more.

There is a sexy robot voice that enchants tourists inside with her calming English ways and a promise of all you can eat dim sum. Sail onwards sailor, take heed and don't be lured in by the siren call.
Dim Sum, Pastry and a variety of other food and beverage items in one stop? Nice!

Like lots of other people have said this place wasn't great but it also wasn't terrible. For the price I feel like I honestly got my money's worth. The hot and sour soup was delicious but the fried veggie rolls were mushy and cold. My friends all said pork buns and dumplings were good and I really liked the semi-weird mixed vegetables. Overall I would go back again just for the experience, the hot tea and the desserts.
The lamb is nice! The all you can eat is cheap and worth! Just 5.99!
I would never miss this one if ever I visit again San Francisco. Good food+ good cheap price? It doesn't get better than that. And I enjoyed the hospitality of the friendly staff!
I've been there a few times, and the previous reviews are generally accurate.

Like I have said earlier, I look at my misguided tour of the side of Chinatown the tourists don't venture into during my first SF excursion as an unexpected adventure in retrospect. That said, while I tried to make the best out of it due to not having very much money, the food I had here wasn't very enjoyable.

This is my absolute favorite subway of all that I have been to over the years.  I go out of my way to go to this one instead of the one closest to my office.  I only come in about once a month, but they know my order.  friendly employees, fresh ingredients, and clean venue.

The 5 stars is for the guys that work the lunch hour M-F. Whenever I want something healthy, cheap, and fast. I turn to Subway. The sandwiches here are sandwiches. Nothing extraordinary. But the staff is another story. Every time I come to this location, they seem to know their customers and are really personable. They are always so happy and the customer service is awesome.
